abstract: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Europa, we receive advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 18th, and Queenstown on the 19th inst. The English shippers and merchants interested in the trade with Matamoras have worked themselves into a high pitch of excitement regarding the interference with their business by the United States cruisers. A deputation of them waited upon Earl RUSSELL on the 16th, in relation to the matter. During the interview the statement was made that Minister ADAMS had recently given a special license for a ship to proceed from England to Matamoras, free from any interference by American cruisers, to carry supplies of arms and ammunition for the Mexicans in their war with France. This appeals to have been the case, as attempts were made to negotiate a policy of insurance at Lloyds, on a vessel furnished with certificates from Mr. ADAMS, addressed to Admiral DUPONT. The publication of these facts furnished the occasion for a furious attack upon Mr. ADAMS by the London Times and other English papers. The Times characterizes the proceeding as an arrogant assumption, and says, in reference to it, "The exercise of the slightest authority by foreign Ministers in England is not to be permitted for one moment." Notice was given in the House of Commons on the 16th of intention to call up the matter of the seizure of the supposed rebel gunboat Alaxendria. An investigation in regard to the "greenback" forgeries at Sheffield had revealed the fact that large amounts had been issued in five, ten and twenty-dollar notes. The London Daily News believes that the irritation between England and the United States is increasing, and the Paris Moniteur has a paragraph in which it is stated that the "the last dispatches from the Washington Government have a character of increasing irritation." The British Chancellor of the Exchequer had made his annual statement, showing a surplus of three and three-quarters million pounds, which he proposed to reduce by reducing the duty on tea and the tax on incomes. The Polish question, according to a Vienna dispatch threatens to assume greater complications. The movements of the insurgents are becoming every day more active. Numerous engagements are reported, and an attack on Karlisch was daily expected. The Liverpool Cotton market was buoyant and prices had further advanced. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 92 3/4@92 7/8 for money.

abstract: Experiences of
lead_paragraph: Among the recent arrivals of fugitives from the South, I have met with one from the Central region of North Carolina, whose career, from its singularity, is calculated to awaken curiosity and interest. Mr. BRYAN TYSON is a native of Randolph County in that State, where he has resided the greater portion of his life. He is a man of profound religious convictions and experiences, is about 33 years of age, of great simplicity and sincerity of manners. He rendered himself obnoxious to the rebel authorities by the publication of a small volume, entitled A Ray of Light, or a Conservative Treatise on the Sectional Troubles, with other essays of a similar character. In this work, a copy of which he has placed in my hands, he mildly but firmly urges upon the people of the South that the act of secession was uncalled for; that it was not brought about fairly, by submitting the question to the popular vote; and that the only wise and safe course is to return to the Union. He points out, in his brief review, the acts resorted to by the secession leaders to deceive the people, and to precipitate them into the rebellion; and sustains his allegations by facts and citations, some of which are familiar to the public on this side the lines, and some of which, I believe, are new to us.

abstract: At the Laight-street Baptist Church. Rev. I.S. KALLOCH introduced the devotional exercises of the congregation by reading selections of Scripture appropriate to the day: It is always proper to pray; but it is essential now. God will be inquired of by us. It is very appropriate that such a day as this should be set apart, and given to our country. Let us devote it well and wisely. Let us look over the ground and see where we stand. Let us first, try to appreciate more thoroughly the importance of the contest. Everything is involved in it. It is a contest between two civilizations, or rather between civilization and barbarism; and its issue bears upon the fate not only of slaves, but of freemen; not only of black men, but of white men: not only of America, but the would. The point in dispute is not one of political platforms, or the policy of an Administration -- it is a simple question of civil life or death. Whether we are to continue a free people, or go down beneath the wave, and become the butt and jeer of all the dynasties of the world; whether we are to be a lighthouse on the shore, or a buoy on the waters; all this is involved. The consolidation of a Southern Empire with Slavery as its chief corner-stone -- with fillibustering, privateering and border strifes -- would be a surrender of all that has been won in the past -- would be a relapse into a condition much worse than that from which our fathers emerged through seas of blood. Can any one doubt the disastrous effects of Southern supremacy? The South is the type and asserter of Oriental Absolutism -- the defender of the divine right of tyrants. We are fighting in the noblest cuuse in which weapons can be wielded, or armor girded on, or treasure lavished, or willing blood poured out like water. But we should not only appreciate the importance of the contest.

abstract: -- In reference to a paragraph stating that the pilot of the iron-clad Keokuk ran her ashore in order that the rebels might capture her, we have the very best authority for saying that the Keokuk was not in charge of a pilot at any time at Charleston, and was not run upon Morris Island, but sunk about one mile from the beach, while an effort was being made to tow her into smoother water, and to get her stern to the swell.

abstract: There was no special observance of the National Fast in our Catholic churches yesterday. This was owing to the well-known fact that the Church of Rome never countenances any feast or fast of a secular character, the doctrines of the church being in strict accord with canonical rules.

abstract: The Army of the Potomac is undoubtedly in motion. On Monday morning at daylight the movement began, the Seventh and Eleventh Corps and the Cavalry Corps taking the lead. How far the grand movement has progressed we can only infer from the time which has elapsed. The direction which it has taken will soon be indicated in the reports which will reach us. A gentleman who arrived in Philadelphia yesterday from the army, reports that the pontoons were laid on Thursday night and Wednesday morning across the Rappahannock at Port Royal, and that the troops immediately began to cross, and by 10 o'clock four corps had got over in safety. Subsequently cannonading and severe firing were heard across the river.
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac is undoubtedly in motion. On Monday morning at daylight the movement began, the Seventh and Eleventh Corps and the Cavalry Corps taking the lead. Subsequently cannonading and severe firing were heard across the river.

abstract: The Grit of
lead_paragraph: Every race possessing any sort of vitality has some share of fighting men and military capacity. Not a few have developed a proportion amounting at times to national prowess of the most splendid character. And yet but two or three races have ever arisen so purely heroic as to endure the uttermost extremity and adversity of war without yielding. "The hardest fend off," is a common expression of the commonest of natural laws, and hence the inevitable supremacy of such a race is as clearly written in the nature of things as in history. There need be no antecedent lust of conquest. Man is naturally a fighting animal; and, whatever the particular cause of the quarrel, it is grit that almost invariably carries the day in the long run.

abstract: Mr. E.F. WILLIAMS, the ship-builder, launched from his yard at Greenpoint, on Wednesday afternoon, another yacht, for the Sandy Hook pilots. Her dimensions 81 feet over all, 61 feet keel, 20 feet 6 inches beam, 8 feet depth of hold, and she will measure 111 tons. Her foremast is 69 feet in length, and the mainmast 71 feet; she is built of oak, cedar and hackmatac, treenailed and copper-fastened in the most substantial manner, and, for beauty of model and elegance of finish, has no superior. Her cabins are very tastefully laid out, there being six berths, with washroom, water-closets and baggage-room; bird's-eye, maple, rosewood and other fancy woods are among the veneering and inlaying. She was built for the company formerly owning the Edwin Forrest, No. 14, which was wrecked on Long island some months since. Her company consists of the following pilots: HENRY HARLINSON, Captain; Thos. Connolly, David Kelse, Jacob Erickson, Jas. Clark, and Chris. Peterson.
lead_paragraph: Mr. E.F. WILLIAMS, the ship-builder, launched from his yard at Greenpoint, on Wednesday afternoon, another yacht, for the Sandy Hook pilots. abstract: The Tenth Regiment Maine Volunteers, Col. G.L. BEALE, arrived in this City en route for home, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. This regiment enlisted for two years, and its term expired last week. They went out 850 strong and returned with 450. On their arrival here they proceeded to the Park Barracks, where they remained till morning and took breakfast. At 12 o'clock M., they took their departure for home in a special steamer (the Commodore) chartered for the purpose. They go by way of Stonington. The regiment served in the battles of Cedar Mountain, Antietam, and many other engagements in Virginia, and what remains of it are as fine a looking set of men as one would wish to see.

At 12 o'clock M., they took their departure for home in a special steamer (the Commodore) chartered for the purpose. They go by way of Stonington. The regiment served in the battles of Cedar Mountain, Antietam, and many other engagements in Virginia, and what remains of it are as fine a looking set of men as one would wish to see.

abstract: National Fast "Day Sermon; National Fast sermon
snippet: National Fast "Day Sermon; National Fast sermon
lead_paragraph: The reverend doctor announced as his text the 107th Psalm, from the 11th to the 14th verses. He commenced by saying the day and the service in which they were engaged were significant, the observance of the day was significant as was its appointment by the President; and so, also, was the neglect to observe it by so great a multitude. Prior to the commencement of the present war two national fasts had been observed, and only two, that he remembered. One was when the executive head of the Government had been stricken by death, and the other when the cholera, in epidemic form threatened the land -- then the nation had with propriety been called to recognize God, and ask him to remove the scourge from us. Since the commencement of the war we had been called upon to fast and pray. And on the present occasion it was a significant fact that we were not called simply to pray for victory nor to lament defeat; but in the prospect of victory to remember our sins and ask forgiveness.

abstract: Adams, Mr.; Grant of Special Protection to Matamoras Vessel
snippet: Adams, Mr.; Grant of Special Protection to Matamoras Vessel
lead_paragraph: On the 16th instant a deputation of shippers and merchants interested in the Mexican trade, waited on Earl RUSSELL. The importance of the interview was considerably enhanced by an announcement being made during its progress, that while the United States Government have been seizing British vessels bound to Matamoras without any contraband of war being on board of them, Mr. ADAMS has been giving a special license for a ship to proceed from England to Matamoras, free from any interference by American cruisers, to carry supplies, which are stated to consist of arms and ammunition for the Mexicans in their war with France.

abstract: The seizure of flour by the military authorities at Richmond, Va., a month or two ago, produced a deep commotion in the Old Dominion, and was felt throughout the South. The flour taken was the property, not of merchants or speculators, but of private citizens, and the  Confederate Government seized it, fixed its own price which was below the market value, and compelled the owners to take their arbitrary valuation or nothing.

abstract: Capt. COOK alias Capt. Lee, a notorious slave-trader, master of the slave-ship Gandora, of Boston, was arrested in Brooklyn, late on Saturday evening, by Deputy Marshals BORST, of this City, and WARREN, of Boston. There are six indictments pending against him in Boston, for piracy in connection with the Slave-trade. He was taken to Boston on Sunday evening, by Deputy-Marshal WARREN.

abstract: The service at St. George's Church was of a deeply impressive character, and was participated in by a large congregation. The text selected was the 132d Psalm, 1st, 2d, 5th and 6th verses. After alluding to the destruction of Jerusalem, Dr. TYNG proceeded to show wherein our own people resembled in some particulars the people of that ancient city. Touching upon the subject of loyalty, he declared that for a man to say he has no loyalty, it is to say he has no honesty. The child's love of his home, and the father's love of his family, was the patriot's love of his country. He would not consider himself, his family nor his property, safe within the grasp of a man who had renounced the obligations of loyalty for the purpose of adopting plans to overthrow the dominion of that authority which had furnished him all his social enjoyment and success, and under the protection of which he had peacefully lived and grown up. It was his intention to speak fearlessly and independently on the subject of loyalty, and that none might be taken unawares, be had previously announced his intention. His loyalty was not confined to a single State; but extended over the whole continent of America. He would never give his consent to its dismemberment, and desired not to live to see disunion upon any terms that could be devised. Still less would he recognize a combination of political intriguers to overthrow the established Government, He had roamod in other lands, and had not affected to despise their many advantages; but he had ever returned to his native land with renewed gratification and pride. Every part of his native land was his, and he loved every part equally well. South Carolina and Georgia was his as much as Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Massachusetts had planted her seed in every part of the country -- a seed that would grow and bear good fruit. To separate this land, to parcel it out to a set of traitors, was a transaction to which he would never, as one citizen, give his consent, He would never yield the right of his home to the power of adversity. Political questions and national debts were nothing unless our country was preserved. Let the land of our fathers be transmitted unbroken, solid, entire, untarnished to our children who succeed us. Some men had called the Constitution a mass of glittering generalities, but they had no affinity with the purpose for which it was designed and destined to be exercised. The fathers of the present generation, even on the very soil of Slavery, testified to the infamous curse of human bondage. Dr. TYNG then cited the authorities of WASHINGTON, JEFFERSON, MADISON, MONROE and other statesmen, to show how heartily they disapproved of the system of Slavery. We were certainly in the midst of a war for freedom, and it was the greatest and grandest contest which the world had ever seen. Slavery at last had received its inevitable destruction, its reconstruction could never be effected without a greater contest and more terrific scenes of violence than those we are now called on to witness. The Constitution was next alluded to by the eminent preacher, who closed his able discourse with an appeal to his hearers to stand unflinchingly by the principles which our fathers endeavored to establish.

abstract: HORRIBLE ACCIDENT. -- An accident occurred on the New-York and Erie Railway, at Jersey City, yesterday forenoon, resulting in the death of a little girl ten years of age, named MARY MEHAN, and probable fatal injury to a flagman, in an attempt to save her life. The little girl attempted to cross the track at the Erie-street crossing just as a locomotive and tender were backing up, and the flagman, named DAVID D. MAFFEY, seeing that she was in imminent peril, and would be run over, sprung forward, and attempted to rescue her, when he was struck on the head by the tender, and knocked prostrate upon the track. The wheels passed over his right leg and arm, crushing and nearly severing them. The little girl was also knocked down, and, the wheels passing over her body, crushed and mangled her in a horrible manner, and caused instant death. The remains were conveyed to the residence of her parents, corner of Third and Erie streets. MAFFEY was conveyed to his home, No. 179 South Third-street, where his arm and leg were amputated by Dr. QUIMBY; but, owing to the great loss of blood, his life is despaired of.
lead_paragraph: HORRIBLE ACCIDENT. -- An accident occurred on the New-York and Erie Railway, at Jersey City, yesterday forenoon, resulting in the death of a little girl ten years of age, named MARY MEHAN, and probable fatal injury to a flagman, in an attempt to save her life. The little girl attempted to cross the track at the Erie-street crossing just as a locomotive and tender were backing up, and the flagman, named DAVID D. MAFFEY, seeing that she was in imminent peril, and would be run over, sprung forward, and attempted to rescue her, when he was struck on the head by the tender, and knocked prostrate upon the track. The wheels passed over his right leg and arm, crushing and nearly severing them. The little girl was also knocked down, and, the wheels passing over her body, crushed and mangled her in a horrible manner, and caused instant death. The remains were conveyed to the residence of her parents, corner of Third and Erie streets. MAFFEY was conveyed to his home, No. 179 South Third-street, where his arm and leg were amputated by Dr. QUIMBY; but, owing to the great loss of blood, his life is despaired of.

abstract: Nothing has been published at Washington of the movements of Gen. HOOKER since Monday, when it was announced by the National Intelligencer that our army had commenced crossing the Rappahannock at daybreak. It was generally supposed that this was indicative of an immediate general action. In December last, Gen. BURNSIDE threw his pontoons over the Rappahannock on Thursday the 11th, and his army crossed that night and next day, and on Saturday they fought the battle of Fredericksburgh. Gen. HOOKER'S plan of action is probably fundamentally different from that adopted by Gen. BURNSIDE, though what it may be he has not advertised the public; and most of his officers, and even the rebels, seem up to the latest hour to have been altogether ignorant of it. Some persons writing from the army as late as Tuesday, assert that he is going up the Rappahannock, others that he is going down; one rebel writer Insinuates that he will make the Mattapony his base of operations, while JEFF. DAVIS' private organ, the Richmond Enquirer, has a long article making it clear that his movement is to be up the Pamunkey. We have no doubt that the latter article was based upon information obtained from JEFF. DAVIS himself, who had it published to confuse HOOKER by showing that the rebels knew all about his plans -- which HOOKER in turn will probably prove was a mistake. We have read a letter from the army written in the early part of this week by one who would be likely to know, which said that "everybody was in the dark, and that three at least of the Major-Generals were then totally ignorant of the plan of action." Under these circumstances, the public will be compelled to simply wait for the development of events -- which they will be very well satisfied to do; and will, in the meantime, indulge the thought that plans so well kept have at least one element of success not possessed by some previous ones.

abstract: The Siege of Puebla
lead_paragraph: At length we have intelligence from Mexico which gives us some idea of what is taking place at Puebla, the seat of war in that country. By telegraph from San Francisco we have advices from Puebla to the 6th inst., and per steamer Sheldrake, from Havana, the dates are given up to the 9th inst. The general tenor of these advices is that a good deal of hard fighting had taken place, and the contest was still raging. The Mexican dispatch to San Francisco, via Acapulco, states that since the 31st ult., the French had kept up a constant bombardment of Puebla. Their fire had destroyed the convent of San Agustin and six blocks of buildings, with no special progress toward occupying the city; coupled with this is the French account, which states that Gen. FOREY is in possession of the environs of Puebla, and master of the communications and fortified works commanding the city.
headline: {'main': 'The Siege of Puebla.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Siege of Puebla.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- "THOMAS M. CAMPBELL, of the so-called Confederate army," was condemned by a Court-martial, sitting at Cincinnati, on Monday of this week, to be executed by hanging, and Gen. BURNSIDE has had him put in irons, at Sandusky, Ohio, and has issued an order to the commander of that post to see that the sentence of the Court is duly executed at  12 o'clock, noon, of this day, May 1st. The charge against the prisoner is that of being "found and arrested within our lines as a spy," and the specification sets forth that he "was found and arrested within the lines of the United States forces on the 11th of April, near Ruggles' Mills, Bourbon County, Ky., as a spy." The Court, after mature deliberation on the evidence adduced, found him guilty of both the specification and the charge, and the sentence of death was the result. We have not learned, up to the present hour, that the President has interfered with the sentence of the Court or the order of Gen. BURNSIDE.
lead_paragraph: -- "THOMAS M. CAMPBELL, of the so-called Confederate army," was condemned by a Court-martial, sitting at Cincinnati, on Monday of this week, to be executed by hanging, and Gen. The Court, after mature deliberation on the evidence adduced, found him guilty of both the specification and the charge, and the sentence of death was the result. We have not learned, up to the present hour, that the President has interfered with the sentence of the Court or the order of Gen. BURNSIDE.

abstract: New STEAMBOAT FOR ALBANY AND NEW-YORK. -- The new steamboat City of Albany, intended for the passenger and freight trade between this City and Albany, built by Messrs. BRAINARD & LAWLER, of the latter city, has been completed, and furnished throughout in the most recherche manner by her owners. She is to take her regular place on the morning line, on Monday next, leaving New-York on the alternate mornings, at 7 o'clock, from the foot of Harrison-street, North River. The City of Albany is 215 feet in length and 30 feet in width, and her model was designed to attain great speed with a light draft of water. She draws four feet of water only, and will be able to pass safely over the bars at lowest tide. The engines are very superior, and were built by Messrs. CURTISS & SHAPTER. She is owned by HENRY SMITH, Esq., of the First Ward -- the Ex-Alderman.
lead_paragraph: New STEAMBOAT FOR ALBANY AND NEW-YORK. -- The new steamboat City of Albany, intended for the passenger and freight trade between this City and Albany, built by Messrs. abstract: The National Fast Day was observed yesterday in Brooklyn by the business community generally. All the city offices and nearly all the stores were closed after 10 o'clock, A.M. Services were held in the churches, although sermons were preached in but few, the exercises consisting of reading the Proclamation, singing and praying. A large number of the community about changing residences, took occasion to go into their new quarters for the next year. The streets were filled with vehicles loaded with furniture, and the sidewalks with persons carrying light articles.

abstract: Mr. LEEDS announces another of his great picture sales for to-day and to-morrow, at the old Dusseldorf Gallery, over Dr. CHAPIN's church. The works to be disposed of consist of the collection of the late Gen. GEORGE M. KEIM, of Reading, Penn. -- a well-known connoisseur -- with the balance of the American and European pictures remaining over from the sale of the 26th and 27th of March last. Of the old school there will be found specimens of Rosa di Tivoli, Snyder, Gampidoglio, Francisco Albano, Raphael Mengs, D. Teniers, Sir Joshue Reynolds and others. Of the modern European school, pictures by Lessing, Wm. Shayer, J. Hubner, Van Starkenburgh, T. Birch, Rolffe, T. Grass, Meyerheim, Bonfield, Robbe, Leickert, Vernon, Boddisgton and others equally celebrated; and of the American school, works by Rothermel, Paul Webber, G.C. Lamdin, Moran, Laurie Ranney, Gilbert Siuart, Sully, W.T. Richards, Chapman, Whittridge, Burford, Bierstadt, Hamilton, May, Hart, Johnson, Lewis, and others. The collection will be on exhibition up to the evening of sale. A free exhibition, previous to a sale of Mr. LEUTZE's pictures, will open on Monday next, at the Derby Gallery, in Broadway. The collection will comprise several of this artist's best and latest works. The sale at auction will take place on Thursday evening, May 7, at the gallery of exhibition.

abstract: Sermon on National Fast Day
lead_paragraph: In conformity with the President's Proclamation of the 30th of March, yesterday was very generally set apart by the citizens of New-York and Brooklyn as an occasion for fasting and prayer. The public buildings and private stores were closed, and business of every nature was suspended for the day. The churches of all denominations, save the Roman Catholic, were open, and in the majority of them appropriate services were held. The attendance noon the religious services was unusually large, and the congregations seemed impressed with the deep solemnity of the occasion and a consciousness of its necessity.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon
snippet: National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon; National Fast Day Sermon
lead_paragraph: At All Souls' Church a large congregation assembled to listen to the Fast Day sermon of Dr. BELLOWS. Prayer was offered by Dr. OSGOOD, and hymns appropriate to the peculiar character of the day were sung. Dr. BELLOWS selected for his text the 29th, 30th and 31st verses of the 5th Chapter of Jeremiah, and began by alluding to the necessity our country has for prayer, and the eminent fitness of the President's setting apart such a day as this. Every nation has abundant cause to confess its sins and supplicate the Divine forgiveness; but ours has peculiar reason to acknowledge its unfaithfulness. For we have grievously sinned against light, humanity and love. With all our advantages of personal liberty, of a free religion, of schools and the pious example and teachings of our fathers, in all these so highly favored above other nations, it is not enough that we surpass foreign peoples, and even the best of them, in general morality. The question is, are we in any fair degree equal in our piety to our talents, opportunities and blessings? We have enjoyed, as a people, singular advantages, and our responsibility is relative. This American people must either be the best or the guiltiest people on God's earth. There can be no doubt that for twenty-five years past the American people has been making progress in everything rather than morals and piety. In all arts and sciences there has been rapid advancement. We have become a more cultured, more tasteful, more quiet and more graceful a people. Yet, although there is more good taste, good sense and decorum, there is no more principle, In respect of morals here is no corresponding advance. Nay, there has rather been a degeneration, and sufficiently so to deserve and invoke the solemn warnings of Providence. These twenty-five years have been essentially a time of externalities, of compromises and concessions. Every one has been seeking to make money, and everything has accommodated Itself to the money-maker. In politics, in theology, art, society, religion, there is less real sturdy principle than there was a quarter of a century ago -- less earnestness, less faith, less devotion. As a consequence, we have little substantial reading, almost no earnest poetry. we have twenty times as many artists, and a hundred times as many patrons of art, but fewer earnest and devoted in their profession. We have splendid churches; but where are the saint? We have eloquent preachers; but where is the old doctrinal strength? Religion has degenerated into an ethical system. It is polite, civil, gentle. popular, where it ought to be uncompromising, stern, unbending. The devotion of the people to money-making has withdrawn their attention from National questions, has giver, the control of State, city and county elections to grog-shops and corner groceries, has kept fit men out of Congress, and has suffered the South to gain and hold its imperious rule in the politics of the country. Another general cause of demoralization is the institution of Slavery. More than we are aware it has polluted our whole political system and undermined the morals of the whole people. We of the North have been bred to regard it with kindliness. We had accommodated ourselves to this sinful institution in commerce, in literature and religion, until it had extended its corrupting influence over them all. What effect it has had upon the South we have but lately learned. Now we see how it has so barbarized a people as to lead them madly to sacrifice themselves and a national existence to satisfy a spirit of revenge. Slavery has set fire to her own prison-house. Out of the annals of American Indians there never was a more savage immolation of all the rights of a people made for their revengeful feelings, Rather than yield to the most paternal Government that ever existed, they are burning cities, laying waste their fields, so that a hundred years' toil will not recover them to life and fertility, and sacrificing the very institution which they have so fiercely nursed.

abstract: There is one thing for which the rebels are certainly entitled to credit, if for no other,  and that is the rapidity with which they appreciated the difficulties of their position, and the energy with which they adapted their policy to their circumstances.
lead_paragraph: There is one thing for which the rebels are certainly entitled to credit, if for no other, and that is the rapidity with which they appreciated the difficulties of their position, and the energy with which they adapted their policy to their circumstances. This has been shown in no Way so remarkably as in their choice of leaders, and in the measures they have employed for enforcing efficiency in their service. They had no sooner seceded than they placed the ablest man amongst them at the head of their affairs, and from that moment he has been permitted to deal with his subordinates precisely as he sees fit, without murmur, remonstrance, or even comment on the part of the Press or the public. Generals have been dismissed, removed, and changed from one department to another, torn from brilliant positions and consigned to obscure ones, raised from obscurity to places of prominence and responsibility, and the people and the army look on approvingly, or, at all events, silently. BEAUREGARD fought and won the first battle of the war, and what with strutting, posing and rhodomontade, unquestionably answers the Southern ideal of a hero; and yet he was, soon after Bull Run, thrown into the background. He has been driven backward and forward, up and down, from East to West, from a picayune command to no command at all, and latterly he has been assigned to the important, but not first-class position of taking charge of the defences of Charleston. And yet hardly a syllable of complaint have we had either from him or his friends. There is nobody, who has a drop of the milk of human kindness in his composition, who must not have been afflicted at the sight of the various fortunes which have chequered the career of the unfortunate BRAGG, and yet he bears it like a man, and the Confederate world seems not in the least moved by the spectacle.

abstract: Some excitement was occasioned yesterday in naval circles by the announcement that the iron-clad battery Onondaga, building by Mr. GEO. QUINTARD, for the Government, was not to be finished. She was to be launched next week, and being a novelty in architecture, considerable interest was felt in her progress. It appears that orders have been received here, from the Navy Department, directing Admiral GREGORY to stop the preparations for launching, and to commence at once improvements in her armor, which it will take some time to execute. She is to have a wooden and iron mail over the hull, as it stands at present. There being no wooden packing to the ship, and the iron outside having been fastened with through bolts to the hull, it was suspected all along that some radical change would be made in the plan of her construction. The Onondaga has already been described in these columns, Mr. ROWLAND is building her on Mr. QUINTARD's plan, and expected to have her ready for launching by the 20th ult. She is 1,250 tons burden, about 200 feet long, and of proportionate width and depth.

abstract: If nobody knew in advance Gen. HOOKER'S plan of movement and operation against LEE'S army, certainly no one can tell what they are going to be from the manoeuvres he has thus far made.
lead_paragraph: If nobody knew in advance Gen. HOOKER'S plan of movement and operation against LEE'S army, certainly no one can tell what they are going to be from the manoeuvres he has thus far made. Those who predicted he would go down and over the Rappahannock, now see that he has done so; and those who foretold that he would go up and over, now find their sagacity vindicated. He has done both. His active army has been divided into two great forces -- of what precise relative strength we are not told -- which started on their divergent march on Monday. The right force, after a march of eighteen or twenty miles, reached Kelly's Ford, on the Rappahannock, above Falmouth, and by Wednesday morning the pontoons were laid, and our men crossed the river without loss. The left force after a brief march from their quarters, struck a point on the river a couple of miles below Falmouth, and by Wednesday morning the pontoons were there laid at two places, and two divisions crossed. At both crossings, the rebels made a slight resistance, and at the lower one a brisk skirmish took place. We publish letters this morning from both of the great sections of the army, the upper and the lower; and in these the details of the march and crossing will be found, and the condition of affairs up to Thursday. The report of heavy cannonading, of which we published a statement yesterday, evidently came from the fight below Falmouth on Wednesday morning, and indicated, as we suggested, not the opening of the general action, but the preliminary skirmishing. Gen. HOOKER himself was present with the upper section of the army, and superintended its crossing, and subsequently, with his Staff, made a reconnoissance for some twenty miles.

abstract: Dis  patches from Washington have twice alluded, with emphatic surprise and disappointment, to a great falling off of receipts from internal revenue.
lead_paragraph: -- Dis patches from Washington have twice alluded, with emphatic surprise and disappointment, to a great falling off of receipts from internal revenue. Our own correspondent yesterday represented Commissioner BOUTWELL to be no little concerned to find that his estimates, "made from correct data, and justified by the statistics of the country," have proved "alarmingly delusive." And two causes are assigned for this falling off -- first, "a very general neglect to comply with many of the requirements of the Revenue Act in regard to the use of stamps," and second, "the prodigious extent to which stamps once used are fraudulently detached from the instruments to which they were attached, and used again."

abstract: Gothamites seem to move annually with the devout punctuality of a hegira. May-day is the cartman's harvest, the junk-dealer's delight, the old clo'man's rejoicing, the juvenile paradise of confusion, and all sensible people's horror. This year our necessary evil came in as mild a form as possible. Never was there a more propitious sky. Old Sol smiled serenely on the metropolitan upheavings, and though a somewhat free and easy gust would occasionally lift a box-cover, or raise a blanket, and expose more than tidy housekeepers care to show to the general public, the weather was quite as favorable as could rationally be expected in these days of tribulation and uncertainty. There were, of course, whole corps of draymen and regiments of laborers reaping the fruits of the harvest. Such sallies upon furniture, such onslaughts upon looking-glasses, such charges upon chairs, and such an appearance of debris on the battle-field can only be appreciated by those who have indulged in the delights of such migrative campaigns. If "three movings are as bad as a fire," as the saying goes, one moving must certainly be both a tax on patience and pocket. It would be a good idea to have a company to insure people against moving. The scrip would certainly always remain above par, and it may be questioned whether it would not command a very high premium. Much of the moving this year was effected on Thursday -- making that day more effectually a day of fasting, though by no means more characterized by thankgtving and prayer, than it would otherwise have been. Not to have moved, is not to know the whole of human misery. The insolence of landlords, and the spurns which patient movers from the unworthy bear, are enough to entitle them to the designation of martyrs. Blessed, therefore, are they who do not move; who live in homesteads, or pay their rent, or do not get too proud to stay where they are, or abstain from of-f[???]ding their house-owners [???]r in any way manage to [???]intain their local ha[???] [???] throughout May-Day. O[???] if people must move [???] blessed a[???] they if they can get such a day as yesterday on which to do the dir[???]ful deed.

abstract: SAILOR FOUND DROWNED. -- An inquest was held, yesterday, upon the body of a United States sailor, found drowned near Fulton Ferry on Wednesday. He was a large man, about six feet in height, with brown hair. His face had been eaten away by fishes, and there were other indications that he had been in the water for a long time. The sum of $15 in greenbacks was foung tied in his shirt. There was nothing about the clothes to identify him. A verdict of found drowned was rendered.

abstract: ITALIAN OPEHA. -- MAX MARETZEK's Summer season will commence on Monday next, with VERDI's new opera, "Aroldo," with a superb cast, new scenery, dresses and appointments. abstract: Prize Proceedings in New-York
lead_paragraph: The investigation which the Secretary of the Treasury has ordered in connection with the prize proceedings in this District, is a matter of no small importance to New-York. There has been so much said about them, so many charges of malpractice, so many imputations of gross overcharging, if not of dishonesty, that it is due to the fair fame of our City that such an investigation should be had, and that it should be sweeping, thorough, honest and fearless. Let us know the facts in the matter, cut where they will. If there is any reason why the expense of prize proceedings should properly and rightfully be 15 per cent. here, as against 6 per cent. in Boston, let it be known. If there is no reason for it, except in dishonesty and plunder on the part of those to whom the interests of the public and of the captors have been committed, let that, too, be brought to light. It is an unpleasant and ungracious task to uncover dishonesties in high places, but to cover them up is to make ourselves parties to them. We understand that the present investigation is set on foot at the instance of a committee of the merchants of our City. We trust they will not be satisfied with merely having set it on foot, but that they will take an interest in it, watch it, and help it along.

abstract: Some of the men of the First regiment of New-York Volunteers refused to do duty a few days ago, on the ground that their term of service had expired. Their claim was wrong, however, in the matter of a fortnight or so, and it was so decided by the military authorities. The decision did not satisfy the mutineers, and the disaffection extended from a single company to the whole regiment. Suddenly the ringleaders were arrested, the men were stripped of their arms and regimental colors, and confined to their quarters strongly guarded; and Gen. SICKLES issued an order in the case, which unites the stringency of military law with even-handed justice and true clemency. He promises consideration and redress to all complaints as soon as the men return to duty, but orders that they be put under instant surveillance and punishment for their ill conduct, and warns them that if on the next day at noon they be found mutinous, a certain number of them will be tried by Drumhead Court-martial, the sentence of which shall be immediately executed -- all the remainder shall be drafted into other regiments -- the officers will be mustered out, dismissed, or reduced to the ranks -- "and the First regiment New-York Volunteers thus disbanded in disgrace, will cease to exist as a military organization in the service of the United States." Next day the men purged themselves by repentance, and evinced their desire to return to duty, which they were permitted to do, and their arms were restored.

abstract: The enthusiasm of the Viennese population for Mlle. PATTI has assumed an alarming phase. It is announced that this charming singer sang on Easter Sunday at the Church of, the Augustines, which was crowded at an early hour by an eager throng. The pressure was so great, in fact, that many persons fainted. On leaving the church Mlle. PATTI was accompanied by an enormous crowd, and the popular enthusiasm was shown by loud applause and other demonstrations. The anxiety of the crowd to see the young artiste was so great that she was separated for a moment from her carriage, and the lady who accompanied her. In vain she assumed an air of supplication, and tried to force herself a passage. She was at last borne away by the crowd, obliged to take refuge in Prince PALFFY's palace. Fortunately the lady's maid of the Countess FERRARI ZICHY had viewed the scene from the balcony, and, quick as thought, she darted down the stairs, admitted Mlle. PATTI, who was more dead than alive; and then shut the door in the face of the crowd. The music-mad Viennese were not satisfied, and their excitement became more intense. Uttering deafening cries, they broke open the door, rushed up the stairs, and were on the point of entering some of the rooms, when the Princess DE PALFFY appeared, and by her calm and dignified attitude so much subdued the crowd that they retired and quitted the palace. Mlle. PATTI was greatly alarmed by this occurrence, and was not able to sing in the evening.

abstract: -A dispatch yesterday from Cairo set forth that it was doubtful whether any of the half-dozen transports which attempted to run the batteries of Vicksburgh, on the night of the 23d ult., succeeded in passing; and it was added that four of the six were known to have been sunk. This report, if true, which appears doubtful, loses any importance it might seem to have when we remember that these transports were but a sort of scow or broken-down old steamboat, had no troops aboard, and were going down all but empty, to be used by the army below, which has already moved by an interior route from Milliken's Bend to New-Carthage, La. Each transport had a small volunteer crew on board, barely sufficient to man it.

abstract: SERVICES IN THE FORSYTH-STREET CHURCH. -Rev. JAMES O. ROGERS, the former paster of the Alanson Methodist Church in Norfolk-street, will preach to-morrow morning and evening in the Forsyth-street M.E. Church. This announcement to the Methodist fraternity of that part of the City will be sufficient to attract a large audience. One of the attractions of Mr. ROGERS consists in his vocal abilities, and he takes occasion during the delivery of his sermon to sing with considerable pathos a hymn appropriate to the theme.

abstract: London Times on Mr. Adams' Protection to a Matamoras Ship
snippet: London Times on Mr. Adams' Protection to a Matamoras Ship
lead_paragraph: The London Times is doing its best to get up another storm seizing upon the circumstance that Mr. ADAMS had given a certain vessel a certificate that she was bona fide bound for Matamoras and not a Confederate port. It fulminates very vehemently over the idea that British ships can cross the seas only by virtue of an American protection. Doubtless the "Thunderer" knows what is best calculated to impose upon the senses of its devotees; but, as for ourselves, we must say that this is about the sorriest specimen of the sheet-iron article we have heard in that quarter this many a day. There are respectable shams; but this is not -- it is simply ridiculous and contemptible.

abstract: The "big ship" is to be floated and removed to her moorings to-day. The repairs were all completed yesterday evening, and we are informed that everything has been done to the entire satisfaction of the surveyors for the Board of Trade, so that her hull may be considered as perfect and almost as good as when she was launched. The tide will be at the height at a quarter before 11, so that she will be removed about that time. It anything should occur to prevent her getting off to-day she is certain to go off on Saturday; but there is little doubt about her getting removed to-day. Immediately after she gets to her moorings she is to commence taking in her coals and cargo, and she will sail for New-York on the 2d of May.

abstract: The panel of Grand Jurors was filled up this morning, and the jury having been sworn, were charged by the Judge briefly as to the matters which would come before them. There were but few cases -- one of murder, one of cruel and unusual punishment, one of larceny, and one of counterfeiting a fifty cent postage stamp, to which the Judge called their especial attention, because, as he said, it was reported that there were a good many counterfeits of this kind in circulation, and a prompt administration of justice might check the crime. The Judge also congratulated them that there were so few cases to come before them, the result, he thought, of prompt and thorough justice heretofore.
lead_paragraph: The panel of Grand Jurors was filled up this morning, and the jury having been sworn, were charged by the Judge briefly as to the matters which would come before them. abstract: A somewhat more definite knowledge of the movements of the Army of the Potomac begins to reach us.
lead_paragraph: A somewhat more definite knowledge of the movements of the Army of the Potomac begins to reach us. It appears that the Rappahannock has been crossed at three or four different points, both above and below Fredericksburgh -- certainly at Port Royal, near the point where FRANKLIN crossed before the battle of Fredericksburgh, and at Kelly's Ford, several miles above the town; and probably at United States Ford, still further up. Accounts state that there was considerable fighting at the crossing below, but none of consequence above. Full details of these movements will be found in the letters of our special correspondents. Gen. HOOKER appears to have commanded the movement at Kelly's Ford in person. A report reached Philadelphia last night, and was telegraphed to us, that Gen. HOOKER, with 50,000 men, had fought a battle and won a victory. This is about the number of men supposed to have crossed at Kelly's Ford, and the report, though unofficial, may have some foundation in fact.

abstract: The United States steam transport Escort, Capt. R. WALL, (Capt. SHAW, Agent,) arrived at this port last night from Newbern, N.C., 29th and Hatteras Inlet 30th, at 6 A.M., making the passage in 55 hours.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Escort, Capt. R. WALL, (Capt. SHAW, Agent,) arrived at this port last night from Newbern, N.C., 29th and Hatteras Inlet 30th, at 6 A.M., making the passage in 55 hours. The Escort is the steamer which ran the rebel blockade at Washington, N.C., with Gen. FOSTER and the Rhode Island Fifth Volunteers on board. She comes to New-York for repairs to her hull and machinery, which are considerably damaged by the shots she received from the rebel batteries.

abstract: Additional news from Mexico has been received by way of San Francisco. The advices from Puebla are to the 7th of April two days earlier than were received a day or two ago by way of Havana.
lead_paragraph: Additional news from Mexico has been received by way of San Francisco. The advices from Puebla are to the 7th of April two days earlier than were received a day or two ago by way of Havana. The character of these advices is totally different from the version of affairs given by the French. On the 5th and 6th of April, according to the dispatch, the French, after severe fighting, succeeded in gaining a portion of Puebla, but on the 7th the Mexicans drove them out with great slaughter, pursuing them with the bayonet beyond the outposts. The French are said to have then retired to Cholula, seven miles from Puebla, where they were fortifying themselves at last accounts.

abstract: Messrs. D.W. IVES & CO. announce the sale of some of the lately executed works of E. LEUTEE. A free exhibition of this collection will be opened on Monday next, at the Derby Gallery, on Broadway, above Houston-street, and continue until the evening of the sale, which takes place on Thursday, May 7. This collection comprises many of the finest pictures by this artist, and includes his celebrated one of "Lafayette Met by his Family in the Prison of Olmutz," which was in the Academy exhibition of last year; "Spray and Bubbler," a picture which to the casual observer will be simply a delineation of the sea breaking upon the shore, but which, if he studies it closely, will resolve itself into an army of water-spirits battling against the rocks, only to be beaten back or cast up with the surf upon the shore; "Unexpected Friends," representing a wounded knight, imprisoned in a tower by a neighboring prince, who has entrapped him while on the chase, and now holds him confined until ransomed -- his daughter is with him, and the "unexpected friends" appear in the shape of a Robin Goodfellow and his raven, who, having fround their way into the prison from above, by a rope-ladder, are ready to effect their deliverance; "Prairie Bluffs," depicting a herd of half-tamed horses being driven into camp before the coming storm breaks -- the yellow bluffs of the prairie are seen in the background, relieved against the stormy sky; "Ichabod Crane and the Headless Horseman," illustrating a well-known story in Irving's Sketch Book; "The Deserted Hall," "Entertaining the Messenger," and "Tired of Waiting," each architectural in their character, and fine examples of the artist's power in this line; a "Gentleman of the Time of Charles II." and a "German Knight," besides the original sketch in oil of the historical picture, "Emigration to the West," in the Capitol at Washington, and several study heads of females in the same work. An opportunity of seeing so many fine pictures by this artist may seldom, if ever, again occur, consequently all lovers of art should avail themselves of this coming exhibition to carefully study his works therein to be found.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. D.W. IVES & CO. announce the sale of some of the lately executed works of E. LEUTEE. abstract: Col. NUGENT, of the Sixty-ninth, regiment, recently appointed General Provost-Marshal for this District, in place of SIMEON DRAPER, resigned, entered upon the duties of his office yesterday forenoon. He has established his headquarters at No. 27 Pine-street. The subordinates appointed by Mr. DRAPER will be retained for the present, and the general system pursued by the late incumbent will be followed by his successor. His jurisdiction extends over the first nine Congressional Districts, including this City, Brooklyn and Staten Island. Preparations will be immediately made to carry out the Conscription act, as soon as its execution shall be ordered from Washington.
lead_paragraph: Col. NUGENT, of the Sixty-ninth, regiment, recently appointed General Provost-Marshal for this District, in place of SIMEON DRAPER, resigned, entered upon the duties of his office yesterday forenoon. He has established his headquarters at No. 27 Pine-street. The subordinates appointed by Mr. DRAPER will be retained for the present, and the general system pursued by the late incumbent will be followed by his successor. His jurisdiction extends over the first nine Congressional Districts, including this City, Brooklyn and Staten Island. Preparations will be immediately made to carry out the Conscription act, as soon as its execution shall be ordered from Washington.

abstract: of the rebel success over Col. MULLIGAN at Fairmount, in Western Virginia, loses much of the interest it would otherwise have had, occurring now just as the public are intently watching far more important operations on the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: of the rebel success over Col. MULLIGAN at Fairmount, in Western Virginia, loses much of the interest it would otherwise have had, occurring now just as the public are intently watching far more important operations on the Rappahannock. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company lose two of their admirable bridges, one at Fairmount, over the Monongahela River, and the famous one over the Cheat River. The latter was one of the most beautiful structures in the United Slates, and, being placed amid scenery of unsurpassed grandeur, it had already become a classic spot in the guide-book of American art. It was vandalism fit for ingrates and traitors of the lowest type to destroy what was at once so beautiful and useful a monument of taste and science.

abstract: most astounding facts to croakers and enemies of the Government is the affluence of the people's faith in the final triumph of the sacred cause of Freedom and the Union over...
lead_paragraph: most astounding facts to croakers and enemies of the Government is the affluence of the people's faith in the final triumph of the sacred cause of Freedom and the Union over the still powerful and unconquered rebellion. And this popular faith is proved by a test the severest of all others that are applied to merely temporal interests -- the money test. A man may love a cause and yet hesitate about investing his money in it -- he may have a thorough conviction that an enterprise will succeed, and yet prudently decline to risk his earnings on it. But when one so believes in success that he stakes his fortune on it, and does not wait to be invited even, but comes forward voluntarily and offers his assistance, then indeed is there a faith that may be relied on to bring out all of the best wishes and energies of the man.

abstract: Medals for brave soldiers
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Navy has recently made an award of forty-four medals of Honor under the Act of Congress of December, 1861, which authorized such distinctions to be bestowed for gallantry in action and seamanlike qualities on the part of our sailors and marines. The encouragement and reward of acts of individual heroism is a very important part of the conduct of military and naval affairs. NAPOLEON knew it to be so, and appealed continually to the love of honor of his men, and our people are also easily impressible by such motives. They have not been sufficiently appealed to heretofore. We are glad to see a move in this direction, and we look upon the distribution of these medals as a guarantee of yet greater gallantry on the part of our navy.

abstract: We publish this morning in full the testimony of Gen. MCCLELLAN before the Committee on the Conduct of the War. It will be found deeply interesting, and should be read by every one who would understand the great campaigns of 1862. Taken in connection with the testimony of Gen. HOOKER and other officers, which we have already published, and the very full report of the Congressional Committee, which we gave on the 6th of last month, an excellent understanding of the Peninsular campaign, the Maryland campaign, and the operations in front of Washington, may be had. Beside these documents, we have given our own opinion of Gen. MCCLELLAN's operations; on Friday we quoted a rebel opinion; and now we complete the circle by permitting Gen. MCCLELLAN to speak for himself.

abstract: SUPPOSED SUICIDE BY DROWNING. Officer CONKLIN, of the Thirty-second Precinct, reported yesterday that a quantity of female wearing apparel had been found secreted among some rocks, at the foot of One Hundred and Eighty-third street, North River.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED SUICIDE BY DROWNING. -- Officer CONKLIN, of the Thirty-second Precinct, reported yesterday that a quantity of female wearing apparel had been found secreted among some rocks, at the foot of One Hundred and Eighty-third street, North River. The clothing consisted of a poplin dress, with gold-colored stripes, a white flannel skirt, calico skirt, two white muslin skirts, a red shawl, a pair of black gaiters and white silk stockings. From all the circumstances attending the case, the authorities are induced to believe that the wearer of the above-named articles of clothing committed suicide by drowning herself in the North River, at or near the place above indicated.

abstract: Ward's Statue of the fugitive negro
snippet: Ward's Statue of the fugitive negro
lead_paragraph: With the exception of a few monumental works, the American sculptors of our day have been gravitating toward decorative art. A large majority of works of this kind are the faces or figures of pretty girls and children, out of which all traces of soul, have been elaborated away in a mere aim at prettiness and mechanical finish. These emasculations, in a spirit of weak sentimentality, are called, incessantly, "Hope," "Faith," or "Innocence," to suit the pleasure of the purchaser, and may be changed at his sweet will, so that one statue can be made to do service for a whole gallery of sentiments. So much multiplied has this class of work become, and so ostentatiously has it been thrust before the public, that they have almost come to think that nothing better is worthy of their notice. It is not a little refreshing, therefore, to find a man who can gr[???]ple successfully with the higher requisites of his noble art.

abstract: The opening of the month of May shows an almost universal activity in our armies, great and small. Everywhere we are acting on the offensive, with the trifling exceptions of the...
lead_paragraph: The opening of the month of May shows an almost universal activity in our armies, great and small. Everywhere we are acting on the offensive, with the trifling exceptions of the affairs in Missouri and in Western Virginia. Sen. HOOKER's movements are, of course, those which most profoundly excite the interest and stir the heart of the nation, for they are more important than any other -we may say than all others put together. His army is the grand army of the nation, and his work is to strike the fatal blow at the rebellion's head. In the inception of the movement which commenced on Monday last, he certainly appears to have shown consummate skill. He moved both of the wings of his army rapidly and cleanly; and so well were his purposes and aims covered, that the rebels at each point seem to have been taken entirely unawares. The laying of the pontoons and the crossing of the river were admirably performed, and in less than two days from the time his movement commenced the main body of his army had made a march of twenty miles, crossed a difficult river, and was ready for action on the other side. It would appeal that it was by far the larger part of his army which marched north from Falmouth, and crossed the Rappahannock at Kelly's and adjacent fords. Judging by our letters, it is the lower movement that is a feint; but what is to be the real mode of action on the upper line cannot yet be told. What last week opened, however, this week will undoubtedly develop; and we prefer waiting for events to indulging in useless speculations. The movement which seems most obvious and likely to the non-military observer will probably be the movement which Gen. HOOKER will not make.

abstract: Lecture on Three Methods of Peace

lead_paragraph: Those relentless scribblers, who have ransacked dictionary and thesaurus for oprobrious epithets, which they have showered upon Miss ANNA E. DICKINSON, would have been thoroughly ashamed of themselves could they have witnessed the unequaled audience which so cordially greeted that lady last evening at the Cooper Institute. Never was there a more respectable or more intelligent assemblage in that building. Among others of mark there present were Mayor Opdyke, Peter Cooper, N.P. Willis, Judge McCunn, George Francis Train, Oliver Johnson, Charles King, G.W. Blunt, Charles Gould, and beautiful ladies ad libitum. The fair oratress was introduced by Mayor OPDYKE, who presided.

abstract: A meeting was held in Atlanta, Ga., on the 17th inst., to organize a joint stock company, and establish a provision store for the benefit of mechanics. The Confederacy says: "The idea is to raise a fund to pur- ...
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held in Atlanta, Ga., on the 17th inst., to organize a joint stock company, and establish a provision store for the benefit of mechanics. The Confederacy says: "The idea is to raise a fund to purchase provisions at the cheapest rate, and sell them at a reasonable profit above expenses. So many shares of stock are to be taken -- no person permitted to take more than a given number -- so as to allow all a chance to invest in it. The shares will be put at a small amount, so as to make it the more accessible to those of limited means. It is expected of every mechanic to give the weight of his influence to the store, although he may not take stock in the company. The profits are to be divided among the stockholders."

abstract: Reading in a foreign newspaper that the new Boulevards in Paris were to be named after the eightteen Marshals of the First Empire, excluding MARMONT, the thirteenth Marshal, for his treachery in...
lead_paragraph: Reading in a foreign newspaper that the new Boulevards in Paris were to be named after the eightteen Marshals of the First Empire, excluding MARMONT, the thirteenth Marshal, for his treachery in 1813, it brought up into my memory the history some of the distinguished soldiers of France, both true and traitor, the histories of whom I should like briefly to state, as an encouragement to the loyal and a warning to the Copperheads. We begin with BAYARD. After he was struck down in covering the retreat of the French army by a stone bullet, he was placed, at his own request, with his back to a tree, his face to the enemy, his eyes on the cruciform hilt of his sword. The first who approached him was the Spanish General, PESCARA, who addressed him in the kindest manner.

abstract: ASSAULT ON AN OFFICER. -- A deserter, known by the name of WAXY, was arrested by Deputy Provost-Marshal SPRAGUE on Friday, near the City Hall. WAXY showed a disposition to fight, when the handcuffs were applied. He then drew a knife and attempted to stab the officer, but it was wrenched from him, and he was secured and taken to Governor's Island.

abstract: THE HACKENSACK BRIDGE ACCIDENT. The body of the engineer who was drowned at the time the locomotive of the Hoboken and Newark Road run off the bridge, several months since, was found near the spot where the accident occurred on Friday forenoon. The body was removed to Newark.

abstract: Levi Robinson, Edward Van Buren and Charles Felmette, three colored men, charged with poisoning Martin Van Buren, also colored, a brother of the prisoner Edward Va[???] Buren, was brought before Judge MCCUNN, yesterday, upon a writ of certiorari, obtained by Wm. J. Howe, Esq., their counsel. It is a somewhat singular and mysterious case, and Judge MCCUNN ordered. hearing before him, when the following facts were brought out. It appears that these men have been confined in the City Prison since the 13th of March last by the commitment of Police Justice Connelly, upon the suspicion of poisoning Martin Van Buren, a steward on board of the steamboat City of New-York, based upon the affidavit of Andrew Murray, a Policeman of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, who swears that he was informed that poison was administered to Martin, who subsequently sickened and died at the City of New-London, in Connecticut, on the 11th of March, and that, from facts and circumstances within his knowledge, and from information received by him, he believed the parties charged were guilty of administering the poison to Martin. Martin had died in New-London, and the Coroner's inquest revealed the fact that he had died of poison, and that it had been administered to him by some unknown person or persons in New-York. The deceased's stomach and viscera were then sent by the authorities of New-London to Prof. St. John, of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of this City, with directions to analyze the contents. Dr. St. John reported to Judge MCCUNN that he had made a chemical examination, and found a sufficient amount of arsenic to destroy life, and that the examination occupied several weeks. Andrew Murray, the policeman, was then examined by Mr. Howe, when it appeared that he knew nothing of his own knowledge of the case. William Townsend, a colored witness, was then examined, who swore that on the 2d of March he was in company in this City with the deceased and the prisoners; that they went into a drinking-saloon on the corner of Leonard-street and West Broadway, and drank some liquor, when he saw Robinson, one of the prisoners, put his arms around the deceased, and when the bar-keeper called for the money for the drinks, deceased put his hand into his pocket to pay, when he exclaimed that his money was gone, and Robinson said he would make it all right for the drinks. Edward and Martin Van Buren had previously had a fight. On the same night he saw deceased on the steamboat City of New-York, when he manifested feelings and symptoms of great sickness. Witness asked him what was the matter, and deceased answered, "I don't know, that he had been drinking all that day, and mentioned particularly a glass of ale." He was in great pain, and remained sick until he died. Several other witnesses were also examined, but they knew nothing whatever of the case. There can be no doubt, from Dr. St. John's testimony, that Martin died of poison by arsenic, but when it was administered, or by whom, or from what motive, is shrouded in mystery. Mr. Howe, at the conclusion of the examination, moved for the discharge of the prisoners; and Judge MCCUNN said there was no evidence against these prisoners, and that the prosecution had had nearly three months to obtain any, if there was, and that longer to detain them upon suspicion he thought was wrong, and he would therefore discharge them.

abstract: The Situation in
lead_paragraph: -- The Polish insurrection appears more and more formidable. It extends now from the shores of the Baltic to the confines of Gallicia. It encircles Warsaw, the seat and centre of Russian power. It has taken root in Lithuania. It stretches from end to end of the Prussian frontier. The fire extinguished by the dispersion of the forces of LANGIEWICZ, has burst out afresh at a hundred other points, under a host of new leaders; and the Muscovites must gain not one, but one hundred victories, if they would subdue its flames.

abstract: Two sorts of snake have been very much spoken of in this country during the last two years -- the anaconda and the copperhead. The Anaconda came first, the Copperhead next. The anaconda was the largest serpent, the copperhead the meanest reptile. The anaconda was military, the copperhead political -- the first was loyal, the other traitorous. The anaconda had an illustrious parentage, the copperhead was very low-born. It was the aim of the loyal anaconda to twine around the huge carcass of the rebellion, break its backbone, and make a festive meal of it; it was the aim of the copperhead to strike its venomous fangs into the heart of the North, and to reduce to "cold obstruction's apathy" the glorious vitality of the nation.

abstract: The country will not be slow in awarding to Maj.-Gen. BANKS a full measure of its admiration and gratitude for his late brilliant and highly successful campaign in Louisiana. The thorough and soldierly manner in which he has carried out his purpose, marching from his base at Berwick's Bay quite through and through the heart of the enemy's country, beating their armies, destroying their gunboats, taking their fortified places, and wholly demolishing their organization both for war and agriculture, and all without serious loss to himself, entitles Gen. BANKS to unquestioned credit as a general. He has fully vindicated the claims to military talent of the best order that his friends have always put forward in his behalf.
lead_paragraph: The country will not be slow in awarding to Maj.-Gen. BANKS a full measure of its admiration and gratitude for his late brilliant and highly successful campaign in Louisiana. The thorough and soldierly manner in which he has carried out his purpose, marching from his base at Berwick's Bay quite through and through the heart of the enemy's country, beating their armies, destroying their gunboats, taking their fortified places, and wholly demolishing their organization both for war and agriculture, and all without serious loss to himself, entitles Gen. abstract: We observe by our last advices from the Federal States of the North, that the army commanded by Gen. Fighting JOE HOOKER (as he is still called by the mob of New-York, though he has fought no battle, after being...
lead_paragraph: -- We observe by our last advices from the Federal States of the North, that the army commanded by Gen. Fighting JOE HOOKER (as he is still called by the mob of New-York, though he has fought no battle, after being for three months in command of the "finest army on the planet,") has left its Winter camping ground at Falmouth, in Virginia, and marched for Port Royal; and one of the reliable newspapers of New-York informs us that after reaching the latter point JOE will move his troops in the direction of Bowling Green!. We rubbed our eyes and took a long breath on perusing these statements. Such movements, indicating such mingled madness, vanity and imbecility, were never heard of in war, from the days when, on the windy plains of Troy, ("Arma virumque cano Trojoe,") the Hellenic heroes played at high strategy, down to the period of our own great war in the Crimea, which was illustrated and made memorable by the charge of the Light Brigade -- not to speak of several very heavy ones. For we suppose every Englishman knows that Port Royal, the first point to which Fighting JOE is said to be marching his military rabble, is situated on the coast of the State of South Carolina, some five hundred miles from his camping ground at Falmouth -- while Bowling Green, the other point mentioned as on his line of march, is located in the very heart of the State of Kentucky, nearly a thousand miles distant from Port Royal, and will be remembered as the place so long held against the Yankee threats by that brave Confederate, Gen. ALBERT SIDNEY JOHNSTON. To reach his first point, Port Royal, JOE will have to march over the entire State of Virginia and through the midst of Gen. LEE's fine army of a hundred thousand men; he will also have to pass through the State of North Carolina, and through Charleston itself. To reach BOWLING Green, he will have to cross several rivers and hills, and traverse the entire area of the Southern Confederacy. How such stupendous folly could be contemplated, even by Fighting JOE, certainly passes British comprehension. ("Quem Deus vult perdere," etc.) It is probable that the campaign was planned by Honest Old ABE, (which latter word the Southerners spell Ape,) and --

abstract: -- Dr. WM. DARLINGTON died at West Chester Penn., on Wednesday, April 22. The Philadelphia Press gives these particulars of his eventful life: He was born in Birmingham township, Chester County, in 1782, and until his eighteenth year engaged in the pursuit of agriculture, acquiring in his leisure hours a fair English education. In 1800 he commenced to study medicine, under the tuition of Dr. JOHN VAUGHAN, of Wilmington, Delaware, and four years after graduated with the title of M.D., at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. In 1806-7 he made a voyage to India as surgeon of a vessel. During the last forty-four years he filled several important positions of trust under the General Government, as well as that of the State. The degree of L.L.D. was conferred upon him by Yale College. He was President of the Bank of Chester County until his death -- a period of more than thirty years. Dr. DARLINGTON had devoted a large portion of his life to the study of botany, his favorite science. In which he acquired a vast fund of information. He likewise attained considerable celebrity as an author. In 1804 he published his Mutual Influence of Habits and Disease. In 1826 his most successful work. Flora Cestrica, appeared, and passed to three editions. It was favorably noticed by the greatest botanists of Europe, and established its author in the front rank of American scholars. In 1843 he revised and published Reliquioe Baldwinioe, and four years afterward issued his Agricultural Botany. In 1849 he gave to the public Memorials of John Barton and Humphrey Marshall. These were the principal works which gave him transatlantic fame, and most of them were favorably reviewed in the foreign journals of agricultural science. Dr. DARLINGTON, during the Administration of Gen. JACKSON, was a prominent candidate before the Legislature of Pennsylvania for the position of United States Senator, being defeated by very few votes. During the existence of the Whig party he took an active part in support of its principles, but soon after its death he retired from the political field. During all this war, and until the day of his death, he was a firm friend of the Administration.

abstract: The Finances of
lead_paragraph: A recent survey of the military situation in Canada showed us the practical results of sixteen months' endeavor in the business of warlike equipment. Those results were less alarming to neighboring communities than we had been led to anticipate; and those who may be disposed to look with mistrust on the international situation, were, no doubt, relieved to find that the volunteer armaments of Canada barely out-numbered those of Rhode Island, at the opening of the present year. Such a military organization, one would suppose, could hardly bear with inordinate weight, even on a moderately well-to-do population of nearly three millions. It was, therefore, with some surprise that in looking into the Blue Book just issued from the Finance Department of the Province, we found, not only a serious deficit in the accounts for the past financial year, but a series of gradually increasing deficits, extending back for a period of six years.
headline: {'main': 'The Finances of Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Finances of Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: - The fashion of having embroidery on cloaks, ladies' dresses, and, in fact, garments of almost every description, is rapidly on the increase in this country -- imported, as are other fashions, from Paris. Fortunately for the ladies, the crisis has not caught them unprepared, and left them with no other means of ornamenting their articles of dress but the tedious and tiresome one by hand. There is at least one of our popular sewing machines (GROVEE & BAKER's,) which is adapted to both sewing and embroidery -- the latter as well and as rapidly as it sews the plainest sewing. So long, then, at least, as the present fashion prevails, the manufacturers of this machine are assured of large sales. -- New-York Evangelist.

abstract: Fighting qualities of the Mexicans
lead_paragraph: Europeans, with their incapacity to judge correctly of events on this continent, have always supposed, since the conquest of Mexico by the United States, that Mexicans cannot fight. It has suited them to believe that Gen. SCOTT marched to the Mexican capital, not because of any great ability on his part or that of his troops, but because of the cowardice and weakness of his foe. In their jealousy of the Americans, this has been a pleasant belief, but this easy credulity is now costing them dear. The truth is, and always has been, that the Mexicans, however unable to govern their country, can yet defend it with tremendous vigor.
