abstract: Cen. HOOKER has thrown his army down from the points at which it crossed the Rappahannock above Fredericksburgh, toward Chancellorsville, a hamlet lying a few miles in the rear of Fredericksburgh, with the design of flanking the rebel army and of compelling them to come out from behind their fortifications and give battle.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HOOKER has thrown his army down from the points at which it crossed the Rappahannock above Fredericksburgh, toward Chancellorsville, a hamlet lying a few miles in the rear of Fredericksburgh, with the design of flanking the rebel army and of compelling them to come out from behind their fortifications and give battle. Three considerable battles took place near Chancellorsville on the afternoon of Friday, in the first of which Gen. SYKES' Division attacked the enemy shortly after 12 o'clock, fought them an hour and a half with great valor, drove them a mile, and took fifty prisoners; but HOOKER ordered the attack to be suspended, and the men to return to their former ground. To this point the enemy came up at 4 o'clock, and attacked SYKES fiercely, but HOOKER himself was on the ground, and after a fight of three-quarters of an hour, the enemy ignominiously retired. At 6 1/2 o'clock, the enemy made a charge for our batteries, when the third fight of the day took place, in which they were again severely repulsed with heavy loss. After this affair there was no serious fighting, but the sharpshooters kept up their desultory work for some time. And thus ended Friday's operations. During the night our troops were kept actively at work building earthworks and abattis to enable them to hold the excellent position they had gained. Our correspondent with this force writes up to 3 o'clock of Saturday morning; and from what he saw around him, he inferred that the "greatest day in the history of the war was about to dawn."
headline: {'main': "Gen. Hooker's Advance.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Hooker's Advance.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Emperor and the Poles
lead_paragraph: The text of the proclamation of amnesty offered by the Emperor of Russia to the Poles, enables us to requires only a very cursory perusal of it to understand why it has not only been rejected by the insurgents, but has stimulated them to fresh exertions. He offers a free pardon to all who have simply taken part in the insurrection, "without having made themselves responsible for other crimes," if they will lay down their arms by the 13th of May -- a month from the date of the proclamation. He purposes, then, that everything shall return to the status quo, and asks the Poles to trust to the "dictates" of the imperial heart, "and to such further development" of the institutions then in existence as the Government may see fit to allow. This is, of course, simply a roundabout way of asking them to place themselves once more in absolute subjection to his will. It is rendered all the more absurd by the fact that it was under the "institutions" to which he invites them to return, that the razzia at the hands of the Cossacks took place which brought on the insurrection. In fact, it requires some experience of the simplicity of absolute monarchs, to enable one to believe that ALEXANDER is in earnest in seeking to tempt the Poles back into peace by the offer of a complete and gracious restoration of a state of things under which it was possible for the Governor, by a stroke of the pen, to have all the males of the upper and middle classes seized by Cossacks at midnight, and hurried off for twenty-five years' service in the ranks of the army. It would be hard to conceive of any possible "development" of institutions of this kind, that would result in satisfying a people who had suffered even one-tenth part of what has fallen to the lot of the Poles.
headline: {'main': 'The Russian Emperor and the Poles.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Russian Emperor and the Poles.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This evening MAX MARETZEK commences a Summer season at the Academy, signalizing the occasion by the production, for the first time in America, of one of VERDI'S least known, but by no means least meritorious works. It is called "Aroldo," and the action of it is supposed to take place in England during the Saxon period.
lead_paragraph: This evening MAX MARETZEK commences a Summer season at the Academy, signalizing the occasion by the production, for the first time in America, of one of VERDI'S least known, but by no means least meritorious works. It is called "Aroldo," and the action of it is supposed to take place in England during the Saxon period. The plot of the opera is thus quaintly explained in an official publication. Harold, a Saxon nobleman, returns to his castle in Kent from Palestine, where he has been fighting as a Crusader. During his absence to the Holy Land, Godwin, a young knight-errant, having become passionately in love with Mina, Harold's wife, and daughter to the old and proud Egbert, Lord of the castle, has succeeded by his entreaties in obtaining from the incautious wife some tokens of indulgent forbearance. She, however, remembering her duties, and terrified at the fearful consequences of a protracted intercourse with a man who has plotted her dishonor and ruin, resolves not to yield to his persuasions.

abstract: The readers of the Times will rememher that on the evening of Wednesday, April 22, JOSEPH SANDS, a Policeman of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, was arrested upon the charge of shooting THOMAS MURPHY with a revolver in the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house.
lead_paragraph: The readers of the Times will rememher that on the evening of Wednesday, April 22, JOSEPH SANDS, a Policeman of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, was arrested upon the charge of shooting THOMAS MURPHY with a revolver in the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house. MURPHY was immediately takes to St. Vincent's Hospital, where he lingered until Saturday evening last, when he died of the wounds received at the hands of Officer SANDS. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest upon the body, yesterday, when the following testimony was elicited:

abstract: seems from the letter of our London correspondent, as well as from our English exchanges, that the war fever has broken out afresh in England. John Bull is in a terrible state of excitement, because our Minister certified to the legitimate character of a British vessel bound to Matamoras. Such an insult to the naval supremacy of Great Britain cannot be tolerated. How is Britannia to "rule the waves" if her vessels are to sail the seas under protection of an American certificate?

abstract: -- We published yesterday the address of the Union members of the Legislature to their constituents. It is a paper of ability and interest. Without discussing the acts of the Legislature or questions of State policy, it is mainly an argumentative vindication of the National Government in its war against the rebellion, and shows, with cogency and force, that the only possible way of restering peace is by prosecuting the war to a victorious end. It assails with vigor and success the position of the Copperhead Democracy, which insists on immediate and unconditional peace, as fatal to the Union and dishonorable to the nation.
lead_paragraph: -- We published yesterday the address of the Union members of the Legislature to their constituents. It is a paper of ability and interest. abstract: Our Special Correspondence from the Army of the Potomac, which is to Saturday morning, gives very full details of the important events which had occurred with that army up to that time. Everything had so far progressed in the most satisfactory manner.
lead_paragraph: Our Special Correspondence from the Army of the Potomac, which is to Saturday morning, gives very full details of the important events which had occurred with that army up to that time. Everything had so far progressed in the most satisfactory manner. There had been some hard fighting, but it had all been in our favor. Below Fredericksburgh, on Thursday afternoon, an artillery duel of considerable magnitude occurred at about the point where the operations under Gen. FRANKLIN were carried on during Gen. BURNSIDE's unsuccessful demonstrations against the enemy's lines in December. Although the firing was very rapid and continuous, the casualties were very few on our side. The enemy, during this cannonade, were drawn up in line of battle, apparently awaiting an attack. On Friday morning it was discovered that they had changed their position -- a movement rendered necessary by the operations of that portion of our army under the immediate command of Gen. HOOKER, on their left and rear. Near Chancellorsville, the point at which this portion of our army was at work, there was some severe fighting on Friday afternoon, caused by efforts on the part of the rebels, to dislodge our forces -- in which they signally railed. The strength of the rebels in that quarter was thus ascertained with considerable certainty, and preparations were made during Friday night for a struggle of greater magnitude, which was expected to take place on Saturday. Our correspondence also gives the destails of a dashing reconnoissance made by the Sixth New-York Cavalry, toward Spottsylvania Court-house, in which they encountered the entire brigade of rebel cavalry under FITZHUGH LEE. A telegraphic dispatch gives a report which reached Philadelphia yesterday, that our cavalry under Gen. STONEMAN, had succeeded in cutting the railroad in the rebel rear. There is no doubt of the fact that our army was in the best condition and spirits. During the forenoon, Thursday. Gen. HOOKER issued the following stirring and significant address:

abstract: We have a direct and reliable dispatch from Clarksburgh, stating that the Morgantown raiders were met, yesterday, midway between Fairmont and Clarksburgh, near Shinston, and defeated and driven back, with the loss of several killed and taken prisoners.
lead_paragraph: We have a direct and reliable dispatch from Clarksburgh, stating that the Morgantown raiders were met, yesterday, midway between Fairmont and Clarksburgh, near Shinston, and defeated and driven back, with the loss of several killed and taken prisoners. They were under Gen. JONES, and numbered some 1,500, and were on their way to make a combined attack on our troops at Clarksburgh, in conjunction with IMBODEN and JACKSON, whose forces are known to be in the Tygart Valley, on the other side of Clarksburgh, in Lewis or Barbour County.

abstract: -- We publish in another column a letter on the nature of the contest our Government is compelled to wage with the rebellion, and the military principles which should govern its conduct, which is entitled to special attention on account of the source from which it comes, as well as the mastery of the subject which it evinces. No one can have followed the progress of the war without seeing very clearly that the conditions under which it is carried on are very different, in many essential respects, from those of any war of similar magnitude in the past history of the world. This fact makes it important that its characteristic features should be studied and discussed by persons competent to compare them with those of other wars. The results of such inquiries cannot fail to be permanently instructive and especially useful to the successful prosecution of the contest.

abstract: The day has closed without firing on either side. The two lines of battle which the enemy showed last night were no longer visible to-day, the troops doubtless having been withdrawn to fight our forces in their rear. Their skirmish line has also been thinned out, and, to all appearances, the rebels have "raked and scraped" together all their forces to meet the rear attack.

abstract: The Magnificent Raid of
lead_paragraph: -- There is no danger now of communication between the rebel armies at Vicksburgh and at Tullahoma. So far as railroad connection is concerned, they seem to be completely severed, and a foot march of the Vicksburgh army northward would be a long, difficult and slow affair. We gave the other day an account of Gen. DODGE's movement eastward from Corinth, on the line of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, and his capture of Tuscumbia, Alabama: and if the reader, taking the bearings of the latter point, will follow the line and sweep of the magnificent raid of Col. GRIERSON through Central Mississippi and Alabama, of which we publish an interesting account this morning, and compare it with the rebel telegram concerning the affair, he will see how every line of road that connects the Gulf States with the rebel army in Tennessee has been cut, that is not already in our control. The Mississippi Central, the Mobile and Ohio, and the newly constructed line connecting Meridian with Selma, were all on his route. It was really a splendid swoop, and the startled rebel organ at the capital of Mississippi asserts that "it exceeds in daring and boldness all former Yankee raids." Our Memphis correspondent compares it with the raid of Col. CARTER into East Tennessee, in December last. It will be remembered that Gen. ROSECRANS attributed to that dash much of his success at Murfreesboro, as, by destroying the bridges on the Virginia and East Tennessee Railroad, it prevented the rebels from receiving reinforcements from Virginia. We published a statement some weeks ago from a rebel paper that these bridges had just been repaired, showing that Col. CARTER had rendered their great military line unavailable for three or four months. As that movement preceded ROSECRANS' great attack on BRAGG's army, so this one, which is very like the other in character and results, may have an important bearing on another advance, which he does not herald, but which he has been steadily preparing for. Col. CARTER's raid, it will be remembered, was over a distance of 200 miles; but the circuit of Col. GRIERSON through rebel territory must have been at least 500 miles.
headline: {'main': 'A MAGNIFICENT RAID.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A MAGNIFICENT RAID.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The collectors of internal revenue will to-day commence issuing their notices to citizens liable to pay an income tax. F it particulars about the tax, and directions for making a statement in each individual case will be left at the residence of every citizen. Every person will be obliged to swear to the truth of his statement. The income tax now to be collected includes the period between the 1st of July and last of December, 1862. It will be 3 per cent. on all incomes over $600 after deducting from the excess the amount of rent actually paid by the party.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon your correspondent learned that the gallant little remnant of the Sixth New-York cavalry, Lieut.-Col. McVICAR commanding, had started out upon a reconnoisance toward Spottsylvania Court-house. As there was nothing more interesting on hand I determined to see what a reconnoisance might be like. I accordingly dashed across the country and overtook the expedition about two miles beyond our outer pickets.
lead_paragraph: CHANCELLORVILLE, Friday, May 1, 1863.

abstract: The Berlingske Lidende, of to-day, officially announces that Prince CHRISTIAN has had a long interview with Sir A. PAGET, the British Minister, at which His Royal Highness declared that the only obstacles which had hitherto opposed the acceptance of the Crown of Greece, viz., the abdication of King OTHO, and the finances of Greece, having now been fully removed, he definitely accepted it for his son, Prince WILLIAM.

abstract: -- Gen. HOOKER, on the 30th ult., issued an order requiring newspaper correspondents in his army to "publish their communications over their own signatures," and declaring that "in case of failure to comply with this order, through their own or their employers' neglect, such correspondents will be excluded from, and the circulation of the journals for which they correspond suppressed, within the lines of this army." In conformity with this requirement we append to our army letters the names of the writers, as we have done from the time the order was brought to our notice. We shall be very glad if in this way or any other Gen. HOOKER can succeed in suppressing the transmission of false intelligence, and the betrayal of the movements of the army by injudicious publications, of which he complains.

abstract: Chancellorsville, The Battle of
lead_paragraph: Two of our correspondents with Gen. HOOKER's army, arrived in the City yesterday, bringing the latest intelligence from the field of battle. Mr. SWINTON left Gen. HOOKER's headquarters at 6 o'clock on Sunday morning and reached this City at 6 o'clock yesterday morning: Mr. CROUNSE left at 9 o'clock on Sunday evening and arrived at 10 o'clock last night. We have from them, therefore, very full and complete reports of everything that has happened on the Rappahannock down to a late hour on Sunday night.

abstract: By the steamship Roanoke, which arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, we receive advices from Vera Cruz to the 17th ult. Puebla had, up to that time, not been taken. The French had been repulsed three times, in trying to take Fort St. Xavier, when it was finally abandoned by the Mexicans, and the ruins were quietly taken possession of by the French. The accounts in regard to affairs at Puebla vary and contradict each other, victory being claimed by both the Mexicans and the French. They are mainly repetitions of the accounts which have already reached us.

abstract: We are informed upon trustworthy authority, that a prospectus has just been issued of an English joint-stock company, with a proposed capital of several hundred thousand pounds, for conveying cargoes of "assorted goods" from England to "a well-known port in Mexico," payment for the goods to be made in Confederate cotton.
lead_paragraph: We are informed upon trustworthy authority, that a prospectus has just been issued of an English joint-stock company, with a proposed capital of several hundred thousand pounds, for conveying cargoes of "assorted goods" from England to "a well-known port in Mexico," payment for the goods to be made in Confederate cotton. This well-known Mexican port is no doubt Matamoras, and the object of the proposed company is the evasion of the Southern blockade, by furnishing goods to the South via Mexico. We are not prepared to say that the company or its objects are illegal, or that so long at least as the vessels which it charters do not carry contraband of war, those vessels would be subject to seizure by Northern cruisers; but can any one in his senses doubt that such a traffic would be in the highest degree offensive to the States, or that it would not tend to embroil us with the Government of Washington? It may keep within the letter of the law, but it will not the less be regarded as another blow struck by Englishmen at the North, and as another proof of our complicity with the South. We indeed fully acquit its originators of any Southern proclivities. They probably care nothing at all for the interests of the Confederate States, and are simply bent upon turning a penny to the very best advantage. They only send their "asserted cargoes" to Matamoras rather than to New-York, because the former seems the better speculalation. But, although they act from purely selfish motives, credit will be given to them at Washington for sympathy with the South, and they will be regarded there as representatives of English feeling.

abstract: We have abandoned the lower crossing, not because compelled to do so, but in accordance with the general plan. On doing so, a few moments since, a rebel straggler came down to take a look at the bridge, but was kept back at a respectful distance by show of our artillery.
lead_paragraph: We have abandoned the lower crossing, not because compelled to do so, but in accordance with the general plan. On doing so, a few moments since, a rebel straggler came down to take a look at the bridge, but was kept back at a respectful distance by show of our artillery. While some pickets of the Flying Division were engaged in ball playing this morning, in front of the ruins of the Bernard House, the rebels commenced throwing shells at them, but did no damage. As I write, skirmishing has commenced between our pickets on the right, the men firing rapidly.

abstract: The steamship Etna, from Liverpool on the 22d ult., and Queenstown on the 23d, arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices are four days later. The excitement in England regarding the interference of American cruisers with the Matamoras trade, and the permit granted to a steamer by Minister ADAMS, continued. In the House of Commons, information had been asked regarding Mr. ADAMS' course. Mr. LAYARD said the question was under advisement, but no communication had been made to Mr. ADAMS. Mr. ROEBUCK wished information regarding the proceedings of Admiral WILKES, and the course the Government intended to pursue; but Lord PALMERSTON did not choose to give it immediately. It is stated in reference to the rebel gunboat Alexandra, that her owners and builders would probably in a few days be summoned before the local magistrates on the charge of designing to infringe the Foreign Enlistment act. From Paris, we have a report that the French Emperor has become offended at the course of the National Government and Admiral WILKES, and intends to recall Count MERCIER. This report, however, is considered of a dubious character. There is no definite intelligence regarding the Polish revolution. In the Liverpool Cotton Market, prices were unchanged. Breadstuffs were steady, and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 92 7/8@93 for money.

abstract: The brig Leonidas, Capt. SKIFF, (whaler,) from St. Domingo, March 28, has just arrived. Capt. SKIFF reports that he was chased into St. Domingo by the rebel pirate Retribution, which waited off the port three days for the Leonidas to come out. On the fourth day the United States steamer Alabama came down and captured the Retribution, and when last seen had her in tow.

abstract: -- The rebel Governor of Louisiana, MOORE, exercises sway now over rather a diminutive fraction of his State; and he has been put to as many shifts to retain a foothold as was poor CLAIB. JACKSON in Missouri. Shortly after our forces took New-Orleans, MOORE fled from his capital, Baton Rouge, and steamed away to find a place to set up his tent. He pitched it for a short time at Opelousas, in the Teehe country; but our troops soon began to operate in that region, and he shifted his quarters to Alexandria, on the Red River. Both these places are now in our hands; but we have not heard where MOORE has fled since the capture of Alexandria. He must, of course, have pushed up the Red River, as all of Louisiana east and south of Alexandria is completely in our control. He is thus crowded to the furthest edge of the State he pretends to govern, and it would not be surprising if he had fled over the line into Texas. It was to Texas that JACKSON escaped from Missouri, and there he died. It's a nice region for the head rebels to flee to. But unfortunately none of them on this side of the Mississippi can now get there.

abstract: The Vanderbill, having on board Admiral WILKES, was at Santiago de Cuba on the 24th; it was to leave the next morning. The customary salute was fired and responded to from the Castle. Admiral WILKES landed to see the Governor.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA, Wednesday, April 29, 1863.

abstract: The Rebel Loss of
lead_paragraph: Among the many appeals to the Southern people from their leaders, on the question of food, there has been none more earnest than one issued by the Governor of Alabama. It is not, however, his earnest request to the planters to devote every acre to the production of food which so much attracted our attention, as the reason which he gives for the danger which he would avert, viz., that "the enemy has called to his aid the terrible appliances of want and starvation, and is carrying out this savage and inhuman policy by the wholesale larceny of slaves, the seizure of provisions, and even the destruction of agricultural implements."

abstract: -- It seems that while our troops on the Rappahannock were getting into position on Thursday last, for the battle that occurred on the three ensuing days, our army on the Mississippi had begun operations against Vicksburgh. Gen. SHERMAN, it appears, passed up the Yazoo, with gunboats and transports, on Thursday morning, and in the afternoon of the same day he was joined by some land forces; and soon the sound of musketry and artillery was heard, which continued till long after nightfall. We have no doubt this movement of Gen. SHERMAN is a feint, somewhat analogous to that which HOOKER made the same day below Fredericksburgh -- with a reverse position, however, as to the point of attack. The main attack on Vicksburgh is undoubtedly to be from below; and we this morning publish the fact that the main body of GRANT's army landed last week on the eastern bank of the Mississippi River, eight miles above Grand Gulf, which is some fifty miles below Vicksburgh, and that some preliminary operations had there also opened.

abstract: The correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette says that VALLANDIGHAM made a speech in Columbus, Ohio, on Fast day, from the steps of the Capitol, to a yard full of Copperheads. The correspondent says he was as bitter and seditious in his utterances as he dared to be, with "General Order No. 38" staring him in the face. The long and loud tooting of brass instruments succeeded in drawing together a crowddevoid of enthusiasm, numbering hundreds -- though the Statesman and Crisis will probably have it thousands -- and the greater portion of which had been attracted there from mere curiosity to see a man whose notoriety is much greater than he deserves. The speech was a very poor one for VALANDIGHAM to make. It was void of point or pith, incoherent , and, taking it altogether, it strongly reminded one of the maniac ravings of GEORGE FRANCES TRAIN. He denounced "General Order No. 38," declaring that for one he would not obey it. Whether he was sincere in his declaration, or not, perhaps future events will develop, but he certainly did not possess the "backbone" to make it good last evening. He pronounced the proceedings of the late Military Commission in Cincinnati, in condemning to death certain rebel spies found in our midst, as unconstitutional: but he did not say that the hanging by the minions of JEFF. DAVIS of certain Ohio soldiers, sent by Gen. MITCHEL to destroy rebel communications, &c., was unconstitutional.

abstract: THE BROOKLYN ACADEMY Mr. BANDMAN gave his much extolled representation of Shylock to a very large audience last night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The interest created by his appearance in this City last season, added to the fact that ...
lead_paragraph: THE BROOKLYN ACADEMY -- Mr. BANDMAN gave his much extolled representation of Shylock to a very large audience last night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The interest created by his appearance in this City last season, added to the fact that Mr. DAVIDGE was to make his debut in the City of his residence, was sufficient to crowd the house, and had not the night been unpropitious, there would, undoubtedly, have been one of the finest gatherings on the season. As it was, nothing was left out that was desirable. Mr. BANDMAN's reading and fidelity to the text, pleased the many Shakespearean scholars who assembled to witness his performance, and to the [???] polloi a first-class attraction was presented.

abstract: The friends of the Fifth New-York Volunteer regiment (Duryee Zouaves) are making arrangements to extend a suitable reception to that body of troops on their return from the war to this City, which event will take place this week. A meeting was held at the Seventh regiment Armory, Monday evening, over which Gen. DURYEE presided, and who also made a few remarks complimentary to the Fifth regiment, with which he was at one time connected as Colonel. A committee consisting of Lieut.-Col. DURYEE, Capt. MCCONNELL, Lieut. CREIGHTON, and Sergt. THAYER was appointed to confer with the National Committee of the Common Council with reference to completing the arrangements for the reception. It is understood that the Tenth N.Y.V., and the Thirty-seventh N.Y.S.M. regiments, will parade on the occasion.

abstract: Copperheadism Here and the War Spirit Abroad
snippet: Copperheadism Here and the War Spirit Abroad
lead_paragraph: The two salient points in the last intelligence from England were, a revival of the agitation for war and an intense interest in the result of the Connecticut election. This is no chance coincidence. Each has a bearing upon the other. They are, in fact, but different aspects of the same condition of the British mind, and every American should understand it.

abstract: Mr. EDWARD JORDAN, Solicitor of the Treasury, commenced an investigation at the Custom-house, on Monday, into the alleged frauds connected with the sale and disposition of prize property in this City.
lead_paragraph: Mr. EDWARD JORDAN, Solicitor of the Treasury, commenced an investigation at the Custom-house, on Monday, into the alleged frauds connected with the sale and disposition of prize property in this City. This investigation has been brought about through representations made at Washington by prominent gentlemen of this City, among whom are MOSES H. GRINNELL, Capt. MARSHALL, Capt. NYE, ROBERT MINTTURN and others. The parties alleged to have been implicated in the frauds, if any have been committed, are the Prize Commissioners, the United States Marshal, and others. It is reported that the charges have been preferred since the removal of SIMEON DRAPER as auctioneer of prize property. Mr. JORDAN, who has been deputed by the Government to investigate the facts, commenced his sittings in the Customhouse at 12 o'clock yesterday. Reporters for most of the City papers were in attendance, and, before commencing the investigation, Mr. JORDAN stated that he deemed it advisable for the promotion of the ends of justice, and to prevent ex parte or one-slded statements from going before the public, to conduct the investigation in private, and he should therefore be compelled to exclude all reporters of the Press. The Government had employed a phonographic reporter to record everything that occurred, and, at the conclusion of the investigation, It would be submitted to the Department with which he was connected, accompanied by a full report by himself of the conclusions arrived at -- all of which would then be published. Until then, justice to all concerned required that the testimony should not be made public.
headline: {'main': 'THE ALLEGED FRAUDS IN PRIZE SALES.; An Investigation Commenced by the Solicitor of the Treasury REPORTERS NOT ADMITTED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE ALLEGED FRAUDS IN PRIZE SALES.; An Investigation Commenced by the Solicitor of the Treasury REPORTERS NOT ADMITTED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Commencing to-day, and continuing for the period of a week or ten days, most of the moral, religious and philanthropic organizations that radiate their influences from this City as in focal point, will commemorate, as usual, their anniversaries. Such of these enterprises as are of a purely benevolent character have found that the war augments and constantly enhances the demands made upon their resources; but it is, nevertheless, gratifying to know that, in the hot excitement of the times, our people have not been unmindful of the calls of charity, and have bestowed lavishly upon the needy of that material prosperity with which they have been providentially blessed. At the coming meetings, each Society will present the result of its last year's operations, and map out its plans for the future, while eloquent speakers will urge the claims of the several organizations upon the regard and sympathy of the public. Strangers are already tending hitherward in large numbers, and the anniversary exercises promise to be more than ordinarily well attended and interesting.
lead_paragraph: Commencing to-day, and continuing for the period of a week or ten days, most of the moral, religious and philanthropic organizations that radiate their influences from this City as in focal point, will commemorate, as usual, their anniversaries. abstract: As previously announced, the Ninth New-York Volunteer regiment (Hawkins' Zouaves) arrived in the Lower Bay Monday night, but, in consequence of a dense fog, the steamer Kennebec, which transported them thither, was unable to proceed up the stream till yesterday morning, and did not anchor opposite Pier No. 1, North River, till 8 A.M....
lead_paragraph: As previously announced, the Ninth New-York Volunteer regiment (Hawkins' Zouaves) arrived in the Lower Bay Monday night, but, in consequence of a dense fog, the steamer Kennebec, which transported them thither, was unable to proceed up the stream till yesterday morning, and did not anchor opposite Pier No. 1, North River, till 8 A.M Here the steamer was detained three hours, in order to facilitate the execution of the arrangement as agreed upon by the Twelfth New-York Militia regiment and the fire companies, who volunteered to escort the Zouaves through the City. At about 11 A.M., the steamer came up to Pier No. 1, and, having been made fast, the troops immediately commenced to disembark. A short time previous the Twelfth regiment had marched down Broadway, and, when the Zouaves left the vessel, were drawn up in open order on the pier. From an early hour in the morning till the time the troops had fairly reached terra firma, not only Pier No. 1, but the adjacent piers, also the streets in the immediate vicinity and the entire space usually occupied by the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company for freighting purposes, were crowded with the relatives, friends and acquaintances of the Zouaves. At intervals the rain would pour down in torrents, but that event did not have the effect to disperse the crowd who evinced remarkable persistency under such trying circumstances. It must not be inferred that the assemblage consisted wholly of males, as the gentler sex was largely represented. Indeed, at one time the gentlemanly police officer who carefully guarded the entrance to the pier was almost thrown upon his back by the immense tide of fair and unfair damsels who pressed against the gate in such a confused mass that it was almost impossible to prevent some from being injured. Fortunately, however, tnrough the exertions of the aforesaid officer and one or two coadjutors, the anxious party were admitted safely within the iron railing. To appreciate fully the greetings extended to the Zouaves, and by them in turn reciprocated, it was necessary to be a spectator of the scene. As the brave fellows one by one stepped off the plank to the pier he was recognized by some one in the crowd, who caught him by the hand, congratulated and embraced him. The preparations for the ma ch up Broadway were not completed till about 11 1/2 o'clock. It was expected that a portion of the Fire Department would be in waiting on the cross-streets to fall into line as the column moved forward, but the heavy fall of rain caused them to abandon their design. The Twelfth New-York Militia regiment, preceded by a band, took the lead of the column, and was followed by thirty members of the Hawkins Zouaves who have been staying in the City for the past two or three weeks on account of wounds or disability, which were in turn followed by the main body of the Zouave regiment, numbering 450 men. The regiment arrived here without arms the order countermanding the order requiring them to deliver up their arms to Government before leaving the Military Department, not having reached them before their departure from Suffolk. Through the kindness of the Eleventh New-York Militia regiment, however, the Zouaves were provided with guns, a quantity, corresponding in number to the returned soldiers, having been sent to the pier prior to the disembarkation. The Zouaves were commanded by Col. HAWKINS himself. In passing up Broadway much attention was directed to the tattered, soiled and blood-stained flag, which was conspicuous in their midst. To gaze upon that flag, and not call to mind the many terrible encounters through which the brave fellows that had flocked round it had passed -- aye, and in so passing, how many had looked upon that noble emblem for the last time? -- would not be natural, would not be possible. There is not a man in that regiment who has not been through battles hard-fought and hard-won, and it needs no better mark of appreciation of their services than the hearty welcome which greeted them on their arrival yesterday. After marching up Broadway to Union-square, the column turned down Fourth-avenue and proceeded to Bond-street, where it was dismissed. The Zouaves will be mustered out of service the latter part of this week. It will be remembered that the regiment was formerly commanded by Lieut. Col. KIMBALL, who met with such a lamentable fate not long since. By request of the regiment the body of Col. KIMBALL was deposited in a vault at Greenwood, there to remain until their arrival, when the burial service would be performed. The day appointed for that sad duty has not yet been announced, but the ceremony will probably take place some time next week. The following are the officers of the regiment:

abstract: Orders have been received at the Brooklyn Navy-yard to dispatch to sea at once the new steam frigate Ticonderoga. She was hauled in to the wharf yesterday, and will receive her officers and crew to-day. New valves have been attached to her machinery, and on their trial, which took place yesterday, they worked well. She will receive her sailing orders to-day.
lead_paragraph: Orders have been received at the Brooklyn Navy-yard to dispatch to sea at once the new steam frigate Ticonderoga. She was hauled in to the wharf yesterday, and will receive her officers and crew to-day. New valves have been attached to her machinery, and on their trial, which took place yesterday, they worked well. She will receive her sailing orders to-day.

abstract: The first anniversary of the above institution was held yesterday afternoon in the edifice corner of Fifty-first-street and Lexington-avenue. The attendance was large, The annual report shows that 1,284 sick and wounded soldiers had been received in the Hospital during the year, of which 283 are at present remaining. The Hospital was supported from May to August by voluntary contributions, but since the latter date it has been under the charge of the United States Government. Over $2,000 have been raised for the benefit of the patients. Yesterday remarks were made by Rev. J.P. NEWMAN, Rev. J.B. MERUM and Senator POMEROY. The Hutchinson family was present and sang a number of patriotic airs. The Hospital is conducted by Dr. ALEXANDER A. MOTT. In the evening there was a magic lantern entertainment for the benefit of the patients.

abstract: Our Special Correspondence this morning gives details of the important events at Fredericksburgh down to Monday morning. From the best knowledge in our possession, we think it unlikely there was any general engagement fought on Monday by Gen. HOOKER, although there was undoubtedly some heavy skirmishing.
lead_paragraph: Our Special Correspondence this morning gives details of the important events at Fredericksburgh down to Monday morning. From the best knowledge in our possession, we think it unlikely there was any general engagement fought on Monday by Gen. HOOKER, although there was undoubtedly some heavy skirmishing. A report from Washington states that the rebels made an attempt on Monday morning to retake the heights beyond Fredericksburgh, but that they were repulsed. Our correspondent with Gen. SEDGWICK's command gives a full account of the storming and capture of those heights on Sunday by our forces, together with a list of some of the casualties. Among the prisoners captured by our forces, is said to be the noted cavalry officer, FITZHUGH LEE, whose arrival in Washington is announced.

abstract: In consequence of the reported dashing operations of Gen. STONEMEN on the line of railroad to Richmond, Gen. LEE could not "ingloriously fly," but was compelled to "come out from behind his defences" and fight on HOOKER's "own ground," selected near Chancellorsville, about ten miles southwest of Frederickburgh. The battle lasted most of the day on Saturday, and continued with great fierceness until two o'clock on Sunday morning, when hostilities ceased for two hours.
lead_paragraph: In consequence of the reported dashing operations of Gen. STONEMEN on the line of railroad to Richmond, Gen. LEE could not "ingloriously fly," but was compelled to "come out from behind his defences" and fight on HOOKER's "own ground," selected near Chancellorsville, about ten miles southwest of Frederickburgh. The battle lasted most of the day on Saturday, and continued with great fierceness until two o'clock on Sunday morning, when hostilities ceased for two hours.

abstract: At 9 o'clock, yesterday morning, Gen. PECK sent a force of infantry, cavalry and artillery across the Nansemond River at Suffolk to make a reconnoissance. They advanced cautiously up the old Petersburgh turnpike, and when two miles out, encountered the enemy's rifle pits which were thoroughly manned.
lead_paragraph: SUFFOLK, Va., Monday, May 4.

abstract: The cargo of the prize brig Robert Bruce was sold at auction yesterday, at noon, by BURDETT, JONES & Co., under direction of ROBERT MURRAY, United States Marshal for the Southern District of New-York, at the Union Stores, near the Hamilton-avenue Ferry. It was an assorted cargo, consisting of drugs and medicines, hosiery, shirts, cloths, blankets, flannels, hardware, iron, cutlery, crockery, stoneware, corks, rum, porter, ale, &c. There was quite a large number of dealers present, and most of the goods brought good prices, especially the blankets, flannels, &c. The auctioneer stated in the commencement of the sale that the property would be sold without any guarantee by the Government as to the condition, quality or quantity, the purchaser assuming the entire risk; also, that no goods could be purchased by the Marshal, nor any one connected with his office, nor the auctioneer, or any one connected with him. The first sold were the drugs and medicines, all bringing full prices. The quinine, consisting of 460 ounces, brought $2 92 1/2 per ounce. A large quantity of hosiery was sold by the lot from $25 to $810 a case. The hardware was next sold. The pig led sold at 8 5/8 cts. per pound. Pig iron, $31 per ton. Hoop iron, 3 7/8 cts. per pound. The hardware brought from $300 to $800 a cask. The crockery brought good prices. The rum brought from $1 50 to $1 77 1/2 per gallon. The whole brought from $75,000 to $100,000.

abstract: At the opening of this Court on Monday mornieg, ASA CROSBY was placed on trial, charged with the murder of his wife by beating her with a chair, on the 8th of February last. The prisoner is a respectable looking man, about 40 years of age, and is said to be a relative of Prof. DIXI CROSBY of Dartmouth College. He formerly followed the sea for a livelihood, but at the time the act was committed with which he now stands charged, he was living in Monroe-street in this City, occupying two rooms on the second floor. On the evening of the homicide, the people living in the house heard the prisoner and his wife quarreling, and after the prisoner left the house his wife was found lying on the floor of her room with her head horribly beaten, and nearly insensible. She, however, lived, until the 13th of February, and before she died made an ante mortem statement, in which she stated that her injuries were received at the hands of her husband. The prisoner was arrested at a saloon, and when taken before a magistrate and asked what he had to say to the charge, replied, "Why should I wish to kill my wife?" The testimony for the prosecution showed that the prisoner and his wife have not lived peaceably together, but the proof of the murder rests entirely on circumstantial evidence and the declaration of the wife. The defence claim that the deceased was an intemperate woman; that she had been several times in the Penitentiary, and that her injuries were received at the hands of some other person thnn the prisoner. The prosecution offered to accept a plea of manslaughter in the second degree, but the prisoner refused to avail himself of it. The testimony for the prosecution closed yesterday, and the defence will open this morning. District-Attorney HALL conducts the case in person for the people, and the prisoner is defended by JNO. D. TOWNSEND and GUNNING S. BEDFORD, Esqs.

abstract: McEwan vs. Burgess et al. -- This motion was stated in the TIMES of the 27th April. An order was issued for the examination of the judgment debtor in proceedings supplementary to execution. On the return day motion was made to discharge the order, on the ground that the Court had no jurisdiction, the judgment debtor being a resident of Brooklyn, where he had a peace of business. The motion was opposed on the ground that the defendant had a place of business also at No. 56 Broadway, and where the order was served upon him. In reply it was urged that the place of business at No. 56 Broadway was a Government position or office, and that such position did nat make it a "place of business" of the defendant, within the meaning of the act giving jurisdiction in such cases. It was a place of business of a Government department and not of the defendant. It was, however, shown that the defendant, who was a manufacturer of chemicals for photographs, took orders and conducted his correspondence at No. 56 Broadway, although he had his principal place of business in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: McEwan vs. Burgess et al. -- This motion was stated in the TIMES of the 27th April. abstract: mence to-day the printing of the TIMES upon paper manufactured expressly for our use in Belgium, and imported for us through Mr. F. DUYSTERS, who is the largest importer ...
lead_paragraph: mence to-day the printing of the TIMES upon paper manufactured expressly for our use in Belgium, and imported for us through Mr. F. DUYSTERS, who is the largest importer of foreign paper in this City. One vessel, containing a consignment of this part to us, has already arrived, and several others are on the way. We have paid to the Government the sum of $4,500 for duties on the paper already received, under, the amended tariff act of last session. This is a larger amount, we believe, than has ever before been received from all the publishers in the country for duties upon imported paper used for newspaper purposes. It will be more than quadrupled within the next few weeks.

abstract: Against forts and- earthworks the Ironsides have not obtained any signal or unqualified advantage, and the repulse of the attack on Charleston repeats the failure of the gunboats on the Mississippi. The Federal commanders, it is stated, "show no disposition to renew the conflict," and certainly the result of the first attempt is not encouraging; but it is by no means certain the Federals will not try again. As in the case of Richmond, the attempt may probably be repeated, unless the Federal officers have found the defences so strong as to make success impossible. As long as this "seven Monitors" can be kept "all quiet within the bar," but outside the harbor, the whole purpose of the expedition is defeated.

abstract: We have intelligence this morning from the Army of the Potomac to the morning of Tuesday, though not so definite as we could wish.
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence this morning from the Army of the Potomac to the morning of Tuesday, though not so definite as we could wish. The only fighting which took place with the main portion of our forces under Gen. HOOKER at Chancellorsville on Monday was late in the afternoon. Gen. HOOKER then sent out one division of the Fifth Corps to feel the enemy's lines toward Fredericksburgh. A brisk action ensued, resulting in driving back the rebel lines, when our troops returned to their intrenchments. We have reason to believe that a battle of much greater magnitude was fought on Tuesday, of the results of which we are yet uninformed, though it was probably undecisive. On the left, at Fredericksburgh, there was considerable fighting of a desperate character on Sunday and Monday. The accounts of this fighting and its results are very much confused, and we are unable to say exactly what has been done, either by the rebels or ourselves. It appears that a portion, at least, of the fortifications on the heights captured by us on Sunday, were recaptured by a rebel force coining up from below, and one account has it that they were all retaken by the rebels, and that Gen. SEDGWICK had withdrawn his troops to the north side of the Rappahannock, and hastened up the river to join Gen. HOOKER. We also have the statement that Gen. HOOKER has been reinforced by 30,000 men from Washington, under Gen. HEINTZELMAN. Nothing definite has yet been heard from Gen. STONEMAN, but it is believed that he has accomplished the work assigned to him.

abstract: In accordance with orders just issued by Col. CHARLES ROOME, this regiment will assemble for instruction at the State Arsenal, corner of Thirty-fifth street and Seventh-avenue, this evening, at 8 o'clock. After the drill a parade will be made with Dodworth's Band and the drum corps of the Thirty-seventh. The parades of this regiment have always, unfortunately, been made at a few hours' notice, and, therefore, were not as strong a turn-out as the regiment is capable of making. The parade this evening will be undoubtedly a fine one, and well worth the attention of the friends of the National Guard.

abstract: Wounded Heroes of Our A???
lead_paragraph: Great and momentous as the crisis is to which Gen. HOOKER'S timely audacity has brought us within the last few days, and eager as we may be to learn the result of the tremendous game which he is now playing on the Rappahannock, the country must not forget that the last week has added several thousands to the long roll of the sick and wounded and maimed. We say nothing of the dead, for they reck little now of our remembering or forgetting. Whenever we recall these, it will be for our consolation and encouragement, and not for theirs. But those who were struck down in the fight, and are still alive and suffering, may be greatly comforted and much supported by the thoughtful charity and kindness of the millions at home whose honor and interests they have so well defended. No one can have read the story of the three bloody days through which our army has just passed without feeling proud, not simply of his country, but of his kind. To stand as fast as they have done, and fall as bravely, after two years of disaster and disappointment, does honor not simply to the United States, but to human nature; and happily our admiring their courage and constancy does not depend in the least on our opinion about the lawfulness or unlawfulness, expediency or inexpediency of the war. Nor does it depend even upon the value we may attach to the preservation of the Union. We therefore have no hesitation in challenging for our heroic army the admiration of men of every land in which bravery and fortitude are still virtues, and in which dying for one's ideas is still held to be a noble thing. Any cause which could by possibility be just, would have been ennobled by being maintained and defended as our cause was at Chancellorsville last Saturday and Sunday. It is a matter of no small moment for us and our posterity, that there should be in our history some of those great days, the memory of which is a more valuable inheritance to a nation than either riches, or territory, or power -- days that our children's children may read of with dimmed eyes, not because they were crowned with triumph, but because they were fought out manfully to the last. America is frequently reproached with its want of great traditions, but we must not forget that it is better still to furnish posterity with the material for them than to have inherited them from our ancestors. They are a precious legacy to leave, for they are the nurse and the support of all that is noblest and strongest in National life. Let us, therefore, be doubly grateful to the brave men who adorn our history in the tangled Virginian woods, with episodes, which will hereafter be held worthy of our destiny, even should it prove tenfold more brilliant than our wildest dreams have ever pictured it. And we must never forget that the greatest glory lies, after all, not so much in winning as in deserving to win. It is well to be proud of triumphs, but it is a far nobler thing to be able to be proud of defeats. "Ce n'est pas la victoire qui fait la joie des nobles coeurs; c'est le combat."

abstract: AURORA FLOYD IN BROOKLYN. -- Last night, at the Brooklyn Academy, Mr. GAYLER's dramatization of Miss BRADDON's "Aurora Floyd" was given by Miss HERON and a very fine company. The inclemency of the weather kept away the paying throngs who generally greet Miss HERON in Brooklyn, but an audience large for the night made up in appreciative enthusiasm what it lacked in numerical array. On Friday night the same company, which, by the way, includes Miss HERON, Mr. CHAS. WHEATLEIGH, Mr. JAMIESON, Mr. BECKS, Mrs. HIND, and other favorite actors, will appear in the same play, and doubtless an immense house will testify its appreciation of the work and the actress on that occasion.

abstract: The steamer Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $205,057 in treasure, and later news from the Isthmus of Panama and Central and South America. It was believed that the Convention of the United States of Colombia would vote to remove the capital from Bogota to Panama, the "project" for that purpose having passed a second reading by an almost unanimous vote.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $205,057 in treasure, and later news from the Isthmus of Panama and Central and South America. It was believed that the Convention of the United States of Colombia would vote to remove the capital from Bogota to Panama, the "project" for that purpose having passed a second reading by an almost unanimous vote. Among the items of news from South America is the announcement of the death of President SAN ROMAN, of Peru. Some excitement existed in Chili in consequence of a report that the British representative in Valparaiso had been instructed to take vigorous measures to enforce the payment of a claim considered by the Chilians as unjust. From Guatemala we have a report that President CARRERA was making preparations for another invasion of Salvador.

abstract: Various statements and rumors reached town yesterday and last night that the general engagement which raged through Sunday between the main Union and rebel armies near Chancellorsville had, after the pause of Monday, been removed on Tuesday morning, and was continued throughout the greater part of the day. It seems to be more than probable that this was the case; but the same difficulty has prevailed in regard to getting news of that day's engagement that has existed in regard to the previous days; and we have received nothing definite as to the character or results of the day's operations.
lead_paragraph: Various statements and rumors reached town yesterday and last night that the general engagement which raged through Sunday between the main Union and rebel armies near Chancellorsville had, after the pause of Monday, been removed on Tuesday morning, and was continued throughout the greater part of the day. It seems to be more than probable that this was the case; but the same difficulty has prevailed in regard to getting news of that day's engagement that has existed in regard to the previous days; and we have received nothing definite as to the character or results of the day's operations.

abstract: Answering a call through the newspapers for a mass meeting of the musicians of this City and vicinity, about one hundred and fifty gentlemen of the profession met yesterday afternoon in Metropolitan Hall, Hester-street, by far the larger number of them being of German birth. Mr. FRANCIS H. DILLER called the meeting to order, and explained its object to be the formation of a Society of Musicians, protective in its character, and aiming to advance the social and pecuniary interests of its members. Addresses were made by Messrs. HUGO VON BARTELS, GEO. GROSCURTH, SCHREIMSER and others, of which the burden was that the increased cost of living required an advance in the rate of compensation, and this desideratum could only be attained through the unanimity of action. The remarks drew out a fair show of enthusiasm, and upon motion a roll of membership was opened, and permanent officers of the Society chosen, as follows: President, Hugo Von Bartels; Vice-Presidents, H. Schmitz, E. Boehm; Treasurer, H. Stoebe; Financial Secretary, Geo. Groscurth; Corresponding Secretary, David Schaad. An Executive Committee of eleven was selected to draft by-laws and select a Lame for the Association, and, at their pleasure, a future meeting will be held. The audience was of a very respectable character, and included musicians of every class.

abstract: The latest news from Guatemala informs us of the intended departure of President CARRERA for the frontier, with 2,000 men, on the 10th or 11th instant. It is said he will be joined by 2,000 more, when he will again invade Salvador.

abstract: Our latest advices from the battlefields on the south side of the Rappahannock are up to last night.  Correspondents who were at Chancellorsville last night, state that Gen. HOOKER has captured over eight thousand prisoners, and a large number of guns and rebel standards. Among the guns captured are ten belonging to the famous Washington Battery, of Louisiana.

abstract: In the Matter of Thomas Fairbairn. -- It will be remembered that at the opening of the General Term on the first Monday in May, Mr. Thomas Fairbairn, a native of Canada, petitioned the Court to be allowed to be examined as a candidate for admission to our Bar. It appears that Mr. Fairbairn is a regular practitioner in the Canadian Courts. The Court, however, has denied the application, on the ground that not being a citizen of the United States he is ineligible.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Thomas Fairbairn. -- It will be remembered that at the opening of the General Term on the first Monday in May, Mr. Thomas Fairbairn, a native of Canada, petitioned the Court to be allowed to be examined as a candidate for admission to our Bar. It appears that Mr. Fairbairn is a regular practitioner in the Canadian Courts. The Court, however, has denied the application, on the ground that not being a citizen of the United States he is ineligible.

abstract: The telegraph last night was altogether dumb in regard to military movements on the Rappahannock; and the few items of news that reached us by mail and otherwise during the day and evening did not bring us down beyond Monday.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph last night was altogether dumb in regard to military movements on the Rappahannock; and the few items of news that reached us by mail and otherwise during the day and evening did not bring us down beyond Monday. The extensive operations of Sunday were not renewed on Monday, and there was, on that day, no general battle between the armies. In the afternoon one division had a fight for half an hour with a rebel column, but beyond that nothing was done by HOOKER or LEE, except to prepare with all their might for the renewal of the action, which each knew could not be postponed.

abstract: This gallant officer, whose death took place on the 23d by typhoid fever at Washington, was buried on Tuesday in Greenwood the funeral services having been performed at St. Thomas' Church. Col. NAZER was a native of Suffolk, in England, and served for some years as an officer in the British army, having been Adjutant of the Ninetieth light infantry, one of the crack corps in that service, and was highly esteemed by his superior officers, both as a gentleman and soldier. On retiring from the British army he accepted the position of Treasurer of the Winter Garden Theatre, in which capacity he acquired in this City many friends by his obliging disposition and courteous manners. With the breaking out of the war the love for his old profession returned, and he accepted the position of Lieutenant-Colonel of the New-York Mounted Rifles, a regiment raised chiefly through the exertions and liberality of Mr. LOUIS LAFARGE. The same qualities which won for him respect and esteem in the British, he carried into the American service. He was equally beloved by both officers and men, and his early military training, combined with undaunted courage and great self-possession, combined to render him one of the best and most efficient officers in the service. He has been most honorably mentioned in several reports, and his death greatly lamented by his division and by all with whom he came in contact.
lead_paragraph: This gallant officer, whose death took place on the 23d by typhoid fever at Washington, was buried on Tuesday in Greenwood the funeral services having been performed at St. Thomas' Church. abstract: The remoteness of Gen. BANKS' department and infrequency of communications with him render it difficult to keep the public supplied with accurate and connected details of his operations, or to accompany the accounts we do ...
lead_paragraph: The remoteness of Gen. BANKS' department and infrequency of communications with him render it difficult to keep the public supplied with accurate and connected details of his operations, or to accompany the accounts we do publish with the requisite explanations of his plans and purposes. His late campaign from Berwick's Bay to the Red River was, in many respects, a complete surprise to the country.

abstract: The first anniversary of the above institution was held last evening, at the church corner of Second-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The exercises were conducted by Rev. Dr. ASA D. SMITH, who also made a few remarks explaining the object of the institution. The children -- fifty in number -- who are thus provided for, were seated on elevated platforms each side of the pulpit, and presented a very attractive appearance. A number of little boys attired in the Zouave costume looked particularly interesting. The "Hutchinsons" were present, and at intervals sung with their usual good effect a number of national and pathetic airs. Master DUDLEY WALKER evidently made his mark -- judging from the applause he received -- in his recitation of "The Charge of the Light Brigade," "Fair Bingen on the Rhine," and other pieces. The reports of the Secretary and Treasurer were read, from which it was shown that the amount of funds received from various sources was $3,363 16, and an equal amount expended. The Institution has received the favor of many of our most popular and influential citizens, and it only remains for a sufficient sum to be raised to place it on a permanent basis. During the evening addresses were made by Rev. J.T. DURYEA, Rev. PETER STRYKER, THEODORE TILTON and others.

abstract: By the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Australasian, we have advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 20th ult.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Australasian, we have advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 20th ult. We receive by this arrival reports of important debates which have taken place in the British Parliament on American affairs. The Marquis of Clanricarde, in the House of Lords, called up the subject of the seizure of British merchant steamers while in the Matamoras trade, and inveighed against the proceedings of Admiral WILKES. In the course of his remarks he also alluded to the fact that Minister ADAMS had granted a permit to a steamer carrying arms and munitions to the Mexicans, and characterized it as a most unwarrantable act. After remarks by other members, Earl GRANVILLE, on behalf of the Government, deprecated angry discussion on imperfect information, and the subject was dropped. In the House of Commons, Mr. ROEBUCK led off the debate on the same topics, and delivered himself of a strong philippic against the Northern dis-United States. Lord PALMERSTON gave assurances that the Government was giving due consideration to the matters discussed. The debate was continued in the House of Lords next day, when the Earl of Derby denounced the proceedings of the American Government as monstrous. The case of the Alexandra was also under discussion, and it was stated positively, on behalf of her builders, that she was not designed for the rebels. These debates are commented upon very freely by the London journals. The news of the attack of our iron-clad fleet upon Fort Sumter had reached England, but had attracted very little attention. The Polish Revolution appears to be assuming still more formidable proportions. We have reports that the Russians had been defeated in several engagements, and that the Russian commander has called for heavy reinforcements. The Liverpool Cotton market is reported dull, with unchanged prices. Breadstuffs were active and firm, and Provisions steady. Consols had declined.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR signs or vetoes the Broadway Railroad bill, there is one thing that demands the immediate attention of the City authorities,--we mean the removal of the obstructions put in Broadway by the respective claimants to this franchise.
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR signs or vetoes the Broadway Railroad bill, there is one thing that demands the immediate attention of the City authorities, -- we mean the removal of the obstructions put in Broadway by the respective claimants to this franchise. As soon as the ordinance of the Common Council, giving the grant to the Harlem Railroad Company, was signed by the Mayor, the grantees instantly went to work to make practical use of the franchise thus conferred. They tore up Broadway in several places, and the damage then inflicted on the street still remains. The expectant beneficiaries under the Albany charter, fearing they might lose some portion of their anticipated claim, went to work in the same style, and began to lay down their track in advance of receiving the slightest shadow of authority from any quarter to do so.

abstract: Campaign; The
lead_paragraph: We have not yet fully stated the advantages secured by Gen. BANKS in his late splendid campaign through Western Louisiana. The first and most important result, to be sure, was the defeat, dispersion and demoralization of fully 20,000 armed rebels, who had got together in the western part of the State, and were building gunboats on the bayous and organizing with a view to a descent upon New-Orleans. The result next in importance is the occupation of the banks of the Red River in force, thus thoroughly checking the shipment of supplies from Louisiana and Texas to the rebel armies east of the Mississippi.

abstract: -- A small knot of Mozart Hall Copperheads held a peace meeting last night on the heels of the news of Gen. HOOKER's return to the north side of the Rappahannock. They, of course, reiterated their opposition to this "bloody, relentless, unnecessary and fruitless war," -- their opposition to the Government, and their opposition to the recently proclaimed policy of the Democratic party. They were strictly an opposition party, and represented nobody but themselves.

abstract: The Arrest of
lead_paragraph: It has not yet transpired whether the arrest of VALLANDIGHAM was made by the express direction of the authorities at Washington, or whether Gen. BURNSIDE, in military command of the department, did it at his own instance. Nor is the precise character of his offence yet stated -- whether it was in violation of that section of the Conscription bill which makes penal all counseling calculated to thwart or embarrass that measure, or whether it was in contravention of the stringent "General Order No. 38." Whoever the author or whatever the specific cause of the arrest, we rejoice that a leading man was the subject of it, and not a weak and obscure one, as has too often happened. The true policy of the Government is to strike first at the fomenters of sedition, and not at their miserable dupes.

abstract: Raid Toward Richmond
lead_paragraph: -- We publish this morning some exceedingly interesting accounts of the sweeping gallopade of Gen. STONEMAN's cavalry, which we find in the Richmond papers of Tuesday, and the Washington papers of Wednesday. That part of the force under the immediate command of STONEMAN himself, which went down in the direction of the rebel capital, and cut the communications on the Richmond and Fredericksburgh Railroad, is reported by telegraph to have arrived at White House, on the York River. It seems to have performed its work admirably, though, we are sorry to say, not as rapidly as Gen. HOOKER had hoped. The whole of the rebel army that has lain since December between Richmond and Fredericksburgh appears to have got up to Chancellorsville before Gen. STONEMAN's arrival, as a detachment of his force rode up within five miles of Richmond, and some of the men even within two miles. The raid created a great panic in Richmond, and it is evident from our extracts that hardly a regiment had been left in the rebel Capital itself for defence, as the Home Guard were called out to protect the city. It would certainly have been a beautiful manoeuvre, if after STONEMAN had destroyed the communications between the rebel army and the rebel Capital, our troops now scattered on the Peninsula, at Suffolk, at Norfolk, and on the North Carolina coast, had been so concentrated that they could have marched in the direction of Petersburgh and Richmond, and, accompanied by a Monitor or two on the James, have captured and held the city of JEFF. DAVIS.

abstract: The British at our last advices were suffering under another spasm of indignation against the United States. Their newspapers were more than commonly abusive, and two ...
lead_paragraph: The British at our last advices were suffering under another spasm of indignation against the United States. Their newspapers were more than commonly abusive, and two or three of their sensation orators in Parliament were a trifle more insolent and vituperative than usual. Beyond this we detect no symptom to distinguish this from the attacks to which our apoplectic old relative is of late periodically subject.

abstract: Official information received last evening at the  War Department authorizes us to state that Gen. HOOKER, after waiting in vain near Chancellorsville,...
lead_paragraph: Official information received last evening at the War Department authorizes us to state that Gen. HOOKER, after waiting in vain near Chancellorsville on Tuesday last, for a renewal of the battle by the enemy, recrossed the Rappahannock on the evening of that day, influenced by prudential motives, springing, doubtless, in part, from the great and sudden rise of the Virginia rivers, in consequence of the recent heavy rains.

abstract: London Letter, April 25
lead_paragraph: -- The British newspapers, and some of the more blatant Secessionists in Parliament, are making a great fuss over a certificate of character given by our Minister in London to a British vessel sailing for Matamoras. We have already expressed our opinion of the absurdity of the complaints made in England on this subject. Mr. ADAMS certainly committed no offence against the British Government by giving such a certificate. If anybody was at fault in the matter, so far as British dignity is concerned, it was the British merchants who went to a foreign Minister for such protection, instead of relying on their own Government.

abstract: DURYEE'S Zouaves the famous Fifth regiment of New-York Volunteers will to-day be honored by a triumphal reception on their return home from the war, which they have sacrificed so much to sustain.
lead_paragraph: DURYEE's Zouaves -- the famous Fifth regiment of New-York Volunteers -- will to-day be honored by a triumphal reception on their return home from the war, which they have sacrificed so much to sustain. They went from here more than 1,000 strong; less than 300 come back. The rest have laid down their lives in the service of their country, or have been incapacitated by disease and wounds from continuing in active duty. Three hundred and fifty were killed or badly hurt at the second battle of Manassas, and nearly as many were lost during the fearful six days' fight on the Peninsula.

abstract: Mozart General Committee Peace Resolutions of
snippet: Mozart General Committee Peace Resolutions of
lead_paragraph: The Mozart General Committee held a regular meeting last night, the President, B.P. FAIRCHILD in the Chair, and IGNATIUS FLYNN, Secretary. Among the members present were Fernando and Ben. Wood, Hon. James Brooks, Peter Fulmer and James M. Smith. The name of Hon. A. OAKEY HALL was called among the list of delegates. After the transaction of routine business, Mr. JOHN S. BETTS offered a series of resolutions for the consideration of the Committee.

abstract: The rumors which reached us on Wednesday and Wednesday night, regarding the movements of the Army of the Potomac, involving battles, disasters and retreat, yesterday resolved themselves into positive and authentic reports that Gen. HOOKER had withdrawn his army to the north side of the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: The rumors which reached us on Wednesday and Wednesday night, regarding the movements of the Army of the Potomac, involving battles, disasters and retreat, yesterday resolved themselves into positive and authentic reports that Gen. HOOKER had withdrawn his army to the north side of the Rappahannock. It does not appear that any battle was fought on Tuesday, the only fighting of consequence since Sunday having been on Monday evening, when only a single division of the Fifth corps was engaged. The withdrawal of the army from the south side was commenced on Tuesday night, and was successfully accomplished on Wednesday morning, with comparatively small loss. The movement may be regarded as wholly a providential one, influenced in great part doubtless by the sudden and great rise in the rivers caused by the storm, which raged even more furiously in Northern Virginia than in New-York. It may be considered doubtful, however, whether it would have been made, had Gen. HOOKER been apprised of the entire success of Gen. STONEMAN in cutting the rebel communications. This success is learned from the Richmond papers of the 5th. Gen. STONEMAN, it appears, divided his force into three columns, each one of which comp[???]ed the week assigned to it. One column was commanded by Gen. STONEMAN in person. This force effectually destroyed the Richmond and Fredericksburgh Railroad at Hanover Junction and town to within five miles of Richmond. Another column was commanded by Gen. AVERILL. This proceeded through C[???]pepper, and, after skirmishing with the enemy's cavalry, compel the destruction of the bridge over the Rapidan River. The third column was commanded by Gen. BUFORD. This pushed on directly toward Gordonsville, and information has reached Washington that it succeeded in cutting the Railroad between Gordonsville and Richmond, and also between Gordonsville and Charlottesville, thus entirely breaking up LEE's communications, and very effectually cutting off supplies and reinforcements. In addition to these important operations, we have the statements that Gen. PECK is pushing rapidly forward from Suffolk in pursuit of the rebels retreating from the line of the Blackwater, and that Gen. KEYES is also moving his corps from Yorktown to cooperate with Gen. HOOKER. Our losses in the Spring campaign thus far have been very heavy, but those of the rebels have been much more severe -- necessarily so, from the fact that they have attacked our forces in intrenched positions.

abstract: Discomfiture of Gen. Hooker
lead_paragraph: The retrograde movement of Gen. HOOKER to this side of the Rappahannock has been to the people one of the very sharpest of their many disappointments. They had counted with peculiar confidence on a triumphant issue. The superb condition and splendid spirit of the army, the personal prestige of its chief, who had never fought but to conquer, the remarkable ability with which the new campaign was planned, and the signal success with which its first stage was consummated, to all appearance justifying the bulletin of the commander that "the enemy must ingloriously fly, or come out from behind their defences and give us battle on our own ground, where certain destruction awaits him" -- all combined to raise the public expectations to the highest pitch. When next came the tidings that the army was hastening back over the river, with all its material, there could not but be a most painful revulsion of feeling. Every loyal man is in truth smitten to the very soul, and with reason.

lead_paragraph: -- The Courrier des Etats Unis joins the Paris Press in denouncing the action of our Minister in England, in giving a certificate of character to a British vessel bound to Mexico, as hostile to France in her war with that country. It says that "the phrase in which Mr. ADAMS declares that a vessel loaded with arms for the Mexicans has an honorable destination, is, to say the least, strange language to come from the pen of the representative of a nation at peace with France."
