abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, an affray occurred in the porter-house of JOSEPH H. NIXON, at No. 68 Oliver-street, between a party of boarding-house runners, during which PATRICK MCGOVERN was shot in the left eye with a pistol in the hands of JAS. O'HARA. MCGOVERN was immediately taken to the New-York Hospital by Officer KENNEDY, of the Fourth Precinct, where he died soon afterward. Coroner RANNEY held an inquest upon the body yesterday. There was considerable testimony taken, all of which tended to show that there was a large party in the saloon at the time of the shooting, that they had all been drinking, and considerable language of an abusive nature passed between the deceased and JAMES O'HARA. Dr. GALEN HUNTER, made a post mortem examination of the body. He testified that the ball from the pistol entered the left eye, passed through the orbit, and pierced the brain. Death, he thought, must necessarily have resulted in a short time. At the conclusion of the testimony, the jury rendered the following verdict: "That the deceased came to his death by a pistol-shot would, at the hands of JAMES O'HARA, on the 8th day of May, 1863." The deceased was 22 years of age, and a native of Buffalo, N.Y. O'HARA made his escape immediately after the occurrence, and at a late hour last evening had not been arrested.
lead_paragraph: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, an affray occurred in the porter-house of JOSEPH H. NIXON, at No. 68 Oliver-street, between a party of boarding-house runners, during which PATRICK MCGOVERN was shot in the left eye with a pistol in the hands of JAS. O'HARA. MCGOVERN was immediately taken to the New-York Hospital by Officer KENNEDY, of the Fourth Precinct, where he died soon afterward. Coroner RANNEY held an inquest upon the body yesterday. There was considerable testimony taken, all of which tended to show that there was a large party in the saloon at the time of the shooting, that they had all been drinking, and considerable language of an abusive nature passed between the deceased and JAMES O'HARA. Dr. GALEN HUNTER, made a post mortem examination of the body. He testified that the ball from the pistol entered the left eye, passed through the orbit, and pierced the brain. Death, he thought, must necessarily have resulted in a short time. At the conclusion of the testimony, the jury rendered the following verdict: "That the deceased came to his death by a pistol-shot would, at the hands of JAMES O'HARA, on the 8th day of May, 1863." The deceased was 22 years of age, and a native of Buffalo, N.Y. O'HARA made his escape immediately after the occurrence, and at a late hour last evening had not been arrested.

FOREY is said to be quite satisfied with his progress.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. VERDI'S ever popular opera of "Ernani" was given here last evening, to a house that was by far the best of the week.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's ever popular opera of "Ernani" was given here last evening, to a house that was by far the best of the week. It is a favorite work with our public, and there are enthusiasts who claim that it is the only meritorious production of the composer. When rendered as it was last night, it is certainly one of the most spirited operas on the Italian stage. Signor MAZZOLENI, and Signor BIACHI and Signor BELLINI, equally excellent in their roles, were in themselves an ensemble sufficient to insure the success of the performance. But when the chorus and orchestra were good as, they were last night, the combination is little less than electrical. The finale to the first act had to be repeated, and during the evening the audience expressed its sa[???]ion by repeated bursts of applause. Mme. GUERRABELLA was the Elvira of the occasion.

abstract: The Necessity for Reserves
lead_paragraph: The policy of the Government in regard to raising and using armies, is open to a criticism that does little credit to its military sagacity or its resources. It is not too much to say that an immediate reform is imperatively demanded, not only for the honor, but for the success of our aims. We allude to the utter want of any reserved force, upon which the country can fall back in case of disaster.

lead_paragraph: We published yesterday morning the proceedings of a Democratic meeting held at Mozart Hall on Thursday evening. It was emphatically a peace meeting -- and it took action which committed all concerned in it to a speedy and unconditional termination of the war, -- leaving the question of preserving the Union to the chances of future diplomatic arrangements. abstract: The Fifth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, known as Duryee's Zouaves -- First Regiment -- were welcomed on their return to the Metropolis, yesterday, with a splendid military turn-out, and one of the most enthusiastic popular demonstrations that could be imagined. The corps has been in nearly all the battles for the Union in Virginia and Maryland, from Big Bethel to Chancellorsville, and has always distinguished itself for its esprit du corps, its splendid discipline, and its fierce fighting whenever opportunity offered. As is well known, it has been honored by being brigaded with the regulars under Gen. SYKES, and has received from him due meed of praise. No wonder, then, that New-York should be proud of it, and should do the utmost to show the regiment how patriotism and valor is appreciated in the Metropolis of the Empire State. Two of our best regiments of militia, the Seventy-first and Thirty-seventh, paraded to do them honor, while their late comrades in arms, the Tenth New-York, Col. BENDIX, temporarily supplied with arms, likewise turned out to receive them. It was arranged that the Fifth should leave Jersey City at 3 o'clock P.M., and ad interim the attractive red breeches could be seen scattered throughout the City -- everywhere the centre of attraction, the focus of ten thousand questions, the cynosure of all eyes, the envy of the men, the delight of the women. Probably no other regiment in the army is so well known -- certainly none from the City of New-York has more friends. They are the same dashing, daring, free and easy, glorious fellows that they were when they left. It seems but a brief period since they electrified the City by their appearance en route for the seat of war, and their then unequaled marching drill. But how pregnant has been that brief period with memorable events. The eleven hundred men have dwindled to about two hundred and fifty, by the ravages of the bullet and camp disease, together with the natural depreciation of the force from the various disablements which have occurred. They are all still staunch in their love for the Union. The baptism of fire and sword has sanctified the cause to them, and many of them say that after they have seen their friends and enjoyed a brief respite, they will be off to camp and field again to do or die for the good old flag. They bring back their colors -- worn, torn, pierced with many bullet holes, but not dishonored; not stained with the memory of one retreat or one ignoble act. Everywhere, where they appeared bearing these glorious Stars and Stripes, the cheering was loud, long and hearty.

abstract: An important proclamation has been issued by the President, defining the duties of persons of foreign birth, under the Conscription act. In order that all misapprehensions concerning the liability of persons who have declared their intention to become citizens may be avoided, he orders that no plea of alienage shall be received from such person who shall be found within the United States at any time during the continuance of the rebellion, after the expiration of the period of sixty-five days from the date of the Proclamation; and further, that no such plea of alienage shall be allowed in favor of any such person, who has exercised at any time the right of suffrage or other political franchise.

abstract: The cry for his recall
lead_paragraph: We can tell the imps of faction who are shrieking for the restoration of MCCLELLAN that their wind is wasted. The thing cannot and will not be done. The Government has not lost its memory, nor the people their senses. There is an intelligent purpose yet to save this nation. There is a firmer resolve than ever to trust to agents equal to that end, and to those only. There is no more possibility that GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN, after the experience had of him, should be called back to the head of the army, than that JAMES BUCHANAN should be called back to the Executive Chair. The people have bidden a grim good-night to all imbeciles.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, a motion was argued before the Recorder for a new trial in the case of ADOLPH BLANCK, convicted of grand larceny in February last. BLANCK at the time of the alleged larceny was a clerk in the employ of ALBERT DUNG, druggist, corner of Bowery and Canal-street.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, a motion was argued before the Recorder for a new trial in the case of ADOLPH BLANCK, convicted of grand larceny in February last. BLANCK at the time of the alleged larceny was a clerk in the employ of ALBERT DUNG, druggist, corner of Bowery and Canal-street. In January last, $2,000 in gold and Bank bills were stolen from the safe of Mr. DUNG. The defendant and one JOSEPH MATTMAN, the porter, slept in the store. The defendant was at once charged with the theft. The chief witness against him upon the trial was MATTMAN, who claimed to be entirely innocent [???] and wholly ignorant of the robbery. [???] a series of circumstances, which bo[???] BLANCK, and in the absence of any con[???]f (which of course BLANCK could not give. MATTMAN testified to what he alleged occurred [???]nd defendant were alone in the store) the conviction of BLANCK followed almost as a matter of course. BLANCK, who is 43 years of age, up to this time had maintained a most unexceptionable character. He is a man of education and intelligence, and seems to have a very large array of friends, who believe him innocent, and take a very deep interest in his welfare.

abstract: The bold and successful raid of Gen. STONEMAN is the theme of universal and unbounded praise. He not only did all that Gen. HOOKER required him to do in the demolition of bridges and the cutting of railroad and telegraph lines in the rear of the rebel army, but more.
lead_paragraph: The bold and successful raid of Gen. STONEMAN is the theme of universal and unbounded praise. He not only did all that Gen. HOOKER required him to do in the demolition of bridges and the cutting of railroad and telegraph lines in the rear of the rebel army, but more. He carried his fearless riders to within two miles of the City of Richmond, capturing army stores, provisions and prisoners in his way, almost up to the city limits, and sending a fearful panic into the headquarters of rebellion. The affrighted country folks fled into the city, bearing the awful news that LEE's army was overwhelmed, and that hosts of Yankees were at their very doors. The presence of STONEMAN's cavalry was to the quaking rebels proof sufficient of this direful event, and every one who could, amid wild confusion, began to pack up and prepare for flight from the doomed Confederate capital. It is entertainting to read of the consternation that filled Richmond, for the occasion furnishes a fair offset to several audacious rebel operations in a similar line.

abstract: The number of magnificent steamships constructed within the past few months by the shipbuilders of New-York and vicinity for the China trade, deserves especial notice. Great success has attended American steamers in the waters of that Empire, and our mechanics in consequence have won the warmest encomiums.
lead_paragraph: The number of magnificent steamships constructed within the past few months by the shipbuilders of New-York and vicinity for the China trade, deserves especial notice. Great success has attended American steamers in the waters of that Empire, and our mechanics in consequence have won the warmest encomiums. It would seem that science and art have extended their aid more particularly in the construction of these vessels than others from the hands of the same builders, and the appreciation of the fact that their models, and the skill and ingenuity manifested in their erection, are regarded as of a superior order, is practically shown by advices from that region, which state in effect that these vessels have driven, as it were, from those waters, the old-style heavy-built English craft, so numerous there a few years since.

abstract: The United States double-bowed steamer Tacony was successfully launched at Philadelphia on Thursday, Miss WELLES christening her. This vessel belongs to the class of double-enders now in coarse of construction. She is 240 feet long, 35 feet wide, 12 feet deep, and 974 tons burden. In other respects she resembles the twenty-seven vessels building, several of which have been already described.

abstract: Smith vs. Mechanics' and Traders' Insurance Company; Violation of Warranty
snippet: Smith vs. Mechanics' and Traders' Insurance Company; Violation of Warranty
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Smith and another, Executors, vs. The Mechanics' and Traders' Fire Insurance Company. -- This case has just been finished. There were several technical points of defence set up in the answer, which appear to have been abandoned at the trial. But there was one defence urged in which the public have some interest. The premises insured by defendants were a part of a large carpet factory at West Farms, Westchester County, known as "Smith's Carpet Factory." There were fifteen policies on various portions of the premises. Thirteen of the Companies promptly paid the losses on their policies, but two of them refused. It appeared that in the Summer or Fall of 1861, the manufacture of carpets was greatly depressed, in consequence of the war, and the proprietor, as others in the same trade did, appropriated the same machinery with some slight alterations, and the same material used in making carpets, in the manufacture of army blankets; and they moved some of the machinery into the particular portion of the premises insured by defendants. This, the defendants urged, was a breach of the warranty in their policy -that the business to be carried on was carpet manufacturing. Plaintiffs said this was not a material change, and did not increase the risk. Defendants reply that the question of increase of risk is immaterial, as the only question to be tried was whether the warranty or terms of the policy had been violated.

abstract: The New-York Consolidated Stage Company vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York, and the Harlem Railroad Company. -- The argument having been concluded in this case, the Court makes the following order: That the injunction granted on the 23d of April, 1863, be modified so as to permit the Harlem Railroad Company to complete and put in good order the track commenced on Broadway between Thirteenth and Fourteenth streets, and in Whitehall-street, so far as the pavements have been taken up and timbers laid, and where the timbers are not laid to an equal length, to prolong the shorter to an equal length with the longer, and to place rails thereon, and replace the pavement between the rails, and that no part of the said track shall be laid beyond the point to which timbers have already been laid down on either side, that the pavement shall be entirely replaced in those parts of the street which have been excavated. The injunction order in all other respects is to remain in full force, but without prejudice to an application to dissolve the same, and nothing contained in the order is to be considered as a recognition of the rights of either party.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Consolidated Stage Company vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York, and the Harlem Railroad Company. -- The argument having been concluded in this case, the Court makes the following order: That the injunction granted on the 23d of April, 1863, be modified so as to permit the Harlem Railroad Company to complete and put in good order the track commenced on Broadway between Thirteenth and Fourteenth streets, and in Whitehall-street, so far as the pavements have been taken up and timbers laid, and where the timbers are not laid to an equal length, to prolong the shorter to an equal length with the longer, and to place rails thereon, and replace the pavement between the rails, and that no part of the said track shall be laid beyond the point to which timbers have already been laid down on either side, that the pavement shall be entirely replaced in those parts of the street which have been excavated. The injunction order in all other respects is to remain in full force, but without prejudice to an application to dissolve the same, and nothing contained in the order is to be considered as a recognition of the rights of either party.

abstract: MY DEAR FATHER: I have barely time, but will write a few lines to let you know that up to this time I am safe.  On Tuesday, the 28th ult., we left camp and marched all night to the Rappahannock, which we reached the next morning at daybreak. We carried the pontoon boats, in order to avoid making a noise, two miles, thirty-six men to each boat.

abstract: Lieut.-Com. MCDERMOTT, of the gunboat Cayuga, who was killed at a reconnoissance up Sabine Pass, on April 18, was a native of this city, having been born in 1824. He received his commission in 1841, and has been in active service ever since. He was in the Mediterranean at the time of tlie bombardment of Algiers by the French, and witnessed the action; made the voyage around the world with Commodore BIDDLE, when he took Hon. ALEXANDER EVERETT as Commissioner to China. On his return from that voyage he passed his examination as Midshipman. At the time of the breaking out of the war he was on duty in the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and first saw active service in the Bibb, whence he was transferred to the Cayuga. A short time before his death he made a prize of the schooner Tampico, loaded with cotton. As we have already stated, he was wounded while making a reconnoissance at Sabine Pass, in company with Capt. READ, of the gunboat New-London. The rebels carried him to Sabine City, where he died in three hours, and the same afternoon, under a flag of truce, they brought back his body to the officers of the Cayuga, having first taken from him his uniform, boots, watch, money, &c. He was carried on board the Cayuga to New-Orleans, where his funeral took place at Christ Church, on the 25th ult., numerously attended by officers and civilians. A brave man, a gallant officer, and a true patriot, our country numbers none upon the record of her sons more, truly devoted to her cause than he; and, could he have chosen the manner of his death, it would have been to die, as he has done, in her defence.

abstract: Streets, Filth of the
lead_paragraph: The streets of this city are now in a condition of filth without parallel in the memory of this generation. We do not refer to the mud created by the week's rain. That is trivial and temporary. But the accumulation of garbage, ashes and all pollutions, the choked gutters, the reeking and deadly odors, in most of the back and side streets, is intolerable. Broadway, Fifth Avenue, and one or two of the other main streets and avenues, are necessarily clean and orderly to a degree. But for one street that is moderately clean, there are one hundred immoderately and disgustingly unclean. And these latter, too, are the very ones that should be kept clean. They are not those inhabited by the wealthy, but lined by the residences and shops of middling and poor folks, who suffer fearfully by the neglect.

abstract: Reply on Fredericksburg battle to Committee on conduct of the war
snippet: Reply on Fredericksburg battle to Committee on conduct of the war
lead_paragraph: Having published all that portion of the report of the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War which charges Major-Gen. WILLIAM B. FRANKLIN with the chief responsibility for the failure of Gen. BURNSIDE'S attack on Fredericksburgh in December last, it is proper that we should also place before our readers so much of the reply of Gen. FRANKLIN to this allegation as the limited space at our command will enable us to do.

abstract: The League meeting at Cypress Hills' Methodist Church on Thursday evening, the 7th inst., though the night was dark and weather inclement, was largely attended. The large attendance on this and other meetings of the East New-York League, shows that the spirit of the people is onward; and that they are anxious and determined in every possible manner to bring their whole influence to bear in favor of a vigorous prosecution of the war, and the overthrow of the rebellion -- the most wanton, causeless and guilty ever known in history. The feature of the evening was the address of Rev. Mr. POWELL, who for nearly an hour and a half held the undivided attention of the audience. His speech, like the one delivered at East New-York the previous week, was an eloquent vindication of the rights of labor, and of our imperiled nationality. He scourged as with a whip of scorpions those men at the North whom he declared worse than the traitors in arms, who were ready to rejoice over reverses to our arms, or to magnify reverses into disasters. Seldom has it been our pleasure to listen to a more candid, able and convincing address than Mr. POWELL's, which, in some respects, surpassed his cloquent effort at Central Buildings. East New-York. Such was the favorable impression made by him at East New-York and Cypress Hills, that we learn a third invitation has been tendered him to speak, and that application has been made for the Dutch Church, which, large as it is, will, we have no doubt, prove too small to hold the large audience of loyal men and women who will be drawn together by his eloquence.

abstract: -- The U.S. steamer Circassian, which arrived yesterday from Texas, brought on twenty-nine prisoners, six of whom are prisoners of war, and the remainder blockade-runners. The prisoners of war are F. Palinquist, Jos. Pagan, Antonio Messena, Charles Fowler, Edward Leach and John McLean. The last three were captured from the rebel gunboat Jacob Bell, and are all New-Yorkers. FOWLER is well known here, and has two brothers in the rebel service, one a Colonel in a Louisiana regiment, and another a Colonel in the Sixty-third Georgia regiment. The prisoners of war were all taken down to Fort Lafayette yesterday afternoon, in charge of Deputy Marshals BORST and MCCAY.

abstract: Last evening the Twenty-second regiment NewYork N.G. assembled at the pier foot of Cortlandtstreet for the purpose of extending a suitable welcome to the Fourth regiment New-York Volunteers, which was expected from Washington on the arrival of the afternoon train. Information, however, was received at 10 o'clock P.M., that the regiment would not reach this City till about 7 o'clock this (Sunday) morning.

abstract: GARRET LAUNDRESS, an Irishman, 37 years of age, was arraigned in this Court, on Friday, for the murder of JOHN CAIN, also an Irishman, 22 years of age, on the evening of the 19th of March last, at No. 25 Washington-street. It appears from the testimony that ill feeling existed between the deceased and the prisoner, growing out of something the latter had said about a female friend of the former, and on the night of the homicide CAIN came into the dwelling of LAUNDRESS and challenged him to go out and fight him on the Battery. This LAUNDRESS declined, and, after ordering CAIN out of the house, and his refusing to go, LAUNDRESS called a policemen and had him taken out. Later in the evening CAIN returned to the house, and insisted that LAUNDRESS should fight him. After considerable wrangling, a snuffle ensued, during which LAUNDRESS inflicted two stabs with a knife upon CAIN which caused his death the next day. No one was present during the affray except the wife of the prisoner, who could not legally be a witness. It was proved on the trial that CAIN was unarmed at the time, so that LAUNDRESS could not have stood in such imminent danger as to bring the killing within the law of justifiable homicide.
lead_paragraph: GARRET LAUNDRESS, an Irishman, 37 years of age, was arraigned in this Court, on Friday, for the murder of JOHN CAIN, also an Irishman, 22 years of age, on the evening of the 19th of March last, at No. 25 Washington-street. It appears from the testimony that ill feeling existed between the deceased and the prisoner, growing out of something the latter had said about a female friend of the former, and on the night of the homicide CAIN came into the dwelling of LAUNDRESS and challenged him to go out and fight him on the Battery. This LAUNDRESS declined, and, after ordering CAIN out of the house, and his refusing to go, LAUNDRESS called a policemen and had him taken out. Later in the evening CAIN returned to the house, and insisted that LAUNDRESS should fight him. After considerable wrangling, a snuffle ensued, during which LAUNDRESS inflicted two stabs with a knife upon CAIN which caused his death the next day. No one was present during the affray except the wife of the prisoner, who could not legally be a witness. It was proved on the trial that CAIN was unarmed at the time, so that LAUNDRESS could not have stood in such imminent danger as to bring the killing within the law of justifiable homicide.

abstract: Tax law, intended to regulate the expenditure of the appropriations for advertising made on City and County account, and which specifies that no paper shall hereafter receive any pay for advertising for either the City or County, except four dailies of the largest circulation, and six others, to be selected by the Mayor and Comptroller, who are empowered to act in the matter, Mayor OPDYKE and Comptroller BRENNAN have advertised for statements, duly verified, from the various daily newspapers published in the City, of their average daily circulation, exclusive of Sundays, to be submitted to them by the 13th inst. This action indicates an intention to put the first portion of the provisions of the law into effect very soon. It will make a change of Corporation papers from the present arrangement. The list now comprises the TIMES, World, Transcript, Staats Zeitung, Commercial Advertiser, Evening Express, Leader, Daily News and Metropolitan Record.

abstract: AN ATTEMPT TO EXTORT MONEY BY MEANS OF THREATENING LETTERS. WM. SMITH MITCHELL, of No. 202 East Fourteenth-street, was arrested yesterday by Detectives KELSO and RADFORD, and brought before Justice DODGE, at the Lower Police Court, on the charge of having attempted to extort money from Mr. WM. J.G. ESCHMANN, of Nos. 293 and 295 Broadway, by means of threatening letters.
lead_paragraph: AN ATTEMPT TO EXTORT MONEY BY MEANS OF THREATENING LETTERS. -- WM. SMITH MITCHELL, of No. 202 East Fourteenth-street, was arrested yesterday by Detectives KELSO and RADFORD, and brought before Justice DODGE, at the Lower Police Court, on the charge of having attempted to extort money from Mr. WM. J.G. ESCHMANN, of Nos. 293 and 295 Broadway, by means of threatening letters. The testimony produced was very conclusive against the accused, in the judgment of the magistrate, it consists of two letters -- one received by Mr. ESCHMANN on the 4th inst., and the other on the 7th. The writer, who signed himself WM. SMITH MITCHELL in both of them, demanded the sum of $100, to be sent in a letter to Station D, New York Post-office, or in default of that, he (MITCHELL) would expose Mr. E. in his relations with the wife of a certain man whom he named in his letters, and in addition to this he would do other things of a violent nature. The letters of Mr. MITCHELL are too gross for publication in our columns. The way the detectives managed to effect MITCHELL's arrest, was by means of a decoy letter deposited by them in the office at Station D, addressed to MITCHELL, and purporting to contain the amount of money demanded by the latter of Mr. ESCHMANN. The officers testify that they saw him take the decoy letter from the office and read it, and that they then immediately arrested him. Justice DODGE committed the accused in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: Reports, definite and indefinite, of a highly important character, reached us last night from Philadelphia, and are given in this morning's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: Reports, definite and indefinite, of a highly important character, reached us last night from Philadelphia, and are given in this morning's TIMES. The statement is made in the Philadelphia Bulletin of last evening, primarily on the authority of a gentleman arrived from Washington, that Gen. Hooker recrossed the Rappahannock in force on Friday, his men carrying eight days' rations with them. This statement is repeated, on what is alleged to be perfectly reliable authority, and is reiterated in the most positive manner. But the most startling announcement made by the Bulletin is, that Gen. Keyes has taken Richmond, having advanced upon it from Yorktown, and that the National flag now floats over the rebel capital. In part confirmation of this it is stated that ten thousand National troops arrived at Fortress Monroe on the 5th inst., and were immediately moved forward in the direction of Richmond. We give these important rumors as they come to us, and leave our readers to judge of their authenticity.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN has taken no steps toward transferring this Bureau from the City Inspector's Department to the Finance Department, beyond notifying the persons employed in it to report to him, and has exercised no authority over it further than to remove the deputy clerk of one of the markets, and appoint a man in his place. Col. DELAVAN's men continue to perform their duties, and to report to him as they have done heretofore. The Colonel is determined to test the validity of the clause in the City Tax law ordering the transfer. He is satisfied that it is in conflict with section sixteen of the State Constitution, which specifies that no legislative bill shall embrace more than one subject, which must be expressed in the title. He thinks that it the transfer can be sustained in the Courts, all sorts of changes in the City Government may be made by designing persons, by securing brief clauses in the Tax laws, which, not appearing in the title of the bills, would run little chance of discovery in the course of the rapid third reading that such documents receive in the closing hours of the Legislature. The Comptroller has the advantage of the City Inspector, however, in being able to pay his appointees.

abstract: We noticed some days ago the gallant act of the pilot PEDRICK, who carried the steamer Escort past the rebel batteries which invested Washington, N.C. His skill and bravery doubtless saved our garrison there, by the supplies which he brought to them in the Escort. But he, the only man exposed to fire in the steamer, was shot by the rebels and killed on her return passage. He was a Union-loving North Carolinian. He leaves a wife and child in poor circumstances. It is proposed to raise by subscription a sum of money sufficient to make her comfortable. Contributions or subscriptions for this purpose may be sent to Mr. G.W. BLUNT, No. 179 Water-street; or to F. PERKINS, Secretary to the Pilot Commissioners, No. 69 South-street.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held a special meeting at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to take suitable notice of the death of Mr. JOHN HOGAN, who died on Friday morning, and who was a member of the Board during the years of 1860, 1861 and 1862.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held a special meeting at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to take suitable notice of the death of Mr. JOHN HOGAN, who died on Friday morning, and who was a member of the Board during the years of 1860, 1861 and 1862. The President, MORGAN JONES, Esq., presented a preamble and resolutions, expressing the regret of the Board at the mournful event, tendering their sympathy to the family of the deceased in their bereavement, and in favor of the appointment of a Joint Special Committee to take charge of the obsequies; also, that the members of the Common Council would attend the funeral in a body, and ordering the resolutions to be ingrossed and transmitted to the family of Mr. HOGAN. The preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted, and the Board adjourned. The funeral will take place at 2 1/2 P.M., to-day, from the late residence of the deceased, No. 4 Bowling-green.

abstract: Mr. JOHN HOGAN, who was a member of the Board of Councilmen during the years of 1860. 1861 and 1862, died at his residence, No. 4 Bowling Green, of brain fever, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, after a short illness. Mr. H. was of Irish parentage, and was born in Henry-street, in this City, in 1832, a brush-maker by trade, and for the last twenty-five years resided in the First Ward, where he was familiarly known and highly regarded. He was a bachelor, and was much attached to his relatives, with whom he made his home. His success in politics was attained through adherence to the Muzart Democracy, and he was the only representative in the Council Board from the Fourth Senatorial District ever elected solely on the strength of the nomination of that faction. He was a self-reliant, determined and independent minded man, of somewhat brusque manner, but warm-hearted and genial in his general disposition. While in the Board of Councilmen he kept a better run of City affairs than most any other member of either Board, and was rarely found uninformed on any subject that came up.

abstract: Kaufman vs. Sicher; Assault and Battery
snippet: Kaufman vs. Sicher; Assault and Battery
lead_paragraph: Isador Kaufman vs. Charles L. Sicker. -- This action was brought to recover $5,000 for an alleged assault and battery and slander. The plaintiff was a witness on his own behalf, and testified that in November, 1861, he called at the store of Messrs. Hersh & Rich, in Murray-street, in this City, where he met defendant and asked him for payment for a bill of goods; that defendant thereupon assailed him with vile epithets, among other things calling him a "thief." That the defendant at once struck him violent blows, and was hauled off by Messrs. Hersh & Rich, at the same time brandishing a knife which he held in his hand.

abstract: The official charges against VALLANDIGHAM set forth that on or about the 1st of May, at Mount Vernon, Ohio, he publicly addressed a large meeting of citizens, declaring that the present war is an injurious, cruel, and unnecessary war -- a war not being waged for the preservation of the Union, but for the purpose of crushing out liberty and establishing a despotism -- a war for the freedom of the blacks and the enslaving of the whites; and that, if the Administration had so wished, the war could have been honorably terminated; that peace might have been honorably obtained by listening to the proposed intermediation of France; that propositions by which the Southern States could be won back, and be guaranteed their rights under the Constitution, were rejected the day before the battle of Fredericksburgh. He is also charged with having said that Order No. 38 of Gen. BURNSIDE was a base usurpation of arbitrary authority, and that the sooner the people informed the minions of usurpated power that they will not submit to such restrictions the better. He declared also his purpose to defeat an attempt to build up a monarchy upon the ruins of our tree Government, and that he believed the men in power were trying to establish a despotism.

abstract: Vistorious Advance of
lead_paragraph: The capture of Grand Gulf, on the Mississippi, by Gen. GRANT, and his immediate advance thence upon Port Gibson, where he attacked and defeated an army of the enemy 11,000 strong, seems at last to cut the gordian knot of the Vicksburgh difficulty. Gen. GRANT is now on the high road to the rear of Vicksburgh, with his army in full force and high spirited around him, and the rebels defeated and flying before him. The pursuit will hardly slacken before the rebels rally and reinforce their broken columns; and when they do this and meet GRANT face to face in battle, the fate of Vicksburgh will be decided. The contest can thus be conducted on somewhat equal terms. It is a vast gain to the National cause to have turned the powerful batteries that for nearly twelve long months have laughed our siege to scorn, and to have gained an equal footing in the field with the enemy. Everything now depends on Gen. GRANT's so closely following up the enemy, that they will have no time to take and fortify a new position to ward off the coming attack in the rear. That this will be looked to by Gen. GRANT the country has every reason to believe. That patient and long-suffering strategist has had too hard a time of it, getting on the flank of Vicksburgh, to delay a single day in availing himself of his advantage.

abstract: The People ex rel James B. Taylor et al. vs. Matthew T. Brennan, Comptroller. -- The facts of this case are too widely known to need repetition. The case comes before this Court on an appeal from the order made by Judge BARNARD some time since, directing a peremptory mandamus against the Comptroller, to compel him to issue bonds to the amount of $533,433, payment for the Fort Gansevoort property. The case was submitted to the Court on the points of counsel without argument.

abstract: Harassthy, A.; Grape Culture, Wines, >amp;c .
lead_paragraph: The last work of this martyr-philosopher is preceded by a speaking likeness that will recall to many the fervid and glowing eloquence of Prof. MITCHEL, that seemed to kindle with his high themes and held its hearers spell-bound in admiration and delight. The career of such a man is better told by a brief enumeration of the employments he filled -- not only well, but with eminent success. "A graduate of West Point, he was a Lieutenant of artillery, a lawyer, a railway engineer, an astronomer, the founder of one observatory, the director of two, a Doctor of Laws from more than one institution, a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society, a Major-General of Volunteers." Nothing but the supreme love and devotion he felt for his country could have drawn this "many-sided man" away from the chosen fields of science to the fulfillment of patriotic duties that he would have been the last to disregard. His premature death adds interest to the lectures contained in the present volume. They are the last and ripest fruits of his keen and vigorous intellect, applied to the illustration of the most momentous questions that can interest humanity -- the agreement between science and revelation, constantly widening and increasing in proportion as our knowledge itself grows -- most clearly recognized by those whose high acquirements enable them to speak with authority. Our limits forbid any statement of Prof. MITCHEL's line of argument. Nor is it necessary; the rapid sale of the first edition (5,000 copies) shows that the book is in the lands of an appreciative public.

Our loss is about 100 killed and 500 wounded.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. Gilmore, the gallant, efficient and accomplished officer, so well known in connection with the memorable engineering operations of last year on the Southern seaboard, and who only a few weeks ago, defeated and routed a large rebel force at Somerset, Ky., is now in this City under medical treatment for disease of the throat.
lead_paragraph: -- Brig.-Gen. Gilmore, the gallant, efficient and accomplished officer, so well known in connection with the memorable engineering operations of last year on the Southern seaboard, and who only a few weeks ago, defeated and routed a large rebel force at Somerset, Ky., is now in this City under medical treatment for disease of the throat. Gen. Gilmore is in command of the column operating in Southeastern Kentucky, in the Department of Gen. Burnside. He has completely expelled the rebels from that part of the State. But it is hoped that all the troops under Gen. Burnside will soon have an opportunity of aiding Gen. Rosecrans in his great operations against the main rebel army in the Southwest. It is the opinion of Gen. Gilmore's physician that he will speedily be able to rejoin his command.

abstract: The steamer Morning Star, Capt. A.D. PERKINS, which arrived yesterday, left New-Orleans on the 30th April at 9:30 A.M., arrived off Havana at 6:30 P.M. on the 2d May, and left for New-York on the 4th, at 12:40 P.M. On the 2d, at 1 P.M., 45 miles northwest from Moro Castle, spoke United States gunboat Huntsville on a cruise; all well. She had taken three prizes in the previous twenty days. The Morning Star has had strong head winds and heavy sea since leaving Hatteras. Among the passengers are a portion of Gen. BANKS' Staff, his Secretary, with dispatches, and several officers wounded in the late engagements on the Teche.

abstract: If there is any time at which we feel almost inclined to doubt our speedy success in putting down the rebellion and reestablishing the authority of the Government from the Lakes to the Gulf, it is when we look over the whole North and see how little it has been affected by the struggle in which the country has been engaged for two years and more.
lead_paragraph: If there is any time at which we feel almost inclined to doubt our speedy success in putting down the rebellion and reestablishing the authority of the Government from the Lakes to the Gulf, it is when we look over the whole North and see how little it has been affected by the struggle in which the country has been engaged for two years and more. No one going through the land would dream that we were waging so mighty a war, from anything that he would see. If he entered the great cities he would see our streets as thronged as ever, our merchants as intent on gain, our mechanics crowded and pressed with the abundance of work, our warehouses overflowing with all the good things of this life, our places of amusement as well filled, our whole people as active at their various avocations as in the times of piping peace. It would need a close observer to detect by observation of the people themselves any sign that this nation was engaged in a struggle for its life and for the principles of constitutional free Government with which it has been our continued claim that the very hopes of humanity are enwrapped.

abstract: Forty-five Abolition prisoners, who were captured at Kelly's Ford on the 29th of April, arrived at the Libby Prison on Saturday. They were mostly foreigners, and represented forty regiments, each man nearly belonging to a different one. Speaking of Yankee prisoners reminds us to say that all the Yankee officers, (including the two Generals,) in number exceeding 200, and the privates and sailors, will be sent North under flag of truce on to-morrow, Judge OULD having arranged satisfactory terms with Col. LUDLOW, the Federal Commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Forty-five Abolition prisoners, who were captured at Kelly's Ford on the 29th of April, arrived at the Libby Prison on Saturday. abstract: The Geographical and Statistical Society held a regular meeting in their rooms in Clinton Hall, on Thursday evening, which was presided over by HENRY GRINNELL, Esq. The attendance was moderate. A lengthy but still interesting paper was read by Capt. JOHN MULLAN, U.S.A., on the geography, topography and resources of the northwestern territory of the United States, for which the author received the thanks of the Society, and a request for a copy for publication. Rev. Dr. THOMPSON read the report of the Committee of the Council, showing the finances of the Society to be in a flourishing condition. Judge DALY then addressed the Society briefly on the subject of Arctic Explorations -- speaking specially with reference to what has already been accomplished in that field by Capt. C.F. HALL, and of that distinguished officer's intention to resume his explorations, through another expedition. He spoke effectively of the pecuniary difficulties Capt. HALL had had to contend with, in fitting out his second expedition, because of his strong desire that it should not only originate in, but be supported entirely by his own country. There being still a sum of less than $2,000 to make up in order that the required preparations may be completed, the learned Judge offered a resolution appointing a Committee of Three to solicit subscriptions to the amount required. The resolution was carried unanimously, and a Committee of Three was appointed to collect the money. If all goes well, Capt. HALL expects to be ready to leave the port of New-London, Conn., on his second expedition, on the 2d of June next. The Society then elected the following officers for the ensuing year:

abstract: The route from Milliken's Bend to this point, as constructed by our forces, is in the highest degree complimentary to their ingenuity and perseverance. The entire distance, by land, is about sixty miles, and for the greater portion of its length it has been constructed across swamps that at first sight would seem impassible for anything, save alligators or other amphibuous denizens of the country.

abstract: Magazines for May
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly -- Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS -- takes its usual high literary stand, by the help of writers as distinguished as HAWTHORNE, WHITTIER, Miss. PRESCOTT, GAIL HAMILTON and others, while Science is represented by Prof. AGASSIZ, in his "Fern Forests of the Carboniferous Period," and Dr. OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES. The article of Dr. HOLMES, "The Human Wheel; Its Spokes and Felloes," with its mixture of fact, fun and fancy, could have been written by no one but himself. It is an exposition of the philosophy and practice of walking, in conoexion with an account of the admirable substitute provided by B. FRANK PALMER for a missing limb. NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE's "Up the Thames" is another picture from the gallery of English scenes, so peculiarly impressed on his mind by his residence abroad, and now reproduced with wonderful, though unapparent art. It includes the account of a visit to LEIGH HUNT, told with the tender and graceful sympathy common to minds of a kindred order. "CHARLES LAMB's Uncollected Writings" will be acceptable to all lovers of "Elia," and shows how much remains to be done for their favorite author. The politics of the number are comprised in "Shall We Compromise?" by D.D. WASSON, where a conclusion is arrived at from which there will be few dissentients.

abstract: We published yesterday, on the authority of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, a statement that Gen. Hooker again crossed the Rappahannock in force on Friday, his men carrying eight days' rations. We now have positive knowledge that this statement is true. The crossing was successfully accomplished, but at what point, or in what direction the army moved, is not at present known.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday, on the authority of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, a statement that Gen. Hooker again crossed the Rappahannock in force on Friday, his men carrying eight days' rations. We now have positive knowledge that this statement is true. The crossing was successfully accomplished, but at what point, or in what direction the army moved, is not at present known. But the most startling announcement made by the Bulletin is, that Gen. Keyes has taken Richmond, having advanced upon it from Yorktown, and that the National flag now floats over the rebel Capital. In part confirmation of this it is stated that ten thousand National troops arrived at Fortress Monroe on the 5th inst., and were immediately moved forward in the direction of Richmond. Further evidence is wanting to corroborate the report, however.

abstract: The two great cavalry raids that have been going on during the last fortnight, the one in Eastern Virginia and the other through the State of Mississippi, have completely uncovered the weakness of the rebels in some very vital points of the Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: The two great cavalry raids that have been going on during the last fortnight, the one in Eastern Virginia and the other through the State of Mississippi, have completely uncovered the weakness of the rebels in some very vital points of the Confederacy. They have shown that, excepting the few chief points at which the rebel armies are immediately concentrated, the South is not only entirely bare of troops, but that it has been swept clean of the material out of which troops are made. There seems to be hardly an able-bodied white man out of butternut clothes in the Southern Confederacy. In the gallopade of Gen. STONEMAN's troopers round in the rear of Fredericksburgh and down toward Richmond, ten counties were passed through-many of these formerly the most densely populated Counties in Virginia -- and not only were there very few rebel troops in the region, but hardly a grown man was to be seen. There were women, children and negroes -- a good many of the latter in uniform -- but all the able-bodied men had been conscripted into the rebel army, and driven off to be food for gunpowder.
headline: {'main': 'Behind the Rebel Armies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Behind the Rebel Armies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: His Capacity for Command
lead_paragraph: When warning the public, a few days ago, against extravagant expectations, and, above all, against extravagant language touching Gen. HOOKER's capacity and possible achievements, we took occasion to say that his winning a battle in the movement which he was then commencing, would by no means prove that he was a great General, and would by no means entitle him to be compared to NAPOLEON the Great. We said that no single success, or even no half-dozen of successes, would prove that he was really the "coming man" for whose appearance we have been so long and so wearily waiting; that for this the successful conduct of a whole campaign would suffice, but nothing less.

abstract: From early sunrise yesterday morning till long past the small hours of evening this Metropolis was kept in a constant whirl of excitement, by the appearance on the streets of military and civic pageants, the beating of drums, the sounding of trumpets, the blazonry of banners and the firing of cannon. Not for a long period has New-York witnessed such an eventful Sunday.
lead_paragraph: From early sunrise yesterday morning till long past the small hours of evening this Metropolis was kept in a constant whirl of excitement, by the appearance on the streets of military and civic pageants, the beating of drums, the sounding of trumpets, the blazonry of banners and the firing of cannon. Not for a long period has New-York witnessed such an eventful Sunday. It seemed as though the entire population of old and young, great and little, rich and poor, had mutually determined to come out of their houses to witness the ovation extended to the returning New-York regiments from the field of battle. From the roofs of public and other buildings, the National flag was displayed, and in many instances mottoes of welcome in letters of evergreen were exhibited at the windows of private residences. That the troops had an earnest and sincere reception at the hands of the people will not be doubted by any one who saw the proceedings of yesterday. That the troops appreciated the feeling which prompted the manifestation of interest in their behalf was also apparent The absence of omnibuses and other vehicler which monopolize Broadway on weekdays, rendered that thoroughfare comparatively free for the occasion. Wherever the returning soldiers appeared they were greeted with repeated acclamations. On all the down-town streets, little knots -- the nucleus of which was one or more of the volunteers -- could be observed, and if one was near enough to listen, he could hear question upon question concerning experience of the regiment during its two years' service, asked the brave fellows who at times must have considered the ordeal equal to that to which they had been subjected on the battle-field. As a general thing, the troops looked well, although, of course, camp-life had taken from them their naturally fair complexions, and given in return a bronzed and hardy visage. According to the late order, they were permitted to retain their arms.

abstract: The past week was an unfavorable one for Mr. MARETZEK'S operatic enterprise. Its opening was in dangerous proximity to the great "moving day," and its close, with the exception of Saturday, was moist and forbidding. Notwithstanding these circumstances the spirit of the manager was unflagging, and hence we had four splendid performances three of them being of VERDI'S new opera of "Aroldo," and the fourth of the same maestro's "Ernani."
lead_paragraph: The past week was an unfavorable one for Mr. MARETZEK'S operatic enterprise. Its opening was in dangerous proximity to the great "moving day," and its close, with the exception of Saturday, was moist and forbidding. Notwithstanding these circumstances the spirit of the manager was unflagging, and hence we had four splendid performances three of them being of VERDI'S new opera of "Aroldo," and the fourth of the same maestro's "Ernani." The company was heard to great advantage in these works. "Aroldo" is an opera that deserves to become a favorite with our public. It is well written, effective and popular in its character. Mr. MARETZEK has produced it with great care; the dresses are thoroughly magnificent, and the scenery is as good as it can be had for love or money at the Academy. Altogether the work is a spectacle for the eye, as well as a treat for the ear. The matinee on Saturday was attended by a brilliant gathering of the fair sex. To-night VERDI's "Trovatore" will be played for the debut of Miss PARKER, a lady who appeared here some months since in a concert, and created a very favorable impression. Miss PARKER has improved the interval in study and actual experience of operatic singing -- having essayed the stage successfully in California. The present is of course an ordeal of greater gravity, but much is confidently expected of the lady. The principal artists of the troupe are in the cast.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. Halleck, General-in-Chief:  We landed at Boulinsburgh, April 30th, moved immediately on Port Gibson, met the enemy, 11,000 strong, four miles south of Port Gibson, at 2 A.M. on the let inst., and engaged him all day, entirely routing him with the loss of many killed, and about 500 prisoners, besides the wounded. Our loss is about 100 killed and 500 wounded.

abstract: Yesterday, at Plymouth Church, was the regular Sabbath for the baptism of infants, and the delightful Spring morning tempted a larger number of parents than usual to bring their offspring forward. Having administered the rite to all but one of the children, Mr. BEECHER paused a moment, and, turning to his interested audience, stated that there was still another child to be christened. Her history, however, contained a moral, and he should take the liberty of carrying her upon the platform where all present might look upon her features. This preface caused a flutter of increasing interest, which was not abated until the reverend gentleman had ascended the pulpit steps, bearing in his arms a little laughing-eyed, sweet-faced, fair-haired girl of five years, who nestled closely against his breast, toying with his watch-guard, as she timidly met, with her dark, lustrous eves, the concentrated gaze of the now hushed congregation. In a voice tremulous and tearful, and in words that touched a sympathetic chord in the hearts of his hearers, Mr. BEECHER told about the child. "She was born in Slavery," he said. "A benevolent woman, who was nursing our sick soldiers in the hospital at Fairfax, found her, sore and tattered and unclean, and requested the good sister who has adopted her, to bring her North and take care of her. She will be treated as this lady's own child, and it is designed to educate her as a teacher for her race. Look upon this child," continued Mr. BEECHER, "and tell me if you ever saw a fairer,  sweeter face? And this child," he added, "is a sample of the Slavery which absorbs into itself everything fair and attractive. The loveliness of this child would only make her so much more valuable as a chattel; for while your children are brought up to fear and serve the Lord, this little one, just as beautiful, would be made, through Slavery, a child of damnation. The whole force of my manhood revolts and rises up in enmity against an institution that cruelly exposes such children to be sold like cattle. [Loud applause.] Look upon this child," he repeated in conclusion, "and take away with you an impression of her beauty, and remember to what a shocking fate Slavery would bring her! May God strike for our armies and the right, that this accursed thing may be utterly destroyed." [Renewed applause.]

abstract: West mentioned that Gen. PRICE had gathered quite a number of white and red troops at Little Rock, and that he was mounting them, and preparing to enter Missouri, which he would do some time in May. We hope we are not going to have another panic in Missouri about Gen. PRICE; and we hope that, having warned the State fully, the State will take the warning. Missouri has 10,540 troops in the National service, embracing fourteen regiments of cavalry, one regiment of infantry and two batteries of artillery; and the return of the Enrolled Militia, organized under call of the Governor, shows an aggregate strength of 52,056 men liable to be called out for the defence of the State. The latter force is the one that should now be organized and armed for home defence. They would be more than competent to thrash PRICE and all his force, though he and they were multiplied by ten. Let them be made effective for militia service, and let another Price-par be avoided, by all means.
lead_paragraph: West mentioned that Gen. abstract: DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE. -- The Police have been busy for a few days past in arresting persons for permitting their dogs to run at large without being muzzled, as required by law. Several individuals have recently been bitten, and one alleged case of hydrophobia has been reported, which, together with the fact that several dogs, which showed evidence of being afflicted with that fearful malady, have lately been killed has, caused an intense degree of excitement among certain portions of the community. The Mayor is daily called upon and appealed to. to enforce the law; and, in accordance with his request, the Police have been directed to arrest all owners of unmuzzled dogs, and to take up or kill all dogs having no owners. Some twenty persons have been arrested daily since Thursday last, and fined by the Justices from $2 50 to $3 each. Within the same time some two dozen ownerless dogs have been killed.
lead_paragraph: DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE. -- The Police have been busy for a few days past in arresting persons for permitting their dogs to run at large without being muzzled, as required by law. abstract: The sudden change of plans for the formal reception of the First regiment New-York State Volunteers, has a brief history, of considerable interest. The notice of the programme for Sunday was issued on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: The sudden change of plans for the formal reception of the First regiment New-York State Volunteers, has a brief history, of considerable interest. The notice of the programme for Sunday was issued on Saturday night. Early on Sunday morning there was a meeting at the Mayor's office of such gentlemen as rarely assemble in the City Hall -- especially on the Sabbath. Among them were Messrs. James Brown, Wm.E. Dodge, David Hoadley, Jno. T. Johnson, C.R. Roberts, R.H. McCurdy Norman White, Fred. DePeyster, R.S. Stuart, Stewart Brown, F.S. Winston, Ed. Dwight, W.R. Vermilye, F.G. Foster, A.R. Wetmore, Jas. W. Beekmen, Jas. Suydam, O.E. Wood, Alex. Stuart, S.B. Scheiffelin, and the venerable Gen. Swift. These gentlemen expressed to His Honor their belief that the arrangements for the Sunday ovation must have been made without his sanction, and their desire that it should be deferred to some secular day, when they and those who shared their views of the Sabbath, might be allowed to take part in the public proceedings.

abstract: The announcement in the Philadelphia Bulletin of Saturday, published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, naturally created intense interest in this City. Its leading points were that Gen. HOOKER had recrossed the Rappahannock, and that Gen. KEYES had advanced upon and entered Richmond from Yorktown.
lead_paragraph: The announcement in the Philadelphia Bulletin of Saturday, published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, naturally created intense interest in this City. Its leading points were that Gen. HOOKER had recrossed the Rappahannock, and that Gen. KEYES had advanced upon and entered Richmond from Yorktown. A portion of this intelligence we know to be true. Gen. HOOKER has transferred his army again to the south side of the Rappahannock, with the purpose beyond all doubt of at once resuming offensive operations. Probably he has been led to this step by intelligence of the complete success which attended the brilliant movement of Gen. STONEMAN, which seems to have so far destroyed the communications of the rebel army with Richmond as to render the receipt of supplies for some days, if not weeks, quite impossible. If they were at all short of supplies at the time of the late battles, it is difficult to see how they can avoid the necessity of immediately falling back to some point much nearer their base.

abstract: in the brief dispatch of Gen. GRANT, concerning the fight on the 1st of May near Port Gibson, Miss., that he found and fought there a garrison of eleven thousand men, seemed almost incredible, as Port Gibson was a place...
lead_paragraph: in the brief dispatch of Gen. GRANT, concerning the fight on the 1st of May near Port Gibson, Miss., that he found and fought there a garrison of eleven thousand men, seemed almost incredible, as Port Gibson was a place of which little had been heard, and it was not known that the rebels had a single man there, nor could it be supposed that they had such large bodies of troops scattered here and there over the Mississippi Valley. But the fact is that these eleven thousand men were part of the rebel army defending Vicksburgh, which had been marched hastily down to Port Gibson to oppose the landing of GRANT's land force on the east bank of the Mississippi River. We published a letter yesterday, written from a point on the west side of the Mississippi, nearly opposite to where the battle was subsequently fought, in which our correspondent asserted that he could see the rebel regiments filing down the east bank of the river from the direction of Vicksburgh. In defeating and routing these eleven thousand men, Gen. GRANT has diminished by just so much the labor he will have to do when he moves immediately upon the enemy's works at Vicksburgh.

abstract: At a late hour on Saturday afternoon last, quite a number of the "fancy men" of this City received a notice to the effect that on Monday morning, (yesterday,) about daylight, a prize fight would take...
lead_paragraph: At a late hour on Saturday afternoon last, quite a number of the "fancy men" of this City received a notice to the effect that on Monday morning, (yesterday,) about daylight, a prize fight would take place between JAMES ELLIOTT and JAMES DUNN, at Camp Scott, Staten Island. The stakes were $1,200 a side. A large number of the sporting men of this City went down to Staten Island by the last boat on Saturday night. All day on Sunday large crowds of those immediately interested in the fight, availed themselves of the chances of a leisure day and repaired to the place, where it was supposed the battle would take place. The parties most interested did everything they could to prevent the Metropolitan Police from learning the time and place of the fight. The Dunn party went down, on Saturday night last, and were safely rendezvoused in the vicinity of Camp Scott; but Elliot's party did not undertake to leave the City until a late hour on Sunday night. The Metropolitan Police had, in the meantime, received notice of the intended fight, and orders were immediately issued by the Superintendent to the Captain of the Harbor Police Boat, to arrest all persons who endeavored to leave the City in a certain boat, which it was supposed would leave the Battery some time during the night. Police Boat No. 1 was accordingly manned, and every preparation was made to overhaul the suspected craft. About 2 or 3 o'clock on Sunday morning, a sloop was seen to pass down the North River, past the Battery and as it answered the description of the suspected craft, the Police-boat, which had steam up for several hours, gave chase, and in a short time overhauled the former. It proved to be the boat containing the Elliott party. When the Metropolitan boat first hailed the other, no answer was given; a second hail and the Elliott boat reponded, "Don't mind the Metropolitans, but crowd on the sails." The Captain of the Police-boat then said, "Unless you come to and surrender, shall at once fire upon you." This threat had the desired effect. The Elliott boat took in sail, and the Police steamer took her in low, and brought her back to the City, with all on board. On the captured boat, there were about four hundred of the friends of ELLIOTT, their champion. Some fifteen hundred or two thousand disappointed men -- most of them the friends and backers of DUNN -- after waiting at different places on the east shore of Staten Island until 8 or 9 o'clock yesterday morning, were compelled to wend their way back to the City, much disappointed at the idea of not having witnessed the "fun," and all the time venting curses loud and deep against the Police for the part they performed in the matter. The leaders in the fight say that it will come off at an early day, at some place beyond the jurisdiction of the Metropolitan Police.

abstract: The ex-officers of the First regiment New-York Volunteers, through a Committee consisting of Major JAMES M. SURMER, Capts. BERGE and UNDERHILL, desire to say to the citizens of New-York and their fellow-citizens in other States that nearly one month since a a delegation from the Seventh New-York State Militia tendered an escort to the First on its arrival in New-York City. The Colonel, and his officers through him, accepted the invitation. They only ask that those who may take exception to their arrival "home," will bear in mind the fact that the regiment left New-York Bay on Sunday, and that it arrived back again after two years' faithful service on Sunday; with the additional fact that on the Sunday previous, they had lost one hundred and twenty men -- killed, wounded and missing -- from their ranks.

abstract: -- The naval attack on the rebel batteries at Grand Gulf, on the 28th ult., of which our correspondent yesterday furnished an account, seems to have been a very hard-fought affair. Our killed and wounded amount to seventy-six, and the damage to the gunboats was considerable. The Tuscumbia, a turreted iron-clad, was completely riddled in every portion not protected by plating. Her chimneys were perforated until they resembled huge graters, and her woodwork torn and splintered in every conceivable shape. Her turrets alone, in their thickest parts, were able to resist the projectiles hurled against her. She was finally disabled by a shot that cut one of her hog-chains, by which, in river phrase, she was "broken in two." The Lafayette proved herself the most formidable as well as invulnerable vessel of the fleet, for though struck a number of times, she was not in the slightest degree injured.
lead_paragraph: -- The naval attack on the rebel batteries at Grand Gulf, on the 28th ult., of which our correspondent yesterday furnished an account, seems to have been a very hard-fought affair. Our killed and wounded amount to seventy-six, and the damage to the gunboats was considerable. The Tuscumbia, a turreted iron-clad, was completely riddled in every portion not protected by plating. Her chimneys were perforated until they resembled huge graters, and her woodwork torn and splintered in every conceivable shape. Her turrets alone, in their thickest parts, were able to resist the projectiles hurled against her. She was finally disabled by a shot that cut one of her hog-chains, by which, in river phrase, she was "broken in two." The Lafayette proved herself the most formidable as well as invulnerable vessel of the fleet, for though struck a number of times, she was not in the slightest degree injured.

abstract: The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this city Sunday from the army, were yesterday honored with a municipal and military ovation.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this city Sunday from the army, were yesterday honored with a municipal and military ovation. The old Scott Life Guard received back its colors deposited in the City Hall when it left for the war two years ago. The column was reviewed by the Mayor and members of the Common Council in the City Hall Park, and by Gen. SCOTT at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The Fourth was entertained with a banquet in the evening.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: How is it must a human creature smell powder to become a man? Is there indeed such virtue in "villainous saltpetre?" Surely there must be something strange to account...
lead_paragraph: How is it -- must a human creature smell powder to become a man? Is there indeed such virtue in "villainous saltpetre?" Surely there must be something strange to account for the strange difference between the manly spirit of the soldiers and the unmanly spirit of civilians. All accounts agree that the troops on the Rappahannock came out of their late bloody fight game to the backbone. Their submission in retreating was as steady and heroic as was their courage in advancing. It did not take from them one jot of confidence, either in themselves or their leader. But the news of the retreat no sooner came to the people, than thousands of them began to curse, and other thousands to whimper and whine. HOOKER was denounced as a braggart, a blunderhead and a humbug; and the cause itself was besniveled and bemoaned as sacrificed, ruined and lost. We do not say these feelings were universal. They were not -- far from it. There were men whose hearts were firmer set, and whose faces were more like flint that day than ever. But that the general feeling was despondent, the public pulse low, was shown beyond all doubt by that unerring index, the price of gold, which, under the news, went from seven to nine per cent. higher than it was before, or is now.

abstract: The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment, (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this City Sunday from the seat of war, met with an enthusiastic public reception yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth New-York Volunteer regiment, (Scott Life Guard,) which arrived in this City Sunday from the seat of war, met with an enthusiastic public reception yesterday. The programme arranged by the municipal and other authorities for the occasion was minutely observed, to the edification of multitudes of spectators. The military and firemen's display was the grandest witnessed in the City for a long period, and the honors paid to the returning regment were from seurces which cannot fail to make a deep impression upon the memories of the recipients.

abstract: Valley; emigrant's successes
lead_paragraph: The gratifying progress that Gen. GRANT is making in circumventing the rebel army in Mississippi is one of the most hopeful features of the war. The West is not divided into many separate topographical systems, each independent of the other, as is the case with the Atlantic Seaboard States. The New-England harbors might be blockaded by an enemy, and New-York not feel it. New-York harbor might be closed, and yet the States conduct a foreign commerce without limit. It is different in the West. The Mississippi Valley is a grand unit, and a blockade of its great river at a single point, as at Vicksburgh, acts as a paralysis on commerce throughout its whole vast extent -- from Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico. It is easy to comprehend, therefore, what an inspiriting and vitalizing effect will be produced on the loyal millions of the Mississippi Valley by the success of Gen. GRANT in removing the rebel blockade from the Mississippi River.
headline: {'main': 'The Mississippi Valley Almost Redeemed.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mississippi Valley Almost Redeemed.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Bohemian arrived off Cape Race yesterday morning, having left Liverpool on the 30th ult., and Londonderry on the 1st inst., and the City of Washington arrived at this port this morning.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Bohemian arrived off Cape Race yesterday morning, having left Liverpool on the 30th ult., and Londonderry on the 1st inst., and the City of Washington arrived at this port this morning. Her advices are five days later, though not specially important. It was reported that Mr. ADAMS had made an explanation regarding his letter of protection covering supplies for the Mexican Government, and that no diplomatic protest was necessary; but it is further stated that the French Government has taken offence, and has demanded an explanation. The London Times, in its issue of May 1, announces that Lord LYONS has been instructed to state to the Government of the United States that the British Government considers full reparation due for the losses sustained by the detention of British subjects on board the Peterhoff, and their imprisonment in New-York. The Times further states that the Ministers have announced that the Peterhoff's mails will be forwarded to their destination unopened, and that the same course will be pursued in similar cases. Polish affairs were unchanged. Some diplomatic correspondence relating to the Polish question had been published, but it was unimportant. The Liverpool cotton market was dull, and prices were generally lower. Breadstuffs were steady, but quiet, and provisions inactive. The latest quotation of consuls is 93 1/8@93 1/4, for money.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There was a poor attendance last evening when "Il Trovatore" was performed. The work seems to be out of favor with the public, except on extraordinary occasions. Last evening was not one of these. The performance lacked spirit. Signor MAZZOLENI did not seem to be in good voice, and, indeed, was unable to finish the opera -- Signor SBRIGLIA assuming his role. Signor BALLINI sang with much power, but was, nevertheless, a little hoarse. Miss PARKER -- a lady who made the acquaintance of our public some eighteen months since at a concert -- was the Leonora, but failed to satisfy the audience with the performance. Miss PARKER possesses a good voice, but is destitute of the culture that should enable her to use it to advantage.

abstract: One-sided Neutrality of
lead_paragraph: Etats Unis fails to point out a word or syllable in the letter of Mr. ADAMS which indicates the slightest suspicion on his part that the cargo of the British vessel whose neutral character he certified consisted of arms, or was contraband of war. That journal, nevertheless, persists in its assertion that he must have known it, because he is too acute and too sagacious a man to be deceived in such a matter. We beg to ask the Courrier what evidence it has even now that the vessel carried arms and munitions? We have seen nothing more conclusive on this point than some unsupported statements of the London Times, repeated by Secessionists in the House of Commons. If the Courrier has any better authority, we should be glad to know it. But it has failed at any rate to show that Mr. ADAMS had any reason for suspecting that he was doing anything more than certifying to the bona fide neutrality of a British vessel seeking a market for British goods in a Mexican port. The Courrier thinks it quite right for the British to send arms to the Mexicans for the express purpose of fighting the French. This is certainly a curious mode of defending the rights and interests of France, though it is a matter with which we have no concern.

abstract: We have no later intelligence from the Army of the Potomac this morning. We have, however, from various sources, a reiteration of the statement made in yesterday's TIMES, that Gen. HOOKER is again across the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: We have no later intelligence from the Army of the Potomac this morning. We have, however, from various sources, a reiteration of the statement made in yesterday's TIMES, that Gen. HOOKER is again across the Rappahannock. It is believed by some that the rebels have fallen back from the line of the river, and that the movement of Gen. HOOKER is a pursuit of a retreating foe. The enemy are said to have left large numbers of their killed and wounded on the field of Chancellorsville. This statement is borne out in part by the announcement, in the Richmond Examiner of the 7th inst., that, in consequence of active operations and limited transportation, the wounded on the field and at Guinea Depot were suffering for food. We also have, from a Richmond paper of the 9th, a list of National officers who fell into the hands of the rebels, and who are now prisoners in Richmond.
