abstract: London Times on Neutral Obligations; the obligations of
snippet: London Times on Neutral Obligations; the obligations of
lead_paragraph: The restored harmony of the North for the prosecution of the war, or some other potent cause, has wonderfully opened the eyes of the London Times to our national rights. Probably no argument has from the outset been more frequently pressed in favor or extenuation of the building and fitting out of the Confederate privateers than that the National Government had no right to complain, because its own agents had been all the while importing arms and munitions from the British market. There has been a persistent attempt from the outset to jumble up these different transactions, and produce the impression that it was all a matter of traffic which both belligerents were availing themselves of, and of which neither could justly complain. Our complaints have been treated precisely as if we claimed, as a matter of law, that England should not observe the obligations of a neutral, but discriminate in our favor.

abstract: GRANT, THE BURGLAR. CHAS. H. GRANT, alias GORDON, the burglar, about whom so much excitement was caused some months since, in consequence of his numerous and successful burglaries, was arraigned before the Court of Sessions yesterday. The accused pleaded guilty to the indictments found against him, of which there are some eight or nine, and was remanded to jail to await sentence.
lead_paragraph: GRANT, THE BURGLAR. -- CHAS. H. GRANT, alias GORDON, the burglar, about whom so much excitement was caused some months since, in consequence of his numerous and successful burglaries, was arraigned before the Court of Sessions yesterday. The accused pleaded guilty to the indictments found against him, of which there are some eight or nine, and was remanded to jail to await sentence. The prisoner looked well and appeared rather cheerful, although pale on account of his long imprisonment. After GRANT was disposed of, a thin, emaciated-looking young man, named JOSEPH WILMOT, was arraigned on the charge of burglary in the first degree, in breaking into a house and stealing a watch-chain worth fifty cents. He pleaded guilty to burglary in the third degree, and was sent to State Prison for two years. WM. COFFEY was placed on trial, on an indictment for rape on a young female, 15 years of age. named MARGARET GLEESON. The complaining witness was examined, after which the Court adjourned.

abstract: The Government of Lord PALMERSTON has been forced into the confessional by threatening parliamentary majorities. In the House of Lords the aspect became cloudy enough far Lord RUSSELL when such a Whig placeman as the Marquis of Clanricarde undertook to expose the pusillanimity of his friend and patron in the Foreign Office.
lead_paragraph: The Government of Lord PALMERSTON has been forced into the confessional by threatening parliamentary majorities. In the House of Lords the aspect became cloudy enough far Lord RUSSELL when such a Whig placeman as the Marquis of Clanricarde undertook to expose the pusillanimity of his friend and patron in the Foreign Office. And Lord PALMERSTON must have found that the basis of his power was gradually being undermined, when the twin radical members for Sheffield led the assault on the foreign policy of the Government, in its bearing on the right of search and the claims of belligerents.

abstract: -- The steamboat City of Albany, built for, and running on the day route, is already classed among the fast boats, for which the North River is justly celebrated. This boat draws but four feet of water, and will, in consequence, avoid the annoyance of detention on the bars. The City of Albany was designed as a test as to whether a wide, light-draft steamboat could be made to attain great speed. Her draft of water is satisfactory, and her speed was shown on Friday in coming from Albany to Hudson in one hour and thirty-two minutes, and to Rhinebeck in three hours, landing as usual.

abstract: Yesterday morning another daring robbery was discovered at the Brooklyn Navy-yard this time on board a man-of-war in commission. Between midnight and 4 A.M. the Quartermaster of the watch on board the United States gunboat Sumter, assisted probably by some accomplice, actually seized the safe locked up in the Purser's room, and absconded with it in a small boat, a watchman looking on, and believing all to be right.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning another daring robbery was discovered at the Brooklyn Navy-yard -- this time on board a man-of-war in commission. Between midnight and 4 A.M. the Quartermaster of the watch on board the United States gunboat Sumter, assisted probably by some accomplice, actually seized the safe locked up in the Purser's room, and absconded with it in a small boat, a watchman looking on, and believing all to be right. The thief expected to find $28,000 in the safe; but he was foiled, for, although the Paymaster applied for the money the day before yesterday to the Sub-Treasurer, he did not receive it. There were, however, some $500 in the drawer, which, of course, are gone. Had there been any of the ship's officers on duty, as the law requires, the burglary would have been impossible, and Capt. "WINCHESTER will, doubtless, have to explain the matter. It is said that chloroform was administered to some of the officers, who slept very soundly during the removal of the safe. Detectives were after the thief last evening, without much success, so far as could be learned. A Court of Inquiry about the matter was ordered, and will examine all parties concerned to day.

abstract: We publish this morning a congratulatory order from Gen. HOOKER to the Army of the Potomac. He says if it has not accomplished all that was expected, the reasons are well known to it. The obstacles were of a character not to be foreseen or prevented by human sagacity or resources. New laurels have been added to its former renown.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a congratulatory order from Gen. HOOKER to the Army of the Potomac. He says if it has not accomplished all that was expected, the reasons are well known to it. The obstacles were of a character not to be foreseen or prevented by human sagacity or resources. New laurels have been added to its former renown. Long marches have been made, rivers have been crossed, the enemy has been surprised in his intrenchments, and wherever the army has fought, it has inflicted heavier blows than it has received. It has taken from the enemy five thousand prisoners and fifteen colors, captured and brought off seven pieces of artillery, and placed hors du combat eighteen thousand of his chosen troops. His depots, filled with vast amounts of stores, have been destroyed, his communications have been damaged, prisoners have been captured within the fortifications of his Capital, and his country has been filled with fear and consternation.

abstract: The failure of the Federal attack on the Charleston forts was the theme of general comment; but there is a wide difference in the deductions drawn from the event.
lead_paragraph: The failure of the Federal attack on the Charleston forts was the theme of general comment; but there is a wide difference in the deductions drawn from the event. The London Times says that the effort against Charleston, which was to retrieve and avenge all previous disasters, has ended in a catastrophe more signal than any reverse the North has yet sustained. Continual failures are not mere accidents. The object of the North is impossible. Those who appeal to arms should surely be prepared to accept the decision of the field. Even if the conquest of the South were to he achieved, it would only destroy the North by turning it into a Russia of the New World, compelled to be the despotic oppressor of a Poland of the West.

abstract: One of the most terrific gunpowder explosions which ever took place in this City, occurred at a late hour on Monday night, at the foot of Seventy-eighthstreet, East River. The report was heard in every part of the country for the distance of fifty miles. The damage to the property is very great, and the wonder is, that no lives were lost by the catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: One of the most terrific gunpowder explosions which ever took place in this City, occurred at a late hour on Monday night, at the foot of Seventy-eighthstreet, East River. The report was heard in every part of the country for the distance of fifty miles. The damage to the property is very great, and the wonder is, that no lives were lost by the catastrophe. The particulars of the occurrence areas follows: For about eighteen months past there has been a cartridge manufactory and a powder magazine locatedat the foot of Seventy-eighth-street. East River. The proprietors, Messrs. JOHNSTON & Dow, have had contracts with the United States Government for the manufacture and delivery of cartridges. During the last year and a half, they have had on an average 300 persons in their employ. There were two buildings devoted to the business -- one of them between. Seventy-eighth and Seventy-ninth streets, and the other a short distance below the foot of Seventy-eighth-street, East River. No accident of any kind had occurred during all this year and a hair, until that on Monday night, Mr. DRAKE, the foreman for JOHNSTON & Dow, informed our reporter that the strictest watch had been, kept upon the premises, and that the utmost care had been taken to prevent an explosion, or to avoid accidents of any kind. He further stated that at about 11 1/2 o'clook on Monday night, he was aroused from his slumbers by the explosion.

abstract: Trial of and where he should go
snippet: Trial of and where he should go
lead_paragraph: We published on Monday morning the charges upon which Mr. VALLANDIGHAM was recently tried by Court-martial in Cincinnati. We have no doubt that the evidence offered was sufficient to establish their truth. There remains the question, what sentence the Court will pass upon him. If we could have our choice in the matter, it should be that he be sent South beyond our lines. Taking his life might seem too hard, imprisonment would quite likely make a martyr of him, but every one will recognize the fitness of sending him to Dixie, to join that noble company of traitors whose praises he has sounded so loudly, and to receive from them in person that meed of praise which they have so steadily bestowed upon him at a distance.

abstract: Letter to Prof. Morse, favoring rebellion
snippet: Letter to Prof. Morse, favoring rebellion
lead_paragraph: Some of our readers may remember Mr. J. L. O'SULLIVAN, formerly of this City -- at one time member of the State Assembly, afterward Minister to Portugal, and now a resident, for private purposes, of London. He has just published in that City a letter to Prof. MORSE, in favor of the rebellion, which goes a little beyond any literature of the same kind we have had the misfortune to fall in with hitherto. He insists upon the adoption by the Democratic party, of which he has long been a prominent and influential member, of a peace policy; but he disdains the pretexts by which Messrs. WOOD, BROOKS and other peace men here at home seek to commend their projects to public favor. He denounces the old Union as having been "very defective," and affects no sort of regard for the present Constitution. He avows frankly his entire sympathy with the South -- rejoices in every triumph of their arms -- declares that every American worthy of the name should be far "more proud to share in the magnificent glory of defeat, than to swell the exulting hosts of brutal triumph," and declares that if the South is conquered, he shall "claim the high honor of sharing in such noble misfortune."

abstract: Arrest and Habeas Corpus Case of
snippet: Arrest and Habeas Corpus Case of
lead_paragraph: Some two weeks ago Mr. JAMES P. HAMBLETON, of Georgia, formerly editor and publisher of the Southern Confederacy, a paper rendered infamous by the publication several years ago of the "black list" of New-York merchants, (those not supposed to be favorable to the peculiar institution,) was arrested in this city having lately come from Georgia, and having in his possession $27,000 of Confederate money and bonds. When arrested, HAMBLETON claimed to be a Union man and to have opposed the rebellion from the start; but the fact of his having in his possession so large an amount of Confederate money, coupled with his own declaration that he intended soon to return to Georgia by way of Nassau, was regarded as sufficient cause for his detention, and he has since that time been in the custody of the Government authorities, nominally confined in the Park Barracks, but in reality allowed what might be called the freedom of the City. Last week a writ of habeas corpus was issued by Judge MCCUNN to Capt. ARMSTRONG, of the Park Barracks, and Gen. WOOL, requiring them to produce the body of HAMBLETON for the purpose of inquiring into the cause of his detention. On Saturday Capt. ARMSTRONG made return to the writ that he held him by virtue of an order from his superior officer, Gen. WOOL. He also produced the body of HAMBLETON, and Judge MCCUNN adjourned the hearing of the case to 3 o'clock Monday afternoon. At the hour appointed, SAMUEL G. GLASSEY, Esq., as counsel for Gen. WOOL, appeared and made the following further return to the writ:

abstract: Charles J. Abrams vs. James Lynch, Sheriff. -- Replevin for contents of furniture-store levied on under an attachment issued out of the Supreme Court in favor of Christian Fenrich against Eliza J. Boyd, wife of George Boyd. Mrs. Boyd bought the store and good will in July, 1860, for $4,400. Her husband managed the business, and debts for furniture were incurred to a large amount, to various mechanics and manufacturers and for accommodation indorsements. in January, 1862, the plaintiff took a bill of sale of the stock for about $1,250 of which $509 was by assuming a debt due to a firm of which plaintiff was a member. The balance of the consideration was alleged to have been borrowed money, and the assumption of debts to mechanics and others who had furnished goods. George Boyd continued in the management of the business. The defendant claimed that the stock was worth $2,000, and that there was in reality no other consideration paid than the $509. That the plaintiff was the son-in-law of Mrs. Boyd, and the sale was only designed to cover the property from Mrs. Boyd's creditors. The evidence was quite conflicting as to some of the points at issue. The jury rendered a verdict for the defendant.

abstract: The necessity for reserves
lead_paragraph: The return of the two years' and nine months' men during the next few weeks will reduce our Army of the Potomac by a good many thousands; battles, marches and disease will reduce it by a good many more. And yet not a single man has been raised by the Government to fill up the gaps; so that it is not impossible that we may find ourselves this Summer as we found ourselves last Summer, with the army in the field reduced so low as to be unable to act on the offensive, and with no organized reserves ready to reinforce it. The natural result of such a state of things as this, is, of course, a long period of inaction, during the very best weather of the year, with a fair prospect of the Winter setting in just as we are once more ready for the field.
headline: {'main': 'The Depletion of Our Army The Imperative Demand for Reserves.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Depletion of Our Army The Imperative Demand for Reserves.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The hearing in the habeas corpus case of JAMES J. HAMBLETON, the Georgia spy, reported in yesterday's TIMES, did not take place yesterday morning according to adjournment, owing to the absence of the parties on whom the writ was served. At the opening of the General Sessions. Judge MCCUNN presiding, WM.C. TRAPHAGEN, counsel for HAMBLETON, arose and stated to the Court that Capt. ARMSTRONG, who had his client in custody when last before His Honor, had not seen fit to obey the order of the Court for the production of the prisoner, and he therefore moved that an attachment issue against him for contempt. The Judge granted the motion, and Capt. ARMSTRONG will probably be arrested as soon as found. We learn, however, that he was relieved from duty at the Park Barracks on Tuesday night, and immediately left town. As for HAMBLETON, he also left town on Tuesday, having been sent to Fort Lafayette by order of Gen. WOOL. This action has probably been taken to avoid the trouble of a long argument upon the question of the jurisdiction of the military and civil authorities. It is not at all probable, however, that HAMBLETON would have been released by Judge MCCUNN, if Gen. WOOL had submitted to the investigation, for the evidence of his being here in the interest of the rebels is ample and decisive. Those who have been with him since he has been in custody, say that he is an open, avowed and rampant Secessionist, and before the late battles at Fredericksburgh he frequently expressed the wish that HOOKER would get cut to pieces, and offered to bet odds that he would be. But the course taken by the military authorities to evade an investigation, will afford the Copperheads an opportunity for another blow about the "Lincoln despotism." Albeit, it will be hard for them to get up much sympathy in this community for Mr. JAMES P. HAMBLETON, the black-mail editor of the quondam Southern Confederacy.

abstract: Ireland, Relief Meeting for, at Brooklyn
snippet: Ireland, Relief Meeting for, at Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The grand mass meeting of the citizens of Brooklyn, held last night at the Academy of Music, under the auspices of the "Irish Relief Executive Committee," for the purpose of collecting funds to aid the distress now prevailing in Ireland, was a complete success, in a pecuniary point of view, but not numerically, as the inclement weather deterred many of the ticket holders from attending; the same reason also prevented Gens. SCOTT, MCCLELLAN and FITZ JOHN PORTER from being present. The house was moderately filled by an enthusiastic, patriotic and appreciative audience. The orchestra was occupied by the Navy-yard Band. On the stage were seated the officers of the meeting and invited guests, among whom were all the prominent public and private citizens.

abstract: The thirty-eighth annual meeting of this Society, at Irving Hall yesterday morning, attracted a large audience. Rt. Rev. CHAS, P. MCILVAINE, D.D.,  President of the Society, occupied the Chair, and Rev. JOHN M. KREBS, D.D., opened the proceedings with prayer.
lead_paragraph: The thirty-eighth annual meeting of this Society, at Irving Hall yesterday morning, attracted a large audience. Rt. Rev. CHAS, P. MCILVAINE, D.D., President of the Society, occupied the Chair, and Rev. JOHN M. KREBS, D.D., opened the proceedings with prayer. The Treasurer's report was read by MOSES ALLEN, Esq. The following is an abstract of it: Received in donations and legacies, $91,722 46; sales, $159,197 69 -- making, with balance in the treasury, $251,446 19. Expended -- in manufacturing and issuing, $162,327 89; colportage and the army, $35,528 67; cash for foreign lands, $7,000; all other expenses, as by the Treasurer's report, $34,227 32; total, $239,683 88; balance in the treasury, $12,362 31.

abstract: Col. BENJAMIN RINGGOLD, late of the One Hundred and Third regiment New-York Volunteers, killed on Sunday, the 3d inst., at Suffolk, Va., while gallantly leading his regiment into action, was buried yesterday at Greenwood, with befitting pomp and honor. For two days the remains of the dead soldier lay in state at the Governor's Room, City Hall, under guard of a detachment of the lately-returned Ninth regiment, (Hawkins Zouaves,) and a large number of citizens called to take a last look upon the features of the deceased. Owing, however, to the long time that has elapsed since the Colonel was killed, it was thought inadvisable to confer this gratification, and visitors were fain to content themselves with a sight of the decorated rosewood coffin, the sword, the hat, the immortelles and the funereal trappings. The funeral was under the direction of the Common Council Committee on National Affairs, who, of late, unfortunately, have had large experience in burying the country's heroes, and the arrangements were perfect. The procession left the City Hall, at 1 1/2 o'clock, in the following order, under the direction of Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS:

abstract: -- In our report of the explosion in yesterday's TIMES at the foot of Seventy-eighth-street, East River, was mentioned as the locality. It should have been Seventy-ninth-street. Mr. SETH C. abstract: Mr. MARETZEK, although the best of managers, is the most unfortunate of men. If his singers do not happen to be sick, or to have an appointment with their lawyers in Belgium, the weather is sure to be execrable.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK, although the best of managers, is the most unfortunate of men. If his singers do not happen to be sick, or to have an appointment with their lawyers in Belgium, the weather is sure to be execrable. It is certain to happen that in some way or other there will be a good excuse for a bad attendance. Last evening, when "Ione" -- a work that really pleases our public -- was played, the attendance was of course affected by the storm that awaited the opening of the doors, but there was an indication that, had it not been for these adverse circumstances, the audience would have been measurably up to the old standard.

abstract: Cavalry Raid in Georgia, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -The cavalry (or rather, mounted infantry) force of Col. STREIGHT, which the rebels claim has fallen into their hands, was on its way to Rome, Ga., to destroy the rebel powder-mill and ironworks at that place, and also to break up certain railroad communications. The expedition was projected by General ROSECRANS, and left Corinth under escort of a heavy infantry force, under General DODGE, some three weeks since. Gen. DODGE pushed as far east as Tuscumbia, Ala., and had four fights on his way -- two at Buzzard's Roost, and the others at Bear Creek and Town Creek; -- the precise location of the battle-fields it is difficult to give, but they are all near the line dividing Alabama from Mississippi, in the north. From Tuscumbia STREIGHT's horsemen started across Alabama for Rome. The preceding fights, however, had put the rebels on the alert, and a cavalry force, under the guerrilla FORREST, was detached from BRAGG's army to operate against them. They seem to have very soon fell in with a part of STREIGHT's raiders, and attacked them; but STREIGHT pushed straight on for Rome, relying upon the pluck of his men and the bottom of his horses, and fighting the rebels ceaselessly as he went. Finally the pursuing rebels overmastered him, and took, we know not how large a part of his force, captive -- BRAGG, in his brief report of the affair, claiming that the whole detachment are prisoners.

abstract: Elliott and Dunn at Weehawken
lead_paragraph: A fight for $250 a side, between ELLIOTT and DUNN, came off at 7 o'clock A.M., yesterday, at Weehawken. Twelve rounds were fought in the space of thirty minutes. During the last round DUNN fell upon the ropes, and while in that position was struck by ELLIOTT, which was decided by the referee to be a foul blow. Such being the decision, the fighting ceased, and the crowd dispersed. The scene was witnessed by about 500 of the sporting fraternity, who crossed the river at the Barclay-street and Forty-second-street Ferries. The Sheriff of the county in which it was first proposed to have the encounter, appeared on the ground before the ropes were put up, and urged the "roughs" to advance a few rods on the road, which would place them within the precincts of another county. But the combatants had hardly clasped hands before opening the entertainment, when the Sheriff of that county suddenly made his appearance within the ring, announced his office, and stated that he had not with him a sufficient force to compel them to observe the law, but demanded that they should not disturb the peace. Cries of "Pitch him out," "Give him a clipper," &c., were instantly raised, and before the Sheriff could count ten, he was launched on all fours at a distance of fifty feet from the stakes. About half a dozen policemen in disguise were present, but they made no attempts at interference. As a general thing the betting was in favor of ELLIOTT. On the eleventh round 100 to 40 was offered that ELLIOTT would win. At the conclusion of the fight the combatants were driven from the ground in carriages. It is claimed that ELLIOTT won the first blood, and DUNN the first knock-down. The result of the affair is very unsatisfactory to ELLIOTT's friends, and possibly the parties will arrange for another meeting. ELLIOTT and DUNN are the parties that attempted to fight on Staten Island on Monday, but were prevented by the Police. ELLIOTT is from New-York City, and DUNN from Brooklyn. The ground selected for the fight, yesterday, is situated about two miles back of the Forty-second-street Ferry. Before the principals had arrived a number of rows occurred, during which several of the combatants had their countenances terribly damaged. Among the backers present were Kit Burns, Phil Clare, Mike Norton, Harry Hill, Mike Henry and Tim Riley. As a preliminary arrangement the principals made a private bet of $50. The stakes have not yet been paid over.

abstract: To-day "Holy Thursday," or Ascension Day, the usual church service for the occasion will be performed in Trinity Church, the rector, Rev. Dr. DIX, preaching the sermon. An unusual feature of the service will be the presence of a combination choir, including those of Trinity and of St. George's, Flushing, and numbering sixty men and boys. This is the largest choir of male voices ever heard in the country, and the effect cannot fail to be most imposing. The service (Te Deum and Jubilate) is by NARES, in F. Anthem -- "God is gone up with a merry noise," by CUTLER. The Proper Psalms for the day -- 8th, 15th, 21st -- will be sung to the Anglican chants in common use. It is an interesting feature of the occasion that to-day is the seventeenth anniversary of the consecration of the church. The services will begin at 11 o'clock.

abstract: The steamer Cosmopolitan, which arrived yesterday from Hilton Head, S.C., brought home 198 sick and discharged soldiers, and 1 sick soldiers, to be placed in the hospitals of this City. One of the discharged men -- Corp. C.R. ABBOTT, Company K, Eleventh Maine regiment -- died on the passage, and will be buried in this City. Thirty-two of the discharged men require hospital treatment. They were transferred to the General Hospital at David's Island. Medical Inspector MASSEY was a passenger on the steamer. The vessel, being in the hospital service, will return as soon as some alterations have been made.

abstract: Jackson, Stonewall, the death of
lead_paragraph: In the death of Stonewall JACKSON, the rebels have unquestionably lost by far their greatest military leader, in the peculiar style of strategy which has made his name famous. Immediately after the secession of Virginia he appeared on the scene, and ever since then he has been one of the foremost figures. He was the leader in the first hostile act of the Secessionists of Virginia -- the march upon Harper's Ferry. In the first great action of the war, the battle of Manassas Plains, he took part, and one of his characteristic personal and military qualities, expressed in his title of "Stonewall," here first appeared. In every great battle fought since that time by the main rebel army, and in many minor affairs, he has been a leading actor -- in the Peninsular battles, where he was the first to attack our right; in the second battle of Manassas; at the battle of Antietam; at the battle of Fredericksburgh, and lastly at the battle of Chancellorsville, on the 3d, in which engagement he received his death-wound -- inflicted accidentally, it is said, by one of his own men. His campaign up and down the Shenandoah Valley, in the Spring of last year, and his series of engagements with Gens. BANKS and FREMONT, were only inferior in importance to the six or seven first-class battles in which he played his part. In each of the battles in which he acted subordinately, he was generally assigned to the peculiar and critical duties of opening the assault, making a dashing movement upon the flank or rear, or seizing and holding a point which might be called the key of the situation. In a short letter, written by him about a year ago, in reply to the accusation of having written a piece of sentimental poetry, he denied the poetical imputation, and said that the only ambition of his life was to serve the South, and "give a practical illustration of some of the simplest rules of war." These rules seem to have been celerity of movement, concentration of force, and rapid, persistent and heavy blows on his adversary's most vulnerable point; -- while the body with which he operated he kept in an extraordinary state of mobility. The numerical strength of that force seems to have varied from the twelve or fifteen thousand he commanded in the Shenandoah Valley to the forty thousand he was usually credited with in the great actions.
headline: {'main': 'The Death of Stonewall Jackson.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Death of Stonewall Jackson.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The statements in relation to the sale of the La Crosse Road are conflicting, and calculated to mislead. The whole road from Milwaukee to La Crosse is still in the hands of the receiver, where it will remain until the United States Court at Washington settles the relative rights of the eastern and western sections, or they are settled by the parties procuring the recent sale, and the Milwaukee and Minnesota Company, which has undoubted control of the franchise east of Portage.

abstract: We have advices from Mexico of an important character, by way of Havana, received by the steamship Eagle, which arrived at this port last evening. The latest authentic news from Puebla is to the 23d ult., at which time the city was still in possession of the Mexicans, and was likely to continue so.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Mexico of an important character, by way of Havana, received by the steamship Eagle, which arrived at this port last evening. The latest authentic news from Puebla is to the 23d ult., at which time the city was still in possession of the Mexicans, and was likely to continue so. The French appear to have lost some of the important positions gained by them at the date of our last previous advices, and to have been forced back to the fort of San Javier. One account even goes so far as to say they have abandoned the siege entirely, and have fallen back on their original position at Amalucan, on the road to Amalucan. This, however, is probably an overstatement of the case. A private letter received in Havana states, that since the first occupation of the Fort San Javier, the French army has not obtained any advantage. Several attacks have been made upon various points, but always with ill success, and sometimes with absolute defeat. On the 19th they opened a cannonade upon the Carmen Fort, which lasted forty hours, when a breach was made. Several columns then proceeded to make an assault, but they were driven back by the bayonet, leaving the streets filled with their killed and wounded. Their losses have been very heavy.

abstract: Yesterday the anniversary of the above Society was held at Irving Hall. The exercises were opened with prayer and singing, after which the President of the Society, WILLIAM A. BOOTH, Esq., made a brief address. He alluded to the objects of the institution, and the general plan of its operations, and concluded by introducing to the audience Rev. Mr. WARREN, Secretary of the Society, whom he had invited to draw up a statement of facts connected with the management of that body. Mr. WARREN read a lengthy report, which covered in detail the system of operation adopted by the Society. The administration of it is divided into two parts -- the business and the charitable departments. The nature of those parts and the relation existing between them were next considered. It was the province of the business department to provide for the sale of all books, tracts and publications manufactured by the Society, and to attend to the accounts, and all matters pertaining to the financial branch of the institution. That department pays from the proceeds of its sales all its own expenses, of whatsoever kind, and all the general expenses of the Society, save those directly connected with its charitable work. It has also, during the past four years, paid in all $7,488 24 of the cost of administering the Charitable Department; and should its business increase as rapidly as it has done. It will, as is hoped, soon sustain the whole cost of that administration, or even have a surplus to add to the charitable funds, as is the case with the Religious Tract Society of London. There have been printed during the year as follows: Of Tracts, in the 12mo. series, 1,220,000 copies; envelope tracts, 576,000; pocket tracts, on tinted paper, 116,000; children's tracts, each with an engraving, 72,000; square miniature tracts, 15,000; hymns, in small leaflets, 60,000; total, 2,079,000 copies, comprising 10,208,000 pages. Volumes, including stitched pamphlets in covers, 382,303 copies, embracing 36,061,885 pages. Papers, Tract Journal, 647,800 copies; Child at Home, 1,595,000: Christian Banner, 630,000. Whole amount of printing done -- tracts and books, -- 46,269,895 pages; papers, 2,872,800. The receipts in cash for publications sold were $52,149 19; from the Charitable Department for grants, $30,705 39; making a total amount of $82,654 58. There have been expended for publications as above, $67,793 86; salaries of Treasurer, Depositary and Clerks, freight, cartage, stationery, interest, repairs, &c. $12,207 65: making a total of $80,001 51.

abstract: Hon. ROBERT OULD, the rebel Commissioner for the exchange of prisoners, came down the James River to Newport's News, yesterday, to confer with Col. LUDLOW, the United States Commissioner, in reference to the delivery to the latter of the large number of officers and men now in Richmond, recently captured at Fredericksburgh. Transports were sent up to City Point for them this morning. Suitable provision has been made for the sick and wounded.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Tuesday, May 12.

abstract: Rebel Negro Troops at Grand Gulf
snippet: Rebel Negro Troops at Grand Gulf
lead_paragraph: We have, from one of our Mississippi gunboat correspondents, confirmation of the statement already made by our correspondent with Gen. GRANT'S land force, that the troops who manned the rebel batteries and fought the action, in the recent battle at Grand Gulf, were negroes. The writer is in a position to speak knowingly, for he was not only present at the engagement, but, we believe, had a hand in it, and saw the enemy with his own eyes, as well as felt him. He says:

abstract: By the arrival of the English steamer Clyde at Havana, from Vera Cruz, and the steamer Eagle at this port, from Havana, files of papers from the Mexican Republic have been received, containing full details of the operations of the siege of Puebla.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the English steamer Clyde at Havana, from Vera Cruz, and the steamer Eagle at this port, from Havana, files of papers from the Mexican Republic have been received, containing full details of the operations of the siege of Puebla. Those in the French interest and the papers that favor the Mexican Government are very discordant in their accounts, giving often an entirely different version of the same affair, as will be seen in the accounts of the battle at Atlixco. The accompanying extracts from a Vera Cruz paper, the Eco del Comercio, are evidently written to mystify the world, for the diary of the siege proves that the resistance is obstinate, and that FOREY, instead of taking the place, has been driven back to San Javier, the fort which he took at the commencement of the siege -- or which he rather destroyed, for it was only a heap of ruins when he occupied it.
headline: {'main': 'IMPORTANT FROM MEXICO.; Advices from Puebla to the 23d ult. A DIARY OF THE SIEGE. The Mexicans Resolute, and the French Losing Ground. They Are Driven Back to the Fort San Javier. abstract: The State Convention of
lead_paragraph: We are glad to know that large preparations are being made to insure that the Convention of the Loyal Leagues of the State, to be held at Utica on the 27th inst., in pursuance of the resolution of the great Madisonsquare gathering, shall be worthy of the occasion. The design is to give concentrated expression to the war spirit of the Empire State. If properly carried out, it cannot fail to have a prodigious influence in reassuring and reanimating the loyal people throughout the North. New-York has an influence proportioned to her magnitude and power. When she speaks at all, she is listened to; when she speaks with emphasis, she is sure to carry a special moral force.

abstract: The Rappahannock has been passed, probably for the last time, by the grand army of the Potomac. It is scarcely possible that the successor of Gen. Judas HOOKER will again attempt to carry it on to Richmond by the mail route. Where the army of the Potomac will next turn its dismal steps, and where it will next be beaten is yet unknown. It is certain, however, that it must move somewhere. From the beginning of the war to this hour it has led the life of that famous "Joe," whose name and fate have been rendered familiar to the world by the most popular of living writers:

abstract: The Siege of Puebla
lead_paragraph: We give this morning a brief, but thoroughly reliable, letter from our Vera Cruz correspondent, in addition to the full advices from Mexico which appeared in our columns yesterday. These late advices are by the English mail packet, from Vera Cruz 1st inst., at Havana. The monthly steamer from Vera Cruz brings usually the latest and most reliable Mexican intelligence. In this instance, the news from Puebla is no later than the 23d ult., when it should have been to the 29th. The reason given for this is, that Gen. FOREY had absolutely interdicted the transmission of all dispatches to the seaboard. This interdiction is proof positive of an unfortunate state of affairs among the invaders. Such advices as we have, however, are highly important, as corroborating this view of the matter.

abstract: The British frigate Rinaldo arrived this afternoon, having left Charleston at 3 P.M. last Monday.  By this steamer a copy of the Charleston Daily Courier, of May 11, has been received, which contains the announcement of the death of Gen. THOMAS J. JACKSON, known as "Stonewall JACKSON." It states that he died at Guinea, Virginia, on the 10th, at 3 o'clock P.M., from the combined effect of his wound and an attack of pneumonia.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Wednesday, May 14, 1863.

abstract: EDWIN WHITE has now on the easel at his studio in the New-York University, a picture of unusual interest. The subject belongs to a period in whose picturesque and poetical art material he is perhaps more thoroughly at home than any other American painter, and is treated with a vivacity of composition and color which testify how fully heart and hand sympathized in the work. He calls it "RAPHAEL explaining his fresco of the Incendie del Borgo." The scene is one of the apartments of the Vatican, assigned for ornamentation to the great painter. In the centre is a group of visitors, consisting of three ladies of rank and an aged ecclesiastic, to whom RAPHAEL, standing a little to the left, is explaining his study for the fresco. This group affords a happy opportunity for the application of Mr. WHITE's studies in middle-age costume and is full of spirit and beauty. The rich draperies of the ladies, who stand with their faces toward the artist, and the fine sitting figure of the monk, with his sombre robes and beautiful old head, form a most charming harmony of lines and hues. Behind these, on the lofty wall, is seen the fresco in progress, its bold, nude forms in striking contrast with the quiet elegance of the living group below. Just over the heads of the latter, on a light scaffolding, some pupils and workmen are busily engaged on the fresco; one lays on the plaster and one mixes the colors, while GIULIO ROMANO rapidly applies to the moist surface. On the right, a dark massive curtain, which conceals the entrance and arranged with artistic skill to supply the depth of space and breadth of effect wanting in the bare and unarchitectural camera, sweeps from the ceiling to the floor. To persons of refined culture this picture, when completed, will be a rare treat.

abstract: The NEW-YORK TIMES appears this morning printed on paper imported by the proprietors from Belgium. It is white, and of texture sufficiently good for newspaper use. It was bought in Belgium for seven and a half cents per pound, at the very time when the Paper Makers' Association or combination here had, by simultaneous action, forced printing paper up to twenty-two and twenty-four cents the pound.
lead_paragraph: From the Evening Post.

abstract: We have advices from Gen. GRANT's army to Thursday of last week, which render the report of a battle at Clinton donbtful. On Thursday he was eighteen miles from Grand Gulf, and encamped near the Black River. There may, however, have been a skirmish of an advanced force at Clinton. Heavy reinforcements were being received by Gen. GRANT, preparatory to operations of importance. No part of the railroad was yet in our possession. Congressman WASHBURNE, who arrived at Cairo, yesterday, from Gen. GRANT's army on Wednesday of last week, reports the advance as then being within fifteen miles of Edwards' Station, which is but eighteen miles east of Vicksburgh.

abstract: On the 6th of May there was a commotion at Port au Prince, caused by an insurrection, headed by Gen. AIME LE GROS, who had betaken himself to a village called Dessaline, in the Department Artibonite. On his way he was joined by some partisans in his foolish attempt to overthrow the Government of GEFFRARD. The good sense of the people, however, soon settled the matter, for, in 48 hours, he was arrested and was expected to be brought to Port-au-Prince.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's new and excellent opera of "Aroldo" will be given here for the last time to-night, the principal roles being sustained by Mme. ORTOLANI, BRIGNOLI, Signor MAZZOLENI and Signor BELLINI. The work is most admirably placed on the stage, and is presented and performed in a way that would be considered creditable in the leading opera-houses of Europe. This, however, is the case with all the operas produced under the management of Mr. MAX MARETZEK.

abstract: Mercantile Library. Annual Meeting
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the Mercantile Library Association was held Tuesday evening at their rooms, Hon. JOHN COCHRANE presiding. abstract: This regiment arrived here early yesterday morning in the steamer Kennebec, and proceeded without delay to Albany. It went out two years ago with over one thousand men and returns with 430. There are a number of men, however, whose term of service has not yet transpired. This portion will be consolidated with a portion of the Ninth New-York, who have also a longer term to serve.

abstract: This favorite regiment -- 400 men -- arrived in the City yesterday, at 2 P.M., having left Washington at noon the day previous, and Falmouth, Va., on Tuesday. Their presence at the Jersey City terminus of the route was the signal for a large gathering of people, and as the regiment proceeded on board the ferry-boat they were honored with enthusiastic cheers. Since the formation of the Fifth army corps the Fourteenth has been one of its conspicuous regiments. It took an active part in nearly all the engagements on the Peninsula, and subsequently in the battles before Washington, those in Maryland, and the recent terrible conflicts at Fredericksburgh and Chancellorsville. In every instance the regiment has heroically performed its duty, and achieved imperishable renown. The commander of the Fourteenth, Col. JAMES MCQUADE, has been esteemed from the first for his military ability and daring, and upon more than one occasion has been made the recipient of congratulations from his superior officers. For a long period he was Acting Brigadier-General of a brigade. The regiment yesterday was in command of Lieut. Col. DAVIS, Col. MCQUADE having temporarily yielded the post, in consequence of injuries in the foot, which he recently sustained while riding a fractious horse. The troops were received at the foot of Cortlandt-street by a Committee of the Sons ot Oneida, and by them escorted to the Park Barracks, where the men were furnished with a good dinner. In the meantime the officers and Committee repaired to the Astor House and partook of a sumptuous repast provided under the auspices of the Sons of Oneida. At 5 P.M., the regiment, headed by a band, marched to the Hudson River Railroad depot and took the cars for Hudson. To-day they will be publicly received by the citizens of that place. Company K is made up entirely from young men of Hudson. On the following day they will proceed to Albany, thence to Utica, when they will again be entertained with a reception. The following is a list of the officers:

abstract: The steamship America arrived at Halifax yesterday, with advices from Europe two days later She left Liverpool on the 2d, and Queenstown on the 3d inst. The news is not specially important. It is announced by the London Shipping Gazette that the case of the Alexandra, (supposed rebel gunboat,) is the first case to be tried in the Court of Exchequer, Westminster, before a special jury. The Times makes a statement that the United States Government has resolved to send an agent to England, versed in maritime and international law, to cooperate with Mr. ADAMS in London, in order that questions likely to arise may be settled promptly, instead of being subjects of tedious correspondence. The announcement had been made in Parliament that our Government had decided to forward the mails of the Peterhoff to their destination, and it was received with cheers. The London Observer, in a pacific article, does justice to President LINCOLN and his advisers, who, it says, evince a sincere and earnest desire to cultivate the most friendly relations with Great Britain, and to avoid giving just cause of offence. From Poland, we learn that several collisions have occurred between the revolutionists and the Russians, in which the former have generally been successful. It appears not unlikely that the Polish question will yet result in serious European complications. It is reported that all the Danish ships-of-war are to be put in commission, and that the army is to be mobilized. A French fleet of seven ships-of-war, including iron-clads, was at Cherbourg, and it was believed its destination was the Swedish port of Carlskrona. A Russian force had been defeated by 3,000 Circassians, and the Grand Duke MICHAEL narrowly escaped capture. The Liverpool Cotton market was firmer, and prices were slightly higher. Breadstuff's and Provisions were steady. Consols 93 2/8.

abstract: This gallant body of men, commanded by Col. FRANCIS E. PINTO, will leave for home in a few days. They have served two years, and in actual engagements numbering twelve. The precent officers are from promotions for gallant conduct on the field, and only two who have not served the whole period in some capacity. This says much, and is as it should be, on the part of the Colonel, for recommending those entitled to promotion from his own ranks. Mark them, and see if you cannot observe cleanliness, discipline and general soldierly appearance, which can only be accomplished by a positive will to instruct, as also a good will to retain. Each man seems to pride himself on his position, from the Colonel down. They numbered, on leaving 1,000, and now number some 400.

abstract: Order against Traitors and Spies; Vallandigham--Gen. Burnside
snippet: Order against Traitors and Spies; Vallandigham--Gen. Burnside
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead journals, with their habitual eagerness to turn every event to some factious end, are denouncing Gen. BURNSIDE for the summary arrest and military trial of the notorious VALLANDIGHAM. They set themselves forward as the peculiar guardians of constitutional law, and affect to be terribly concerned lest the last vestige of American liberty should be crushed out by the ruthless heel of military power. A cool spectator would imagine that all the Orator Puffs of the planet had been turned in upon us for our sins.

abstract: Generalship and Political Sentiment
lead_paragraph: The blast blown by the Abolitionists, at their recent meeting, against all Generals who do not hold their opinions on the Slavery question, is an exact and appropriate response to the lamentations of the Copperheads over the downfall of MCCLELLAN. TO neither of these parties are our officers' military qualities of the slightest consequence. The one thing they seek for in "the chief of their choice" is the profession of certain "views," religious and political, which they think of the utmost importance to the State. In the laudations lavished by WENDELL PHILLIPS on FREMONT and HUNTER and BUTLER, and in his invectives against the Administration for not giving them the entire conduct of the war, there is little or no stress laid on their military skill, for about this absolutely nothing is known. Not one of them has had charge of operations of any magnitude for more than a few days, and not one has commanded in a general action of any importance. So that all this extravagant praise of them is based on the curious presumption that, inasmuch as they are strongly opposed to Slavery in principle as well as in fact, they would be sure, if placed at the head of great armies, to play havoc with any enemy fighting in defence of it. It seems strange that, after two years' experience of war, there should be any body of intelligent or educated men amongst us who suppose that moral sentiments are a measure of intellectual faculties; that such is the case, is a fresh illustration of the danger of devoting one's self exclusively to the contemplation of any one subject. It is as absurd to conclude from HUNTER's or FREMONT's hostility to Slavery that he possesses the necessary qualifications for conquering armed and organized slaveholders, as to conclude that he is a good architect because he admires fine buildings, or a good lawyer because he hates fraud, or a good mining engineer because he loves gold.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, several papers were introduced in relation to the subject of street-cleaning. Six sub-contractors and the foremen of laborers in several Wards engaged under the present contract, remonstrated against any abrogation of it till provision is specifically made to pay them their arrears -- about six weeks' pay. These remonstrances and a message from the Mayor, stating that the Health Commissioners had ordered a transfer of the work of street-cleaning to the City Inspector, and requesting that a provisional appropriation be made to carry it on till the expenditure shall be recovered by a suit at law from the sureties of the Hackley contract, were all laid over. The Committee on National Affairs submitted a statement, which was laid over. It sets forth that, being without specific directions as to the manner in which to receive the New-York two year regiments returning home, they had used their own judgment in the matter, but as the costs of the receptions so far given have much exceeded their anticipations -- already amounting to over $14,000 -- and in view of the fact that many more returning regiments are soon to arrive, they ask for definite instructions how to receive them, and what expense to incur. A petition was presented from persons whose houses and furniture were injured by the recent powder explosion in Seventy-eighth-street, asking for reparation, the parties owning the magazine where the explosion occurred having located it there on a permit from the Mayor. Referred to a Special Committee of live. The Board adjourned to 3 o'clock P.M. on Saturday, when the report of the Committee on Cleaning Streets, in favor of abrogating the Hackley contract, will be taken up.

abstract: Messrs. H.H. LEEDS & Co. will sell at auction, at the Dusseldorf Gallery, on the evenings of May 21 and 22, a collection of modern pictures, consisting of original specimens by artists of the schools of Dusseldorf, Holland, France, Belgium and England, among which are the works of Haman, Boettcher, Shelf hout, Eugene Verboechoven, Sidney, R. Percy, Cobbet, Vautier, &c. Also, several rare examples by American artists, as Leutze, Eastman, Johnson, Cropsey, Gignoux, Sully, Hays, Tait, G.C. Lambdin, Shattuck, Bingham, Sonntag, &c.

abstract: -- A monster plant of the Daphne Cneorum, a hardy evergreen in full flower is now on exhibition at MILLER's Horticultural Depot, No. 634 Broadway. It was raised by A.G. BURGESS, of East New-York, Long Island. The plant attains a height of one foot, is covered all the season with bright pink flowers and very fragrant, and is admirably adapted for garden, lawn and cemetery purposes.

abstract: Inauguration of a in New-York
lead_paragraph: The Legislature, at its last session, appropriated $200,000 for the care and protection of soldiers of this State returning from the seat or war. Under this appropriation the Board controlling the expenditure, and consisting of Adjt.-Gen. SPRAGUE, Inspector-General MILLER, Quartermaster-General TALCOTT and Surgeon-General QUACKENBUSH, have arranged a depot in this City, on the corner of Howard and Mercer streets, called the Soldiers' Rest, and established a very complete and well-conceived plan for the protection of returning volunteers.

abstract: That very pleasant custom of the Congregationalists in connection with their anniversary, of having a social gathering by way of dessert after disposing of the heavy courses of annual reports and addresser, was observed last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Neither the cold rain nor the absence of the usual collation and cheering cup of tea (heretofore an incident of these occasions,) were sufficient drawbacks to the assembling of a large audience in which the ladies largely predominated. But, lacking a material repast, there was an abundant "feast of reason and flow of soul" to repay all comers. Brighter flashes of wit, and keener sallies of humor have never delighted and amused a happier audience. The

abstract: National Intelligencer on Extravagant Journalism
lead_paragraph: -- The National Intelligencer remonstrates with great force against the habit of dealing in extravagant language concerning the merits and proposed projects of Generals in the field, in advance of expected engagements. The effect of such excessive laudation is to beget undue expectations in the public mind, and to induce a corresponding depression and disappointment in the event of failure. We concur fully in the timely justice of the Intelligencer's remarks on this subject: indeed, our readers would recognize in them little more than a repetition, after the event, of cautions and suggestions to precisely the same effect which we made before Gen. HOOKER's recent advance and failure. As long ago, for example, as on the 30th of April, we took occasion to protest against indulging toward Gen. HOOKER any of the extravagancies of language or of expectation with which it had been common to herald the movements of our commanding Generals. One sentence from that article will serve to show its drift, as well as the general tone of all our articles on that subject. We said:

abstract: Congressional Elections in
lead_paragraph: It is gratifying to discover that unconditional loyalty to the Government is the prevailing sentiment of Kentucky politics, and that this sentiment grows more unanimous with the lapse of time. It has been feared in some quarters that Kentucky was inclined to be as much against the Administration as against the rebels, and that, in trying to balance between the two, her influence would be neutral, if not decidedly against the Government, in the vigorous prosecution of the war.

abstract: From every side we hear that the spoils left by HOOKER'S army exceed these on any previous battlefield, not excepting the engagements around Richmond. Not only an immense number of small arms  variously estimated from 30,000 to 50,000 but an almost infinite quantity of overcoats, knapsacks, caps and blankets.
lead_paragraph: From every side we hear that the spoils left by HOOKER'S army exceed these on any previous battlefield, not excepting the engagements around Richmond. Not only an immense number of small arms -- variously estimated from 30,000 to 50,000 -- but an almost infinite quantity of overcoats, knapsacks, caps and blankets. An idea of the sp its may be gathered from the statement made to us by an artillery officer in regard to the men of his battery. He says that the country is so strewn with blankets, &c., that his men in marching from one field to another, since the late battles, have never cumbered themselves with anything, being satisfied that wherever they may camp for the night a plenty of blankets and overcoats will be found. Shall these things be gathered up, or thrown away, left to rot, or to be collected by negroes and citizens, who, after all the trouble of getting them together, are to be insulted for so doing? We trust most sincerely that Quartermaster MYERS will show a proper efficiency in this important matter.

abstract: Official advices from Gen. GRANT to the 8th inst. have been received in Washington. He expresses himself as satisfied with the condition of affairs in his vicinity. His satisfaction seems to be justified by the tone of a rebel letter from Vicksburgh, published in the Jackson Appeal, which takes a gloomy view of affairs, and says that Gen. GRANT'S movement has deceived the rebels, both civil and military.
lead_paragraph: Official advices from Gen. GRANT to the 8th inst. have been received in Washington. He expresses himself as satisfied with the condition of affairs in his vicinity. His satisfaction seems to be justified by the tone of a rebel letter from Vicksburgh, published in the Jackson Appeal, which takes a gloomy view of affairs, and says that Gen. GRANT'S movement has deceived the rebels, both civil and military. Our dispatches by way of Cairo state that our troops, all the way from Memphis to Young's Point, are moving to reinforce Gen. GRANT, who will endeavor to cut the railroad between Vicksburgh and Jackson, and who expects to fight a battle in the vicinity of the Big Black River Bridge. He has also notified the War Department that Port Hudson is undoubtedly evacuated, except by a small garrison and the heavy artillery. The greater portion of the troops recently there have probably been withdrawn for the defence of Jackson, and for cooperation with the Vicksburgh garrison.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- An excellent performance of "Aroldo" was given last night, to the usual indifferent attendance. All the artists were in fine voice, except Signor MAZZOLENI, who has hardly recovered, and the work -- which merits more favor than it has received at the hands of the public -- was received with applause. Mr. MARETZEK cannot thrive on this, and judiciously announces that the season will terminate on Monday, when PETRELLO's opera of "Ione" will be given, for the last time. It is clea[???] of no use to struggle against the stream. The public don't want any more opera for the moment.

abstract: For May, from Le Follet
lead_paragraph: One of the first inquiries just now with regard to fashion is, what will be the form for mantless this summer? We really cannot inform our readers of very much novelty in out-of-door garments. That called saute-en-barque last year, rather shorter and slightly more fitting, is in favor. Collets or camails to match the dress are also much seen. They are frequently trimmed like the skirt, and lined with white taffetas or foulard. The latter is an extremely suitable material for linings. A band of taffetas, trimmed with braid, or a wide grecque of taffetas ribbon, is a style of trimming much used for the collet, when made of fancy material, alpaca or mohair.

abstract: On Rebel Emancipation
lead_paragraph: WENDELL PHILLIPS, in his speech on Monday night, spoke of the danger that the rebels may adopt an emancipation policy, and asked, argumentatively, "If loyal men will surrender their slaves to save the Union, don't you suppose the disloyal will surrender theirs to save the Confederacy?"

abstract: The American and Foreign Christian Union has Missions in the United States, South America, Mexico, Sweden, Belgium, France, Italy and Greece. The missions in the United States are among the French, German, Italians and Irish Catholics, and confined principally to the great cities. In South America there are three Mission Stations, and the missionaries have been doing a good work. In Mexico, there is a Station at Matamoras. In Peru and Brazil they hope during the year to supply the places of those missionaries who have left. In Belgium, they aid a native Home Missionary Society in supporting fifty laborers, with forty-five churches, and 15,000 attendants, where, in 1835, hardly a Protestant could be found. In France, as in Belgium, the funds go into the treasuries of native Missionary Societies. They aid three, "The Central Protestant Society of Paris," "The Evangelical Society of France" and "The Evangelical Church of Lyons," which is also a Missionary Society. These employ in France about 170 laborers. In Sweden they have one Missionary, Rev. Mr. ROSENIUS. In Italy Rev. E.E. HALL is the Missionary agent at Florence, directing their work, and employing, for the whole or a part of the year, twenty laborers, -- double the number of the previous year. During the season of Lent he hired a large room, and secured the services of GAVAZZI, who preached for the forty days in succession to crowds of people. In Greece they have commenced a mission in Athens. The missionary, Rev. GEORGE CONSTANTINE, is a native Greek, educated in this country, and enters upon his labors with good prospects. In the same city they have aided Dr. KALOPOTHAKES, also a native Greek educated in this country, and for the last four years publishing a paper in Athens called The Star of the East. There are also two American chapels, one at Paris and one at Florence -- the first under the care of Rev. Dr. MCCLINTOCK, the last under Rev. Mr. HALL. Since the last Anniversary they have sent out three missionaries: one to Belgium, Rev. Mr. BRANDT, a native of Holland, educated in this country, and connected with the Reformed Dutch Church. One to Italy, Rev. Mr. MOOREHEAD, connected with the United Presbyterian Church. He is so far advanced in the Italian language that he expects soon to go to Sienna to make trial of his gifts. 3d. Rev. GEO. CONSTANTINE and Mrs. CONSTANTINE, to Athens, Greece.

abstract: The enemies of the Government have taken much comfort from the fact that a considerable portion of the volunteer force now in the field would soon be withdrawn from the Union armies by the expiration of their terms of enlistment. The reduction of our military strength from this source has indeed given some uneasiness to the loyalists of the North, and they have anxiously inquired how a like force was to be put in the field promptly enough to take the place of the returning volunteers.

abstract: Gignoux R.; The Alps by sunrise
snippet: Gignoux R.; The Alps by sunrise
lead_paragraph: This is the name given by GIGNOUX to his last and best work, now on exhibition at Goupil's Gallery, and which is attracting the attention and admiration of all lovers of art. Without being a portrait of any particular locality, it yet possesses, in a sufficient degree, enough of the general features of Switzerland, its ice-capped mountains, its placid lakes, its verdant plains, its rocky hills and shadowy valleys, to warrant the assumption that it conveys, even to those who have never visited that land, a correct idea of the Bernese Alps and the surrounding country. Heretofore little credit has been awarded GIGNOUX for any expression of tenderness in his pictures; aught in their treatment like poetry or sentiment, seemed foreign to this nature, and while he gave us, so to speak, the strong prose of autumn in brilliant reds and yellows, he never presented us with the delicate poetry of Spring-time with its light tints of green and blue. This feeling, however, is pleasingly apparent in the present picture, which is an eminently thoughtful and suggestive one, breathing the very spirit of rural peace and quietude. It is in marked contrast, both in its subject and color, to his "Indian Summer," though it possesses the same freedom of execution and harmonious management of light and shade which characterise that work. The luminous nature of the atmosphere is skillfully expressed, and the aerial perspective, observable in the immense distance given to the mountains, is admirably carried out.
headline: {'main': 'The Alps by Sunrise.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Alps by Sunrise.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Chattanooga Rebel says: "As yet we have received no particulars of the killing of Gen. VAN DORN, nor of the causes which led to it, other than from street rumors, which, if correct, would seem that the killing was justifiable. Dr. PETERS, who killed him, was formerly State Senator from Hardeman County, in this State, and is a gentleman of wealth, position and influence, whose family connections rank with the first in Tennessee. He is reported to have approached Gen. VAN DORN in the street, and, presenting a pistol, shot him in the head."

abstract: -- The operation of recto-vesical lithotomy was performed for the first time successfully in New-York, on Monday, by EDWARD H. DIXON, M.D., in presence of a number of our surgeons and physicians. The patient was Mr. GEORGE LOW, of Muscatine, Iowa. He had been afflicted with the disease for thirty-seven years. Peculiar interest attached to this case, from the fact that the stone, from its long presence in the base of the bladder, had sunk downward, and formed for itself a sack, and protruded into the bowel, making, as it were, two separate bladders. No instrument could be introduced to guide the knife, in the usual way of operating, from the fact that the large size of the stone made pressure upon the urethra. All had to depend on the tact of the surgeon, and his knowledge of the anatomy of the parts. In less than a minute the stone lay on the table, undergoing the surgical scrutiny of the gentlemen who were present. It will gratify Mr. LOW's friends to know that his condition is very comfortable, and there is no doubt of his complete recovery, and surgeons will find a new resource for a complicated disease in this rare operation. -- Tribune.
lead_paragraph: -- The operation of recto-vesical lithotomy was performed for the first time successfully in New-York, on Monday, by EDWARD H. DIXON, M.D., in presence of a number of our surgeons and physicians. The patient was Mr. GEORGE LOW, of Muscatine, Iowa. He had been afflicted with the disease for thirty-seven years. Peculiar interest attached to this case, from the fact that the stone, from its long presence in the base of the bladder, had sunk downward, and formed for itself a sack, and protruded into the bowel, making, as it were, two separate bladders. No instrument could be introduced to guide the knife, in the usual way of operating, from the fact that the large size of the stone made pressure upon the urethra. All had to depend on the tact of the surgeon, and his knowledge of the anatomy of the parts. In less than a minute the stone lay on the table, undergoing the surgical scrutiny of the gentlemen who were present. abstract: The above regiment returned from the seat of war yesterday. Two years ago they left the State with over 900 men; they came back numbering 300. The regiment was raised by Col. JACKSON, late Inspector-General of the State, and, after his death, was commanded by Col. YOUNG, who resigned. The regiment is now in command of Col. MYERS. Temporary accommodations were provided for the troops at the Park barracks. After partaking of a dinner they marched to the Hudson River Railroad depot, and took the cars for Albany.

JACKSON, late Inspector-General of the State, and, after his death, was commanded by Col. YOUNG, who resigned. The regiment is now in command of Col. MYERS. Temporary accommodations were provided for the troops at the Park barracks. After partaking of a dinner they marched to the Hudson River Railroad depot, and took the cars for Albany.

abstract: "The War, and its Influence on Commerce, Education, Religion, and the duties it imposes on the Citizen," is the subject of a series of Sunday evening discourses by Rev. B. PETERS, in the Universalist Church, corner of South Third and Fourth streets, Williamsburgh. The second lecture of the course. "The Influence of the War on Religion," will be delivered to-morrow evening. Mr. PETERT is one of the most devoted Unionists in the Brooklyn pulpit, and has been outspoken in his advocacy of the rights of the Government, and the atrocity of the rebellion from its incipiency to the present time; and is now, in this series of lectures, inculcating the most patriotic views, and giving Copperheadism some of the severest thrusts it meets with.

abstract: Board of foreign Missions; Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The above meeting took place yesterday, at 10 A.M., at Irving Hall, and was presided over by WILLIAM E. DODGE, Esq. The exercises commenced with prayer by Rev. Dr. ASA SMITH, which was followed by singing, in which the congregation joined. The Chairman then addressed the meeting. He referred to the high rate of exchange on foreign countries, consequent upon the war, and considered that it should not influence the Board to fail to remit the usual sums to the Missionaries abroad. The early operations of the Society were briefly dwelt upon, and in that connection the speaker feelingly alluded to the conversion of the veteran WINSLOW, who is now laboring as a Missionary in India. The finances of the Society were in a prosperous condition, and evidences were daily accumulating of the millions of souls constantly benefited through the exertions of the Mission.

abstract: -We trust that no one who possesses or can procure a map of the State of Mississippi will fail to follow up the accounts we publish almost daily of the different strategic operations and manoeuvres of Gen. GRANT against Vicksburgh. As we have said before, it is by far the most complicated, interesting and exciting game of strategy that has been played in this war. Every day develops new movements of different kinds at new points in novel ways. To the military student, as well as to the general student, the history of GRANT's siege of Vicksburgh will prove one of the most absorbing chapters of modern war. It is well to follow up this history while it is being made.

abstract: Hambleton Case, the
lead_paragraph: The notorious HAMBLETON, of Georgia, who came on to New-York three years ago or more to extort money from the wholesale dealers of this City, by making out a "black list" containing the names of persons who were inimical to the South, or who refused to pay him for not so considering them, recently had the audacity to show himself here again, and was properly and righteously arrested as a spy and a traitor, and is now properly and righteously held in durance vile. But all this, so far from constituting a reason for not bringing him before the court when a writ of habeas corpus is issued for the purpose, constitutes the strongest possible reason why the writ should be instantly obeyed.

abstract: And Richmond, the Results of Capture of
snippet: And Richmond, the Results of Capture of
lead_paragraph: The public mind has been so much engrossed by the late movement upon Richmond and its unfortunate sequel, that the new movement upon Vicksburgh has excited little attention; and yet the latter promises far more important reslts than could have come from the former, however successful. The fall of Richmond would have been but the fall of a city; the fall of Vicksburgh will be the fall of a half of the Confederacy. The one place can scarcely be called a strategic point; its importance is chiefly factitious as the temporary [???] of an itinerant Government. The other is the very key of the lower Mississippi, and its seizure will unclose military as well as commercial movements for an area of hundreds and even thousands of miles.
