abstract: Lecture on what shall be done with the negroes
snippet: Lecture on what shall be done with the negroes
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Academy of Music was filled to repletion last evening by an audience of ladies and gentlemen, assembled to hear the colored orator, FREDERICK DOUGLASS. The speaker was introduced by Postmaster LINCOLN, and commenced by saying that the great question before the public at present was, "What shall be done with the negro?" The word negro had become the most frequent word in the language. Amid the conflict of opinion and the thunder and smoke of battle, the negro looms up, and will continue to do so until the question with regard to him is settled on the basis of justice. He proposed to-night to advocate the adoption of the negro into the family of the nation on terms of the most perfect equality as the only salvation of the country. The only way to secure peace to the nation was to do justice to the negro. He must not only be given freedom, but must be admitted to all the privileges of a citizen of the United States. Heretofore the negro had been regarded only as the means of putting money in the white man's pocket, like a bale of cotton, but hereafter he must be regarded and treated as a man. Under the past treatment of the negro we had seen nothing but the most abject servility from the North to the South; and what was our reward? Half a million of armed men were now seizing at the throat of the Government and threatening the destruction of the Republic. Having sacrificed 250,000 of our youths in bloody graves by this rebellion in the interest of Slavery, it was now time that we adopted a new policy. Under the old system, the golden rule. "Do unto others as ye would that they should do unto you," had been found impracticable; the Declaration of Independence had been found impracticable; the Constitution had been found impracticable; even the worthless carcass of the Democratic party had been found impracticable, and the South had broken it up and destroyed it at Charleston. But what, is now asked, shall he done with the negro? There were three or four schemes put forth to settle this question. The first was to reduce all black men to Slavery throughout the entire country, and enact laws to make the system uniform. But the trouble with this plan was that it would create an aristocracy -- a master who would wish to rule all, whether white or black, so that those who did not own slaves would be like the poor whites of the South -- mere trash. The second scheme was to colonize them. This was a very pleasing scheme to a large number of people at the North, but it was like sending missionaries to the moon; it was easy to see what great good they would do when there, but the question was how to get them there. By the time this war was ended there would hardly be money enough left to pay their transportation. Besides, the great trouble has been in years past that there were not negroes enough at the South. They have now tried to revive the Slave-trade for the sake of getting more. And they will need more than ever after the war. It had been said that the negro was lazy, and would not work. This has been the favorite talk even of slaveowners; but how happened it that all Europe was at the point of starvation the moment the industry of the negro was interrupted? Again, it was said that some day or other a war of races would break out, and then the negro would be exterminated. There were men base enough to advocate this. Even in Brooklyn men had lately been driven from their work and mobbed, for no other reason than the color of their skin. The truth was, there was only one way of disposing of the question, and that was to admit the negro to full equality in political and civil rights. He did not wish to be misunderstood. He did not mean to insist on what is called "social equality;" he did not know -- in fact, he much doubted -- if there were such a thing; certainly it had never been developed to his knowledge in history. If it were possible, he did not know but the negro would have as much to dread from it as he white man. Thus far, in the history of this country, the negro had groped about among us un seen -- killed by Slavery in the South, smothered by prejudice in the North; but he was still a man, with aspirations, feelings, courage, hopes, fears. He was not an animal. The laws enacted about him showed that. It is not necessary to pass laws to prevent horses from reading. Congress lately came near passing a law that the negro should never be equal to the white man; thus showing that there was a possibility that he might become so. A great deal was said about the negro intermarrying with the white. He did not ask the Government to regulate this matter, it would regulate itself. All the negro asked was equality before the law. But it was said that the Constitution opposed this. They might he surprised to be told that not one in ten of the white citizens of the United States ever read the Constitution. They are not aware that the word slave is not in it. WENDELL PHILLIPS had said the other day that WM.H. SEWARD refused to give a passport to a negro. That could be explained from the fact that Mr. SEWARD was a lawyer, and knew perfectly well that the Constitution does not know the word negro. He gave passports to American citizens, not to Irishmen, Germans or negroes. The speaker know Mr. SEWARD well, and there was no man freer from prejudice against color than him. The Constitution had been tortured ever since the formation of the Government, to make it mean what it did not say, and what its framers never intended it should say -- all for the protection of slavery. Lastly came the old argument that the negro was an inferior race. If this were true, it would be a mean and blasphemous apology for enslaving him. When a man is on crutches, give him a kick. This was the apology for despotism the world over; the same used by us against the Mexicans, by the Russians against the Turks, by the English against the Irish. And, speaking of the Irish, he was amazed at their conduct here. There was no more generous, warm-hearted, hospitable people at home than the Irish; none who treated oppression and tyranny with a deeper hatred. He never had been treated more kindly than in Ireland; never had his good opinion of human nature more exalted and strengthened than in that Green Isle. And he never could understand how it was that when the Irish get to this country they become the most cruel, the meanest, and most vindictive of all the oppressors of his race. He could not account for it except on the principle that when a man gets suddenly rich he becomes more purse-proud and overbearing than if he were born to riches. Still he believed the Irish would yet become the warmest friends of the negro. There was a remarkable analogy in the history of the two races. Two hundred years ago the Irish were almost as badly persecuted for their religion as the negro is now for his color. When the bastile of Slavery is demolished all this prejudice will cease. When the white race begin to do justice to the negro then they begin to love them. The negro loves the white man and is going to stay with him; he is not going to die out as many think; he does not belong to the die out race; he will rather die in. He must remain with the whites -- even as slaves, it not as freemen; but it were better for you as for him that he be free than slave. And since this must be so, is it not better that he become a free and equal citizen before the law, than that he be an outcast, vicious and criminal? The speaker closed by alluding to the Fifty-fourth regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, (colored,) in which he said he had two sons, and which he expected soon to see march down Broadway, keeping step to the music of "Old John Brown." When the negro got fairly into this war, the end of the rebellion might be looked for. One thing was certain; they would not be in haste to get captured for the sake of being exchanged.

abstract: The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the Elm-place Congregational Church, located in Elm-place, between Fulton-avenue and Livingston-street, took place Thursday afternoon, in presence of a numerous congregation, notwithstanding the threatening state of the weather. The congregation originally worshipped in a small building situated in the rear of the site of the proposed edifice. The popularity of the pastor, Rev. WM. ALVIN BARTLETT, soon made it necessary to procure more accommodation, and, with this object in view, a large building was erected on a lot in the rear of Fulton-avenue, and which has since been known as the Brooklyn Tabernacle. The Tabernacle was intended as a temporary arrangement, and about a year since the trustees concluded to build the new structure which has now been commenced.

abstract: -- A certain portion of the Copperhead newspapers seem to have entered systematically on the business of ascribing to the TIMES articles which never appeared in its columns, and of imputing to its Editor political sentiments which he never entertained. Not long since we pursued with our denials for several weeks a forged extract from what purported to be a speech of the Editor -- yet we see it still going the rounds of the secession prints as a genuine expression of our opinions. The Cooperstown Freeman brings us another pretended extract from our columns, declaring that "martial law over the entire North is a national necessity" -- a sentiment which we never entertained, embodied in a paragraph which never appeared in the TIMES, but was cut from the columns of the Herald. So also we find in the Cleveland Plaindealer an article of over half a column, vindicating the rebel accounts of the affair at Chancellorsville, denouncing Gens. HOOKER, WADSWORTH and SEDGWICK, and assailing the Administration, -- credited to the NEW-YORK TIMES. Nothing of the sort ever appeared in our columns. What the Copperhead newspapers expect to accomplish by this systematic forgery we cannot imagine. In spite of all denials, they will, doubtless, continue to practice it to the end of the chapter.

abstract: Annual Meeting
lead_paragraph: Thursday evening the Academy of Music was crowded on the occasion of the annual meeting of the above institution. GRAFULAL's Seventh Regiment Band was in attendance. Two hundred children of the institution were present, seated on an elevated platform at the rear of the stage, so that upon the rising of the green curtain an exceedingly beautiful effect was produced. Rev. PETER STRYKER was called to preside, and on taking the chair made a few appropriate remarks. The children then sung, with touching effect, a hymn, entitled "Sweet Hour of Prayer." The singing was under the direction of T.B. PERKINS, Esq., Principal of the Normal Musical Academy. A prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. FULLER, after which Rev. R.G. TOLES, Principal of the Institution, read the annual report. There have been received from all sources $15,713 36, of which sum $3,163 50 was donated by Mrs. MERCY M. CARTER, of North Wilmington, Mass., and $12,519 66 from donations and the sale of pictures of children and the Little Wanderer's Friend. The expenses amount to $13,680 69, of which $2,186 41 were paid for provisions, and the balance for salaries, traveling, rent, repairs, printing, &c. The balance in favor of the Mission is $2,062 67. During the year 312 barrels and boxes of provisions, 8 tons of coal, and 151 boxes and packages of clothing, containing more than 13,000 garments, pairs of shoes, boots, and pieces of bedding have been received. 1,224 children have been received and washed, fed, clothed and taught. These represent 734 families, consisting of 4,037 persons.

abstract: Women's Loyal League Organization and Pledge
snippet: Women's Loyal League Organization and Pledge
lead_paragraph: The ladies desiring to perfect a National League held a meeting at Dr. CHEEVER's Church yesterday afternoon to complete their organization. Miss SUSAN B. ANTHONY presided, and there was a large audience present. Both Miss ANTHONY and Mrs. STANTON took occasion to state fully and frankly that while they could not pledge themselves to an unconditional loyalty to the Government, and were loyal only to "freedom and humanity," they did not wish to stand in the way if a larger and more effective League could be formed without them.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of the New-York Produce Exchange was held, yesterday, JAMES P. WALLACE in the Chair, to adopt measures for facilitating communication between the Great West and the Atlantic seaboard. A series of resolutions was offered by Gen. HIRAM WALBRIDGE, and unanimously adopted, setting forth the necessity of increased facilities of communication between the two sections of the country, both in a commercial and military point of view, and appointing a Committee of twenty-five to represent the Produce Exchange in the National Commercial Convention, to be held in Chicago on the 2d prox.

abstract: -- The Burlington Times, of Friday, May 8, says: "A Secessionist named STONE, who is a Vermonter by birth, but has been for some time a resident of Atlanta, Ga., was arrested in St. Albans on Monday by Capt. ROLLA GLEASON, Provost-Marshal, and was sent to Fort Lafayette on Thursday, in charge of Capt. GLEASON. STONE was in Franklin County about two years ago, when he provoked loyal men greatly by his outspoken treason. But a few days since he made his reappearance in Berkshire, where his father lives. Having suspicions of him, Collector CLAPP institued inquiries which confirmed his suspicions. STONE's correspondence by letter and telegraph with parties in New-York was intercepted, and is now held as evidence against him and others of being engaged in a scheme to fit out a blockade-runner and furnish the rebels with supplies, &c., and bring out cotton. STONE has acknowledged their purpose to run the blockade with cotton. STONE was arrested in St. Albans just as he was to take the cars. He was confounded and greatly agitated when the arrest was made. It is known that he had money to operate with. It is said that he has boasted that he saw the Ohio soldiers hang in Atlanta, who were sent out by Gen. MITCHELL to destroy railroad bridges, but were captured. Collector CLAPP has been indefatigable in his endeavors to ferret out the operations of the rascal."

abstract: Resume of his Operations
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago to-day was fought the great battle of Chancellorsville, or, as the rebels prefer to call it, the battle of the Wilderness. One week ago to-day we had news, which stirred the City and the whole country, that Richmond had fallen into our hands, and that Gen. HOOKER'S army had again crossed the Rappahannock, to assail the rebels. The battle of the 3d was a failure, and the reports of the 10th were falsehoods.

abstract: A public meeting in behalf of the Tabernacle of the Christian Alliance, will be held Sunday evening, May 17, at its Hall, the City Assembly Rooms, No. 446 Broadway. Maj.-Gen. ANDERSON, U.S.A., will preside. Addresses may be expected from Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, CHAUNCEY SHAFFER, Esq., Rev. JOHN S. MITCHELL, D.D., and others. Rev. C.C. Goss, the Pastor, will present statistics respecting the lower Wards of the City. This Tabernacle has been opened upon the Union plan, with free seats for the accommodation of the masses, generally strangers and young men, to supply the need once met by the Old Broadway Tabernacle. The support of the enterprise depends altogether upon the voluntary contributions of the public.

abstract: THE SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. -- The inquest on the body of the man found shot through the head Thursday morning, on the West Hoboken road, was held at Hoboken on Friday, before Coroner Bohnstedt. The body was identified as that of OSCAR SCHALK, brother and partner of SCHALK, the extensive beer brewer, at East Newark. From facts before the inquest there is no doubt that deceased was not in his right mind at the time he committed suicide, and a verdict to that effect was rendered.

abstract: "Necessity is the mother of invention," and as an evidence of what a people can do, when cut off from their natural channel of supply, we have been shown a most beautiful speciman of a lady's bonnet, in fact, a "love of a bonnet," made from the cabbage palmetto, a plant which grows extensively in Florida. The bonnet is complete in itself, and trimmed with flowers of the common goose feather, in imitation of the orange blossom and other colors. The skillful artisan of this new evidence of ingenuity among Southern ladies, is Miss ANN ELIZABETH FARMER, of Norfolk, Va., whom we learn, while only following the employment for pastime, has become so skillful in the art, and so enamored of it, that she has determined to procure from Florida a quantity of the material, and manufacture a number of the bonnets.

abstract: People vs. Mayor and Harlem Railroad; Broadway Tracks Enjoined
snippet: People vs. Mayor and Harlem Railroad; Broadway Tracks Enjoined
lead_paragraph: The People of the State of New-York et als. vs. The Mayor and Commonalty of the City of New-York and the Harlem Railroad Company. -- This is a new action which has been commenced by the people to restrain the Harlem Road from laying down their tracks in Broadway. The complaint was served on the Mayor and on the Company on Saturday, 16th inst., together with an order to show cause why an injunction should not issue, pendente lite, restraining the Harlem Company from laying down any tracks on, or interfering with Broadway, for the purpose of locating, a railroad therein. And meanwhile, and until the 25th inst., the day when the order is returnable, the Harlem Railroad is enjoined from taking any steps toward the carrying out their designs on Broadway.

abstract: -- A London correspondent writes to the Boston Transcript: "Those who were present at the last great dinner party given by Mr. Peabody in London will never forget his eloquence when speaking upon the perpetuity of the American Union and the vital importance of keeping every star intact in the banner of the glorious transatlantic Republic. Mr. Peabody's influence, as far as it extends, is constantly exercised in preserving harmonious feelings between the people of America and Great Britian. Mr. Joshua Bates, also of the great firm of Baring Brothers, is as ardent a friend of the Union as any person fighting for it in the National armies, and his large intelligence, wide information and extensive influence are palpably felt on public opinion."

abstract: Ellen Burns vs. Charles Erben and Thomas Frost. This was an action for a false arrest. On Saturday evening, July 6, 1861, the plaintiff, a young sewing girl, and a minor, visited her acquaintance, a chambermaid in the employ of Henry Erben. Soon after she left, it was discovered that a drawer of silver had been stolen from the sideboard in the basement.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Burns vs. Charles Erben and Thomas Frost. -- This was an action for a false arrest. On Saturday evening, July 6, 1861, the plaintiff, a young sewing girl, and a minor, visited her acquaintance, a chambermaid in the employ of Henry Erben. Soon after she left, it was discovered that a drawer of silver had been stolen from the sideboard in the basement. Patrolman Frost was called in, who advised a complaint to be made. Accordingly, Erben proceeded with the policeman to the Station-house, where a complaint was made, and they both proceeded thence to the residence of the plaintiff, with a verbal order for arrest. It was about midnight when they entered plaintiff's room, in a tenant house, and plaintiff was in bed. She was brought before the Sergeant, examined and discharged. The drawer of silver was afterwards found. It appeared to have been stolen while the plaintiff was at Erben's house, conversing with the chambermaid. A noise was heard at the basement door, which the chambermaid remarked was the cook coming home, but upon going to the door it was found unlocked, when she supposed it must have been the cat playing with the oil-cloth. The chambermaid insisted that plaintiff was an honest girl; and stated that to the best of her belief she told them about having heard the noise at the basement door. There was no pretence that the plaintiff was connected with the theft.

abstract: Nearly a thousand complaints have been filed by the United States Collectors for violations of the Internal Revenue law. The United States District Attorney has prepared the papers in a large number of these suits, and taken steps to try them in the Circuit Court. Most of them are against parties who refused or neglected to take out licenses, after proper notification. In some instances, the parties have called at the District Attorney's office and offered to take out licenses. They were allowed to do so upon paying the costs -- about $12.

abstract: New Phase of the Conscription
lead_paragraph: There is news of a decision by the Secretary of War in regard to the Conscription Act that will lead many thousands to take a very different view of the approaching enrolment from what they have hitherto been quietly cherishing. Persons subject to military duty, but who, nevertheless, have no penchant for campaigning, have felt quite comfortable in the possession of three hundred dollars, and have continued to shout lustily for the vigorous prosecution of the war, in the full belief that they would never have to do any of the fighting. Under the Thirteenth Section of the Conscription Act, they understood, they might, with $300, purchase exemption from the draft.

abstract: A MAN SHOT IN THIRD-AVENUE. -- At a late hour on Thursday evening, STEPHEN GEOGHAN was passing down the Third-avenue, when he was met by two men named JAMES O'BRIEN and JOHN MEHAN, near the corner of Thirty-ninth-street. The parties there had a quarrel, and during the melee, GEOGHAN was stabbed several times in the head and face with a knife, in the hands of MEHAN. GEOGHAN thereupon drew a pistol, and shot MEHAN in the thigh, inflicting a dangerous wound. The latter was taken to the New-York Hospital, and GEOGHAN was arrested by the Police of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, and held to await the result.

abstract: Denmark and Germany
lead_paragraph: The "despots of Germany" are hard to please. Formerly they were wroth with the Danish King because he denied liberty to his Teutonic Duchies; and now they are no less indignant because he has proclaimed these same Duchies autonomous. From the alacrity with which Prussia and Austria have protested against the tenor of FREDERIC's proclamation, and from the readiness evinced by Hanover and Bavaria to join in a war against the little Cimbrian Kingdom, it might be supposed that the Government of Copenhagen had inflicted some grievous wrong on the inhabitants of Holstein and Lauenburg, rather than conceded to them privileges which render them the freest and most favored of all of German race. But if the Holsteiners and Lauenburghers are not aggrieved, Fatherland, it seems, is. When a great Power wants to quarrel with a petty Power, a pretext can always be found, even though it may be as shallow as that under color of which the wolf devoured the lamb; and so it is in the present case. There is a "river in Macedon as well as in Monmouth," and there are Germans in Schleswig as well as in Holstein and Lauenburg; and it is because the Danish proclamation presumes to draw a line of demarcation between the former and the latter, and to refuse those privileges to the Teutons of Schleswig which it has granted to their brethren of the Teutonic Duchies, that all this indignation has been manifested, and all these protests and menaces put forth, on the part of the German potentates. So anxious are those despots to establish a casus belli against Denmark, that they keep quite out of view the fact that Schleswig is not a portion of Germany, and that they have no right whatever to call FREDERIC to an account for his treatment of the Germans of that province, however justified they may be in doing so when the people of Holstein and Lauenburg are concerned. The Eyder is the boundary between Scandinavia and Germany; all who dwell north of that river dwell on Danish soil, and the despots in question are no more entitled to interfere between the Danish King and the Teutons of Schleswig, than they are to east the aegis of their protection over the Teutonic citizens of the United States or Mexico. Beside, the Teutons of Schleswig have no very terrible grievance to complain of, their worst one appearing to be that the Danish language is used in the schools and churches of that Duchy in preference to the German.
headline: {'main': 'Denmark and Germany.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Denmark and Germany.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: United States and Cisoo vs. Victor; Texan Frauds
snippet: United States and Cisoo vs. Victor; Texan Frauds
lead_paragraph: The United States and John J. Cisco vs. Theodore Victer et al. -- The plaintiff, having heretofore obtained an injunction restraining defendants from proceeding with an action against Mr. Cisco, who, it will be remembered, had retained certain United States bonds, on the ground that they were the property of the State of Texas at the time of her secession, and that they had been abstracted from the State Treasury, the Judge granted the motion to dissolve the injunction, with $10 costs, and holds that the plaintiffs became the wrong-doers when they detained the bonds which had been submitted to them for inspection. That the plaintiffs were under no obligations to the State of Texas to retain the bonds, nor would they incur any liability to that State, if they returned them to the defendants. That the plaintiffs cannot become volunteers for the protection of supposed rights on the part of Texas, which at present that State does not think proper to claim or enforce. That the United States make no claim to the bonds on their own behalf, except such as may arise from the present position of that State to the Government. That there is nothing to give this Court jurisdiction on any such ground.

abstract: Affairs remain quiet unchanged on the Sea Islands about Charleston. The entente cordiale, which has existed between our own and the rebel pickets, has been some what shaken by a very proper order on the part of one General Commanding there, forbidding personal communication between them. Quite a friendly relation had been established through which an interchange of luxuries have been effected; coffee being bartered for tobacco; the articles crossing the inlet in little sailboats, improvised for the occasion; and at all times the most honorable mode of dealings being observed on either side. Several soldiers having swam the inlet and landed on the rebel shore, and thereafter undergoing a severe and exhaustive "pumping" process at the hands of rebel officers, the order above alluded to was promptly issued, and communication promptly prohibited. No picket firing is allowed on either side. Taking advantage of this wise understanding, many Charleston ladies are daily seen walking the rebel beach, and observing, doubtless with a great deal of interest, the movements of the "Yankees" on Folly Island.
lead_paragraph: Affairs remain quiet unchanged on the Sea Islands about Charleston. No picket firing is allowed on either side. abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 30th: The Earl of Hardwicke asked what course the Government was going to adopt in relation to the continuation of the works on the forts at Spithead, and stated that about  100,000 had been sunk under water, and would be lost unless the forts were proceeded with. He referred to the recent affair at Charleston as another proof of the superiority of forts over ships.

abstract: Western Germans' Efforts to Remove
lead_paragraph: The Germans in the West are engaged in a very general and very determined effort to influence President LINCOLN to remove Maj.-Gen. HALLEOK from his position as General-in-Chief of the army. The Tribune, of this City, makes an open and almost petulant complaint of the Administration for not having placed Maj.-Gen. SIGEL in a command which he has frequently and quite recently sought. Similar complaints and remonstrances have been made by numerous public speakers of late, such as WENDELL PHILLIPS, Miss ANN DICKINSON and T. TILTON, on behalf of Gens. FREMONT, PHELPS, BUTLER, HAMILTON and others; and an attempt to manufacture a popular demand for the restoration of Gen. MCCLELLAN to the command of the Army of the Potomac, was likewise lately manifested in this City, which will be repeated, undoubtedly, with more persistence, if the vicissitudes of the national cause should furnish occasion.

abstract: Gen. CHARLES P. STONE has received orders to report to Gen. BANKS, in Louiisana, for duty, and left Washington on Saturday for New-Orleans. Nothing has transpired, that we have heard of, to disclose the reasons which have long kept Gen. STONE from active service; but whatever they were, they have very recently ceased to influence the Government, as it was but a short time since, as we understand, that Maj.-Gen. HOOKER asked that Gen. STONE might be assigned to duty as chief of his Staff, but the Government did not at that time see fit to accede to the request. -- Nat. Intelligencer.
lead_paragraph: Gen. CHARLES P. STONE has received orders to report to Gen. BANKS, in Louiisana, for duty, and left Washington on Saturday for New-Orleans. abstract: Many country people hearing that horses were being impressed in this city for military purposes, have discontinued their visits to our markets. Their fears are entirely without reason. We are authorized to say that no horses of country people attending the markets will be interfered with. The Government, whilst it is supplying an urgent necessity, is, at the same time, conferring a great benefit upon the city. It is impressing the pampered studs of luxurious gentlemen and the fat hack horses, which have been consuming the food so much needed by our citizens. For months past it has been a common thing for hackman and livery stable-keepers to buy meal at seven and eight dollars for their horses. Moreover, the movement relieves the city of the hacks and their impertinent and extortionate drivers, it has been a long time since any honest person outside of the upper ten could afford to ride in a hack, and in consequence that class of vehicles have been appropriated to the special use of negroes, thieves and prostitutes.

abstract: The Chicago Tribune learns from a gentleman who participated in the recent campaign of Gen. GRANT, up to the time the enemy crossed the Big Black in the retreat toward Vicksburgh, that in starting on the movement the General disencumbered himself of everything, setting an example to his officers and men. He took neither a horse nor a servant, overcoat nor blanket, nor tent, nor camp-chest, not even a clean Shirt. His only baggage consisted of a tooth-brush. He shared all the hardships of the private soldier, sleeping in the front and in the open air, and eating hard tack and salt pork. He wore no sword, had on a low-crowned citizen's hat, and the only thing about him to mark him as a military man was his two stars on his undress military coat. On the battlefield he was omnipresent, riding everywhere, generally alone, into the very thickest of the fight, inspiring his the troops by his imperturbable coolness and bravery.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Tribune learns from a gentleman who participated in the recent campaign of Gen. abstract: Certainly none of the Anniversaries has attracted a finer audience than that which crowded Irving Hall, Friday evening, on the occasion of the Annual Exhibition of the pupils of the New-York Institution for the Blind. For many years the miraculous attainments of these unfortunates have surprised and delighted the New-York public, but on this, the performance was even more astounding than ever before. Indeed, the blind boys and girls seemed to know quite as much History, Geography, Reading, Arithmetic, and even Geometry, as most juveniles, who have the benefit of vsion, while their knowledge of the existing war even surpassed that of many grown people. One of the boys was asked when the war would end, and brought down the house with the reply, "When the Stars and Stripes float from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and from the Lakes to the Gulf." One of the boys read raised print through four thicknesses of a pocket handkerchief. Another traced on raised maps different routes from one part of the globe to another; another replaced in a block map the States which had been disconnected. But the most surprising, as well as agreeable portion of the entertainment, was the musical part -- vocal and instrumental -- consisting of solos, choruses, madrigals, catches, duets, glees and rounds, all of which elicited enthusiastic praise. The piano solo, composed and performed by Mr. E. KANSKI, one of the graduates; the solo from "The Creation;" the madrigal, "Now is the month of Maying," and the battle hymn, by Mrs. JULIA WARD HOWE, were excellent. The following is the concluding verse of the last-named:
lead_paragraph: Certainly none of the Anniversaries has attracted a finer audience than that which crowded Irving Hall, Friday evening, on the occasion of the Annual Exhibition of the pupils of the New-York Institution for the Blind. For many years the miraculous attainments of these unfortunates have surprised and delighted the New-York public, but on this, the performance was even more astounding than ever before. Indeed, the blind boys and girls seemed to know quite as much History, Geography, Reading, Arithmetic, and even Geometry, as most juveniles, who have the benefit of vsion, while their knowledge of the existing war even surpassed that of many grown people. One of the boys was asked when the war would end, and brought down the house with the reply, "When the Stars and Stripes float from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and from the Lakes to the Gulf." One of the boys read raised print through four thicknesses of a pocket handkerchief. Another traced on raised maps different routes from one part of the globe to another; another replaced in a block map the States which had been disconnected. abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT's army is exciting and extremely important. It is from the Richmond Enquirer of Friday, and is as late as that day. It indicates, we are glad to say, that Gen. GRANT is pushing the enemy before him in a manner which will doubtless insure his ultimate success, The Enquirer states that our forces on Thursday advanced, one thousand strong, upon Raymond, seven miles from the railroad connecting Vicksburgh and Jackson, and about twelve miles from the latter place. Gen. GREGG held the place with 4,150 rebel infantry and a few cavalry. Skirmishing commenced at 9 o'clock in the morning. Our forces were gradually reinforced until 1 o'clock, when, after a heavy musketry fire, the enemy retreated through Raymond, and fell back on reinforcements at Mississippi Springs, in the direction of Jackson. Here the battle was renewed on Friday, and at last accounts the firing was heavy and continuous.

abstract: Mr. MARETZFK, having given the promised series of six performances, and throwing an extra one in to-night, by way of full measure, will this tribulalation past retire into profitable idleness, until again goaded into industrious loss by the necessity of giving six nights more.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK, having given the promised series of six performances, and throwing an extra one in to-night, by way of full measure, will -- this tribulalation past -- retire into profitable idleness, until again goaded into industrious loss by the necessity of giving six nights more. The month ot May has been anything but merry for the impressario. It has, in fact, used him scurvily. He has been ill-treated by the weather and neglected by the public. In short, he has learned that opera at this particular time is both unseasonable and unpopular. Judiciously, like a good general, but not hastily, like a bad one, he retires from the untenable position.

abstract: The Operations on the
lead_paragraph: -- We had intelligence from the Southwest, a week ago, that part of Admiral PORTER'S fleet had gone down the Mississippi as far as the mouth of the Red River, and ascended the latter stream. There were some fears that these vessels might suffer disastrously from the rebel batteries on the Red River which opened so fatally upon the Queen of the West, near the close of last year, and which, we were told, had been greatly strengthened of late. We also had statements from the rebels that an immense iron-clad fleet had been built or was building up the Red River, and that its whole line was swarming with rams -- if rams may be said to swarm. We characterized these statements at the time as being funny rather than fearful. And so the event has proved. Three of our gunboats attacked the batteries of Fort De Russy, on the 4th instant, and soon two rebel steamboats appeared and took part in the fight. But, after a little tussle, the fort surrendered, and one of the steamers fled and the other was disabled.

abstract: The steamship City of New-York arrived at this port late last night, with four days later advices from Europe. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Queenstown on the 7th inst. A deputation of Trade Unionists waited on Mr. ADAMS, our Minister in London, on the 2d, and presented the addresses recently adopted at a public meeting. Mr. ADAMS made a reply of considerable length, in which he alluded to the relations of Great Britain and the United States in a manner which seems to have pleased the London Press. Parliamentary proceedings had been unimportant. The replies of Russia to England, France and Austria on the Polish question had been declined, and and were regarded as unsatisfactory. Several successes of the revolutionists against the Russians are reported. Prices of Cotton had advanced in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs were dull, and Provisions steady. Consols were quoted at 93 3/4 -- a decline.

abstract: -- We drew the inference the other day, from the facts developed in the raids of Gen. STONEMAN and Col. GRIERSON, that, excepting the few chief points at which the rebel armies are immediately concentrated, the South is not only entirely bare of troops, but that it has been swept clean of the material out of which troops are made; and also that when its present armies are broken, the Confederacy will give us little more trouble -- its backbone being then pretty effectually broken. This view, we observe, is confirmed by Col. GRIERSON himself. "I tell you, General," said Col. GRIERSON, as narrated by our New-Orleans correspondent, "no one can pass through that country without knowing that the Confederacy is broken up. It is a mere shell with nothing in it."
lead_paragraph: -- We drew the inference the other day, from the facts developed in the raids of Gen. STONEMAN and Col. This view, we observe, is confirmed by Col. GRIERSON himself. "I tell you, General," said Col. abstract: Time as an Ally of the North
snippet: Time as an Ally of the North
lead_paragraph: In almost every struggle, Time is sure to figure as a great ally, on the one side or the other; and the whole result often depends upon the question whether this ally can be secured or not. FABIUS saved Rome from HANNIBAL chiefly by obtaining it, and turning it to the best account. The enemies of NAPOLEON were overthrown mainly because almost uniformly deprived of it by his terrible celerity. The Southern revolutionists owed all their first success more to the fact that the last Administration allowed them time than to all other things combined. It was Mr. BUCHANAN's fatal mistake. Had he garrisoned the Southern forts with promptitude, as Gen. SCOTT entreated him to do, and used with proper dispatch his other powers called for by the occasion, the secession movement might have been checked. He gave it time, and it soon acquired a breadth and strength that enabled it to sweep the whole cotton region, from the Atlantic to the Rio Grande. The different action of the Border States was determined entirely by the fact whether the Unionists obtained the advantage of time or not. In Virginia they did not, as the State was hurled out of the Union by the Convention in the storm of excitement following Sumter, before the people had time to deliberate. In Kentucky they did, the Unionists gaining time by the temporary device of what was called the neutrality plan. In Maryland they did, through the interposition of the President, who ordered the arrest of the legislators just on the eve of launching their secession ordinance. In Missouri they did, through the summary action of Gen. LYON in breaking up Camp Jackson. After the war had fairly opened, it was, however, by our own slow operations that time was given to the rebels to make their immense levies, and to arm and equip them, that they acquired such prodigious military power. Had we made a mighty effort to raise and arm soldiers, and struck both promptly and skillfully, the rebellion would probably have been crushed in its first year. But we gave it time to develop and compact itself, and the consequence has been that, for the last year, it has been quite our match.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship George Washington, we receive highly important intelligence from the Department of the Gulf. She left New-Orleans on the 10th inst. On that day Admiral FARRAGUT, with several other officers, arrived in New-Orleans, with the news that early on the morning of the 6th, Admiral PORTER, ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship George Washington, we receive highly important intelligence from the Department of the Gulf. She left New-Orleans on the 10th inst. On that day Admiral FARRAGUT, with several other officers, arrived in New-Orleans, with the news that early on the morning of the 6th, Admiral PORTER, with his own and a portion of FARRAGUT's fleet, captured Alexandria, on the Red River, and that on the evening of the same day, Gen. DWIGHT's cavalry, the advance of Gen. BANK's army, entered the place, thus affecting a junction between the land and naval forces. Previous to the capture of Alexandria -- on the 4th -- the gunboats Albatros, Estrella and Arizona proceeded up the Red River on a reconnoissance, and had an engagement with Fort De Russy, resulting in its capture. Two rebel gunboats took part in the engagement, one of which was disabled by a shot in her boiler, when the other made her escape up the river. A rumor had reached New-Orleans that Port Hudson was being evacuated. It will be recollected that Gen. GRANT, a few days ago, notified the War Department that it had been evacuated, except by a small garrison and the heavy artillery. Gen. BRAGG had issued an order proposing the organization of a corps d'armee of colored troops, to be designated as the Corps d'Afrique. It is to consist ultimately of eighteen regiments, representing all arms -- making nine brigades of two regiments each, and three divisions of three brigades each.

abstract: Mississippi Raid; a Detailed Narrative
lead_paragraph: In obedience to orders of Col. B.H. GRIERSON, commanding the First cavalry brigade, Col. EDWARD PRINCE moved with his regiment, the Seventh Illinois cavalry volunteers -- 542, officers and men -- from Lagrange, Tenn., at 10 o'clock A.M., on the 17th of April, 1863, on the Ripley road, and camped on the plantation of Dr. ELLIS, four miles northwest of Ripley, Miss. -- distance about 30 miles.

abstract: Grierson's Raid and the Romance of War
snippet: Grierson's Raid and the Romance of War
lead_paragraph: We have heretofore published such facts and fictions as we have been able to gather from the rebel journals that reached us from time to time, concerning the great raid of Col. the GRIERSON through the length and breadth of very long and quite broad State of Mississippi. It is just a month since the expedition started on its perilous tour, and during all that time we have known nothing of it except what we learned through rebel reports from the Southwest. Now we heard of it here, then there; now in the north, then in the centre, and sweeping all around; now fighting, now capturing towns -- and so on, until both we and the rebels lost sight and knowledge of it somewhere below the centre of the State.
headline: {'main': 'The Romance of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Romance of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Spring meetings are fast approaching. Very lively and exciting seasons are anticipated, and if the promises now so freely made are fulfilled, our neighboring Courses will this year see greater crowds and more sport than for many years gone by. On to-morrow, at the Fashion Course, Frank Temple, Gen. McClellan and Shark will trot three-mile heats in harness, for the proprietor's purse of $200. Mr. JO. CROCHERON, well-known for his genuine hospitality and his cultured habit of superintending racing affairs, considers this as the opening of the season at the Fashion Grounds, and if the weather be fair a large concourse of horsemen and amateure will meet at the cheery mansion.

abstract: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Senator POMEroy, with a number of other invited guests, including the "Hutchinsons," visited Fort Schuyler, yesterday. The "Hutchinsons" sung, Mr. BEECHER talked, the soldiers cheered, and all concerned enjoyed themselves. Dr. ROBERTS BARTHLOW, the surgeon in charge, escorted the party through the Hospital, and showed them every attention.

abstract: Rumored Taking the Field with Gen. Hooker; Perils of a Halleck-Hooker Divided Command
snippet: Rumored Taking the Field with Gen. Hooker; Perils of a Halleck-Hooker Divided Command
lead_paragraph: It has been rumored, for a few days, both that Gen. HALLECK is about to take the field in person, and that he has been paying visits to the camp and overruling certain plans of HOOKER'S; and nevertheless we are assured he has not the least intention of superseding HOOKER. He is merely to supplement him. As, if this be true, it is a matter which seriously affects the future of the army of the Potomac, and, perhaps, the result of the war itself, we think the public cannot protest too earnestly against anything which promises to inflict upon the most important portion of our whole force the evils of divided command.
headline: {'main': 'Perils of a Divided Command.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Perils of a Divided Command.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the collection of pictures now exhibiting at the Old Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 548 Broadway, are many rare and interesting pictures by artists whose works have hitherto been only known to travelers abroad, and in point of beauty and variety the walls of this establishment at present bear an assemblage of objects of art more than usually worthy of attention. Almost every existing school of painting is represented by one or more highly important pictures. LUTZE's "Washington Crossing the Delaware," the second and smaller picture by him of this subject, is there, and by artists of Holland, Dusseldorf, Belgium, England and France there is enough to satisfy every variety of taste. The collection is the result of years of industrious travel, combined with a critical discrimination and an ample outlay of means by a gentleman well and favorably known in the art word for thirty years past. We recommend lovers of the fine arts to visit the collection, which will remain open free to visitors until Thursday evening next. There are many things in the gallery well worthy of an attentive study, and, as a whole, the assemblage of pictures is an excellent one. There is also included in this sale the entire collection of marble statuary belonging to one of our well-known citizens.

abstract: Miss DICKINSON will speak this week in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. On Fast-Day, Rev. H.W. BEECHER took occasion to score the Directors of that building for "refusing to permit a woman to speak there in favor of Liberty." This statement was corrected by one of the Directors, but last night in giving notice of the lady's intended oration, he reiterated the statement saying that although he had been corrected, he was right and in no way mistaken.
lead_paragraph: Miss DICKINSON will speak this week in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. On Fast-Day, Rev. H.W. abstract: The Union-square meeting, last enemy, for the purpose of sympathizing with Mr. VALLANDIGHAM and denouncing his recent arrest, trial and imprisonment, was attended by about three thousand persons, Most of the distinguished gentlemen announced to speak, excused themselves for non-attendance. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the arrest, and all trials by military commissions, as unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: The Union-square meeting, last enemy, for the purpose of sympathizing with Mr. VALLANDIGHAM and denouncing his recent arrest, trial and imprisonment, was attended by about three thousand persons, Most of the distinguished gentlemen announced to speak, excused themselves for non-attendance. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the arrest, and all trials by military commissions, as unconstitutional. Addresses were made by J.A. MCMASTERS, Judge MCCUNN, ELI P. NORTON, EDMON BLANKMAN, C.G. GUNTHER, JOHN MULLALY, D. FUCH, and others.

abstract: The U.S. Steam-frigate Ticonderega sailed from the Lower Bay at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, making full 14 miles an hour on her trip out of the harbor, which demonstrated the final success of her machinery. abstract: Gen. Grant's Successes Toward
lead_paragraph: We have reports this morning from three widely apart points -- Mobile, Chattanooga and Memphis -- that Gen. GRANT'S forces have captured Jackson, the Capital of Mississippi, lying 45 miles in the rear and directly east of Vicksburgh. All these reports come from rebel sources; and, we suppose, that under the circumstances, with such a weight of testimony, the rebels ought to be believed. Gen. HURLBUT, in transmitting one of the dispatches, adds to it a surmise of his own, that Jackson was captured by a cavalry movement from the cast; but both of the other rebel telegrams assert that it was taken after a hard day's fighting -- that from Mobile asserting that "we (the rebels) fought all day, but could not hold the city."

abstract: A fight for $1,000 a side, between the Colorado "hitter," COOLEY, and KEENAN, who are well known in pugilistic circles, is to come off this morning about sixty miles from the city. It is stated that the affair will take place on Connecticut soil. A large number of the "fancy" left here in the late train last night to attend the "mill," also a large crowd went up the Sound in a boat chartered for the occasion.

abstract: Vallandigham Sympathizers to Meeting
lead_paragraph: In response to a call for a meeting of citiizens of New-York to protest against the recent arrest and trial of Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, a gathering of about three thousand persons look place in Union-square, last evening. At the hour named for commencing, there was not a single auditor at two of the four stands, and at the other two, which were contiguous, there were but a few hundreds. The meeting at the main stand was not organized until half an hour afterward, and then by dint of music and torches, and the fortuitous circumstance that about that time, large numbers of citizens passed through the Square en route for home, the crowd was augumented to about the number named. It was a peripatetic crowd, and wandered from one stand to another with listless curiosity. The few hundreds who kept their places in front of the stands, however, made up in noise and enthusiasm what they lacked in numbers, and vigorously cheered all denunciations of the Administration. The allusions to the Conscription Act were everywhere received with expressions of opposition to the [???], and a statement that VALLANDIGHAM would be rescued if brought through New-York on his way to Fort Warren, was vigorously cheered.

abstract: The report of the capture of Jackson, the capital of Mississippi, by Gen. GRANT, is fully confirmed this morning. A dispatch from Gen. HURLBUT to the War Department, embodies intelligence from the Vicksburgh and Jackson papers of the 14th, giving accounts of the defeat of the rebel Gen. GRIGGS at Raymond and Missis...
lead_paragraph: The report of the capture of Jackson, the capital of Mississippi, by Gen. GRANT, is fully confirmed this morning. A dispatch from Gen. HURLBUT to the War Department, embodies intelligence from the Vicksburgh and Jackson papers of the 14th, giving accounts of the defeat of the rebel Gen. GRIGGS at Raymond and Mississippi Spring, and the later telegram from Canton announces that Jackson had been taken from the east, probably by a cavalry force of Gen. GRANT's command. The battle at Raymond was fought on Tuesday, the 12th. The rebel loss in that engagement is admitted to be 700. The next day GRIGGS was 'reinforced by Gen. WALKER, of Georgia, was attacked at Mississippi Spring, and on Thursday he was driven toward Jackson. The rebel Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON is said to have arrived at Jackson on the day previous to its capture, and to have gone out on the railroad toward Vicksburgh with four brigades. It is also said that Gen. GRANT had struck the railroad at Edwards' Station -- thus probably placing JOHNSTON between two bodies of National troops.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current stories of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: As was announced in the TIMES, several weeks since, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER will sail for Europe in the steamship City of Baltimore, on the 30th inst. During the months of June and September, the pulpit of Plymouth Church will be occupied by Rev. Dr. HITCHCOCK, while July and August will be, as usual, given up to younger and less practiced teachers. Mr. BEECHER will, we understand, occasionally write to the Independent, of which he resigns, during his absence, the editorial charge -- the paper being left in the management of Rev. Dr. JOSHUA LEAVITT, Mr. T. TILTON and Mr. FREDERICK PERKINS.

abstract: Mrs. JANE ENGLISH's experiment at Laura Keene's Theatre has shared the fate of the Opera. The lieges watch it with apathy, and the critics with regret. As a consequence, the benches are temptingly and luxuriously vacant. To account for this state of things we must remender, first, that Laura Keene's has ceased to be a popular theatre, and secondly, that Mrs. ENGLISH is a stranger, whose claims to the honors of Metropolitan management have not yet been recognized. Our people, in the matter of amusements, are singularly jealous of outsiders. They view with ill-concealed annoyance the occasional raids of hardy and enthusiastic provincials. It is seldom that the invaders get off with bag and baggage. We know not the extent of Mrs. ENGLISH's ambition, but for a couple of months at least she proposes to give us a species of entertainment based on the Ravel model, with variations that seem to have been suggested by the circus. The performances on the opening night were not of a very promising character, but they have improved since. We begin to hope that Mrs. ENGLISH may be successful. A novel entertainment on Broadway would indeed be a luxury to a craving community. Was there ever a city in the world with a million inhabitants so badly supplied with places of amusement as is New-York? In reality we have but one theatre on the west side of the town -- Wallack's; all the other places being mere show rooms and platforms for travelling "stars" who revolve in their little orbits punctually enough, but without adding an inch to the space traversed. If it were not for a constant influx of healthy foreigners and of utterly indestructable natives from the East, the proud metropolis of the New World would speedily be depopulated and reduced to a howling wilderness by the fatal agony of its amusements, by the dreadful pressure of its tragedians, by the evil influence of the "stars." Without these robust classes to throw into the arena, we should be roared into fits and tore into pieces by the two-legged furies who there pant and perform. But providential as is this provision, there is an inconvenience about it. The robust classes like their entertainment a little savage, and they have been gratified with a vengeance. The noises of a five-act play are as varied and appalling as those that issue from a menagerie. The secret of our well wishes for Mrs. ENGLISH and her success are thus revealed. Her artists do not speak and cannot howl. Moreover they must, as a rule, understand something of their profession, or they will flounder to the stage a mass of bruised and broken humanity -- sorely punished, indeed, for their pretence. And here is an anomaly that the philosophic mind at once detects in the two professions of tight-rope dancer and tragedian. The one, by a false step, may injure himself grievously, but with true art instinct, to hide all that is painful from the public, he will deliver a hop, skip and jump, and wobble playfully off the stage, to be conveyed, mayhap, by tender hands to the nearest hospital. Not a complaint escapes his lips; his face is wreathed in smiles, even if his body be racked with pain. The other one -- he who chalks his feet for tragedy, and goes on with Shakespeare as a long pole -- howls, yells, and writhes steadily for three hours, although there is not a bone in his body broken, and he knows that when it is all over there will be cakes and ale for him at home. For a cheerful view of life, it is always necessary to go to those who are in the greatest danger of losing it. And this brings us back to Laura Keene's Theatre, where, in addition to two remarkable performers on the tight-rope -- Mlle. ROSITA and ALEXANDER ZANFRETTA -- the lady manager has also provided us with a couple of wonderful gymnasts -- Prof. DONETTE and Young America -- and an Italian singer -- Signor MONTENARE -- who gives buffo scenes very acceptably, and a couple of dancers and a German violinist, who can imitate every thing except music, and, finally, a ballet pantomimic company. Of this latter we can only say, that it has improved in the interval between Monday and Saturday. The quick precision, and brief but intelligible dumb show of the RAVELS, were not attained in a day. Mrs. ENGLISH's pantomimists are profuse. They deliver an oration where they should only utter an exclamation; they are for ever scrambling about the stage; and stamp a great deal more than is good for them. An exception should however be made in favor of Senor CARON, a comic artist of talent, who will, we think, improve on acquaintance. In the "Maison Rouge" he was not always funny, although he tried to be so, but in the bed-room scene, and in the final opportunity of the piece, he was excellent. Let us add that there is an excellent orchestra, and repeat that we hope Mrs. ENGLISH will succeed. Anything as a relief to the necessity of going to a "star" theatre will be acceptable. Above all things we want variety, and when that is provided there will be room for a dozen more theatres in New-York. To-night, a prodigy, named ANGELO, makes his first appearance, and will "perform his Icarean feat on the cloud swing." We hope that the poor child may not meet with the fate of Icarus.

abstract: Generalship, the Question of
lead_paragraph: There is a passage in KIRGLAKE'S Invasion of the Crimea, describing the character of Sir COLIN CAMPBELL, the present Lord CLYDE, which we may read just now with some profit, inasmuch as there is no theme which at this moment so much interests us as the exact nature of the qualities which are needed to make up a good General, and there is no theme which we discuss so much. When the war began, the inexperienced public very naturally were possessed by the notion that a great leader must, above all things, love fighting; that he must have for it a certain amount of ardor, which will make him seek it whenever it holds out a fair promise of a satisfactory result. This notion was held down to the battle of Bull Run. After that memorable engagement, however, it fell into complete disrepute. The idea of subduing the South by hard knocks was scouted as the dream of fanatics and visionaries, and people became possessed with the idea that the proper way to overcome the rebels was, as Sam. Weller would say, to "circumwent" them. The "anaconda plan," therefore, came into high favor. The revolted States were to be encircled with "a wall of steel and fire," and, after a while, the revolt was to be extinguished by mere process of compression, or strangulation, with little or no actual combat.

abstract: We hope that now that Gen. BURNSIDE has disposed of Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, he will at once proceed to pay attention to the heavy force of rebels which, as we learn from the West, have invaded his Department. The dispatch which we publish this morning from Cincinnati, where Gen. BURNSIDE's headquarters are located, announces that seventeen thousand rebels, with fourteen pieces of artillery, have made their appearance in the southeastern part of Kentucky on the Cumberland River, and that twenty-eight additional regiments of rebels are at Norristown, East Tennessee, evidently with the purpose of joining their strength to the aforementioned 17,000. It is said these immense forces are moving upon Richmond, Ky., from whence they will advance toward the northern and middle parts of the State, with a view to flank ROSECRANS and compel him to retreat from Tennessee.

abstract: Gen. HURLBUT, commanding at Memphis, sends, in an official dispatch, the statement of a "citizen," who reported to him that the rebels had abandoned Vicksburgh on Sunday last, and were marching to Livingston, a place 30 miles northeast of Vicksburgh, and 20 from Jackson. We do not know whether the citizen's statement was based upon hearsay, actual observation, or imagination. We do not know anything of the citizen's character -- his reliability, sagacity, or political proclivities. Consequently, we are at a loss to know what value to put upon his report.

abstract: Oram and Geognegan, at South Amboy
snippet: Oram and Geognegan, at South Amboy
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday, a fight between J. CON OREM, of Colorado renown, and OWEN GEOGHEGAN of this City, took place at South Amboy, in Middlesex County, N.J. A large party left the City Monday night in the Keyport boat to witness the encounter, also many persons took private conveyances for the same object. The steam-tug John Tracy was chartered by a certain number of individuals, and at 2 o'clock yesterday morning left Jersey City and proceeded toward the fighting ground, reaching it at about 6 o'clock A.M. The boat, however, struck the bar, where she was held fast, and in order to reach land the passengers were obliged to take to a small boat -- the only one on board -- which made several trips back and forth. The people in the vicinity of the spot where the ring was pitched were greatly incensed at the proceedings, and notified the Sheriff of the County, who endeavored to prevent the anticipated fight, but failed in consequence of not having a sufficient number of men to aid him. The ring was pitched at about sunrise, and was considered one of the firmest that has been put up since the recent fighting-season commenced. All the available points for seeing what transpired within the ring were monopolized by the Geoghegan party, and the betting, as a general thing, was decidedly in that individual's favor. The party assembled, with some few exceptions, seemed determined that OREM should not be the victor, no matter how successful he might be in whipping his antagonist. As the appointed hour for the fight approached, the crowd became very noisy and boisterous, and one rowdy even went so far as to fire a barn which contained a considerable quantity of hay.

abstract: Telegrams from Gen. GRANT to the War Department give a brief statement of his movements up to the 14th inst., and announce that he intended to attack Jackson on that day.
lead_paragraph: Telegrams from Gen. GRANT to the War Department give a brief statement of his movements up to the 14th inst., and announce that he intended to attack Jackson on that day. Telegrams already published have announced the capture of that place, on the day indicated by Gen. GRANT. It is announced to-day that he burned the State Capitol -- it probably bring used as a rebel depot for supplies. Gen. HURLBUT, in telegraphing this intelligence from Memphis, gives the report of a citizen just arrived from Jackson, that the rebels abandoned Vicksburgh on Sunday last, marching on the ridge northeast to Livingston, which is twenty miles northwest of Jackson, and about midway between the Big Black and the Pearl Rivers. Gen. GRANT states that Gen. MCPHERSON captured Raymond on the 12th, after about two hours' brisk fighting. Our loss was 51 killed and 180 wounded. The rebel loss was 75 killed and 186 prisoners, beside their wounded, A dispatch from Cincinnati states that reinforcements for the rebels were being hurried forward, and were stopping twelve miles east of Jackson. The Pearl River is between them and Gen. GRANT, however.

abstract: We have not had this many a day a more ridiculous demonstration than that of the Copperheads at Union-square in protest against what they call the "intolerable tyranny at Washington."
lead_paragraph: We have not had this many a day a more ridiculous demonstration than that of the Copperheads at Union-square in protest against what they call the "intolerable tyranny at Washington." We doubt, indeed, whether there ever was a more absurd assemblage of blatherskites. There, in the face of sober citizens returning home from their business, they stood by the hour ranting against the National Government for stilling free speech -- belching out invective, vituperation, ribaldry, execration, threats and defiance; howling sentiments that, if acted upon, would be outright murder and treason; shrieking like very sybils possessed; outroaring Boanerges; and all because the despot LINCOLN had gagged the country. We wonder what the sensations of a Frenchman, fresh from his own land, or a Prussian, would have been, had he been passing about that time of day. His bewildered ideas would probably have settled down into one of two conclusions: either that there was a very curious custom in the United States of giving the inmates of Lunatic Asylums an airing about sunset, or that the Americans, like SWIFT's people of Brobdignag, had some remarkable powers of utterance, unheard of elsewhere, and that, if they could make such noises when gagged, their regular hullaballoo, with mouths free, must be something that would really frighten the man in the moon, and that it was really a mercy in the ruler of the country to keep them -- gagged.

abstract: THE DANGER OF INTRUSTING FIREARMS TO BOYS. Yesterday afternoon, about 4  o'clock, a boy discharged a loaded swivel in Wythe-avenue, Williamsburgh, the contents of which entered a window ...
lead_paragraph: THE DANGER OF INTRUSTING FIREARMS TO BOYS. -- Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, a boy discharged a loaded swivel in Wythe-avenue, Williamsburgh, the contents of which entered a window and passed through a room in which nine persons were congregated -- none of whom, fortunately, were hurt. The ball passed within two inches of the head of a lady seated at the window, who had changed her position just in time to escape it.

abstract: Crittenden, John J., of Kentucky, Patriotic Speech of
snippet: Crittenden, John J., of Kentucky, Patriotic Speech of
lead_paragraph: We copy in another column a speech recently made in Kentucky by JOHN J. CRITTENDEN, who has been nominated by his constituents for reelection to Congress. We recommend it to general attention -- not because all its opinions will command universal assent, but because its leading sentiment is one which should animate the heart and guide the conduct of every man who loves his country better than he loves the petty schemes of party or the political prejudices and prepossessions of his own judgment. Mr. CRITTENDEN is the sole survivor now in public life of the generation of great men who made public service glorious by the splendor of their talents and the fervor of their patriotism. With increasing years and experience his devotion to the welfare of his country has become more and more conspicuous; and now, in this crowning hour of her peril, he gives men of all parties the timely and useful example of one who stands ready to sacrifice prejudice, party relations, the opinions and convictions of a life-time even, to the preservation of the Union and the salvation of the country.

abstract: Effect of the War upon
lead_paragraph: It is curious to mark the effect that the war has produced upon the three great border Slave States -- Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri. These three States, at the beginning of the rebellion, had a perfect identity of interest, and a perfect identity of feeling. They were all largely slaveholding; Slavery was the dominant interest in each, next to real estate; and the exports of each were mainly the products of slave labor. Their active and enriching trade was based on the slave system, so that, so far as the exciting cause of the war was concerned, Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri were almost as much Southern and slave-bound as Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi.

abstract: Loyal speech at Lexington, Ky.
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: I desire to address you very briefly on subjects connected with our present national difficulties. But it will not be necessary for me to attempt to retrace the history of the war. It is written in the memory and upon the hearts of all our people. I desire only to present to you some general views in relation to it, which will enable me better to explain and you better to understand the course which I have pursued as your representative for the last two years. During that whole period subjects of the deepest interest have engaged all minds and hearts, from the fireside of the humblest citizen to the balls of Congress and the council chambers of the President. By a clear understanding of this course of your representative, you will be able to determine for yourselves the propriety of his views. I have endeavored to perform my duty with a heart faithful to your rights and your honor, but you shall be the judges of my success.

abstract: A general Court-martial convened at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, for the purpose of trying the Executive officer of the United States steam gunboat Sumter, on a charge of having...
lead_paragraph: A general Court-martial convened at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, for the purpose of trying the Executive officer of the United States steam gunboat Sumter, on a charge of having neglected to keep an officer on watch on his vessel during the night on which the safe was stolen. The following are the officers of the Court: Commodore ROWAN, Capt. ROE and Capt. ORLANDO. The evidence taken yesterday shows that Capt, WINCHESTEE distinctly ordered the accused to keep an officer on watch every night. We understand that Capt. WINCHESTER has been detached from the Sumter, partly at his own request.

abstract: The Committee of the Board of Aldermen appointed to investigate and appraise the damage caused to houses and furniture by the recent powder explosion on the East River, between Seventy-...
lead_paragraph: The Committee of the Board of Aldermen appointed to investigate and appraise the damage caused to houses and furniture by the recent powder explosion on the East River, between Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth streets, visited that locality yesterday morning, to inspect the losses occasioned by that affair. The damage caused by the monster explosion surprised the Committee, being far greater than they had conceived. They first visited the residence of Mr. T.C. KEYES, at the foot of Seventy-sixth-street. Here the scene presented was quite astonishing, the buildings giving every possible evidence of wreck and ruin. Fences were prostrated and out-buildings more or less demolished. The main damage, however, was to the house occupied by Mr. KEYES' family, and the furniture in it. Not a room in the house escaped the ravages of the terrible concussion. The eaves and coping of the roots and piazzas were ruthlessly torn o[???] leaders were broken up as if they had been but pipe-stems, the sidewalks were cracked more or less throughout, ceiling walls had tumbled down everywhere, and furniture was broken up indiscriminately, doors, blinds and sashes had been torn away from their places, and forcibly thrown against opposite walls and windows, house timbers were wrenched from their strong joints and panes of glass were broken without limit. In short, the building is so torn and racked that it will be impossible to restore it to its former strength. The tremendous concussion played some curious freaks. Mr. and Mrs. KEYES, who were reading in their bedchamber at the time, were hurled across the room, fortunately with only sight bruises. The marble-top of a large parlor table, standing in the centre of a room, was broken in two, while a large vase on the top of it was unbroken; the cornices of rooms were considerably cracked and smashed, while pictures on the walls were not in the least harmed; a piano and the water tank of a bath-room were taken from their places and tumbled over and over, while lamps were taken from mantels and tables to the floor without damage. Lace curtains were torn to shreds, chairs were broken, some pictures were scratched and cracked and others were left untouched by harm; cartridges, inclosed in boxes, were thrown promiscuously into various parts of the house, and it seems a miracle that life itself did not meet with destruction.
headline: {'main': 'Damages by the Recent Powder Explosion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Damages by the Recent Powder Explosion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a message was received from the Mayor, vetoing a resolution auditing and ordering to be paid certain bills for materials furnished for...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a message was received from the Mayor, vetoing a resolution auditing and ordering to be paid certain bills for materials furnished for the New Court-house, on the ground that the work was ordered by the Now City Hall Commissioners, who should certify the claims. The Mayor also doubts the legality of the clause in the County Tax law for 1863, giving this Board the right to build the Court-house, because the purport of the clause in not embodied in the title of the law, as required by section 16 of the State Constitution; but upon this point he is seeking legal advice. The message was referred to the New Court-house Committee, with instructions to consult the Corporation Counsel in the matter. Another message was received from the Mayor, vetoing the resolution authorizing the Harlem Bridge Committee to settle the question of the boundary line between this County and Westchester County, so far as it concerns the ratio of expense upon the two counties for building the new bridge, on the ground that the boundary question, being a matter of geographical fact, should be decided only by accurate surveys, and not by agreement. Mr. PURDY said the Mayor had misapprehended the purpose of the resolution, which was not to set at rest the troublesome boundary question, but simply to determine how much Westchester County should pay toward building the bridge. A communication from the Comptroller, proposing a transfer of $12,333 36 from the County contingent fund, to pay adjudicated claims for work ordered by the Record Commission, was referred. Bills for work on the new Court-house and materials furnished, since the Board resumed charge of its construction, and amounting to upwards of $100,000, were ordered to be paid. Adjourned to 3 P.M. on next Tuesday.

abstract: "Suppose you subdue the armies of the rebellion, how are you going to subdue the spirit of the people? How can your Government work without the loyal support of the people, and how can brute force compel that support? Try it, and you will have but another Poland, another Hungary, another Venetia.
lead_paragraph: "Suppose you subdue the armies of the rebellion, how are you going to subdue the spirit of the people? How can your Government work without the loyal support of the people, and how can brute force compel that support? Try it, and you will have but another Poland, another Hungary, another Venetia. You will be weakened by it instead of strengthened, cursed instead of blessed. Your true policy is to drop the sword and try the olive-branch, and, if the olive-branch fails, to let the rebel States go in peace."

abstract: One of the commonest of the small jokes by which Pro-Slavery fanatics have always sought to confound the Abolitionists, consisted in asking them why they did not go and preach their gospel in Charleston, or Richmond, where Slavery exists, instead of preaching it here, where there is no Slavery. The same humorists have, since the war began, resorted to another piece of wit of the same character, but intended to be much more biting.
lead_paragraph: One of the commonest of the small jokes by which Pro-Slavery fanatics have always sought to confound the Abolitionists, consisted in asking them why they did not go and preach their gospel in Charleston, or Richmond, where Slavery exists, instead of preaching it here, where there is no Slavery. The same humorists have, since the war began, resorted to another piece of wit of the same character, but intended to be much more biting. This consists in sarcastic inquiries why those those who advocate the war in speeches and sermons, do not go and do some of the fighting themselves. This is so severe and cutting a sarcasm, and so very novel in its nature, that we have not as yet heard of a single orator, to whom it could apply, having had the courage to answer it.
