abstract: National Academy of Sciences, the
lead_paragraph: At the very close of last session of Congress, after the passage of all the gigantic military measures for the suppression of the rebellion had been secured, a short bill of three sections was introduced and passed through both Houses, without even a division in either branch, providing for the establishment of the "National Academy of Sciences." This act, with the authorized report of the proceedings at the first meeting of the Academy in this City, we published yesterday. The nature and objects of this Academy are not specified in the act, further than they may be gathered from its title. It simply provides that the Academy shall consist of fifty members, all of whom are named in it -- LOUIS AGASSIZ's name being first in order -- that it shall have power to establish its own organization and constitution -- that it shall hold an annual meeting -- and in the third and last section certain practical duties, and compensations therefor, are prescribed, in the words, "that the Academy shall, whenever called upon by any Department of the Government, investigate, examine, experiment and report upon any subject of science or art, the actual expense of such investigations, examinations, experiments and reports to be paid from appropriations which may be made for the purpose, but the Academy shall receive no compensation for any services to the Government of the United States."

abstract: There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. This need cause no apprehension, however, as he, in his last dispatches, it will be remembered, notified the War Department that a cessation of intelligence from him for a short period, might be expected.
lead_paragraph: There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. This need cause no apprehension, however, as he, in his last dispatches, it will be remembered, notified the War Department that a cessation of intelligence from him for a short period, might be expected. A report was current in Cincinnati yesterday -- how it reached there is not explained -- that Gen. GRANT, after destroying the State House and rebel stores in Jackson, evacuated the place. This is quite likely to have been the case, if the report of the evacuation of Vicksburgh, and the movement of the rebels to the northward is true. The Government, our Washington correspondent says, expects to hear from Gen. GRANT to-day.

abstract: DISCHARGE OF THE ARRESTED PRIZE-FIGHTERS. The persons arrested on Tuesday, by the Harbor Police, charged with having been concerned in the prize-fight between OREM and GEOGHEGAN, in Middlesex County, New-Jersey, an account of which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, were all detained at the First Precinet Station-house until about noon on Wednesday. In the meantime a writ of kabeas corpus was applied for and granted by Judge McCUNN.
lead_paragraph: DISCHARGE OF THE ARRESTED PRIZE-FIGHTERS. -- The persons arrested on Tuesday, by the Harbor Police, charged with having been concerned in the prize-fight between OREM and GEOGHEGAN, in Middlesex County, New-Jersey, an account of which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, were all detained at the First Precinet Station-house until about noon on Wednesday. In the meantime a writ of kabeas corpus was applied for and granted by Judge McCUNN. The process was made returnable at 3 o'clock P.M., but when that hour arrived, it was ascertained that all the persons held in custody were on their way to the Tombs. Soon after their arrival at the latter place, the Court room was crowded to suffocation by the friends and partisans of the prisoners, and great was the excitement among those who, either from interest or curiosity, had congregated in the halls of justice. Sheriff CLARK, of Middlesex County, was present to make complaint that the laws of New-Jersey had been violated by prize-fighters, but neither he nor any other one present could identify the persons who were brought before the Court as the guilty parties. Justice DODGE was therefore under the necessity of discharging them from custody. Sheriff CLARK, however, succeeded in arresting about 30 of those who were present at the fight, and who were unable to leave the State, before that officer obtained the services of the Police of New-Brunswick. By means of their assistance the accused are all now safe in the jail of the county, awaiting the action of the Grand Jury. Many who would otherwise have been taken, escaped by jumping from the train when in motion, as soon as they saw the officers of the law approaching.

lead_paragraph: Few scientific works have been looked for in late years so eagerly as the present, and we owe to the enterprise of Mr. CHILDS its appearance, at this early date, in an outward form and shape in no ways inferior to the original London edition: a wise proceeding, undoubtedly; for the book is destined not only to be promptly read, but to be carefully preserved; and our community has long ago reached that point where a good price is willingly paid for a good article, though some publishers seem as yet unaware of the fact. We rejoice to say that the rapid sale of the impression justifies Mr. CHILDS' estimate of the public taste and liberality.

abstract: FUNERAL OF CAPT. GAMBLE AND LIEUT. HOWETH. -- The funeral of Capt. JOHN GAMBLE, of the Sixth New-Jersey Volunteers, and Lieut. JOHN HOWETH, of the Fifth New-Jersey Volunteers, who lost their lives from wounds received at the battle of Chancellorsville, took place in Jersey City on Tuesday afternoon, and was a most imposing affair. During the afternoon all business was suspended, and the flags were flying at half-mast from the public buildings, ferry depots, shipping, and hundreds of private dwellings. The funeral cortege moved from the City Hall, where the bodies had been lying in state, at 2 P.M. It consisted of military, the municipal authorities of Jersey City and Hudson City, the Jersey City Fire Department, the members of four lodges of Old Fellows, and many citizens. The funeral services took place at the Hedding M.E. Church, and the sermon was preached by the pastor, Rev. Mr. DAY. The remains were conveyed to the New-York Bay Cemetery, where they were interred.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF CAPT. GAMBLE AND LIEUT. HOWETH. -- The funeral of Capt. JOHN GAMBLE, of the Sixth New-Jersey Volunteers, and Lieut. The funeral services took place at the Hedding M.E. Church, and the sermon was preached by the pastor, Rev. Mr. DAY. The remains were conveyed to the New-York Bay Cemetery, where they were interred.

abstract: -- We had statements from the Southwest, yesterday, that the Vicksburgh rebels were moving northward to reinforce BRAGG; we have intelligence this morning that a portion of BRAGG's force is moving southward to aid the Vicksburgh rebels. We know not which of the statements is correct, or whether either of them is correct. Either of the movements would be exceedingly difficult and hazardous. The two rebel armies are more than five hundred miles apart, by any practicable route; and, to effect a junction, the greater part of this distance would have to be traversed on foot, over a country abounding in rivers and swamps, and, since GRIERSON's raid, very destitute of bridges. Beside, if the Vicksburgh rebels moved northward, that would at once insure us possession of the place, and command of the Mississippi River and State; and if any considerable part of BRAGG's rebels moved south, that would insure a fatal attack on the remainder by ROSECRANS, who is lying very quiet, but all ready for his work, and sharply watching his opportunity. We see nothing yet in the way of proof that the rebels have left Vicksburgh, or that they have been very heavily reinforced. The chances are, that they still remain behind their works, and they are not likely to give up such a fundamental point without a deadly contest.
lead_paragraph: -- We had statements from the Southwest, yesterday, that the Vicksburgh rebels were moving northward to reinforce BRAGG; we have intelligence this morning that a portion of BRAGG's force is moving southward to aid the Vicksburgh rebels. We see nothing yet in the way of proof that the rebels have left Vicksburgh, or that they have been very heavily reinforced. abstract: Over one hundred and fifty years ago, the first Bible ever printed in the American colonies made its appearance, bearing the Imprint of WILLIAM BRADFORD, whose name bears the same relation to the art of printing in this country as does that of CAXTON to the art in Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: Over one hundred and fifty years ago, the first Bible ever printed in the American colonies made its appearance, bearing the Imprint of WILLIAM BRADFORD, whose name bears the same relation to the art of printing in this country as does that of CAXTON to the art in Great Britain. There has recently been discovered written upon the cover of an old book in the Pennsylvania Library, of Philadelphia, the proposals for the publication of BRADFORD's early edition of the Bible, and also for the Book of Common Prayer. Mr. BRADFORD published these books under the auspices of Trinity Church, in this City, of which he was long a respected member, and a vestryman from the year 1703 to 1710.

abstract: [At the time of the arrival of our army at Chancellorsville, among other things found in the Chancellor House was the diary of an officer on the Staff of Gen. JEB. STUART, which we have had in our possession. The individuality of the writer is masked under a pseudonym, which we have penetrated, but do not care to reveal.
lead_paragraph: [At the time of the arrival of our army at Chancellorsville, among other things found in the Chancellor House was the diary of an officer on the Staff of Gen. JEB. STUART, which we have had in our possession. The individuality of the writer is masked under a pseudonym, which we have penetrated, but do not care to reveal. The diary is exceedingly interesting and well written, and bears the impress of a refined and cultivated mind. It extends over several months, and is exceedingly minute and detailed. We give below a few extracts, omitting such passages as might unpleasantly implicate the writer. -- ED. TIMES.]

abstract: The United States frigate St. Lawrence has returned from another crulse. This is her tenth, and at its close she is as sound as when she sailed from Boston, needing only such general repairs as vessels require when a long time on active service.
lead_paragraph: The United States frigate St. Lawrence has returned from another crulse. This is her tenth, and at its close she is as sound as when she sailed from Boston, needing only such general repairs as vessels require when a long time on active service. She will now probably be made a guard-ship, as sailing frigates need too many men and move too slowly to be of use in war-time. The St. Lawrence is a 50-gun frigate, carries 500 men and a guard of marines. Her officers are: Commander, JAMES F. SCHENCK; Fleet Surgeon, G.R.B. Homer; Paymaster, Washington Irving; Assistant Surgeon, Wm.K. Van Paypen; Acting Assistant Paymaster, Albert B. Poor; Acting Assistant Surgeon, A. Shirk; Acting Masters, Wm.H. Smith, John Fuller, Chas. DeBevoise and Geo. J. Murray; Acting Masters' Mates, Edmund Paoys, E.S.D. Howland, John Boyle, Victor W. Jones and Theodore W. Jones; Boatswain, John A. Briscoe.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS In this Court yesterday LOUIS MARX and GOTLIEB KAISER were placed on trial, on the charge of misdemeanor in maintaining a bone-boiling establishment in the town of Flatbush, near the city line, which proved to be a nuisance to many residents of the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS. -- In this Court yesterday LOUIS MARX and GOTLIEB KAISER were placed on trial, on the charge of misdemeanor in maintaining a bone-boiling establishment in the town of Flatbush, near the city line, which proved to be a nuisance to many residents of the neighborhood. The defence sought to prove by medical testimony that the smell arising from putrid animal matter was not injurious to health; while, on the contrary, it was shown that residents of the neighborhood are compelled to keep their doors and windows closed at certain seasons in consequence of the stench. The case was given to the jury, and the defendants were convicted. Sentence was deferred. WILLIAM COFFEY was indicted for rape and tried, but the jury not agreeing, he pleaded guilty to assault and battery, which was accepted, and he was sentenced to the Penitentiary for four months.

abstract: The World's Attacks on; Attacks on Gen. Wadsworth
snippet: The World's Attacks on; Attacks on Gen. Wadsworth
lead_paragraph: WADSWORTH. -- The World has for some days past devoted a large portion of its space to attacks upon Gen. WADSWORTH, based mainly upon the testimony which he gave in the McDowell Court of Inquiry, touching the forces left for the defence of Washington when Gen. McCLELLAN took the Army of the Potomac to the Peninsula. The point is one of historic interest, and open, therefore, to full and free discussion. The World must permit us, however, to say that, when it attempts to convert the question into an attack upon Gen. WADSWORTH's personal veracity, it loses sight of common propriety quite as thoroughly as of the real value of the point at issue. There is no man in the country more incapable of intentional misstatement or misrepresentation than Gen. WADSWORTH, and the devotion he has shown to the welfare of the country should protect him, with every fair-minded man, from such wanton and absurd aspersions.

abstract: Sword Presentation to
lead_paragraph: The gentlemen's parlor of the Fifth-avenue Hotel was last evening the scene of a very pleasant and interesting ceremony, in which most of the representative men participatedt -- the occasion for expressing in a substantial manner the high appreciation in which the citizens of New-York hold the services of the commander of the lately returnedNinth regiment, Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS, during the two years that he has been in the field. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and CHARLES P. KIRKLAND, Esq., was chosen as exponent of the sentiment of the gentlemen present. Addressing Col. HAWKINS, Mr. KIRKLAND adverted to the magnitude of the interests involved in the contest, and complimented Col. HAWKINS upon the alacrity he had shown in organizing the noble Ninth regiment that had distinguished itself at Hatteras, Roanoke Island, Camden, Antietam, Fredericksburgh, Suffolk and other minor points of conflict. He assured the gallant Colonel that posterity would regard the officers and soldiers of the present war with the same grateful remembrance that the heroes of the Revolution have from us of this generation. He was certain of the final result of the contest. Our cause could not fail, because it was the cause of civil and religious liberty, of humanity and God. [Applause.] It was a grateful thing, continued the Speaker, for a generous people to do honor to the brave and gallant men who had periled their lives for their country, and nothing could be more grateful to him personally, than to be charged with the duty of presenting to Col. HAWKINS, as one of those brave defenders, a fitting token of the estimation in which his services were held. He would therefore present to the Colonel, in the name of fifty of his fellow-citizens, a sword and its accompaniments, trusting that the recipient might long live to enjoy the honors he had won, and hoping that, should the contest be continued, to hear of him and his glorious Zouave regiment again from other felds of honor and victory.

abstract: The regular monthly sale of Scranton coal, by order of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, took place to-day, under direction of Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, at the Merchants' Exchange. A large audience was present, who evinced much spirit. The following are the particulars of the sale: 4,000 tons grate coal, at $5 95@$6 32 1/2; 1,000 tons egg size, at $6 27 1/2@$6 75; 5,000 tons stove size, at $6 35@$6 40; 2,000 tons chesnut, at $5 80@$5 85; 6,000 tons lump, at $5 75$6 05; and 6,000 tons steamboat, at $5 75. The purchasers were mainly those of the late sales by the same Company, who consider this one just as good as any of the previous sales.

abstract: The Seventeenth New-York State Volunteer regiment, under the command of Lieut.-Col. N.B. BARTRAM, arrived in this City from the Rappahannock yesterday morning at 8 o'clock. The regiment numbers about 300 men. It was organized by Col. H.S. LANSING, who was with it up to the time of his appointment as general recruiting officer for the State of New-York, which position he now holds.
lead_paragraph: The Seventeenth New-York State Volunteer regiment, under the command of Lieut.-Col. N.B. BARTRAM, arrived in this City from the Rappahannock yesterday morning at 8 o'clock. The regiment numbers about 300 men. It was organized by Col. H.S. LANSING, who was with it up to the time of his appointment as general recruiting officer for the State of New-York, which position he now holds. Col. BARTRAM has led the regiment into some of the severest battles that have been fought, and long since established a reputation for skill and bravery that few officers possess. The Seventeenth was attached to the Fifth Army Corps, and was among the regiments that gallantly drove back the rebels at the battle of Hanover Court House. It was also engaged at the battle of Gaine's Mill, holding a position near the left of our line, and subsequently took part in other engagements in Maryland and Virginia. It bore a conspicuous part in the battle of Chancellorsville, and will long be remembered as one of the fighting regiments.

abstract: The President has approved the findings of the Court-Martial in VALLANDIGHAM'S case, but has ordered him to be forthwith sent beyond our lines. General satisfaction is expressed at the result, which so happily meets the difficulties of the case avoiding the possibility of making him a martyr, and yet effectually destroying his power for evil. It is understood that Gen. BURNSIDE has already executed the order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 20.

abstract: A few days since, S.V. GARVIN, Esq., Assistant District-Attorney, received a letter from Gov. SEYMOUR, deputing him to conduct the investigation into the charges against the Police Commissioners. The investigation was announced to commence yesterday, but Mr. GARVIN has not yet received a copy of the charges against the Commissioners, or any of the papers on which the investigation is based. As soon as the Governor sends on the papers, the investigation will proceed. The law requires the investigation to be had before the County Judge, who in this county is supposed to be Judge DALY, of the Common Pleas. The facts elicited on the investigation will be submitted to the Governor for his action. During the recess of the Legislature, he has power to remove the Commissioners and appoint others in their places.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: We have nothing very stirring in the way of active operations, except the brilliant cavalry dash made by a detachment of the Third New-York Cavalry near Young's Cross Roads, resulting in the capture of a part of a company of the enemy's Cavalry force, stationed in that neighborhood, including thirty horses and twenty prisoners. The expedition was under the command Lieut-Col. LEWIS.

abstract: Ladies' Aid Meeting in New-York
lead_paragraph: FALLON's STEREOPTICON. -- The exhibition of this magnificent exponent of natural beauty and artistic attainment is continued, during this week only, at the Brooklyn Atheneum for the benefit of the Central Sunday School. Mr. ROSE, the lecturer, a gentleman fitted for the arduous task of intelligently describing the multitude of views presented, has, by long residence in Europe and perfect familiarity with the originals of these pictures, become absolutely au fait in the work, and renders the exhibition doubly entertaining and instructive by his narrations of fact and descriptions of scenery. The exhibition in Brooklyn is a success which, if transferred to New-York, would become a fortune. This and to-morrow are the closing days in Brooklyn.

abstract: Trade of its, the Future
lead_paragraph: The notion that the grass would grow in Broadway, if New-York lost the Southern trade, on which the Pro-Slavery partisans used to rely so much in their appeals to Northern baseness and cupidity in old times, has at last been thoroughly disposed of. The hardiest plant in the American fauna has never had less chance of supporting life on Broadway than at this moment. The rush and roar of traffic, the hot haste of thriving trade, were never more unmistakeably manifest than now. There are no more planters at the St. Nicholas or New-York Hotels; the keenest-scented "runner" cannot discover a Southern dealer anywhere in the City; HAMBLETON himself might stalk abroad, pencil in hand, and find not a single merchant or huckster to whom his smiles or his frowns would be of the least consequence; and still we live and flourish. Even the dry goods men, who, more than any other class, were ready to endure anything that Southern insolence might have in store for them, sooner than reveal a shred of conscience or of self-respect, have never made so much money as this year. The delusion that twenty millions of the most industrious, ingenious, energetic people in the world, with half a fertile continent to toil on, were dependent on the custom of 300,000 Southern farmers, most of them living in a very rude and simple way, to save them from ruin, has at last been effectually exploded. The North had during the last twenty years many humiliations to undergo, but we doubt if there has been one of them half so mortifying as the general prevalence and great influence which this transparent humbug and deception once enjoyed.
headline: {'main': 'The Future of Southern Trade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Future of Southern Trade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Enlistment of Colored Troops
lead_paragraph: The requisite preparations for the commencement of the business of enrolling in the district assigned to Col. ROBERT NUGENT, A.A. Provost-Marshal-General, have been completed by that officer, and as soon as the Government blanks arrive from Washington the work will immediately begin. The blanks are looked for daily, and in all probability it will not be later than next Monday that the people liable to be drafted will be called upon to give their names. The same parties employed by the former Provost-Marshal -- Gen. DRAPER -- have been retained by Col. NUGENT. In addition, a large number of assistants have been appointed, so that as little time as possible may elapse -- say one month -- ere the work shall have been finished. The business consequent upon the enrollment in connection with other business dispatched at the office of the Provost-Marshal will, for the next few weeks, cause arduous labor in that Department. The known ability of Col. NUGENT, however, is a warrant that he is equal to the task, and many of the officers and clerks under his command have already proved their efficiency. As an evidence that the officers connected with the Provost-Marshal's Department are faithful and vigilant it is only necessary to state that, on an average, twenty arrests are made daily. The parties arrested include numerous citizens who have exhibited ample proof that they are either Southern spies or Southern abettors. It seems to have become a ruling passion of many to embark in the contraband trade. Only three days ago a man was arrested for fitting out a schooner with an assorted cargo for some secesh point. It is known that vessels for the rebel South have cleared from this port, but of late the business has become rather precarious, and probably it will nut be long before that class of traders will be completely broken up. In order to meet the exigencies of the time, Col. NUGENT has appointed a force of detectives, whose duty it will be to travel in different portions of the Department of the East and arrest all parties found aiding and abetting the enemy.

abstract: -- Emigrants from Europe continue to pour into this port at an astonishing rate. For weeks past they have averaged a thousand a day. Thus far this year, we have had altogether forty thousand, or about three times the number that arrived in the corresponding period of last year, when the imigration was considered respectably large. As yet, the greater part of those who have arrived this year are from Ireland, though a fair proportion are from Germany, the other great European hive. They are attracted here partly by the demand for labor and the high wages laborers command. The general prosperity here also has enabled our foreign population to send larger remittances than usual to their friends in Europe, and thus facilities have been afforded the latter to emigrate. It is probable that after the Spring and early Summer influx from Ireland, a vast German tide will set hitherward. Tens and hundreds of thousands of people in Germany are anxious to come to America, attracted in great measure by the facilities for acquiring land under the Homestead Law. The Governor of Ohio has appointed a Commissioner to visit Germany, and invite the people of that country to remove to Ohio; and the fruits of this action will doubtless appear by Autumn.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS -- SIX CASES OF DROWNING. -- CATHARINE E. SAWYER, a child, fell into a sink yesterday in the rear of No. 189 East Twenty-first-street, and was drowned before assistance could be rendered. Coroner RANNEY held an inquest....An unknown man, about 40 years of age, was found floating in the East River, at the foot of Pine-street. The body was so much decomposed that it could not be recognized....The body of an unknown man, about 30 years old, was found in the water at Pier No. 7, East River. He was about 5 feet 7 inches in height, and had been in the water more than a month....A third unknown man, apparently about 35 years of age, five feet nine inches high, was found floating in the water at Pier No. 18, East River. The body had been in the water about two weeks. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest.....The body of WALTER CONKLING, who had been missing from his home for several days past, was found yesterday in the North River at the foot of Watts-street. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest....The body of an unknown woman was found floating in the North River, near Pier No. 5. Coroner RANNEY was notified.

abstract: the Banishment of Rebels from
lead_paragraph: The Government has been driven, at last, to the policy of deportation of rebels from Missouri. One day last week, a steamer left St. Louis for the South, having on board about forty rebel citizens who had been banished from that City, and condemned to make their abode in the Confederacy till the end of the war. If they return to the North they will be liable to be treated as spies under the military law.

abstract: Alma, which was captured off New Inlet, N.C., on the 2d inst., by the United States brig Perry, put into the lower harbor last night for water and provisions. She is bound to Boston, and is under command of Acting Ensign JOSEPH H. CLARK, of this city. The Alma is a schooner of about 100 tons, belonged to Bermuda, was from that island with a cargo of salt and whisky, and was endeavoring to run the blockade into New Topsail Inlet under British colors. She has on board six prisoners, her crew at the time of her capture. Last night two of the prize crew, one of whom belongs here, took a boat and ran away, coming up to the city. They have been arrested and returned to the vessel. -- New-Bedford Standard, 15th.

abstract: The supply steamer Union arrived yesterday, having completed the round of the blockading stations. She left New-York April 8, with supplies for the South Atlantic and East and West Gulf Blockading Squadrons, and stopped at the following places: Port Royal, New Inlet, Key West, Charlotte Harbor.
lead_paragraph: The supply steamer Union arrived yesterday, having completed the round of the blockading stations. She left New-York April 8, with supplies for the South Atlantic and East and West Gulf Blockading Squadrons, and stopped at the following places: Port Royal, New Inlet, Key West, Charlotte Harbor. Tampa Bay, Cedar Keys, St. Mark's, East and West Pass of St. George's Sound, St. Andrew's Bay, St. George's Bay, Pensacola, Mobile, Ship Island, Pilot Town, New-Orleans, Baton Rouge, Port Hudson, Sabine Pass and Galveston, returning direct from Key West, which port she left May 15. She has 50 prisoners and a number of discharged seamen on board. After leaving Mobile on May 9, the forward engine broke down, and since then she has used only one engine; and only with the help of fair winds was she enabled to reach this port in safety. While in lat. 26° 33′, lon. 84° 89′, the Union captured the British schooner Linnett, having a valuable cargo on board. She is a noted blockade runner, and at the time of her capture was on her fourth voyage. On the afternoon of the same day, between 3 and 4 o'clock, Acting Assistant Paymaster WARNER, formerly of the U.S. gunboat Kineo, jumped overboard while laboring under mental aberration. A boat was immediately sent to his assistance, and he was picked up, but life was extinct. He was burled at sundown with the usual honors.

lead_paragraph: CORONERS INQUESTS. -- Coroner HEGEMAN held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a man found in the water at the foot of Warren-street. The deceased was about 45 years old, with whiskers and hair slightly gray, dressed in dark cloth overcoat, dark cloth pantaloons, dark plaid vest, black silk neck-tie, white shirt, kid gloves and gaiter boots. The body will be detained at the Dead House as long as possible for identification....The body of a boy named LEONARD, drowned about two weeks since while bathing at the foot of Amity-street, was found yesterday morning in the East River, near Wheeler's Stores. The body was taken to the home of the parents, in Willow-place.

abstract: Our correspondent at Fort Snelling on the Upper Mississippi, furnishes rather a surprising idea of the magnitude of the military operations being carried on under Gen. POPE against certain Indian tribes of the Northwest.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Fort Snelling on the Upper Mississippi, furnishes rather a surprising idea of the magnitude of the military operations being carried on under Gen. POPE against certain Indian tribes of the Northwest. Of the ten regiments of Minnesota Volunteers raised for the war, five only are operating against the slaveholding rebels of the South while five are employed against the savage rebels of the farthest North. A military expedition, consisting of three full regiments of infantry, a regiment of mounted rangers, and a battery of artillery, all under the immediate command of that old Indian fighter, Gen. SIBLEY, is about to move from Fort Shelling, to begin war in earnest against the Sioux Indians, who are charged with keeping Minnesota in a condition of disquiet, and the settlers in a state of terror, for some time past. The Sioux have 5,000 warriors encamped near Devil's Lake, in the northwestern part of Minnesota, not far from the British line, and they are under command of the chief LITTLE CROW, whose name will be remembered in connection with the Sioux massacres of last Summer. This is a larger force than that of the whites who have gone out to attack them; but the superior military appliances of the whites will, of course, give them a vast advantage. About two thousand only of the Indian warriors are said to be possessed of muskets, while the majority are armed with bows and arrows and war-clubs. A desperate battle, or series of battles, is expected very soon, unless, as our forces advance, the Sioux retreat to British territory, where it would be impossible for our troops to follow them. They would thus play the part of the insurgent Poles, who lately fled across the frontier into Prussia, where the Czar's soldiers could not pursue them. Should the Sioux adopt this expedient, it would be well, both for them and for us, if, when they get across the lines, they would stay across. For it is a noteworthy and instructive fact, that in all the vast possessions of England in North America, with their tens of thousands of aboriginal Indians, there has hardly been an instance of any difficulty within any of them during the present century.

snippet: Maryland, the present and past of
lead_paragraph: In an article, a few days since, we attempted to show the different positions in respect of Slavery as affected by the present war, of the three great Border States -- Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri. We showed that secession had destroyed, in great part, the external commerce of these States which was based on the products of slave labor, and had also in great measure annihilated the value of their slaves as property.

abstract: The Richmond Sentinel characterizes the lies which floated about the North for a few days after HOOKER recrossed the Rappahannock as "false and absurd beyond precedent." They were false and absurd enough, but the Sentinel need not have gone outside of the columns of the Richmond papers to find in their statements, in relation to the late battle, precedent enough, if that were wanting.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Sentinel characterizes the lies which floated about the North for a few days after HOOKER recrossed the Rappahannock as "false and absurd beyond precedent." They were false and absurd enough, but the Sentinel need not have gone outside of the columns of the Richmond papers to find in their statements, in relation to the late battle, precedent enough, if that were wanting. The fifty guns captured: the ten thousand prisoners; the forty or fifty thousand muskets -- "more than had been seen together at once since the war began;" the clothing and blankets scattered so thickly over the fields that the rejoicing rebels on the march had no need to burden themselves with equipage, being certain of an abundant supply to be had for the picking up wherever their halting-place for the night should be -- all these were Munchausenisms of the first water.

abstract: The Difficulty between Gen. Webb and Mr. Christie; Webb, Gen., U. S. Minister at Brazil, and Mr. Christie; Explanations in Parliament
snippet: The Difficulty between Gen. Webb and Mr. Christie; Webb, Gen., U. S. Minister at Brazil, and Mr. Christie; Explanations in Parliament
lead_paragraph: Gen. WEBB, the American Minister at Rio, adopting an unusual and extraordinary course, addressed, in November last, a letter to Earl RUSSELL, giving an account of a personal difference with me and making accusations against me. He followed up this proceeding by others even more extraordinary. He circulated, in manuscript, his letter to Lord RUSSELL, with a variety of enclosures, as widely as he could in Brazil, and he has caused this correspondence to be printed in the United States and in England. It has appeared in Galignani's Messenger and in some English newspapers, and has been referred to in others; and it has been printed in the Brazilian newspapers. A very offensive passage of Gen. WEBB's letter was quoted in the House of Commons by Mr. BRAMLEY MOORE.

abstract: The $300 Exemption
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War seems still to be laboring under some difficulty in regard to the interpretation to be placed on the thirteenth section of the Conscription act. He is said to maintain that inasmuch as the language of the section is, that a conscript may provide a substitute or pay $300 to such person as the Secretary of War "may appoint," he (the Secretary) can, by failing to appoint any one to receive this money, render this portion of the section entirely nugatory, and thus oblige the conscript to serve, or provide a substitute in his own way, and at his own cost.
headline: {'main': 'The Conscription and the Money Exemption.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Conscription and the Money Exemption.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It cannot be doubted that the fall  of Vicksburgh and the opening of the Mississippi, will give exit to a good deal of cotton. Nearly all of it in Western Tennessee in the cotton-growing region between the Tennessee and Mississippi rivers has already got out, ...
lead_paragraph: -- It cannot be doubted that the fall of Vicksburgh and the opening of the Mississippi, will give exit to a good deal of cotton. Nearly all of it in Western Tennessee -- in the cotton-growing region between the Tennessee and Mississippi rivers -- has already got out, by one means or another, during the year in which our armies have been in that part of the State; but a great deal of the crop of the last two seasons in Mississippi and Southern Arkansas, still remains on the plantations in those States. Col. GRIERSON saw much of it during his ride through the central part of Mississippi; and while GRANT's army was encamped near the Southern line of Arkansas, scouts saw plenty of it in that section -- only a trifling fraction of which was brought away from the region near the river. Recent naval excursions up Deer Creek, in the Yazoo country, and in Red River and other Southwestern streams, have also found cotton -- in some places in great abundance.

abstract: We showed, a day or two ago, that from the opening of this month up to the 14th inst., Gen. GRANT had fought four considerable battles with the rebels in the vicinity of Vicksburgh, in each and all of which he had been successful. We have now to add a fifth, fought on Saturday last, which seems to be much the greatest of all, and equally successful with any of them. It appears that after the battle of the 14th, which resulted in the capture of Jackson, Gen. GRANT, abandoning that place, followed the rebels along the line of railroad in the direction of Vicksburgh, attacked them, under Gen. PEMBERTON, near Edwards' Depot, and, says Gen. JOHNSTON's official report, "after nine hours' fighting," the rebels were again compelled to fall back. The latest rebel intelligence would seem to show that GRANT's forces had then for the sixth time moved up to the attack; for we learn from a telegram in a Mobile journal that by Monday last he had advanced eight miles north, and on that morning found the rebel army under Gen. JOHNSTON in line of battle. At this critical moment we are again left in the dark. It is not likely, however, that much time was lost in beginning the attack.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 8th, the Earl o Shaftesbury brought the subject of Poland before the house of Lords, making a very strong pro-Polish speech.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 8th, the Earl o Shaftesbury brought the subject of Poland before the house of Lords, making a very strong pro-Polish speech. He denounced Prussia very fiercely, and exposed the real character of the Russian rule of Poland. After denouncing as evasive and treacherous the fair-seeming professions of the Emperor's Government in the recent diplomatic correspondence, and insisting that his intentions must be judged of by his acts and the menaces of his Generals, he asserted that the only cure for the evils which existed was the separation of Poland from Russia, to which, as well as to the other European Powers, she was a source of weakness and peril.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT this morning, both from our own and from rebel sources of information, is of the highest importance. After the capture of Jackson, his army, being provided with eight days' rations, he ceased communication with Grand Gulf, on account of the large escorts required for that service.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT this morning, both from our own and from rebel sources of information, is of the highest importance. After the capture of Jackson, his army, being provided with eight days' rations, he ceased communication with Grand Gulf, on account of the large escorts required for that service. From Jackson, it was understood to be his intention to force his way through to Haines' Bluff, on the Yazoo, and secure the enemy's transports. He held the bridge across the Big Black River with five thousand men, and had destroyed several miles of the Vicksburgh and Jackson Railroad near the latter place. Here information from our side ceases. Rebel dispatches state that our forces evacuated Jackson at 2 o'clock on Friday, the 17th, and proceeded toward Vicksburgh. On Saturday, the 18th, there was a heavy battle near Edwards' Station, on the Vicksburgh Railroad, between Gen. GRANT and the rebels from Vicksburgh, under Gen. PEMBERTON, in which the latter were driven back to their intrenchments -- one account states with the loss of sixteen pieces of artillery. Baker's Creek is stated as the exact locality of the battle. Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, in an official dispatch to the rebel War Department does not attempt to disguise the fact that Gen. PEMBERTON was defeated. This dispatch is dated at a point between Livingston and Brownsville, which would make his location westward of Jackson -- the direction in which he retreated when driven out of that place by Gen. GRANT. JOHNSTON says the battle lasted nine hours, when PEMBERTON was compelled to fall back behind the Big Black. The rebel Gen. TIL[???]AN was killed, and the losses are reported to be heavy on both sides.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the London Times has heard corroborations of the report that while every effort will be made to induce England and Austria to act in concert with France on the Polish question, the Emperor NAPOLEON will still pursue his object alone if obliged to do so.
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the London Times has heard corroborations of the report that while every effort will be made to induce England and Austria to act in concert with France on the Polish question, the Emperor NAPOLEON will still pursue his object alone if obliged to do so. The Poles seem to feel as sanguine in their expectations of aid from France as the Piedmontese did before the Emperor entered on the Italian war. This confidence must be founded on something more solid than vague hope. The question has been put from Paris to the Secret Committee which conducts Polish affairs, whether the insurgents are in a position to maintain themselves for two months more, and the reply has been in the affirmative. It is reported that a manifesto will be issued by that mysterious body which still eludes the grasp of the Russian Police, and organizes its bands from Warsaw, announcing that a loan, to a very large amount secured on the property of the wealthier Poles, is about to be raised, for the purpose of carrying on the war. The King of Sweden is heart and soul with the Poles, and the nation, apparently, goes with the King. Much of this feeling is, no doubt, owing to the hope of recovering Finland.

abstract: Decision on the
lead_paragraph: -- New-York importers will be interested in a decision which we publish this morning, made by Judge NELSON, in the United States Circuit Court. It seems that since the warehousing system was introduced, it has been not an unfrequent thing for merchants to enter their goods for warehousing, but before the goods were discharged from the vessels, to change their minds, and desire to enter them for consumption, possibly having sold them. On application to the Collector for liberty to change the entry of their goods in this way, they are informed that they can be allowed to do it upon payment of half a month's storage. This is in accordance with a regulation of the Treasury Department, made some years ago.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting, at 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday, to direct the payment of bills, to the amount of $350, for workmen's wages on the new Court-house, the Mayor having refused to sign a warrant for the necessary funds, because the pay-rolls had been audited only by the Committee of the Board in charge of the construction of the building, holding that the Board have no right to delegate the executive power of passing bills to any committee of that body. Mr. STEWART made a statement of the case, and Mr. TWEED presented the bills, with a resolution ordering them to be paid. The resolution was adopted, and the Board adjourned.

abstract: Advices from Europe two days later are received by the steamship China, which arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left Liverpool on the 9th, and Queenstown on the 10th inst. The news is of very little importance. The New-York correspondent of the London Herald asserts that the passages of the emigrants now arriving in the United States from Ireland are paid by the United States Government -- the sum appropriated to the purpose being $3,000,000, which is charged to enlistment expenses. The London Times thinks the capture of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson will prove a very damaging blow to the rebels. The news of the progress of Gen. BANKS in Louisiana, taken out by the Arabia, had created a cheerful feeling in the Federal element in Liverpool. A discussion had taken place in the House of Commons relative to the conduct of the British Minister in Brazil, during which Lord PALMERSTON sustained the course of that individual, and denounced Gen. WEBB, the American Minister. The Polish revolution was proceeding with varying fortune to the revolutionists. There had been no determination of the diplomatic questions growing out of it. The Liverpool cotton market was firm. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull. The latest quotation for Consols was 93 1/2 for Money.

abstract: Ireland, The Suspension of Habeas Corpus in
snippet: Ireland, The Suspension of Habeas Corpus in
lead_paragraph: It has been, from the outset, the settled aim of the rebel sympathizers and of the anti-war men to weaken, so far as they could, the arm of the Administration. They dared not vindicate the rebellion, and advocate peace with it outright, but what they dared not to do directly, they have constantly done indirectly. Not venturing to justify the rebellion, they have yet never ceased to apologize for it, and extenuate it, by denouncing Abolition as its provocation and cause. Not venturing to oppose the war squarely, they have yet sought to disable the Government from prosecuting it by opposing the conscription act, which alone can supply the men, and the financial measures, which alone could supply the means. Their whole public policy has been, not to plant themselves against the war -- for that would have been suicidal -- but to cripple those who carried on the war.

abstract: The steamers Ellen S. Terry and Thomas Collins from Newbern, N.C., having on board 527 men of the Third New-York artillery regiment, are expected to arrive at this port at an early hour this morning. The regiment was originally the Nineteenth infantry of this State, and has been under the command of Major-Gens. SANDFORD, MANSFIELD, PATTERSON, BANKS, MCCLELLAN, BURNSIDE and FOSTER. Brig.-Gen. LESLIE will return with the regiment, which will take temporary quarters at the Park Barracks. Thence they will proceed to Cayuga County, the place of enlistment. The regiment has been engaged in several severe fights, and on its banner are inscribed the names of eight battle fields. The number of men originally enlisted in the regiment and since recruited was 1,706, of which number 187 were lost in the service. The number of men remaining in the field is 992.

abstract: HARRY SANDERSON IN BROOKLYN. TO-night, at the Brooklyn Academy, Mr. HARRY SANDERSON, a young pianist of great talent and much culture, will give a grand concert. abstract: His Prediction and its Fulfillment
lead_paragraph: -- When the secession leaders were making their last speeches in Congress two and a half years ago, proclaiming the powerful empire they were about to found on the vast territory of the South, and showing how the North and Northwest would be made tributary and subordinate to the new power, Mr. LOGAN, a member of the House from Illinois, told them in an eloquent speech, that they could never make the Northwest tributary, that they could never block its great outlet, the Mississippi, but that, if they attempted such a thing, the "men of the Northwest would hew their way to the Gulf of Mexico with their swords." The rebels laughed at the idea; and soon afterward the now fugitive Governor of the State of Mississippi planted a hostile cannon on the heights of Vicksburgh, and one of the rebel organs in the place insolently inquired how the Yankees on the upper waters could "help themselves?"

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT, this morning is of the most exciting and important character. There can hardly be a doubt that it is the prelude to the announcement of the fall of Vicksburgh. An official dispatch reached the President yesterday, from Memphis, embodying information to Wednesday last.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT, this morning is of the most exciting and important character. There can hardly be a doubt that it is the prelude to the announcement of the fall of Vicksburgh. An official dispatch reached the President yesterday, from Memphis, embodying information to Wednesday last. It states that Gen. GRANT had captured Haines' Bluff, and the outer works of Vicksburgh, a large number of prisoners and 57 pieces of artillery, the battle being still raging, with every prospect of securing the entire force in Vicksburgh. At that time we certainly held Jackson, the Black River Bridge and Haines' Bluff. A previous dispatch, from Gen. HURLBUT, dated the 21st, at Memphis, states that the rebel Gen. JOE JOHNSTON was at Calhoun, 17 miles above Jackson, with 6,000 men -- the force with which he was driven out of the latter place -- endeavoring to effect a junction with PEMBERTON at Edwards' Station. A dispatch from Canton, dated the 13th, announced that Gen. GRANT had driven the enemy into his intrenchments on the Big Black, and that JOHNSTON had ordered all his provisions from Canton. There is sufficient evidence to show that the position of the rebels was extremely desperate.

abstract: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out on the fifth floor of the large five-story brick building located at the junction of Pearl and Cherry streets?the front on Pearl. The premises where the fire originated were occupied by Messrs. SAWIN  OSGOOD as a chair manufactory.
lead_paragraph: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out on the fifth floor of the large five-story brick building located at the junction of Pearl and Cherry streets?the front on Pearl. The premises where the fire originated were occupied by Messrs. SAWIN OSGOOD as a chair manufactory. This building was known as No. 360 Pearl-street. It is a total wreck, nothing but the bare walls having been left. The basement was occupied by Messrs. APPLEBY & SONS, of No. 133 Water-street, as a storehouse for snuff. They had a large amount of that article on store, and it is believed that the most of it was so much injured by water as to be rendered worthless. The Messrs. APPLBY were insured for $30,000 in City Companies.

abstract: And the Great Powers
lead_paragraph: The rashness of Prussia in committing herself to a close alliance with Russia, and in undertaking, in defiance of the opposition of the Chambers, to make common cause with her against the Poles, is becoming every day more apparent. The answer returned by Russia to the remonstrant notes addressed to her by France and England is pronounced by both countries unsatisfactory, and everybody is now asking himself what next? France is anxious to go further, in conjunction with Austria and England, and promises in this case not to look for any exclusive advantage for herself; but in case she acts alone, she hints that she will expect some compensation for her expenditure of blood and treasure. But then the chances are all against any united action on the part of the three Powers. They will all readily enough unite in protesting, but when it comes to enforcing their protests by deeds, the matter takes quite a different aspect. In England the popular dislike to military enterprises in conjunction with France, has, ever since the Crimean war, been very strong. The alliance on that occasion never worked well, and the English came out of the struggle, leaving all the glory in the hands of the French. Their recollections of that episode in their history have recently been still further embittered by KINGLAKE's history of the war, in spite of the efforts of the Times to bring the work into disrepute. It has unquestionably had a large influence in confirming the impression, already current among a portion of the public, that the British Cabinet was beguiled into undertaking it by the French Emperor, for his own purposes, and that he appropriated, rightfully or wrongfully, every particle of the credit and profit resulting from it; so that there has ever since been a very strong determination current not again to undertake a war jointly with the French. The Chinese expedition took place by force of circumstances, rather than as the result of a settled plan, and, like all the Indian wars, the British public felt little or no responsibility for it, and but a minor degree of interest in it. Moreover, the British force was considerably larger than that contributed by the French, and the ascendency consequently remained in the hands of the former.

abstract: Johnson, a Sensible Orator on the War
snippet: Johnson, a Sensible Orator on the War
lead_paragraph: -- It seems as if nothing would please those who claim to be the special and exclusive friends of our African population. After much trouble and bitter discussion, it has been decided that negroes shall have the right to assert their manhood in military clothes and at the point of the bayonet -- that they may fight their rebel masters, slay JEFF. DAVIS, bombard and overthrow the Confederacy that is based on the enslavement of their race, and establish their freedom on a permanent foundation. Thousands have embraced the chance held out to them -- especially in the Southwest and the South, and it seems as if by Autumn we should have a negro army pretty strong, at least as regards numbers. But this is not enough for the men we refer to. It grieves their souls that the black regiments should be officered by whites -- that the pay of the Ethiopian soldier should be less than that of the Caucasian -- that the white regiments laugh at the manoeuvres of the green black ones, and prefer not to mess and sleep with them -- that a regiment of blacks has been detailed for service before being thoroughly drilled -- (it is a wonder the objection is not to their being subjected to drill at all) -- and, in fact, almost every day brings forth a now series of complaints about real, imaginary, probable or possible grievances that the negro troops have been, will be, or may be subjected to.

abstract: By way of San Francisco we have advices from Mexico which fully corroberate the intelligence received from our own correspondents by way of Vera Cruz and Havana. The news is from the City of Mexico to the 2d inst., and from Puebla to the 30th ult. Gen. ORTEGA, in a dispatch to Gen. COMONFORT, thus sums up the situation:
lead_paragraph: By way of San Francisco we have advices from Mexico which fully corroberate the intelligence received from our own correspondents by way of Vera Cruz and Havana. The news is from the City of Mexico to the 2d inst., and from Puebla to the 30th ult. Gen. ORTEGA, in a dispatch to Gen. COMONFORT, thus sums up the situation: "The French have made eight assaults, succeeding only in two. We have lost nothing save our abandoned forts, and one line of defences. For the last thirty-one days we have not lost a foot of ground. The French continue to throw their bombs into the city, and are cutting ditches and covered ways for an attack on Santa Aurta." The Mexicans at last accounts were about to commence offensive operations against the French, under the direction of President JUAREZ in person.

abstract: A fire occurred last evening in Jersey City, in the ship-yard and dry dock, corner of Greene and South Seventh streets, belonging to MICHAEL S. ALLISON, the flames extending to a lumber-yard, and also to the Monitor works adjoining. An engine and rolling mill were destroyed, and there was danger that the three batteries building there would be lost, but they were not injured. The fire commenced early in the evening, in the ship-yard, from what cause does not yet appear. The property is nearly if not quite destroyed, and the loss of Mr. ALLISON is estimated at not far from ten thousand dollars. A large quantity of lumber belonging, it is said, to MCGRAW & Co., was also consumed.

abstract: Bruce, Hamilton; The New Customhouse Guide
snippet: Bruce, Hamilton; The New Customhouse Guide
lead_paragraph: -- The sheets of this handsomely-printed volume which in its typographical appearance reflects great credit upon the printers, Messrs. E.S. WESTCOTT Co. have been laid before us. It is from the pen of HAMILTON BRUCE, Esq., Deputy Collector, in charge of the Warehouse Bureau; the same competent band to which we were indebted for the Warehouse Manual, a work whose speedy success has demonstrated its usefulness to the public. A careful examination of the external and internal merits of the book, enable us to pronounce it an admirable and useful work; well calculated to answer all the purposes which the author had in his mind, when he prepared it for the scrutiny, use, and profit of its readers. Let us "begin at the beginning."

abstract: Cor. of Prince Gorchakoff with England and Austria; Prince Gortschakoff's Reply to England and Austria on the Polish Question
snippet: Cor. of Prince Gorchakoff with England and Austria; Prince Gortschakoff's Reply to England and Austria on the Polish Question
lead_paragraph: On the 14th of April Prince GORTSCHAKOFF replied to the protest of England in behalf of Poland. Earl RUSSELL'S dispatch, dated April 10, instructed Lord NAPIER to protest against the infraction of the treaty stipulations of 1815 by Russia, and expressed the opinion that the insurrection of the Poles was justified by the course of action which Russia had pursued. Prince GORTSCHAKOFF replies in turn to these divisions of the protest; first claiming, in explicit terms, that the treaty stipulations of 1815, in behalf of the Poles, were annulled by their revolt in 1830; and insisting, in the second place, that the continual conspiracies in Poland have brought affairs to their present condition, and that Russia cannot safely make further concessions. The conclusion of Prince GORTSCHAKOFF's dispatch is as follows:

abstract: Grievances of the Inchoate Citizen
lead_paragraph: The notion of the rule being a bad one that wont work both ways is most feelingly rejected by an inchoate citizen, (as we take him to be,) whose brief note is given in this issue. The President has announced, by proclamation, that inchoate citizens, as well as those fully naturalized and those to the manner born, are liable to draft in the forthcoming conscription. The fact was established previously by the simple reading of the statute. There was no ambiguity in the act. The full extent of the exemption, indeed, is therein set forth with a verbal punctiliousness, as well as brevity, which has few precedents in the construction of public laws. No ordinarily well-informed person could have been taken by surprise at the official interpretation put upon the Conscription act. And as to the President's Proclamation the only ground on which it was open to criticism lay in the fact of its being a work of supererogation.

abstract: Progress in
lead_paragraph: -- The old Kingdom of Portugal has taken a step that will make it shine forth in liberal contrast with some other of the States of the Old World. The passport system has been entirely abolished, and many of the time-honored restrictions on commerce removed. A comprehensive Royal Decree, based on the action of the Cortes, has been issued, establishing these changes. It sets forth -- 1. That all passports within the Kingdom are abolished, 2. That every individual, whether native or foreigner, may freely travel or move about within Portugal and the adjacent islands, without a passport or any other similar document. Among the burdens hitherto imposed on travel in Portugal, was a fee of 600 reis (about $10) levied on every foreigner crossing the bar at Lisbon. This fee is abrogated, as well as other fees imposed on vessels themselves.

abstract: THE UNION HOME SCHOOL SOCIETY. The second annual meeting of the Union Home School Society was held at the Home, Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth streets, near Eighth-avenue, on Friday, at 3 P.M. The following officers were duly elected for the present year : Mrs. DRAKE MILLS, President; Mrs. A.V. STOUT, Vice-President; Mrs. Dr. EDWARD WINSLOW, Secretary; Mrs. OLIVE M. DEVOE, Treasurer.
lead_paragraph: THE UNION HOME SCHOOL SOCIETY. -- The second annual meeting of the Union Home School Society was held at the Home, Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth streets, near Eighth-avenue, on Friday, at 3 P.M. The following officers were duly elected for the present year : Mrs. DRAKE MILLS, President; Mrs. A.V. STOUT, Vice-President; Mrs. Dr. EDWARD WINSLOW, Secretary; Mrs. OLIVE M. DEVOE, Treasurer. This School was organized May 22, 1861, since which time 122 children of Volunteers have been received and provided for by the charity of our citizens. The average number of children in the Home has been sixty since the first organization. The Managers failed to participate in the appropriation made by the last Legislature for Asylums in the City of New-York; the Attorney-General deciding that they were not entitled to receive such relief, the Charter title not giving the Society the word "Asylum," which by the bill was required. An application was made to the Common Council of this City for a donation, but failed to pass both Boards, and the Managers are thus left without funds to enable them to receive the many children daily applying for admission. From the report of the Treasurer it appears that the expenses of the Home have been, since its organization, to Jan. 31, 1863, a period of seventeen months, $10,561 90, an average monthly of $621 28, or about $86 for each child, including rent and all expenses, clothing, &c., for the whole time.

abstract: At Vicksburgh
lead_paragraph: Our telegraphic columns this morning contain an official dispatch from Memphis, which the President has furnished to the Press, announcing a great battle in the vicinity of Vicksburgh, and the capture by Gen. GRANT of the outer works of the place, with a large number of prisoners and fifty-seven pieces of artillery. The battle, it is said, was still raging on Wednesday. We are not told when it opened, nor its precise locality; but if we really hold the points mentioned in the dispatch, it must have been close in the rear of the great stronghold. Haines' Bluff, as our readers know, is directly north of Vicksburgh, and has always been considered the key of the position; and "Big Black River bridge" is twelve miles in the rear, or east of Vicksburgh, on the railroad. Looking at the bearing of these points, and considering that we command the line of the Big Black below Vicksburgh to its mouth at Grand Gulf, it is difficult to see how the Vicksburgh garrison can escape, unless JOHNSTON's forces succeed in getting in GRANT's flank or rear, and turning the tide of battle against him. It would seem that JOHNSTON's forces, at latest advices, were still somewhere north of Jackson, which we also hold; and as they did not succeed in effecting a junction with PEMBERTON's army at the heavy battle of Saturday, it is not likely that they effected a junction afterward; for, after that victory, GRANT pushed right on after the rebels, captured the bridge, and advanced to the very environs of Vicksburgh.

lead_paragraph: The Thirty-first regiment New-York Volunteers arrived in this City yesterday via Camden and Amboy line from Philadelphia. The regiment numbers 313 men. The original number was enlisted principally in this City, although two or three of the companies were from Brooklyn and Willamsburgh. The regiment was organized by col. E.C. PRATT, and by him led into action at the first Bull Run battle. Upon the promotion of Col. PRATT to be Brigadier-General, the command of the regiment was given to Col. JONES. During the early part of the Peninsular Campaign it was in Gen. FRANKLYN's brigade, and distinguished itself at the battle of West Point. It was subsequently engaged at the battle of Garnes' Mill and other battles on the Peninsula and before Washington, and more recently made itself conspicuous in the storming of Fredericksburgh Heights by SEDGWICK's division. On their arrival here they were marched to the Park Barracks, where they stacked Arms and remained till about 4 P.M. At that time Co. A. Seventy-first regiment N.Y.N.G., entered the Park for the purpose of escorting the Thirty-first up Broadway. After the parade the men returned to the barracks, and partook of a dinner prepared by Mr. WOOD, of the Astor-house, whose experience in that speciality has secured him an enviable reputation. The following is a list of the field-officers of the regiment: -- Colonel, FRANK JONES; Lieutenant-Colonel, L. Newmann; Major, Robert Daniels, (dead;) Adjutant, Charles C. Haight; Surgeon, Lewis Deaindeille; Assistant Surgeons, John U. Rippee and _____ Pray; Chaplain, F. McAtee.

abstract: -- The London Times of the 8th inst. has a letter from its Richmond rebel correspondent, which contains statements of the condition of affairs in the South that are not very consistent with other stories we have heard of the excellent state of things there, and the sanguine and jubilant feelings that prevail. He depicts the military prospects -shows, of course, that the South can never be conquered -- that the thought is the "wildest of chimeras;" but states that she is "sending into the field the very life-blood of her body politic;" and he is anxious for the "moral interference" of the "civilized Powers of Europe" in her behalf -- adding, that if foreign nations "could only witness the misery which is, from every acre of this once favored continent, crying aloud to Heaven, it could scarcely be but that they would risk some chance of failure rather than permit humanity to be outraged by a continuance of such excess of anguish as has visited no nation since the sword first leaped from its scabbard."

abstract: Dissatisfaction with Jeff. Davis
lead_paragraph: There are new evidences of deep dissatisfaction in the State of North Carolina with the despotism of JEFF. DAVIS. The article from the Raleigh (N.C.) Standard, an extract of which we publish to-day, is one of the most significant, and will arrest attention, both in the Confederate States and in the North. The Standard, it must be remembered, is the organ of Gov. VANCE, as it was his champion in the canvass which resulted in his election. The rebel Administration at Richmond threw all its influence against VANCE, and a number of its prominent stump-speaking members visited North Carolina, and made speeches against his election. The reply of the old North State was a crushing victory for VANCE -- he polling two-thirds of all the votes cast in the State.

abstract: The steamship Roanoke arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana on the 19th inst. She brings highly important intelligence from Mexico, brought to Havana by the French and English steamers from Vera Cruz.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Roanoke arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana on the 19th inst. She brings highly important intelligence from Mexico, brought to Havana by the French and English steamers from Vera Cruz. The French had been obliged to raise the siege of Puebla -- in consequence, as they admit, of the impossibility of taking the place without reinforcements and heavier artillery. The English and Mexican advices, however, say that the French have been defeated, and have withdrawn toward Orizaba, where they are expected to await the arrival of more men and material. It is also reported that a French convoy, carrying $1,000,000, had been captured by the guerrillas.

abstract: The Fall of
lead_paragraph: We have come nowadays to doubt a large number of the announcements of the telegraph; but we earnestly trust there is nothing but truth in the dispatch that Gen. GRANT'S army is in Vicksburgh, and that his victory is complete. We had previously learned that the outer works had been taken -- that Haines' Bluff batteries, immediately on the north, the Warrenton batteries immediately on the south, and the line of the Big Black River, including the great railroad bridge, in the rear, were all in our hands. We had learned that Gen. GRANT had fought five pitched battles with the rebels, in all of which he had been successful. We had seen how skillfully he had divided their forces -- driving LORING south of Jackson, JOHNSTON north of it, and PEMBERTON into Vicksburgh. We knew that he had committed terrible havoc in the enemy's ranks, had captured in the vicinity of 10,000 prisoners and an immense quantity of artillery. We knew that after his victory of Sunday last he had marched directly upon Vicksburgh, and, in the words of his Assistant Adjutant-General, had "invested it closely," while, at the same time, PORTER's fleet in the Mississippi opened a bombardment. On the 20th the right wing of our army had reached and rested on the Mississippi, above Vicksburgh, and, in the language of one dispatch, our men drank water from that river.

abstract: Union League Convention at Utica
lead_paragraph: This gathering, which is to take place at Utica on Wednesday of the present week, bids fair to realize the highest hopes of those who have wished for some demonstration of the loyalty of the State commensurate with its rank and influence in the Union. The efforts that have been made by the Copperheads to dissuade the returned soldiers from participating in the occasion have only recoiled upon the miserable authors. The soldiers have only been made to feel an intenser hate, a profounder detestation of them than ever; and will all the more rejoice in the opportunity to show to the people that they know how to stand by the old flag at home as staunchly as in the field of battle. Many of the veterans of 1812, in various parts of the State, tottering as they are under the burden of years, have caught the same ardor, and have resolved to make one more rally. The presence of these old relics of the heroism of fifty years ago, will give a peculiar consecration to the patriotic spirit of the day.

abstract: "New Eras" seem to be the order of the day, not only in warfare and politics, but in every other development of civilization. This past Winter has seen the successful establishment of German Opera in America, which as an "institution" has been in abeyance as long as was the Italian Opera, now so firmly fixed.
lead_paragraph: "New Eras" seem to be the order of the day, not only in warfare and politics, but in every other development of civilization. This past Winter has seen the successful establishment of German Opera in America, which as an "institution" has been in abeyance as long as was the Italian Opera, now so firmly fixed. No systematic and thoroughgoing attempt has heretofore been made to place English Opera upon a plane with habitually recognized public amusements. We have had charming but brief glimpses at its beauties through the skillful instrumentality of Miss PYNE. Miss RICHINGS and Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIP's, but nothing permanent has resulted. At last the same hand which so handsomely guided the German Opera to public favor, has taken hold of English Opera. When we know that Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ is to be the conductor of the musical elements of the new enterprise, we have at the outset assurance of experience, fidelity and rare skill in the most important position, though perhaps the chief attraction of the whole affair will be the welcome reappearance of Madame FELICITA VESTVALI, to whom we are indebted for the enterprise itself. This lady's reputation for beauty of person and of voice needs no trumpeting. We are glad to see that the first attempt is to be made with GLUCK's celebrated "Orphee," a lyric, comic opera, with which all Europe, and especially all Paris, has been simply wild. The incidents, based on a burlesque rendering of the classic story of the luckless Orpheus hunting after his abducted wife, Eurydice, in the infernal realm of Pluto, are side-splitting if not heart-rending, and the music brilliant and fascinating beyond words. Madame VESTVALI, who seems to be at once commercially and musically and par excellence the prima donna, appears as Orpheus, the god of song, supported by the sprightly and sweet-voiced Madame ROTTER, (whom all will remember as the contralto of the German opera) as Eurydice, also Miss GEARY as Venus, Miss KEMBLE as Hymen, and M. FOUCHE as Pluto.

abstract: The first chapter of the French movement upon Mexico seems drawing to a close. The intelligence by way of Havana, which we publish this morning, indicates the substantial failure of the invasion.
lead_paragraph: The first chapter of the French movement upon Mexico seems drawing to a close. The intelligence by way of Havana, which we publish this morning, indicates the substantial failure of the invasion. The official dispatch of the Mexican Gen. ORTEGA, from Puebla, dated April 29, received via San Francisco, and published yesterday, says: "We have lost nothing save our abandoned forts and our line of defences. For the last thirty-one days we have not lost a foot of ground." In corroboration of Gen. ORTEGA's dispatch, we publish this morning later intelligence from Mexico by the steamer Roanoke, to the effect that the French have actually been obliged to raise the siege of Puebla, and make a retrograde movement toward Orizaba. We have not the full particulars of this movement of the French, but the statement is highly important, as it comes direct and bears the evidence of truth. If it proves to be true, the failure of the French in Mexico is complete for the present at least, and it is very doubtful whether a renewal of the attempt to conquer the country will ever be made.
headline: {'main': 'The French in Mexico Continued Disasters.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The French in Mexico Continued Disasters.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

GRANT and Gen. BANKS, and the fleets of Admiral FARRAGUT and Admiral PORTER; yet, on several occasions lately, there have been happy instances of cooperative action, which are more gratifying to note and to witness than are the frequent and remarkable instances of absence of cooperation in military movements carried on but a few miles from the National Capital.

abstract: Programme of Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: RECONSTRUCTION OF THE UNION. -- Hon. J. GLANCY JONES, a leading Democrat of Pennsylvania, publishes in the National Intelligencer an article setting forth the basis on which the Democracy of Berks County proposes to reconstruct the Union, and which the Democratic party of the whole country is expected to adopt as its platform. He says that they will assent to no peace which shall dissolve the Union, and will submit even to laws that are unconstitutional, because there is no way of resisting them that does not involve anarchy or despotism which are still greater evils. But they will strive for the following amendments to the Constitution:

abstract: -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 128, of which 40 were adults and 88 children. The principal diseases were: Consumption, 19; diphtheria, 10; convulsion and marasmus, 8 each; croup, congestion of the brain and hydrocephalus, 5 each; apoplexy, typhoid fever, cholera infantum and dropsy in chest, 3 each; scarlet fever, erysipelas, pleurisy, casualties, inflammation of brain, heart, lungs and stomach, 2 each, &c. Natives of United States, 104; Ireland, 10; Germany, 6; other countries, 8.

abstract: Some days since, Provost-Marshal-General NUGENT received information of a conspiracy which was being inaugurated in the Sprague Light Cavalry, and giving the matter careful attention, he procured sufficient evidence to convict the guilty parties, who were at once arrested, and are now in a fair way to receive merited punishment. It appears that Capt. JOHN ABENDORFF, of the above mentioned regiment, devised the scheme of forming a band of guerrillas out of the above command, who were to be ready on their arrival at camp to skedaddle, and commence a career of robbery and bloodshed indiscriminately on friend or foe. The Captain's principal confederate was Sergeant BUCKLER, who was stationed at the camp at Plattsburgh, N.Y. A letter was secured, written by Capt. ABENDORFF, in which was written a cypher alphabet, with the key of explanation, informing the Sergeant that thereafter all communications must be in this cypher. Capt. A. was at once arrested and sent to Fort Lafayette, at which quarters his Sergeant is about to join him. As the men who joined the organization claim they did so for the purpose of exposing it, they are, at present, only detained under arrest in camp.

abstract: The President yesterday received a telegraphic announcement of the falt of Vicksburgh. The message came through from Memphis to Cleveland on Saturday night, but did not reach Washington until yesterday forenoon.
lead_paragraph: The President yesterday received a telegraphic announcement of the falt of Vicksburgh. The message came through from Memphis to Cleveland on Saturday night, but did not reach Washington until yesterday forenoon. It says: "The Stars and Stripes float over Vicksburgh, and the victory is complete." Our latest previous intelligence is to the afternoon of the 20th, at which time the surrender of the place is supposed to have been made. The reception of more definite intelligence has been prevented by the disarrangement of the telegraph line connecting Memphis with Cleveland.
