abstract: It is claimed that the Prize Courts in Boston, in disposing of the steamer Aries and cargo, did it with unparalleled quickness, and the Prize Court of this district is asked to follow the example there set. The truth is, the Prize Court here disposed of the steamer Princess Royal in a shorter time than was consumed in the Boston Prize Court over the Aries and cargo. The Princess Royal was reported to the Court on the 9th of February, and the libel was filed on the same day. On the 11th of February an order for the survey and appraisement of the vessel and cargo was made, and on the 17th appraisement of the vessel was returned. The appraisement of the cargo was returned on the 24th of February, and on the 6th of March the condemnation of the vessel and cargo took place, and on the same day, less than one month from the time of the arrival of the vessel, the steamer was transferred to the Government for $112,000. As the cargo was a very valuable one, there were three sales, and the whole was closed up by the 16th of May, the whole amount realized being $344,000. In the Boston case referred to thirty-eight days elapsed between the time of the vessel's arrival and her condemnation and transfer to the Government, while but twenty-five elapsed between the arrival of the Princess Royal and her condemnation and transfer to the Government. The delays that arise in prize cases are for the most part attributable to the claimants. Time is frequently asked by them to obtain additional proof, and often months elapse before the proof is forthcoming. The delay in forwarding the money to Washington, for distribution, is generally caused by the disputes among the captors. Often the officers and crews of vessels claim a share in the proceeds, which the capturing vessel is not disposed to allow. The rule is, that all vessels in sight, or in signaling distance, at the time of the capture, are entitled to an equal share in the sum realized, and it often becomes a nice question which vessels are in sight or signaling distance. -- Philadelphia Ledger, May 23.

abstract: The extensive fire in the ship, lumber and Monitor yards in Jersey City (reported in Sunday's TIMES) was not extinguished until 4 o'clock on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: The extensive fire in the ship, lumber and Monitor yards in Jersey City (reported in Sunday's TIMES) was not extinguished until 4 o'clock on Sunday morning. The ship-yard of Mr. ALLISON was wholly destroyed, but the dry-dock was saved; it received no serious injury. Mr. ALLISON estimates his loss at $10,000. Insured, on the ship-yard and dry-dock, for $15,000, as follows: State Insurance Company, (Jersey City,) $3,750; Jersey City Insurance Company, $3,750; and in four New-York Companies -- the St. Nicholas, $3,750; the Hanover, $3,750; the Metropolitan, $3,500; and the Globe, $3,500.

abstract: The prize steamer Eugenie, of Nassau, from Havana, arrived at Pensacola on the 8th inst., having been captured off Mobile. She is valued, with her cargo, at $50,000. When the chief engineer found she was taken, he commenced cutting the feed-pipes and destroying all the machinery in his power, with an axe; and when ordered to stop, told the officer to go to --. It was quick work to stop him by knocking him on the head, after the revolver had been snapped twice at him. She had four feet of water in her hold, and there was a heavy sea on at one time; yet, by great exertions, she was brought into port.

abstract: On Thursday of last week a ceremony took place at the First Presbyterian Church on Fifthavenue, interesting to the public from its association with a name universally known and honored in America.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday of last week a ceremony took place at the First Presbyterian Church on Fifthavenue, interesting to the public from its association with a name universally known and honored in America. This was the marriage of Miss GIZELLE MESZLENYI, niece of Gov. LOUIS KOSSUTH, to Mr. ADELBERT AMBROZOWITS, a Hungarian gentleman of high position who visited America for the purpose of taking the lady home as his bride.

abstract: The birthday of Her Britannic Majesty Queen VICTORIA, occurring on Sunday, no notice was taken of the event by English residents or English officials, in this City, deeming it better to defer it until yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The birthday of Her Britannic Majesty Queen VICTORIA, occurring on Sunday, no notice was taken of the event by English residents or English officials, in this City, deeming it better to defer it until yesterday. At an early hour in the morning the display of bunting from the Cunard Royal mail steamer China, being at present in port, told that something stirring connected with England was on the tapis, and at once it was ascertained that it was to celebrate the birthday (as one of the jolly tars expressed himself) of their beloved and happy Queen in England.

abstract: And his Successes
lead_paragraph: It is not supposed that our Generals in the Southwest are in need of any suggestions on the subject of strategy, the science which teaches how to get at, how to circumvent and whip an enemy. Gen. GRANT's famous mode of procedure -- to "move immediately upon the enemy's works" -- has proved as effective as it is popular, and it is not doubted that he will continue in the practice of this style of warfare as long as he remains at the head of an army.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on five 14th, and Londonderry the 15th inst., arrived ot[???] Father Point yesterday, on her way to Quebec. The Hansa, from Southampton on the 13th, arrived at this port last evening. By these arrivals we have advices from Europe five days later than were received by the China. A considerable fall in the Confederate loan had taken place in consequence of the success of the National forces in the Southwest. An attempt had been made in Paris to attach the proceeds of the loan in the hands of ERLANGER & Co., to  make good an alleged claim against the rebel Government for the destruction, of a ship loaded with cotton when leaving New-Orleans, in April, 1862, but the Civil Tribunal would not allow the claim, as it had not been legally substantiated. The first news of Gen. HOOKER's advance had reached England, and had given rise to some speculation. The Polish question was generally unchanged. Russia had shown some disposition to submit to the arbitration of a European Congress. Some further collisions are reported, with indecisive results. A further advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were quiet. Consols, 93 1/4@93 1/2.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on five 14th, and Londonderry the 15th inst., arrived ot[???] Father Point yesterday, on her way to Quebec. The Hansa, from Southampton on the 13th, arrived at this port last evening. By these arrivals we have advices from Europe five days later than were received by the China. A considerable fall in the Confederate loan had taken place in consequence of the success of the National forces in the Southwest. An attempt had been made in Paris to attach the proceeds of the loan in the hands of ERLANGER & Co., to make good an alleged claim against the rebel Government for the destruction, of a ship loaded with cotton when leaving New-Orleans, in April, 1862, but the Civil Tribunal would not allow the claim, as it had not been legally substantiated. The first news of Gen. HOOKER's advance had reached England, and had given rise to some speculation. The Polish question was generally unchanged. Russia had shown some disposition to submit to the arbitration of a European Congress. Some further collisions are reported, with indecisive results. A further advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were quiet. Consols, 93 1/4@93 1/2.

lead_paragraph: Punctually as the year renews itself this, the last and best of the Annuals, appears to record in convenient and permanent shape the achievements in science and art that have illustrated the course of the previous twelve months. For fourteen years the editor, Mr. WELLS, has performed this invaluable service, and the entire series now condenses a greater quantity of sterling matter than any other set of books of equally modest and unassuming pretensions, in the world. There is no English publication that can for a moment stand in comparison with it, for though we believe the idea of the work was originally derived from the London Year Book of Facts, the care and intelligence employed in the preparation of the "Annual," place it at once in a higher class than its predecessor ever aimed to reach. Though the past year has not been distinguished by any one or more discoveries or inventions of surpassing value, yet the active investigations now carrying on in every branch of science and art, offer in their results abundant matter for a record like the present, of great interest and importance. In the first section, "Mechanics and Useful Arts," is given the best summing up we have seen of the actual net gain to science from the English Great International Exhibition of 1862. It is prepared by the Editor from notes taken and material derived during a careful personal inspection and study. Every word of this will repay careful reading. In the same division the article on "Progress of Improvement in War Implements and Constructions," embraces the whole subject of iron-clad ships, rifled cannon, and the other thousand destructive and defensive devices that have taxed the ingenuity of military engineers since LOUIS NAPOLEON and the events of the last two years gave an impetus to the study. In Natural Philosophy, light and heat are the properties or substances that afford the greatest novelties. The splendid discoveries of Prof. KIRCHOFF on the physical condition of the sun and the presence of terrestrial elements in the solar atmosphere are detailed, and his researches on the Solar Spectrum and the spectra of the chemical elements, by which they were arrived at, are fully described. The latest improvements in Photography, celestial and terrestrial, are satisfactorily elucidated, and a careful abstract is given of Prof. TYNDALL's conclusions, drawn from the remarkable facts recently developed tending to show the connection or possible identity of mechanical force and heat. In Chemical Science, "The manufacture of color products from coal-tar," the source of the much admired Mauve and Majenta, and other brilliant hues, is, perhaps, the most interesting article. The editor describes a cylinder of mauve paste, shown by the inventor, Mr. PERKINS, at the Great Exhibition, so small as to be easily carried under one's arm, but which required for its production the tar derived from 2,000 tons of coal. Its value was $4,000, and its "tinctorial potentiality" equal to 100 miles of calico. In "Geology," the recent evidence for the antiquity of man, and in "Zoology," his place and distinct position in the animal kingdom claim most attention, while the discovery in the past year of four new planets (asteroids) and four comets, recorded under "Astronomy," shows that our observers of the heavens have been watchful at their posts. A scientific Bibliography and Obituary for 1862 complete a work which will seldom be consulted without without profit and preasure.

abstract: The objection made to the section of the Conscription act which permits persons drafted under it to purchase exemption by paying $300 that it gives the rich an unfair advantage over the poor is a capital specimen of ...
lead_paragraph: The objection made to the section of the Conscription act which permits persons drafted under it to purchase exemption by paying $300 -- that it gives the rich an unfair advantage over the poor -- is a capital specimen of that species of sophistry in which demagogues delight. It is based on two assumptions, which are false throughout, though they may doubtless be used to delude a good many of the ignorant or unreflecting. The first is, that it is possible to frame a conscription law which will impose the burden of defending the country on all men equally; and the second is, that a conscription which did not allow the purchase of substitutes would be more fair than one which did. If there be one of these more absurd than the other, it is unquestionably the first. It would be difficult to conceive of any burden imposed by the State on its citizens more unequally distributed than a forced levy of soldiers must always be. The nearest approach to fairness, in a measure of this sort, that it would be possible to make, would consist in calling the whole male adult population into the field, but even this, in spite of its semblance of equality, would inflict vastly greater hardship on some than on others. A levy en masse is, however, neither practicable nor necessary, nor even expedient. A very much smaller force is all that is required, and all that the highest and most lasting interests of the nation authorize the Government to raise. Therefore, a selection has to be made from the whole body, and in making this by the best conceivable process, the inequality in the distribution of the burden becomes greatly aggravated. Drawing lots is the recognized and most satisfactory mode of deciding who shall go and who shall stay at home. There is no better attainable method, but it is absurd to say or to suppose that the results worked out in this way are not gross violations of abstract justice. There is no reason founded on anything higher than expediency why 100,000 men who have had the misfortune to draw 100,000 tickets from a box with certain numbers inscribed on them, should march off to the battle-field, nolentes volentes, leaving the rest of the community quietly at home, with their families and business.

abstract: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday to listen to a delegation from the Board of Trade of Oswego on the subject of "A Ship Canal around Niagara Falls."
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday to listen to a delegation from the Board of Trade of Oswego on the subject of "A Ship Canal around Niagara Falls." The meeting was addressed, on behalf of that body, by Hon. DEWITT C. LITTLEJOHN, who commenced by remarking that he would proceed in a conversational way to give his views in relation to the subject before them. A Convention had been called by members of the last Congress -- over 100 in number -- to meet at Chicago to take into consideration the expediency of enlarging the facilities or transportation between the West and the East. In 1836 a survey was made with a view of connecting the Lakes with the Hudson River by means of a ship canal around Niagara Falls. Some three or four plans were submitted, and a large expense was incurred in making surveys. The subject had lain dormant for some time, not because it lacked merit, but in consequence of some few local prejudices. We had now arrived at a point when we must have more avenues of transit from the great producing West to the Atlantic The enlargement of the Erie and Oswego Canal had just been completed, and that line was now worked to its utmost capacity. New-York City, in seeking trade with the West, must take an interest in the means of communication between the two points. While we were projecting avenues we had a powerful rival at the North. The Canadian Government, weak herself, but aided by the Mother Country, was fixing her eyes upon the Western trade. The trade of Montreal had been rapidly increasing for the past five years. Mr. LITTLEJOHN then produced a map, by means of which he traced out the various canals connecting the lakes, and stated that by the present route the West was five hundred miles nearer Montreal than it was to New-York. The strong argument in favor of constructing a ship canal was a commercial one. The vessels that now float on the canals in use are confined to a tonnage of 450. By constructing the contemplated canal, ships of 1,000 or 1,500 tonnage would be enabled to land their cargoes on Lake Ontario. The distance from Oswego to Troy would be 172 miles by canal. The construction of a canal around the Falls would enable a ship of 1,000 tons burden to bring her cargo to within 22 miles of tide-water on the Hudson. Why had not this canal been built before? Because necessity had not demanded it. The time had come for action. The projected improvements from Canada and the laws of trade demand that the great State of New-York should examine this whole question most carefully. We represented the interest of the Metropolis of this continent, We had moved on with rapid strides, and the time was not far distant when we would dictate commercial laws to London. It was for the interest of New-York to take hold of the project he presented, and to open up an avenue for her own use, now and forever. It was true the enlargement of the Oswego and Erie Canals had done much good, but we must have a way to get our vessels into Lake Ontario. In the unfortunate event of a war with England, we could improvise our large canal-boats into gunboats, and also have an avenue for getting other war vessels into the lakes. As a military necessity, it was evident that the ship canal should be constructed. It was the intention or the delegation to present the views already given to the Chicago Convention. It was the true interest of the great commercial emporium of this nation to open up an avenue, so that the products of the West might be brought to the nearest point of tide-water, wherever that might be.

abstract: The enrollment of citizens under the Conscription law commenced in this City yesterday. The books prepared last year by Judge-Advocate ANTHON will be used as a guide in the present enrollment. The enrollment will extend over the first nine Congressional Districts, under the jurisdiction of Provost-Marshal General NUGENT. All aliens will be enrolled, and the question of citizenship will be decided by a Board of Examiners which will sit for that purpose, and which will also decide all questions regarding the age of parties claiming exemption on that score. A large number of men have been employed by the Provost-Marshal to make the enrollment, and the work was commenced yesterday in the First Ward. Negroes as well as white persons are to be enrolled, from which it appears that they will also be subject to the draft.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF A SHOOTING AFFRAY  Coroner WILDEY was yesterday notified to hold an inquest at the New-York Hospital, upon the body of JOHN BRAG, a butcher, who died from the effects ...
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF A SHOOTING AFFRAY -- Coroner WILDEY was yesterday notified to hold an inquest at the New-York Hospital, upon the body of JOHN BRAG, a butcher, who died from the effects of a pistol-shot wound, received on the 30th of April last, at the hands of SEBASTIAN DREAHR. At the time of the occurrence it was believed that BRAG could not live many hours; the Coroner was, therefore, sent for to hold an antemortem examination. The victim, however, survived until yesterday afternoon. DREAHR was arrested at the time, and has since been in prison awaiting the result. The quarrel took place in Laurens-street, and grew out of a dispute relative to the payment of some drinks. An inquest upon the body will be held to-day.

abstract: The world of art is not always faithless to its first loves. They who wield the palette and brush have recently gone back to the examples of medieval times in their search for simplicity and truth. Whether the pre-Raphaelites have succeeded is a question which we do not propose to discuss. In robbing the ancients we are governed more by wha we can quickly lay our hands on than by what is most valuable. Following the example of painting, the sister art of music -- after toying dully with the "future" -- has also directed her attention to the past. GLUCK, who has been dead and buried for the greater part of a century, has been "revived." The good people of Paris brought him from his grave, and galvanised him into life, and put him on his musical pins once more, and gave him "a run" in the gay Metropolis. Revived, rescusitated and restored in this manner, the old gentleman is in fine fig for a new career. Indeed, the proof of this is found in the fact that he has already trotted across the Atlantic to America. Mlle. VESTVALI, a lady who will be remembered as a favorite contralto during the seasons of GRISI and MARIO, signalized her rentree upon the American stage last night, by the production of the Maestro's "Orpheus." The version performed was nearly the same as that recently played with so much success in the French capital. It differs from the ordinary one in being denuded of certain modern excresences and inversions, and in following strictly the poem as originally written, and, historically considered, much of the interest of the revival lies in this fact, for GLUCK was a reformer who, with real genius, attempted to do a hundred years ago, what the "School of the Future" pretends to do now. He has himself written very explicitly on the subject of Italian opera, and his theory corresponds singularly with the wordy doctrine of the modern non-melodists. It is -- broadly stated -- that music should be subservient to poetry; that melody, except as a temporary vehicle of expression, is not the sole end and aim of composition, and that ordinary recitative, where a voluble singer gallons through a lengthy speech to a single chord, is nonsensical and childish. The converse of this is that a man may use every kind of elaboration, provided he does not stop the action of the piece by the superfluous introduction of melodies that are intended only for the popular ear. It is difficult now to estimate the extent of GLUCK's influence on art. It is conceded that he imparted largeness to the prevalent Italian style, and gave to the scena a simple intensity and an earnestness that were unknown until then. What was good in his theory was long ago absorbed into the ordinary practice of opera writing; what was bad is not likely to be accepted by the present or any other revival. The general public, however, in listening to "Orpheus," will be struck with the fact that it is melody alone that now imparts zest to the work; melody that is old-fashioned, to be sure, but still, simple, graceful and tender. M. BERLIOZ, the eminent critic, regards it as the best kind of melody the world has ever seen, or is ever likely to enjoy, but on this subject M. BERLIOZ -- a bad melodist himself -- is not absolutely infallible. The popular saliencies of the opera are certainly good or they would not have lasted so long in the public's fickle esteem.

abstract: The latest advices which have reached Washington from Vicksburgh are to 9 o'clock of Friday night, the 22d inst. Although they do not fully confirm the brief telegram from the Telegraph Manager at Memphis, published in yesterday's TIMES, they are of such a character as to ...
lead_paragraph: The latest advices which have reached Washington from Vicksburgh are to 9 o'clock of Friday night, the 22d inst. Although they do not fully confirm the brief telegram from the Telegraph Manager at Memphis, published in yesterday's TIMES, they are of such a character as to lead to the momentary expectation of receiving the official announcement of the fall of the great rebel stronghold. Up to the time specified above the centre corps of Gen. GRANT's army had fought its way to within one mile of Vicksburgh Courthouse; the right wing was about a mile and a half from the same point, and the left wing about the same distance on the left. Six thousand prisoners had already been captured. A dispatch from Gen. HURLBUT, at Memphis, expresses the most perfect confidence in our complete success.

abstract: The annual festival and pic-nic of the NewYork Turnverein took place yesterday, at Jones' Wood. The various Turner societies, to the number of about 3,000, assembed at 8 o'clock in the morning, ...
lead_paragraph: The annual festival and pic-nic of the NewYork Turnverein took place yesterday, at Jones' Wood. The various Turner societies, to the number of about 3,000, assembed at 8 o'clock in the morning, at Turn Halle, in Orchard-street, and at 9 1/2 o'clock the procession moved, via Canal-street, Bowery, Second-street and Avenue A, to the foot of Tenth-street, where they embarked for Jones' Wood in the steamboat Merchant and bark Magnolia. Accompanying the Turners were the different societies of the New-York Sanger Bund, and several independent singing societies; also, the Twentieth regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. VON VEGESACH, comprising 350 men, and Company B, Fourth artillery, N.Y.S.M., Lieut. HOEFLAH. The exercises at Jones' Wood were similar to those of former years, and the varied enjoyments of this year's festival will compare favorably with any heretofore given, albeit the press of news upon our columns precludes the possibility of an extended notice, such as we were wont to give in less warlike times.

abstract: The track of this war is strewed with faded and with ruined military reputations. As we look back to the first year of the war, we are absolutely amazed to find how few who then stood out as Generals of mark have retained their place in the public regard.
lead_paragraph: The track of this war is strewed with faded and with ruined military reputations. As we look back to the first year of the war, we are absolutely amazed to find how few who then stood out as Generals of mark have retained their place in the public regard. Of course we leave those who have lost their lives -- such as LYON, SMITH, KEARNEY, MITCHEL, RENO, STEVENS and SUMNER -- out of the question. They died illustrious, but whether they would have kept that lustre, had they lived, no one can say. Aside from these, we think it would be rather difficult to name more than five or six of all the early Major-Generals whose military career has justified the expectations of the people. Their names have all suffered more or less, some from one cause, some from another; MCDOWELL's from a humiliating defeat, for which he was not at all responsible, STONE's for a disastrous miscalculation, PHELPS' for a foolish proclamation, BENHAM's for a proneness to strong drink, MCCLELLAN's for "pedantic slowness," FITZ-JOHN PORTER's for jealousy and treachery, FREMONT's for deserting his post because of personal feeling, MILES' for drunkenness and suspected treason, BUELL's for lack of earnestness and energy, POPE's for falsehood and bombastic vaporing, SIGEL's for unjust treatment of a fellow-General. BURNSIDE's for self-distrust, HOOKER's for unfulfilled promises, CURTIS' for mercenary dealing in cotton, &c., &c. This loss of former prestige probably has not been in all cases fully deserved, but it is none the less an undeniable fact. Of the very few who have escaped it, BANKS, ROSECRANS and GRANT are the chief, and of these, the last named is the one most notable instance.

abstract: Isidor Kaufman vs. Charles L. Richer. -- This was an action for assault and battery and slander. The plaintiff, a merchant, formerly doing business at No. 14 Dey st., complains that in November, 1861, at the store of Hersh & Rich, No. 34 Murray-street, this city, he met the defendant and asked him to pay him a small balance due on the purchase of some goods; that the defendant thereupon, without provocation, called plaintiff a "thief, robber, villain and scoundrel," and at the same time violently laid hold of the plaintiff and struck him several blows in and about various parts of his body: and the defendant taking at the same time from his pocket a knife, was about inflicting upon the plaintiff a severe injury, but was prevented by the bystanders. Messrs. Hersh & Rich, proprietors of the store, testified that no such language was used, and that the defendant did not assault the plaintiff, not being at any time during the difficulty within several feet of him; that the defendant happened to have a penknife in his hand, whittling or cutting a chair, when the plaintiff came in, but made no demonstration with it against him. The plaintiff, in [???] complant, claims $5,000 damages.

abstract: -- We publish in our advertising columns an acknowledgment of sums received toward defraying the expenses of enabling the returned volunteers from this City to attend the great loyal assemblage at Utica to-day. It will be observed that these expenses are somewhat larger than they were expected to be, from the fact that the New-York Central Railroad refuses to make any reduction in their fare from regular rates. This conduct on the part of the management of that road stands in marked contrast with the liberal action of the Hudson River Road, which charges only one fare for going and returning -- and also with the action of the Central Road last Fall, in running extra trains gratuitously to convey passengers to and from Democratic mass meetings at various points along its line. The fact that the Utica meeting has no political or party purpose whatever, but is merely designed to rally the loyal sentiment of the State to the support of the Government, probably explains the difference. Meantime, we trust the patriotic liberality of our citizens will more than compensate for the partisan niggardliness of the Central Railroad.

abstract: The above regiment, numbering about 550 men, and commanded by Col. FRANCIS E. PINTO, arrived in this City from the Rappahannock yesterday, at 5 1/2 P.M. The regiment was received at the foot of Cortlandt-street by a Committee, and escorted by them to the Park Barracks, where a dinner had been prepared. The Thirty-second participated in nearly all of the Peninsular battles, and was in some of the battles before Washington. To-day it will be escorted through the principal streets of the City by the Eighth regiment N.Y.N.G., Col. J.M. VARIAN. To-morrow morning, Company H, of the Thirty-second, will proceed to Tarrytown, where the citizens of that place will unite in giving them a grand reception. With reference to the parade to-day, the following order has been issued:

abstract: Mr. F.A. COLBURN, of the New-York World, on his arrival in Washington on Monday, furnished the Chronicle, of that city, with a sketch of the adventures of the newspaper correspondents who were recently captured at Vicksburgh in an attempt to run the batteries.
lead_paragraph: Mr. F.A. COLBURN, of the New-York World, on his arrival in Washington on Monday, furnished the Chronicle, of that city, with a sketch of the adventures of the newspaper correspondents who were recently captured at Vicksburgh in an attempt to run the batteries. The correspondents were taken, after two days stay in the "Gibraltar of the West," on their long journey to Richmond. They went by rail to Meridian, thence to the Tombigbee River, thence to Montgomery by steamboat, and across the country, and thence by rail to Richmond. They had a thorough view of the Confederacy.

abstract: River; commerce and possession of Vicksburgh
snippet: River; commerce and possession of Vicksburgh
lead_paragraph: While we cannot greatly over-estimate the importance to the Union cause, in a military view, of the capture of the rebel stronghold at Vicksburgh, it becomes our duty to present to the commercial public some limitations on its value, so far as regards immediate operations in their line. We do this, not for discouragement, but for safety -- to warn impulsive and not well-informed persons against too hasty investments of their capital or time in Mississippi River speculations.

abstract: The Richmond papers, within the last fortnight, have been full of hints and menaces  dark and ominous hints, as well as open and ferocious menaces of an aggressive movement of their Eastern and Western armies, in the direction of Maryland and of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers, within the last fortnight, have been full of hints and menaces -- dark and ominous hints, as well as open and ferocious menaces -- of an aggressive movement of their Eastern and Western armies, in the direction of Maryland and of Kentucky. The pressure is particularly great for an advance of LEE's army. This is not only urged in all the Richmond journals, but they pretend to have knowledge that it is on the very eve of taking place. We gave yesterday extracts from the Richmond Examiner of Saturday last, in one of which occurred the following sentences:

abstract: The London Times notices in its "city article" a financial breach of faith on the part of the Federal Government. The postage-stamp currency, it says, was issued under a contract expressly printed on the stamps themselves, that they should be received in payment for duties in sums below five dollars, and although the law in that respect has never been modified or repealed, the Collector of Customs acting under instructions from the Treasury at Washington positively refuses to accept them. The proceeding has been strongly protested against by those who are injured by it, but Mr. CHASE, in his confidence that they cannot make themselves heard through the various pretended organs of public opinion, is apparently indifferent in the matter."

abstract: Singularly and happily, the sun of yesterday, though hidden from popular observation, was not, as usual, screened from earth by the dampening rain nor the misty vapor. The Thirty-fourth Anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union was the occasion of great preparation in all the Sabbath Schools of our sister City of Churches, and her thousands of children, with happy faces and fond anticipations, greeted cheerfully the bright and glorious day which, for the first Anniversary in many years, was vouch-safed them.
lead_paragraph: Singularly and happily, the sun of yesterday, though hidden from popular observation, was not, as usual, screened from earth by the dampening rain nor the misty vapor. abstract: We have no later, but some additional intelligence from Vicksburgh this morning, embodied in a dispatch from Gen. HURLBUT to the War Department.
lead_paragraph: We have no later, but some additional intelligence from Vicksburgh this morning, embodied in a dispatch from Gen. HURLBUT to the War Department. He had received no official dispatches, but an arrival from Vicksburgh had brought him news to the 22d. Our captures at that time, as before stated, had been 6,000 prisoners, and seventy-four pieces of artillery. Our forces completely encircled the town, our men on Friday night having their colors planted on the enemy's works, and lying themselves on the exterior slope. Our loss had not been heavy, though the rebels were making a firm resistance. The place was expected to fall into our hands next day.

abstract: The Eastern Division was under the marshalship or Mr. GEORGE STAYLEY. It was computed that about 9,000 shared in the celebration, not to speak of the large crowd of interested spectators. The processions were supplied with American flags and with banners, inscribed with the names of the Sunday schools and the fitting mottoes.

It was computed that about 9,000 shared in the celebration, not to speak of the large crowd of interested spectators. About 1 o'clock, Lafayette-avenue and other thoroughfares in the neighborhood, began to be alive with Sabbath schools mustering and marching to the nine churches, where services were to be held. The processions were supplied with American flags and with banners, inscribed with the names of the Sunday schools and the fitting mottoes.

abstract: The great trotting-match for $5,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, between Mr. WALTERMEYER's celebrated stallion, George M. Patchen, and Mr. HENRY GENET's famed gelding, Gen. Butler, takes place this afternoon on the Fashion Course. Mr. TALLMAN will, at usual, drive Patchen, who is in excellent condition, and has shown, in his trial trots, not only great speed, but also that other most essential feature, great steadiness, as well as endurance. Butler is also in the finest condition, but in his, breathings round the Fashion track has shown his usual uncertain restiveness, which, however, is always turned to good account in the hands of DAN MACE, his driver, to whom a good break is at acceptable, and taken as much advantage of, as was often the case with the veterans Mr. MCMANN and Miss Flora Temple.

abstract: Mr. COLBURN, of the World, who was captured while running the Vicksburgh batteries, and carried to that city, gives the following account of the situation in that stronghold at the time he left there. He was confined at Vicksburgh until the 7th, and while in that city had several opportunities to learn both the strength of the works and the number of men to defend them. From the top of the Court-house, a commanding position, overlooking the country for miles around, Mr. COLBURN could not discover any elaborate earthworks of the enemy, except those fronting the river. They never dreamed of being attacked so suddenly in the rear. At Baker's Creek, where the principal battle of GRANT was fought, the fortifications were common earthworks of not much strength, and not presenting a formidable appearance. But, of course, since then they were considerably strengthened.
lead_paragraph: Mr. COLBURN, of the World, who was captured while running the Vicksburgh batteries, and carried to that city, gives the following account of the situation in that stronghold at the time he left there. abstract: Incendiary Letter on Vallandigham's Arrest
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR's incendiary letter to the Vallandigham meeting is thickly posted through all the viler parts of the City. There plainly is a systematic attempt to stir up against the Government all the bad elements of our community, and to prepare the way for the practical application of the Governor's flagitious sentiments. With all of FERNANDO WOOD's characteristic shrewdness, it is at once appreciated what a power for mischief lies wrapped up in those few studied sentences. Its nicely proportioned exaggeration of statement, counterfeit alarm, and affected indignation, were adapted, with consummate art, to fire the passions of the unthinking, and to put them in the mood of adopting and acting upon the final suggestions that the war against the Richmond Government be ended, and war against the Washington Government begun. The official odor, too, of the proclamation, was duly rated. What came from the hands of HORATIO SEYMOUR, as a private citizen, was of little account. What comes from him as the occupant of the Executive Chair of the State of New-York, must be, to the undiscriminating, of great account. Whatever it may be, it strikes their vision as a vermilion edict. They associate authority with it; and, if its language is in the line of their old party prejudices, they are almost sure to accept it implicitly, and shape their action accordingly. It was a clever thought in the rebel allies to placard that missive. It is worth to them all their covert wire-pulling, and all their platform rant, a thousand times over.

abstract: The West India mail contract had been renewed for six years, at an annual subsidy of £172,914 sterling. This is a reduction from present figures of £62,829 per annum, but the Honduras route is excluded and also the service between Greytown and Bluefields -- thus reducing the mileage by 41,304 miles. The projected combination of certain London firms with the Paris Credit Mobilier has been definitely arranged. The title of the London establishment is "The International Financial Society," and the proposed capital is £3,000,000, of which £2,200,000 has been subscribed, leaving £800,000 for allotment The shares are to be £20 each. The firms represented in the direction are those of Messrs. Heath & Co., Stern Bros., Geo. Peabody & Co., Frederick Huth & Co., Fruhlin & Goschen, Dobree & Sons and Robert Benson & Co.; while the Foreign Establishments with whom relations have been formed are the Credit Mobilier, of Paris, Spain and Italy, the Societe Generale de Commerce et d'Industrie of Amsterdam, Holtuguer & Co., Fould & Co., Piliet, Will & Co., Wallet, Freres & Co., Marcuard & Co., and A.J. Stern & Co., all of Paris, together with M. de Uribarren and several others. The object of the Society is simply stated to be "to assist and take part in industrial and financial undertakings, especially foreign loans and enterprises possessing Government guarantees." Another great financial concern, under the title or the "General Company of Credit and Finance," was also about to be launched. The capital is rumored to be fixed at £10,000,000.

abstract: LAURA KEENE IN BROOKLYN. To-night Miss LAURA KEENE, with a very fair company, gives a second appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: LAURA KEENE IN BROOKLYN. -- To-night Miss LAURA KEENE, with a very fair company, gives a second appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The romantic drama called "The Sea of Ice," in which Miss KEENE sustains the character of Ogarita, will be given, with a good cast. The house is already well sold, and doubtless a regular jam will, as usual, greet Miss KEENE's appearance.

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF SUNDAY SCHOOLS. Yesterday afternoon occurred the anniversary festival of the Sunday Schools of Williamsburgh. Thirty schools were represented, and took part in the ceremonies. In all there were estimated to be not less than ten thousand children in line.
lead_paragraph: ANNIVERSARY OF SUNDAY SCHOOLS. -- Yesterday afternoon occurred the anniversary festival of the Sunday Schools of Williamsburgh. Thirty schools were represented, and took part in the ceremonies. In all there were estimated to be not less than ten thousand children in line. Previous to the moving of the procession interesting exercises were had at several of the churches, and brief addresses were delivered by a number of clergymen of Brooklyn, New-York and Williamsburgh. In the evening the children and friends assembled at the South Second-street Methodist Episcopal Church, where addresses were received from Rev. Dr. PORTER and others. The day was fine for the parade, and the children and their friends seemed to enjoy themselves wonderfully. No accident occurred to mar the festivities of the auspicious occasion.

abstract: We suppose the latest news from Vicksburgh may be gathered from the lack of news in the Richmond papers of Monday. Some of the correspondents infer that the remarkable silence of the rebel newspapers of late ...
lead_paragraph: We suppose the latest news from Vicksburgh may be gathered from the lack of news in the Richmond papers of Monday. Some of the correspondents infer that the remarkable silence of the rebel newspapers of late is owing to the fact that they have intelligence of a great disaster, which they are not permitted to divulge. But it can hardly be believed that if GRANT had captured Vicksburgh by Saturday or Sunday last, that the Richmond papers of Monday would have contained articles showing that the place was impregnable. We give an article from the Richmond Examiner of Monday. It considers it certain that two assaults had been made on the land defences of Vicksburgh, both of which were repulsed; and adds that nothing could excuse or explain a want of success on the part of the defence. It gives a vivid picture of the position and strength of the rebel stronghold by saying that Vicksburgh is a mountain situated in a bend of the river -- that on all sides of it are high bluffs, crowned with batteries -- that an attack can nowhere be made with a force equal to the garrison -- that on no side can more than eight thousand men be deployed in line for assault, and that the character of the ground renders regular approaches difficult. The Examiner claims that PEMBERTON's army is the most important Army of the Confederacy; and the value of the position is evidently fully appreciated by the rebels.

abstract: on the Preservation of the Union
snippet: on the Preservation of the Union
lead_paragraph: GERRIT SMITH declared, in his speech before the Union League Convention, that he would sooner consent that Slavery should be restored stronger than ever, than that the Union should be given up. There is not a more thorough hater of Slavery in the land than he; not a man who has spent more money or more effort for the propagation of Abolition principles. His name has not only been prominently connected but completely identified with the Anti-Slavery movement from its earliest days. And yet in this crisis, he plants himself squarely on this high mark of unconditional Unionism. When Pro-Slavery men, of the Free States and the Border States, with equally rooted convictions in favor of the institution, come up to this same mark, and live up to it, as GERRIT SMITH proposes to do -- when they will say that Slavery shall sooner die the death than the Union, and shape their practical action accordingly -- then, and not until then, will they, too, fulfill their duty to their country. There is no other true Unionism than that of this unconditional sort, and at no time, in no place, for no cause, ought any other standard to be recognized.
headline: {'main': 'The True Standard Gerrit Smith on the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The True Standard Gerrit Smith on the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At the meeting of the Seventh Ward Board of School Trustees, held on Monday evening, Mr. JOHN J. ANDERSON, the Principal of Grammar School No. 31, was dismissed, and Mr. TONY GALLAGHER was appointed in his place. A number of the officers had been, for a long time, endeavoring to effect this result, and, at last, aided by outside political influence, they have succeeded. Mr. ANDERSON, we understand, has had the charge of No. 31 for the last fifteen years, and during such time the records show that he has been entirely successful in the management of the school. The only objection urged against him, and the one which seemed to be all potent, was that "he is a Republican."
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Seventh Ward Board of School Trustees, held on Monday evening, Mr. JOHN J. abstract: The work of enrolling names, as a preliminary to the draft, was commenced, as stated in the TIMES, in the Fourth District on Monday. The canvassers in other districts had not commenced their labors yesterday, in consequence of the requisite blanks not having been forwarded from Washington. Yesterday, however, Col. NUGENT, A.A. Provost-Marshal, received a supply of blanks, so, that, in all probability, the canvassers in each district will be employed to-day. The instructions to the canvassers that they shall take the names of parties, even if it is reasonable to believe they are exempt, are being rigidly enforced. The Board of Examiners for the Districts will determine whether said parties are or are not exempt. It is believed that the enrollment will be completed by the 1st of July.

abstract: The depredations of the so-called measure-worm, extend this year over a larger area in the City of Brooklyn than ever before. Although the first-lings of this pest made their appearance this season some ten or twelve days ago, the foliage of many a tree in the streets of this city, and even private gardens where they never were seen before, has already fallen a prey to their voracity. According to a report in Brooklyn, they have also been observed in the next neighborhood of (only two blocks distant from) Greenwood Cemetery. The most expedient and thorough measures should be adopted to check this nuisance in order to prevent the ruin of the far-famed, most beautiful spot in the world that ever was prepared for the burial of the dead.

abstract: A SINGULAR CAUSE OF DEATH. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, concluded an inquest at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, upon the body of a child 4 years of age, son of Mrs. WOOLEY, residing corner of Warren and Bergen streets, who died on Sunday under circumstances which led to the supposition that his death was caused by poison. It appears that a little over four weeks since the child was taken ill, and medical aid was called in. The physician found that the child had the measles, and prescribed a simple remedy, and cautioned the mother to be careful and not allow him to take cold. A few days after the physician called again, and found that the child was getting well, and his services not being required further, he did not call again. On the day following the mother discovered that the upper part of the child's mouth was inflamed, and applied borax and honey and other remedies, but the child's mouth continued getting worse, and several of the upper teeth dropped out. After the lapse of some eight days, another physician was called, and attended the patient. At that time the gum had sloughed off from the upper jaw; a large portion of the bone was bare, and the breath was feted. The patient continued getting worse, and finally died on Sunday. The mother and some of the friends supposed that the medicine first administered contained poison, put up by mistake. The medical evidence went to show that while the child was sick with the measles, it took cold and its mouth became salivated, and the neglect, for several days, of proper medical attendance caused the disease to assume the form of gangrene, and a verdict to that effect was rendered.
lead_paragraph: A SINGULAR CAUSE OF DEATH. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, concluded an inquest at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, upon the body of a child 4 years of age, son of Mrs. WOOLEY, residing corner of Warren and Bergen streets, who died on Sunday under circumstances which led to the supposition that his death was caused by poison. It appears that a little over four weeks since the child was taken ill, and medical aid was called in. The physician found that the child had the measles, and prescribed a simple remedy, and cautioned the mother to be careful and not allow him to take cold. A few days after the physician called again, and found that the child was getting well, and his services not being required further, he did not call again. On the day following the mother discovered that the upper part of the child's mouth was inflamed, and applied borax and honey and other remedies, but the child's mouth continued getting worse, and several of the upper teeth dropped out. After the lapse of some eight days, another physician was called, and attended the patient. At that time the gum had sloughed off from the upper jaw; a large portion of the bone was bare, and the breath was feted. The patient continued getting worse, and finally died on Sunday. The mother and some of the friends supposed that the medicine first administered contained poison, put up by mistake. The medical evidence went to show that while the child was sick with the measles, it took cold and its mouth became salivated, and the neglect, for several days, of proper medical attendance caused the disease to assume the form of gangrene, and a verdict to that effect was rendered.

abstract: THOMAS GAFFNEY, of the Fourth Ward, residing in Madison-street, was arrested yesterday for forcibly resisting an Enrolling officer while in the discharge of his duty. The case was reported at the headquarters of the Provost-Marshal of the Fourth District, which resulted in GAFFNEY being placed in custody. It is the resolute purpose of the officers having the execution of the laws under the Enrollment act, to see that they are enforced without fear or favor. It may be well, therefore, for persons having in contemplation the resisting of the enrolling officers to take warning in due season, or otherwise they may be subjected to an unexpected penalty.

abstract: The first of the series of trotting matches for the total amount of $30,000, between the above wellknown fast trotters, took place yesterday on the Fashion Course, and reminded us of a Flora Temple day. The day was most favorable for the race, and a thousand vehicles of all kinds were unusually well ...
lead_paragraph: The first of the series of trotting matches for the total amount of $30,000, between the above wellknown fast trotters, took place yesterday on the Fashion Course, and reminded us of a Flora Temple day. The day was most favorable for the race, and a thousand vehicles of all kinds were unusually well filled for the purpose of reaching the scene of exciting contest. There must have been at least from seven to eight thousand persons present. The old stand, from where the horses started, was filled from the ground to roof, which latter partially gave way, causing considerable consternation and a stampede among the spectators.

abstract: A few months ago the firm of Messrs. ROOT, ANTHONY  CO., lithographers and stationers of this City, received an order from New-Orleans for the engraving and finishing of a large number of notes which had been authorized and directed as the currency of that city.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago the firm of Messrs. ROOT, ANTHONY CO., lithographers and stationers of this City, received an order from New-Orleans for the engraving and finishing of a large number of notes which had been authorized and directed as the currency of that city. The amount ordered to be executed by this firm was about $420,000. A contract for the engraving and printing of them was made by Messrs. ROOT & ANTHONY with the firm of ORMSBY & CO., bank-note engravers, in Wall-street. The latter firm struck off a large number of sheets containing notes in sums of $5 and $10. Since the first sheets were completed, up to the present time, it is alleged that 531 of them, amounting, in the aggregate, to nearly $20,000, have been stolen from the office of ORMSBY & CO. As soon as the theft was discovered, -- which was some weeks ago, -- the detective Police were applied to, and these officers have been constantly on the alert, doing everything in their power to ferret out the guilty party, and endeavoring, if possible, to recover the stolen funds.

abstract: We have advices from Vicksburgh to the 23d  Saturday in a dispatch from Cairo. At that time the siege was progressing satisfactorily, with every promise of the speedy triumph of Gen. GRANT and his heroic army. A rebel bearer of dispatches from PEMBERTON to JOHNSTON had ...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Vicksburgh to the 23d -- Saturday -- in a dispatch from Cairo. At that time the siege was progressing satisfactorily, with every promise of the speedy triumph of Gen. GRANT and his heroic army. A rebel bearer of dispatches from PEMBERTON to JOHNSTON had been captured, who stated that the number of rebels in the city was between 25,000 and 30,000. On Friday morning, it is stated, PEMBERTON sent a flag of truce to Gen. GRANT, offering to surrender the place if the rebels were allowed to lay down their arms and march out. We have before received dispatches to the evening of Friday, which made no mention of any such communication from the rebel General. The rebels had been driven to the inner fortifications, and our forces completely surrounded the city -- the two flanks resting on the Mississippi above and below.

abstract: AN EX-POLICEMAN COMMITS SUICIDE. An expoliceman, named NATHANIEL S. WHIOAM, committed suicide at his residence No. 163 East Thirty-fourthstreet, on Monday last, by taking a large dose of laudanum mixed with brandy.
lead_paragraph: AN EX-POLICEMAN COMMITS SUICIDE. -- An expoliceman, named NATHANIEL S. WHIOAM, committed suicide at his residence No. 163 East Thirty-fourthstreet, on Monday last, by taking a large dose of laudanum mixed with brandy. After he had swallowed the poison he went to his wife and told her that he had taken his last drink. She, knowing that for two or three days previously he had been imbibing very freely of liquor, took no particular notice of the remark of the time. A few hours afterward he was found in his room in a state of insensibility. Medical aid was speedily called, but all efforts to recover him were useless -- he died in a short time. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest upon the body, and the jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts above stated. They censured Mr. R.V. BRIESEN, the druggist, at whose store the poison was obtained, and also his clerk, HENRY M. WILSON, for having sold laudanum without a label of "poison" upon the bottle, in violation of law. The latter was held by the Coroner to await the action of the authorities. The deceased was a native of this State, aged about 36 years. No cause has been assigned for the commission of self-murder.

abstract: TelegraphicFictions and Popular Faith
lead_paragraph: The way in which the telegraph is abused in this war, was very well exemplified on Sunday last. People were watching Gen. GRANT'S proceedings down the Mississippi with a good deal of interest. They heard, with satisfaction, of his success at Port Gibson, at Raymond and at Jackson. They were wrought up to a high pitch of excitement by the news from Edwards' Station and Baker's Creek; but still nobody expected that he would walk into Vicksburgh on the heels of the rebel army without firing a shot or meeting with any opposition at the town itself -- when somebody in Memphis takes it upon himself to telegraph to Washington that the place was captured, and that the Stars and Stripes were floating over it, &c., &c. The natural result was that on Monday the public was painfully disappointed to find no confirmation of the report; on Tuesday it began to suspect there was something wrong, and on Wednesday there were rumors of disaster, and we presume we shall, during the remainder of the week, and until the matter is decided one way or other, be tormented by the most dismal forebodings.
headline: {'main': "Grant's Campaign Telegraphic Fictions and Popular Faith.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Grant's Campaign Telegraphic Fictions and Popular Faith.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A paragraph has recently gone the rounds of the Press referring to the arrest of certain officers connected with the Sprague Light Cavalry, on the ground of contemplated desertion for the purpose of engaging in a reckless career of robbery and bloodshed on friend or foe. The statement in the main is correct, but a serious discrepancy is discovered in the mentioning of names, especially that of Sergt. BUCKLER, whom, it is alleged, was a principal confederate in the scheme. The facts, as elicited from the officer who made the arrests, are: That JNO. AUDORF, a Captain in the Sprague Light Cavalry, formed a league with certain parties in this City, whose object was to organize a band of plunderers and robbers, who were to carry out their nefarious practices in the States where our active armies exist. In order to secure the complicity of the men under his command, AUDORF wrote a letter to Sergt. BUCKLER, of his Company, intrusting its transmission to Sergt. CAREY, the Captain's real Confederate. The letter was written in German, and contained a series of characters to be adopted in future correspondence. Upon receiving the letter Sergt. BUCKLER proved his loyalty by immediately taking measures to inform Provost-Marshal Gen. NUGENT of what was transpiring, whereupon AUDORF and CAREY were arrested and brought to this City. They will be taken to Fort Lafayette to-day.
lead_paragraph: A paragraph has recently gone the rounds of the Press referring to the arrest of certain officers connected with the Sprague Light Cavalry, on the ground of contemplated desertion for the purpose of engaging in a reckless career of robbery and bloodshed on friend or foe. The letter was written in German, and contained a series of characters to be adopted in future correspondence. Upon receiving the letter Sergt. abstract: The above regiment, whose return from the seat of war was noticed in the TIMES of yesterday, was honored with a municipal and military reception yesterday afternoon. Since the arrival of the regiment in the City, they have been quartered at the Park Barracks. At 3 o'clock the regiment was formed in line in the square opposite the City Hall, and, after being reviewed by the Mayor and members of the Common Council, passed into Broadway, where the Eighth Regiment N.Y.N.G., were waiting to escort them up town. The column moved up Broadway to Twenty-third-street, thence to the residence of Mrs. LAMBEER, in Lexington-avenue, to whom were returned the flags presented to the regiment two years ago. The regiment then marched down Broadway to the Park Barracks, where they partook of a sumptuous collation prepared by that able caterer, Mr. WOOD of the Astor House, by authority of the City officers. The regiment was attached to the Third brigade First division of SEDGWIICK's corps, and has distinguished itself in numerous engagements in the Peninsula and before Washington. The following is a list of the field officers:

abstract: The estate of the late THEODORUS BERGEN, situated on New-York Bay, in the Eighth Ward, and consisting of 70 acres and 850 lots of ground, was sold at auction, yesterday at noon, by A.J. BLEECKER & SON, No. 111 Broadway, New-York. The first section put up was the area bounded by First-avenue, Fifty-fourth and Fifty-seventh streets, and the bulkhead or pier line established by the Harbor Commissioners in 1857. This plot consists of 16 acres, with all the buildings thereon, and was bought by Messrs. WALSH, GASLER & CHASE, at the price of $28,600.

abstract: From the statements of gentlemen who have just arrived from the Rappahannock, it seems probable that the rebels have greatly reduced their strength, and are maintaining a more shell in front of our lines. abstract: The last day's races took place yesterday, in presence of a most brilliant gathering of nearly 10,000 persons, of whom at least a fourth were females -- a large proportion from among the leading families of New-Jersey, many from New-York, and other more distant localities. Those who were present on either or all of the three days of this most successful meeting will fully bear us out in saying, that a more successful and satisfactory race meeting has never been held; and the Executive Committee may reasonably prepare more extensive accommodations to satisfy the public, when they hold their next racing meeting. To show the interest and confidence of the New-York turfmen in the Paterson equine display, it may be remarked that, notwithstanding an enticing pacing match was advertised to take place on the Fashion Course, between two celebrated pacers, only about six wagons were there, and but few persons, to witness the event, while at least thirty Erie Railroad cars were required to convey the New-Yorkers and others to Paterson; and all the available fast and other teams and coaches were put in motion over the New-York and Paterson roads to accommodate others.

abstract: Up to 1 o'clock this morning no later news, official or otherwise, had been received from Vicksburgh. Our Washington correspondent states that nothing had been received there up to a late hour last night. It begins to be the talk in official circles that the siege may continue a fortnight.

abstract: About 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon an explosion occurred in WILSON's new bakery, in Cherry-street, between Clinton and Montgomery streets, whereby two men, named OWEN and TERRENCE LARKIN, were so badly burned on the head, face and arms that no hopes are entertained of their recovery. Four other men, named WM.H. HENDERSON, EDWARD FLANERY, EDWARD MCCAFFREY and JOHN MULLIN, were very much injured by burns and bruises.

abstract: Copperhead Curses Coming Home to Roost
snippet: Copperhead Curses Coming Home to Roost
lead_paragraph: Considering the length of time which Copperhead politicians managed to look on, if not with satisfaction, at least with contentment and in silence, at the practical suspension of the habeas corpus throughout the entire South before this war broke out; considering the placid approval or indulgence with which they witnessed, for nearly forty years, the nullification by every one of the Slave States of that essential and vital clause of the Constitution which guarantees to every citizen of the United States freedom of speech and trial by jury all over the Union; considering the eagerness with which they supported those provisions of the Fugitive Slave act which shamefully set aside the time-honored presumption of the common law, that every man is free till the contrary is proved, and imposed on the people of the Northern States the humiliation of seeing persons who might be their fellow-citizens carried into life-long bondage on the dictum, not even of a Court, but of a Commissioner -- we cannot, for the life of us, much as we value forms, and much as we respect honest human lamentations, help taking a little dismal pleasure in the sight of their present griefs. When we remember that when Slavery daily and hourly either trampled our laws under foot or wrested them for the confusion or destruction of liberty, and for the deification of brute force, these men deprecated all protest and all indignation, we have no bowels of compassion for them, in their present affliction. Seeing how much violence and illegality they could endure for the benefit of Slavery, we know that they can endure very much more than they have yet encountered for the benefit of freedom. They are shocked by Judge LEAVITT's refusal of a habeas corpus to VALLANDIGHAM -- they, who thought it no shame that a Washington Judge should simply fine BROOKS $300 for beating in the skull of a United States Senator in the Senate Chamber itself. They are horrified that a man may not in the North say his say in favor of peace -- they who applauded for long years the system which forbade any man to say, in two-thirds of the Southern States, one word against Slavery, and who voted with the men who upheld this system as the highest political good. When Northern men, or non-slaveholders, were tarred and feathered and robbed every month, not by the sentence even of courts-martial, but by the wild will of ruffianly mobs, the voices that are now so eloquent on behalf of law and order, did nothing but shout approval. Not one note of protest or of warning ever came from them; not one syllable did they ever utter, to admonish the nation of the demoralization which familiarity with such unchecked wickedness and illegality was sure in the long run to work. It is awful, now, forsooth, that men may not preach against war, under the protection of the Constitution; but it was simple and natural, that under that same Constitution no man dared say a word against either the morality or economy of treating the whole laboring population of one-half the Union as beasts of the field.
headline: {'main': 'Curses Coming Home to Roost.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Curses Coming Home to Roost.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A Court of Inquiry has been ordered to convene at Brooklyn for the purpose of investigating charges preferred against ABNER STIMERS, Chief Engineer of the iron-clad depot in this City. The following are the officers of the Court: Admiral GREGORY, Commodores STRINGHAN and NICHOLSON. It is alleged that Mr. STIMERS used disrespectful language about Rear-Admiral DUPONT, when coming home from Charleston in the steamer Arago. JOSEPH COLWELL, of Jersey City, and several others, will be summoned as witnesses.

abstract: National Convention at Utica
lead_paragraph: -- Our neighbor, the Herald, wastes a great deal of space and labor in canvassing the relative success of the two Conventions which met at Utica on Tuesday and Wednesday, in what it assumes to be their objects. The first seeks to make Mr. CHASE President, and the other aims to achieve the same feat for Mr. SEWARD, according to the Herald. Being just now especially devoted to the renomination and reelection of Mr. LINCOLN, that journal naturally opposes both. It can take comfort. Its candidate is in no danger from either of the others, so far as the action of the Utica Conventions are concerned. Both those bodies, according to the best of our knowledge and belief, utterly ignored the claims of the distinguished statesmen named, and, indeed, of everybody else to the Presidency. We did not see nor hear of a single man, in either meeting, who would express himself in favor of CHASE, SEWARD, LINCOLN or anybody else for President. There seemed to be a very general conviction that unless we were to have a country, it would be a matter of very little consequence who should be President; and that the first thing in order was, therefore, to crush the rebellion and restore the Union. When that has been accomplished, we can begin to talk about Presidential candidates.

abstract: The dispatches concerning affairs at Vicksburgh continue to be as nearly as possible incomprehensible. We have really, as yet, nothing definite from either side beyond our Washington dispatch published on Tuesday, which announced that on Friday of last week, the three corps of Gen. GRANT'S army ...
lead_paragraph: The dispatches concerning affairs at Vicksburgh continue to be as nearly as possible incomprehensible. We have really, as yet, nothing definite from either side beyond our Washington dispatch published on Tuesday, which announced that on Friday of last week, the three corps of Gen. GRANT's army had planted themselves on either flank and in the rear of Vicksburgh -- the corps averaging about a mile in distance from the Court-house. We know nothing of any very heavy fighting after the battle of Big Black Bridge, twelve days ago, though we have a telegram from Cairo this morning announcing a terrible and bloody assault on Vicksburgh a week ago to-day. If it be so, the War Department must have known of it for some time, as they have been for four days in possession of intelligence from GRANT's army up to 9 o'clock on last Friday.

abstract: Street Cleaning, City Inspector Delavan's Letter
snippet: Street Cleaning, City Inspector Delavan's Letter
lead_paragraph: -- The contractor, or sub-contractor, for cleaning the streets of this City, having completely failed in his duty, the City Inspector took the job in hand a fortnight ago, in compliance with a resolution of the Commissioners of Health, directing him to do so. The work was commenced with a force of from seven to eight hundred men, including cartmen; and it is claimed that, in a fortnight, fifty thousand loads of stuff, including ashes and garbage, have been removed from the streets. Having accomplished thus much, the City Inspector now reports that "the nuisance arising from filthy streets no longer exists." We are very grateful to the City Inspector for what he has done, and cheerfully acknowledge that it is not a little; but we suspect it would not be very hard work to get another "fifty thousand loads of stuff" from the streets of New-York. Many of the densely populated streets running north from Canal-street are still in a shocking condition, not to mention many others in other sections of the City. Now that the City Inspector has been authorized to take the work in hand, we hope he will have it properly done, as it is impossible to deceive the people in this matter. The evidence daily presented to four, at least, out of five of their senses, forbids deception. It would be well for the City Inspector to actually inspect the City, as his title implies he will do, and not merely be satisfied with the reports of subordinates. It was bad enough to have dirty streets before, and be forced to pay heavily for their being kept dirty; but under our present duplicated and complicated system, or want of system, of keeping them clean, we ought at least to have perfect results, as we will certainly be taxed for them. The City Government, we suppose, will not scruple to pay for work actually accomplished by the City Inspector, though we do not see that it could be called upon to pay the other parties for work not accomplished.

abstract: The action of our Government in withdrawing the mails of the Peterhoff from the custody of the prize-officers, and giving them up to the English authorities, is not passed by entirely without discussion in England; and though there are doubtless many there whose hearts exulted over the announcement of the fact, as being another proof that all the world must crouch before the British lion, yet there
lead_paragraph: The action of our Government in withdrawing the mails of the Peterhoff from the custody of the prize-officers, and giving them up to the English authorities, is not passed by entirely without discussion in England; and though there are doubtless many there whose hearts exulted over the announcement of the fact, as being another proof that all the world must crouch before the British lion, yet there are not wanting some who look at the affair in another aspect, and see in it a limitation of the rights of belligerents, which may hereafter be very injurious to England when she again has a war upon her hands. "Historicus," who has lately published such excellent letters on international questions, has written one upon this subject. He cites the ancient claim that a neutral convoy privileged the vessels under its charge from search and capture, which England resisted, and destroyed the Danish fleet in resisting; and he shows very clearly and forcibly that the claim of inviolability set up for the Peterhoff's mails because they bore the official seal is the same claim, but in a stronger form. For if the convoy of a national ship-of-war is no guarantee of the good faith of a vessel, how much less is the mere presence of an official seal a guarantee of the contents of a mail-bag? And he goes on to show, what is obvious to any one who has given the subject a moment's thought, that the instant the rule is established that a mail-bag is inviolable, that moment all the true papers connected with a vessel and her cargo are sure to be deposited there, leaving only false and simulated ones for the inspection of belligerent vessels.
headline: {'main': 'The Peterhoff Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Peterhoff Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Persia is in with news of two days' fighting south of the Rappahannock, awful carnage, and the defeat and rout of some divisions of the Army of the Potomac. There the news leaves us, and we must remain four or five days in suspense as to the final result. A battle or military movement begun with rout may end with victory; but I need not say that few in England expect it.

abstract: The mass meeting at Utica, on Wednesday, was a decided success. It was very large, very enthusiastic, and distinguished by the entire absence of party feeling and the paramount determination to sustain the Government in its efforts to quell the rebellion and preserve the Union.
lead_paragraph: The mass meeting at Utica, on Wednesday, was a decided success. It was very large, very enthusiastic, and distinguished by the entire absence of party feeling and the paramount determination to sustain the Government in its efforts to quell the rebellion and preserve the Union. A large portion of those in attendance were Democrats, brought thither probably, at least in part, by the expectation of hearing Mr. BRADY or Mr. VAN BUREN, whose participation had been promised: -- but in no instance was the slightest inclination evinced to give party feeling any prominence, or to make party interest the leading motive of effort and of action. Hon. HENRY A. FOSTER, who presided, has always been a Democrat, but, like Judge DENIO and others who sent letters to the meeting, declared that in such a crisis he knew no party and would suffer no political prejudices or preferences to interfere with the duty which he owed his country as a citizen and a patriot. The resolutions, which were adopted unanimously and with the most hearty applause, expressed the same sentiments and evinced the same purpose. They were explicit in repudiating all party interests, in postponing all political differences until the supremacy of the Constitution is reestablished, in pledging full and complete obedience to all laws so long as they remain upon the statute book, appealing for the redress of wrongs and the establishment of political preferences to the judicial tribunals and to the ballot-box, and in repelling all thought of any peace which shall involve the disruption of the Union or the recognition of the right of secession. This seemed to be universally regarded as a platform upon which all loyal citizens could rally, whatever might be their differences as to men and measures, -- and at the same time distinct enough and strong enough in its assertion of principle to carry the country through the war.
headline: {'main': 'The State Loyal Mass Meeting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The State Loyal Mass Meeting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: And How to Get It
lead_paragraph: It has been stated that on a careful calculation it is judged that two hundred thousand bales of cotton have been released from rebel embargo by Gen. BANKS' recent successes in Western Louisiana. This cotton, in one mode and another, but perhaps slowly, will be got to market; for it is to be observed that almost universally, as our armies have advanced into cotton-growing districts, the owners of the staple have been found anxious to sell it, even to Yankees, and to get "greenbacks" in payment. Men who have been active in the rebel army, but who have dodged home on the advent of the "Federals," to look after their negroes and families, (their negroes first,) have been known to degenerate in a few days from chivalric champions of "Southern rights" into cunning and successful cotton brokers and contraband traders -- making partnership with avaricious "Yankees" -- and the twain driving a highly lucrative business in cheating their respective Governments of their "belligerent rights."
headline: {'main': 'Cotton, and How to Get It.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cotton, and How to Get It.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The demonstrative friends of Rev. H.W. BEECHER propose to accompany him, on his trip to Europe, so far as the light-ship. They have chartered the ocean steamer Merrimac, on which they will take their faithful Monitor in holy things a trip down the Bay, returning in time to meet the City of Baltimore just off the Narrows, where Mr. BEECHER and his traveling companions, President RAYMOND, of the Polytechnic, and Rev. Dr. HOLME, of Brooklyn, will be transferred to the steamer. The Merrimac will leave the foot of Montague-street, Brooklyn, at 10 A.M., on Saturday, and all who desire, within a limited number, can, by the purchase of tickets, share the fun and frolic, the solemnities and farewells of the occasion. Tickets may be had at the church, of Mr. WELD, the Trustees' Clerk.
