abstract: Richmond Dispatch on the Vallandigham Meeting at Albany
snippet: Richmond Dispatch on the Vallandigham Meeting at Albany
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Dispatch puts questions to Gov. SEYMOUR and the participators in the Vallandigham meeting at Albany which they will find it rather difficult to answer. "What do these people mean?" asks the rebel organ. "Is there one kind of liberty for them, and another for us? One kind of justice for them, and another for us? Or are we unworthy to be free, and they too good to be slaves? How can they coolly and unblushingly applaud the invasion of the South, and reprobate the arbitrary arrests of the North?"
headline: {'main': 'What Do These People Mean?"', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Do These People Mean?"', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Moore vs.Chapman; Husband and Wife as Witnesses
snippet: Moore vs.Chapman; Husband and Wife as Witnesses
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Moore et al. vs. Lydia J. Chapman. This was an action to recover for iron-work which the plaintiffs had put up in a number of houses owned by the defendant, who was a married woman. The work was done under a written order from the defendant, to the making of which her husband consented orally. The complaint set forth the cause of action, and prayed judgment against defendant in the ordinary manner as if she were a single woman.

abstract: United States vs. Boxes of Sugar; Error in Invoice
snippet: United States vs. Boxes of Sugar; Error in Invoice
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 1,382 Boxes of Sugar, Charles Luling Co., Claimants. This was a proceeding Instituted by Collector Barney in March, 1862, to forfeit 1,382 boxes of sugar, imported from Havre by Charles Luling. The value of the importation in this market was about $40,000. An entry for the sugars for warehouse was made at the Custom-house, Jan. 27, 1862. On March 28, 1862, the importer, desiring to reexport the same, presented at the Custom-house exportation entry for the same, which passed the Collector's office, but was stopped in the naval office, where it was said that the goods had been seized because of certain things appearing on the invoice. The case was sent to the District-Attorney in March, 1862, and the sugars libeled for fraudulent undervaluation.

abstract: DEAR MR. JEROME: I inclose you $50 toward defraying the expenses of the volunteers to the Utica Convention. My first intention was to contribute twenty-five, but as I see they were suffered to cheer for MCCLELLAN, I raise it to fifty. Pray see that nothing is done to prevent them voting for him also when the proper time arrives. Common sense is not so common as is generally supposed, but I should think there was enough left to put a stop to these blind and blundering assaults upon a retired patriot, whom the mass of the people respect and admire, and whom the soldiers love. Truly yours,

abstract: FELIX O. DE LABAUME, a Frenchman, about 25 years of age, was examined before United States Commissioner STILLWELL yesterday, on a charge of presenting false and forged claims against the Government. He forged the signatures of Gen. HARVEY BROWN and Surgeon W.V. WHITE, to a certificate discharge from the hospital at Fort Columbus, and on this certificate obtained $148 back pay. The signature of Gen. BROWN was so well done that the General was unable to swear that it was a forgery except by referring to his books, and ascertaining that no soldier by the name of ORIN T. KNIGHT, mentioned in the certificate, had been in the hospital. DE LABAUME was at one time in the army, connected with the New-York Enfants Perdus. He was committed for trial by the Commissioner.

abstract: The military situation at present is singularly unsettled and threatening. Of our three  great armies, one is in actual conflict, another ...
lead_paragraph: The military situation at present is singularly unsettled and threatening. Of our three great armies, one is in actual conflict, another (if we can believe any of the Tennessee letters or dispatches) is but waiting for the order to move upon the enemy, and our chief army has been for some days kept on the alert for an offensive movement of the main army of the rebels. The long period of quiet and inaction which everywhere existed from the opening of the year up to the close of last month, was broken by HOOKER's crossing the Rappahannock and GRANT's crossing the Mississippi -- which, it may be noted, were done simultaneously; and though some of the greatest and severest battles of the war have been fought by two of our armies during the month, it seems at its end as though all of our armies might again at any instant and at the same time close in with the enemy.
headline: {'main': 'Prospects of Our Armies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Prospects of Our Armies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The most active theatre of the war will probably be, very soon. Eastern and Middle Tennessee. Gov. ANDREW JOHNSON, appreciating the necessity of restoring that region permanently to the Union, and the obligation of all patriots to deliver the suffering Union people there from rebel despotism, is making strenuous exertions to secure these results. One of the best things he has done is to authorize the raising of a regiment of cavalry for special service in Eastern Tennessee. The Governor has, moreover, succeeded in obtaining authority from the War Department to recruit the regiment in this State, and others in any other State where the Governor consents. Gov. SEYMOUR has officially sanctioned this arrangement. Here is a most excellent opportunity to render service to the Union cause where it is most needed. Maj. ERNEST N. BEMENT, formerly of Michigan, and long in the service of the Third Pennsylvania cavalry, has been assigned to the duty or recruiting the regiment in this Stase. Maj. BEMENT has been well and favorably known as an editor and poet, and has distinguished himself in the field as a brave and accomplished officer. He will have command of the regiment when raised, and no better commander could be desired. We hope the ranks will be speedily filled and the regiment sent forward to Tennessee. By the arrangement with Gov. SEYMOUR all recruits will be credited to the State of New-York on the draft. It is expected that a large portion of the men will be recruited in the central and western portions of the State. Maj. BEMENT is now in this City, and has his office at No. 167 Broadway, where he will furnish any desired information. Now is the time to fill up the first regiment of the "Andrew Johnson cavalry."

abstract: Whipple, Gen. A. W.
lead_paragraph: Gen. A.W. WHIPPLE, who was mortally wounded at the battle of Chancellorsville, was born in Massachusetts, entered the United States Military Academy in 1837, and was graduated from that institution in 1841. As a cadet he gave promise of that distinction which he afterwards won in so many different spheres of duty. Having graduated with high honor in a class including such men as Gens. TOWN, WRIGHT, LYON, GARESCHE, BRANNAN, HAMILTON, REYNOLDS, BUELL and RICHARDSON, he was promoted to the corps of Topographical Engineers, and at once entered upon the duties of his profession. For two or three years he served in various unimportant capacities, until, in 1844, he was selected by the the Commission for establishing the Northeastern Boundary as assistant to Major (now Colonel) J.D. GRAHAM, and in the capacity of assistant astronomer he established a reputation for scientific ability that afterwards led to his promotion to still higher positions. After the close of the Mexican war he was intrusted with the location of the boundary line between California and Sonora, in which duty he remained till the close of the war. On the completion of the Southwestern boundary he was called to take charge of an exploration for the location of a route for the Pacific Railroad. He had charge of the line from Fort Gibson, in Arkansas, along the 35th parallel to San Diego, in California. The zeal and fidelity with which he discharged this duty is shown in his report, published in the third and succeeding volumes of the thirteen volume report to Congress. His report of this survey, was extensively circulated, not only in America, but also in Europe, where it fell into the hands of HUMBOLDT. This report, from its ability, attracted the attention of the illustrious savan, and gave rise to a scientific correspondence which was continued during the life of the world's most eminent scientist. At the breaking out of the present rebellion, Gen. WHIPPLE was serving as a Captain of Topographical Engineers on the upper lakes, and he at once applied for service in the field. He was assigned to duty as a Major on the Staff of Gen. MCDOWELL. In this capacity he served at the first battle of Bull Run, and, if we may credit the reports of those who were present, he established for himself a reputation for coolness, intrepidity and daring second to that of none who were engaged in that memorable conflict. During the battle he was ever in the thickest of the fight, unmindful of the bullets that were failing like hail around him, and in the retreat he passed the entire night in the saddle, rallying the broken masses, and contributing in no small degree to the safety of those who were obliged to share in the disgrace of that hurried retreat. For his gallantry on this occasion he was promoted to the rank of Brigadier-General of Volunteers. During the Summer of 1862 he commanded at Arlington, but in the Fall of that year he asked to be assigned to a command in the field. He was in command of a brigade in SICKLES' division at the time of the late advance under Gen. HOOKER, and, as is well known, he was mortally wounded whilst in the act of penning an order. In his death, which took place on the 7th of May, Science was called to mourn one of its most distinguished votaries, and our country one of its ablest Generals.

abstract: Sons of Rhode Island, First Anniversary of the
snippet: Sons of Rhode Island, First Anniversary of the
lead_paragraph: The Sons of Rhode Island, residents of this City, held their first anniversary last evening at the rooms of the Historical Society, corner of Tenthstreet and Second-avenue. The Chairman on the occasion was Mr. JOHN G. WILLIAMS, the Vice-President of the Society. Conspicuous on the platform was the elegant banner of the Association, bearing on its folds the coat-of-arms and motto of the State of Rhode Island. After a few remarks by the Chairman, announcing the programme for the evening, he introduced to the audience Rev. Dr. FRANCIS VINTON, who proceeded to deliver an address on the history of his native State. Rhode Island, he said, although the smallest State in the Union, was the cradle of civilization of the nineteenth century. The foundations of free institutions in that State had been maintained, and spread over the whole country. Its freedom was asserted by ROGER WILLIAMS. When, in the seventeenth century, all Europe was convulsed with revolutions, it was the event of modifying institutions, while in this country new institutions were to be erected. The civilization of the nineteenth century owed to the experiments of Rhode Island men the familiar blessings of liberty and freedom of thought which we prize as our birthright. In reviewing the early history of the State, the speaker remarked that its old Norman name was Vineland. He next spoke of the old mill in Newport, built in the style of the eleventh century, and cited authority to prove that the structure could not have been of later date than the twelfth century. As other relics of antiquity, there were discovered in the excavations made for the improvements of the Fall River and Old Colony Railroad, numerous skulls, with chains of silver and wampum and coins bearing date of LOUIS XIV. These antiquities had been made the subject of a lecture before the Historical Society of this City. The lecturer next alluded to Mount Hope as the country seat of King PHILIP, and pictured in glowing terms the valor of that Indian chieftain, and his intercourse with the early white settlers, not omitting the trials and sufferings he endured, and finally the circumstances attending his death. There had been four eras in the State of Rhode Island -- the settlement, the charter, the adoption of the Federal Constitution, and the adoption of the State Constitution. The first two eras he would combine. With reference to the charter of Rhode Island and Providence Plantation, it was the first written Constitution in the world, and had survived all the attempts of demagogues to supersede it. The principles of free democracy which it embodies were planted there by ROGER WILLIAMS. The men who govern the State own the State. Religion is not interfered with, and that was one thing which conduced to the prosperity of its people. In the language of our honored countryman -- GEORGE BANCROFT, whom he saw before him -- "Nowhere in the world have life, liberty and property been safer than in Rhode Island." In alluding to the men who had emblazoned the banner of the State with their exploits and pervaded the nation with their heroism, the orator cited the name of JOHN WHIPPLE as the first man to shed blood in the war with England, and discharge the first broadside into Her Majesty's navy. The navy of the United States was nurtured in Rhode Island, as is attested by the act of HOPKINS, who trained JOHN PAUL JONES to sweep the seas. That State gave New-York her first Mayor. The name of Bishop BERKELY was next mentioned, and his career dwelt upon. In treating of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States, and the subdivisions under the heading of that era, the lecturer stated he had seen an article in an old Newport Mercury, in which the writer predicted that at some future day New-York would rival the commerce of Newport. Dr. VINTON then spoke of the tenacity of the people of his native State to State sovereignty, and produced a copy -- one of the original 300 -- of the Constitution of the United States, dated May 29, 1790, having attached twenty-one amendments as the only conditions on which the State would consent to enter the Union. In mentioning the names of THOMAS SLATER, GILBERT STEWART, JOHN BROWN, WHEATON and OLIVER HAZARD PERRY as among the eminent men which the State had produced, the speaker could not help referring, although a brother, to JOHN ROGERS VINTON, who fell at the battle of Vera Cruz, while gallantly leading forward his column, and of whom Gen. SCOTT said, that had he lived he would have led armies with heroic valor and skill. The fourth era was next dwelt upon, and with it the attempted insurrection of DORR and his followers. Dr. VINTON closed his address with a beautiful peroration, which, together with his preceding efforts, elicited the unbounded applause of his hearers.

abstract: On Wednesday next the Peaceites will hold a Convention in this City, in the great Hall of the Cooper Institute. We understand that there will be five outside meetings organized, independent of the main Convention itself, which will assemble in the great Hall of the Cooper Institute. The stands will be provided with music, officers and speakers. The names of the speakers for each stand will be stated in the printed programme in advance of the meeting, so that the public may know where to go to hear any particular orator. We are told that, although it is not known as yet which of the distinguished men who have been invited will be present and address the Convention, it is supposed that many such will be there.

abstract: Illinois Ship Canal, The
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday next a Convention will meet at Chicago, to consider the ways and means of constructing a ship Canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River. A project for a Canal of this sort was presented to the late Congress, and came within a few votes of passing. It was defeated, it was alleged, by the jealousy of Pennsylvania members of Congress, who feared that the effect of such a canal would be to enrich the Lake Shore and New-York railroads at the expense of those of the former State.

abstract: Dispatches from Gen. GRANT were received by the, War Department yesterday. They are dated near Vicksburgh, May 25 Monday.
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Gen. GRANT were received by the, War Department yesterday. They are dated near Vicksburgh, May 25 Monday. They represent the siege of that rebel stronghold as progressing satisfactorily, and that Gen. GRANT considers himself abundantly able to maintain his investment, and at the same time repel any attack upon his rear. Forty-five hundred of the rebel prisoners captured by him arrived at Memphis yesterday.

abstract: There has been no lack of visitors during the past two evenings at the spacious rooms of the Cooper Institute to see the very large and creditable display of pictures that the pupils in the Art Department of the establishment have this year.
lead_paragraph: There has been no lack of visitors during the past two evenings at the spacious rooms of the Cooper Institute to see the very large and creditable display of pictures that the pupils in the Art Department of the establishment have this year placed upon exhibition. On Thursday evening the students in the "School of Design for Women" invited their willing friends to come and examine how female genius and talent was able to develop itself under the fostering instruction of capable teachers, and the flag festooned rooms, ablaze with light, were pleasantly full of an assembly as appreciative and cultured as is ever apt to be drawn together. There is a wide-felt interest in this "School of Design for Women." Many years since it was founded by a number of benevolent ladies, who felt that among the poorer classes of the City there must be females possessing innate artistic talent that only needed opportunity to make itself apparent. The school was established, therefore, with competent teachers, to gratuitously instruct any such persons, and many a poor girl who now lives in happy competence as a teacher of drawing, or as a painter, engraver, designer or modeler, blesses the day that her talent for either one of these branches of art found a field in this establishment for its cultivation. When the Cooper Institute was opened the managers of the "School of Design" saw that it was for the best interests of their enterprise that it should be absorbed into Mr. COOPER's praise worthy project. For the past four years, therefore, its sphere of usefulness has been much extended and its good results are constantly augmenting. The roll this year presents the names of about 200 pupils. These young ladies are under the general direction of such a competent artist as Mrs. FIELD, who is ably assisted by Messrs. GRAY, WHITTREDGE and FARR[???] as teachers of drawing and painting, and Mr. O'BRIEN as instructor of engraving.

abstract: PUBLIC SCHOOL EXHIBITION. -- The Annual Exhibition of Primary School No. 11 was held on Thursday morning, in the public school building in Seventeenth-street. The large hall was tastefully decorated with wreaths of evergreens and baskets of flowers, while innumerable canaries in gilt cages, suspended among the flowers, made the scene vocal with their melodious warblings. Commodore WM.D. PORTER delivered a very feeling and felicitous address, and Messrs. DELAMATER and ST. JOHN were especially ad hoc in their remarks to the assembled children. Suitable speeches were also made by the teachers. But the main feature of the proceedings was the crowning of the "Queen of the May," Miss MARY WARD, a little lady of about eight Summers, was called to the throne. After the ceremony of the coronation her youthful majesty was presented with a tiny wand by Master GEORGE BROWN, and with a beautiful garland of flowers by a little girl of six years. Master WILLIAM HAZENFRAT, a liege not quite a dozen years old, who wore a dress emblematic of Autumn, offered his vernal sovereign a basket of luscious fruit as his tribute to the "May Queen." The exhibition terminated with the singing of the "Star Spangled Banner" by all present.

abstract: Address at St. Francis Xavier's College on Theories of Government
snippet: Address at St. Francis Xavier's College on Theories of Government
lead_paragraph: A very interesting occasion thronged the elegant new hall of St. Francis Xavier's College, on Sixteenth-street, on Thursday evening. The postgraduate class of St. John's College, at Fordham, assembled to listen to orations on special subjects, delivered by various members of their body, and a large audience of ladies and gentlemen attended. Among these, but occupying seats on the platform, was a numerous representation of the more eminent Catholic clergy of this and neighboring cities. The exercises were enlivened by the fine performance of NOLL's Band.

abstract: The specimens of embroidery and quilting exhibited at No. 495 Broadway, are worthy of inspection by all who admire the beautiful. We have noticed, in passing this establishment, opera cloaks, and other articles or ladies' wear, in various styles and designs, the embroidery of which surpasses anything we have ever seen. The perfection of the work is highly creditable alike to the talent of Mrs. E. SIMPSON, by whom it was executed, and to the excellence of the Grover & Baker Sewing-machine, by the aid of which the most intricate designs may be fashioned, and every variety of sewing performed with the greatest perfection, case and rapidity. -- Examiner.

abstract: There is a very great  THE CITY HALL PARK.--There is a very great  difference, these Summer days, between the appearance of City Hall Park and Union Park. Union Park, with its luxuriant and verdant grass plots, its heavily-foliaged, nicely-kept trees, its singing birds, its fountain, its tidy domestics and troops of romping children-- all these things of a pleasant afternoon give it a cheerful and animated aspect.
lead_paragraph: -- There is a very great THE CITY HALL PARK.--There is a very great difference, these Summer days, between the appearance of City Hall Park and Union Park. Union Park, with its luxuriant and verdant grass plots, its heavily-foliaged, nicely-kept trees, its singing birds, its fountain, its tidy domestics and troops of romping children -- all these things of a pleasant afternoon give it a cheerful and animated aspect. But the condition and appearance of City Hall Park is a disgrace to the City. In all that part of it fronting the City Hall, the grass has been completely trampled out of existence; the trees are scarred and battered, and many of them withered; the guard-chains which inclose the grass plots have nearly all been broken down and carried off; while the irregular and vile-looking rows of wooden chain-posts stand in dismal disconnectedness. Foul and ragged recruiting-tents are pitched here and there and everywhere; and the desolate and mournful aspect of the region is only relieved by a touch of the tragi-comic, in the presence of that awful bit of brown-stone blasphemy in which the metropolis caricatures the Father of his Country. The dirty children and hard-faced boys who hang around the Park, and fight in it, seem to partake of the spirit of the place and grow continually more foul and desperate.
headline: {'main': 'THE CITY HALL PARK.--', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CITY HALL PARK.--', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The and The Freedmen
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead evening organ was careful last night to inform its readers of a further invasion of the liberty of the citizen by a party of civil and military officials. During the afternoon of yesterday, a company of gentlemen, of the order vulgarly termed bummers, were peaceably enjoying themselves in a public bar-room near the Old Bowery Theatre, when an enrolling clerk entered the house in pursuance of his duties. Having taken the names of the proprietor and his regular boarders, the clerk, in conformity with his instructions, was proceeding to enroll the less solvent habitues of the place, when the latter showed signs of resistance, which ultimately led to their arrest by a Provost-Marshal's guard; not, however, before they had roughly handled the civil officer, and turned him forcibly into the street.

abstract: THOMAS GAFFNEY, the man who was arrested on Tuesday last for resisting the enrolling officer in the performance of his duty, had an examination before United States Commissioner SLILWELL, yesterday, and was held for trial in $500 bail. GAFFNEY keeps an auction store on the corner of Madison and Chestnut streets, and when the enrolling officer (E.A. SWEARINGEN) went into his place to enroll his name, GAFFNEY refused to answer any questions, and forcibly ejected the enrolling officer from his store. It was claimed in his behalf, on the examination, that he was intoxicated at the time, but this, of course, was not held to be any excuse for his conduct. Several other persons have been arrested, within a day or two past, for the same offence with which GAFFNEY is charged, and they will probably be disposed of in the same way.

abstract: Springfield Republican on Why we are Defeated
snippet: Springfield Republican on Why we are Defeated
lead_paragraph: The Springfield (Mass.) Republican has of late been exploiting the theory that the reason the Army of the Potomac was defeated at Chancellorsville, and the reason it has been defeated in so many campaigns, is that the soldiers do not fight as well as the rebels. It has recently been backed up in its position by the opinion of a Massachusetts officer who was taken prisoner at Chancellorsville, carried to Richmond, and has recently been exchanged. It is rather a curious theory certainly to preach in New-England; after what we have seen and heard of the valor and endurance of the troops from that section. But as this officer suffered himself to be taken prisoner by the rebels instead of fighting to the death, it is interesting to hear what he says for and against those of his kidney. After mentioning the circumstances under which he was taken prisoner, he continues:

abstract: Temple, Hon. Wm., of Delaware; Jones, Col. J. Richter
snippet: Temple, Hon. Wm., of Delaware; Jones, Col. J. Richter
lead_paragraph: -- Col. J. Richter Jones, of the Fifty-eighth regiment Pennsylvania volunteers, who was killed near Newborn, was a son of the late Rev. Horatio Gates Jones, D.D., of Roxborough, Philadelphia County, Penn., and was born in the year 1804. He received his academical education at the German-town Academy, and graduated with high honors at the University of Pennsylvania in the year 1821, in the same class with Hon. John Cadwalader, Antony Caussat and Robert M. Barr. Having studied law, he was admitted to the Philadelphia Bar on Nov. 17, 1827, and continued to practice until the year 1836, when he was appointed a Judge of the Court of Common Pleas for the County of Philadelphia, and held that office until his term expired by limitation under the new Constitution in 1847. When the rebellion broke out Col. Jones took high ground in support of the Government, maintaining that the preservation of the Union was worth all the blood and treasure that could be expended. He early offered his services to the War Department, and in July, 1861, received authority to raise a regiment, which by great exertion he succeeded in doing. He was commissioned as Colonel of the Fifty-eighth regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers, in August, 1861, and located his camp in Roxborough, where it remained until January, 1862. On the 8th of March, 1862, he left Philadelphia with his regiment for Fortress Monroe, and was in the advance when the attack was made on Norfolk, and was among the first to enter that city. He remained at Portsmouth, Va., until October, 1861, when he was sent to Suffolk, where he performed some bold movements on the Blackwater. Lo[???]ding for more active service, he was transferred to the Department of North Carolina, under Gen. FOSTER, and reached Newbern in January, 1863, and his regiment was marched to the outposts, about eight miles from Newbern, which position it has occupied ever since.

abstract: A riot of some magnitude occurred here last night. It was emphatically "a war between the races"--first, black pitted against white, and then (to do black no injustice) white against black with a vengeance--in which white, of course, came off triumphant and victorious. It was almost literally "a war carried into Africa."

abstract: -- A pecular case of conjugal infidelity has lately transpired in this city, and is causing so much talk in the streets among those who love to dwell upon such matters, that no harm can result from a reference to the affair in print A week ago the wife of an enterprising young man, engaged in the manufacturing and mercantile business on Exchange-street, suddenly left her husband and an infant, and went westward -- just where does not yet appear. She was accompanied as far as Batavia by a young man, who returned to the city immediately, it is possible that she may be residing in that village or vicinity. What makes this case peculiar, and, we may say, peculiarly aggravating, is the fact that the deserted husband purchased, some time since, the house and lot where he resided, and had it conveyed to his wife, that she and her children might enjoy it in any emergency which might deprive him of his property. As a mark of gratitude to the confiding husband who thus made provision for his family, the wife lately conveyed this homestead to another party without the knowledge or consent of her husband, and after she bad departed he found that she had taken with her the proceeds of the sale or had squandered them here. The matter has been put into the hands of competent persons to investigate, and it may be shown that other parties than those referred to, who have heretofore had a good standing in community, are implicated in this transaction. The woman who has departed is about 20 years of age. While her husband has no positive proof of her infidelity before leaving home, he has, we are told, such circumstantial evidence as makes her guilt conclusive to his mind. Names are withheld to await the institution of legal proceedings, when all will become the property of the public. --Rochester Democrat, May 22.

abstract: RAILROAD POLICE. -- The Legislature of this State, at its last session, passed an act empowering the Governor to appoint policemen on railways, on the application of the proper officers of the respective Companies. The salaries and other expenses are to be paid by those parties who make the application. The bill was prepared by Mr. HUGH MASTERSON, a detective on the New-York and Erie Railroad, and the passage of the law was mainly due to his exertions. The law as it was passed, gives the same power to the policemen on the several railroads of this State as is granted to the police of the towns, cities, and villages through which the roads pass, thus enabling them to make arrests for crime in any county throughout the line of the roads. The law has just been put into operation upon the New-York and Erie, the New-York Central and the Hudson River Railroads, and thus far it has been working admirably. The traveling public will hereafter feel more secure from the outrages of thieves and pickpockets while journeying by railroad through the State of New-York.
lead_paragraph: RAILROAD POLICE. -- The Legislature of this State, at its last session, passed an act empowering the Governor to appoint policemen on railways, on the application of the proper officers of the respective Companies. abstract: U.S. Commissioner C[???]BORNE, yesterday, committed THOS. VAN COTT, a letter-carrier, for trial, on a charge of stealing money from letters. VAN COTT was arrested about two weeks ago, and had an examination before the Commissioner on Monday last, District-Attorney E. DELAFIELD SMITH appearing on behalf of the Government. Complaints have been made for a long time past of the non-receipt of letters containing money which were directed to the upper part of the City, between Twelfth and Twentieth streets, on the east side of the town. Mr. GAYLOR, special agent of the Post-office, was deputed to ferret out the mystery, and by means of a decoy letter containing marked bills, he was enabled to trace the robberies to VAN COTT, who had in his possession when arrested one of the marked bills. He had been employed as carrier about a year and a half.

abstract: The correspondent of the Daily News, writing from Alexandria on the 27th ult., says: "Two severe shocks of earthquake were felt here on Wednesday night last, the 22d inst., at 10 3/4 o'clock. During the evening, the sky was very much overcast by huge, thick clouds, as black as ink; an extraordinary noise was also heard from time to time, until immediately preceding the shock it deepened into a loud roar, as if the dashing of the sea upon the rocks mingled with the dull, heavy sounds produced by the approach of numerous wagons were borne along on the wind, which blew a perfect hurricane. Many persons, fearing the consequences of a third shock, left their houses, and remained until midnight in the Place des Consuls."

abstract: At the breaking out of the war, there were just half a million slaves in Virginia to twice that number of white people. A gentleman, a native and resident of Virginia, who lives close to the rebel lines, and has had excellent opportunities to learn the condition of affairs in that State, assures us that at least two-thirds of its slave population have been carried from it, or have decamped from it since the rebellion begun. Probably not less than seventy or eighty thousand have freed themselves, or been freed by the advance of our armies; while tens of thousands have been sent down to the Carolinas or Georgia to save them from the contingencies of war. Beside all these, some twenty thousand have been taken from their owners, and are employed in various services connected with the rebel army or the war.

abstract: The Cabinet and the Lower Chamber
snippet: The Cabinet and the Lower Chamber
lead_paragraph: Never, during the height of his power, did STRAFFORD dare to treat with such insolence the Commons of England as M. VON BISMARK and his colleagues show toward the Prussian Deputies. The Government are evidently bent on provoking an outburst on the part of the Lower Chamber, and if they fail to do so, the fault will not be theirs. Hardly a question has of late been brought forward in that assembly on which one or other of the Ministers has not heaped insult on the popular Deputies. When the motion of M. TWESTEN, touching Schleswig-Holstein, was under discussion, M. VON BISMARK told the House that if the Government thought proper to go to war with Denmark, it would do so whether the members of that body approved of the act or not, although constitutionally the said Government could raise neither a thaler nor a soldier for any such purpose, without the consent of the Chambers. This was a tolerably audacious expression of contempt for the Deputies, but the Minister-President had not yet given full vent to his insolence, and at a subsequent period of the day, the Deputies had to endure another slight at his hands. VON BISMARK's second breach of policy and good manners was occasioned thus: It is customary for some at least of the Ministers to be present during every important debate. All of them, however, chancing to be absent at the time referred to, Dr. VIRCHOW proposed that the Chamber should in consequence adjourn. Whereon the Minister-President suddenly reentered from an adjoining apartment, and assured honorable members that the debate might continue, as he could hear outside every syllable uttered there. The sang froid of the Premier roused the ire of one of the Deputies, who remarked that such conduct was highly disrespectful to the House, which had assembled not to [???] thus trifled with, but to transact the national business. This reproof, however, did not disconcert his Excellency in the least, and he replied that he cared not what the Deputy thought of his conduct or language, that he thanked Heaven the gentlemen were blessed with such strong voices, since he could at once listen to their eloquent strains, and engage in official duties which would not brook delay. The Minister, in the absence of his colleagues, was bound to attend during the sitting of the Chamber, and his withdrawal before the close of this debate was an insult to the Deputies; but it was not the act itself, so much as the insolence of his deportment and his bantering tone, while justifying it, that provoked their indignation.
headline: {'main': 'The Prussian Cabinet and the Lower Chamber.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prussian Cabinet and the Lower Chamber.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The shower of yesterday afternoon aided, rather than injured the success of the Central Park Concert. The dust was nicely laid, and the walks and drives were rendered far more agreeable to pedestrians and equestrians than they would otherwise have been. The music was delicious, the air balmy, the weather delightfully cool, the crowd joyous and fashionable, the youngsters delighted, the hack-drivers ditto. In fact, all nature smiled, and so did those who knew their way to the adjoining restaurants.

lead_paragraph: A meeting of the Joint Committee appointed to make arrangements for the reception of the above regiments was held at the Astor House last evening. During the day the Committee conferred with Gens. SANDFORD and HALL, and received from those officers the assurance that they would make suitable arrangements in regard to the military display on the occasion of the arrival of the two regiments. The following programme was agreed upon for the procession: Military escort under command of Gen. HALL, officers from different regiments, the veteran Scott Life Guard. Brig.-Gen. WARD and Staff with infantry, Col. STRONG and wounded officers of the Thirty-eighth in open carriages, the Thirty-eighth regiment, the Common Council, the Committees, Gen. HAYMAN and Staff, Capt. JAS. R. O'BEIRNE and Capt. MCGUIRE, the Thirty-seventh regiment, section of battery, Fire Department, civic societies.

abstract: The steamship Jura, from Liverpool on the 21st and Londonderry on the 22d, arrived off Cape Race on Friday afternoon, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. Her advices, which are five days later, are politically unimportant. There was a great feeling of suspense regarding American affairs, and a desire to hear further news. Rumors of an armistice between the North and South had been dispelled by the Glasgow, which arrived out on the 22d. This created buoyancy in the Liverpool Cotton market, and prices, which had been declining during the week, nearly recovered. Breadstuffs and Provisions were steady. Console for money 93 1/2.

abstract: Whatever may be the issue of the conflict that has been, and perhaps still is raging, in and around Vicksburgh, there can scarcely be a doubt that it will take its place on the page of history as one of the most desperate, stubbornly contested and bloody, that has ever been fought.
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the issue of the conflict that has been, and perhaps still is raging, in and around Vicksburgh, there can scarcely be a doubt that it will take its place on the page of history as one of the most desperate, stubbornly contested and bloody, that has ever been fought. Commencing with the fight at Big Black River, twelve miles in the rear of Vicksburgh, and coming down to the latest struggles in the trenches that we have any account of, it will be found that there has been a fortnight of battle and siege, with artillery at close quarters, with musketry and with the bayonet, and in the hand-to-hand encounters that storming attacks consist of. According to all accounts Gen. GRANT's army moved up to the investment of Vicksburgh with irresistible determination and unflinching valor -- STEELE's corps on the right, MCPHERSON's in the centre and MCCLERNAND's on the left -- each to its appointed place, with the steadiness of veterans of a hundred fields. And after they had reached the base of the hH!s on whose heights the enemy rested, confident in the strength of their batteries, the work was renewed, and has been continued with a purpose inflexible as fate, our men taking no account of wounds or death, but closing up every breach in their ranks and pressing on to grasp what they felt to be a foreordained victory.

abstract: Letter to Newark Vallandigham Meeting
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, a meeting in favor of VALLANDIGHAM's course, and in opposition to that of the Government, was held in Military Park, in the City of Newark. There was a pretty good gathering around the stands, if the children and boys be included, otherwise it was a signal failure both in influence and respectability.

abstract: -- An army correspondent gives the following picture of Rosecrans: Gen. Rosecrans is an erect, solid man of 175 pounds weight, whose 43 years sit lightly on his face and frame. He has a clear, mild blue eye, which lights up under excitement until it can flash fire; an intensified Roman nose; high cheek bones; ruddy complexion; mouth and chin hidden under dark brown moustache and whiskers, untouched by the razor; hair a shade or two lighter, with a few threads of silver, and growing thin on the edges of the high, full, but not broad forehead. In conversation, his face is illumined by a peculiarly winning smile, and an eye shining with mirth. As Hamlet would take the ghost's word for a thousand pounds, so you would trust that face, in a stranger, as thoroughly true, full of character, and reserved power. His talk is like it -- direct, frank, overflowing with humor, or strong in emphasis.

In conversation, his face is illumined by a peculiarly winning smile, and an eye shining with mirth. abstract: Up to a late hour last night, no later official advices had been received from Gen. GRANT'S army. A dispatch received in Cincinnati yesterday, via Memphis--date not given--says no fighting had taken place since Monday. Most of the river batteries had been silenced, and the gunboats were engaged in shelling the rest.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, a guard, acting under the authority of Marshal ERHARDT, of the Fourth District, arrested HENRY McCLUSKEY, WILLIAM BARCLAY, GEORGE NASH, MICHAEL HOLLY, MORTIMER McGUFF, and four others, in a saloon adjoining the Bowery Theatre. The facts involved in this arrest, which have been gathered after diligent inquiry from persons of veracity, are these: On Thursday the Provost-Marshal's Guard learned that there was a deserter at No. 44 Bowery.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, a guard, acting under the authority of Marshal ERHARDT, of the Fourth District, arrested HENRY McCLUSKEY, WILLIAM BARCLAY, GEORGE NASH, MICHAEL HOLLY, MORTIMER McGUFF, and four others, in a saloon adjoining the Bowery Theatre. The facts involved in this arrest, which have been gathered after diligent inquiry from persons of veracity, are these: On Thursday the Provost-Marshal's Guard learned that there was a deserter at No. 44 Bowery. Thither they went to arrest him, and they made the arrest; but before they had passed out of the saloon, a party of roughs fell upon them and rescued their prisoner, without whom they were compelled to retire and report to their superior officer their inability to complete the arrest; likewise, that the crowd that stood at the bar boisterously threatened them, and swore that no United States officer should arrest a deserter there, nor should any enrolling officer record a name in that house. On Friday they awaited instructions, and yesterday afternoon they were sent to the saloon under orders to arrest any deserter that they might find. An enrolling officer was sent with them, and it was made his duty to enroll the names of all persons whom he might find in the place.
headline: {'main': "Arrested by the Provost-Marshal's Guard.; AN INCIPIENT RIOT NIPPED IN THE BUD.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Arrested by the Provost-Marshal's Guard.; AN INCIPIENT RIOT NIPPED IN THE BUD.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The War and Religion
lead_paragraph: If it is to be lamented that a state of civil war is impoverishing many of the established charities of the land, and occasioning in the army many defections from a previously moral and orderly life, it must be conceded that it has brought into exercise, if not into existence, other charities of a more practical sort, and burnished other characters till they shine as the pure gold of humanity. Missionary societies, foreign and domestic, Bible societies, tract societies, church organizations for numberless local objects, sectarian and secular, have found their incomes greatly reduced since the beginning of the rebellion. The "sittings" in numerous places of worship have fallen off; in hundreds of instances, especially in the Western rural districts, churches and meeting-houses have been closed; the "sheep" have wandered off to the war, and the "shepherds," having nothing left to tend, have followed them, seeking position and support in the army as chaplains. In their new posts many have nobly reduced to practice the Christian duties they had so long taught, while others, lapsing into the world's ways of wickedness, have brought dishonor on the profession of their lives.

abstract: -- The evidence before the United States District Court, in the case of the prize steamer Aries, shows that she was built in Sunderland, England, a little more than a year ago, and was owned by a Spaniard named F.P. OBICINI. She has made one voyage to Charleston, and brought a cargo of cotton out of that port. She afterward sailed from Gibara, in Cuba, ostensibly for New-York, but really for Charleston, and was captured by the Stettin, near that port The master, who has been here and returned to England, put in no claim for the vessel The only claim is by the British Consul, rather a formal and official claim, in behalf of vessel and cargo, for British owners.
lead_paragraph: -- The evidence before the United States District Court, in the case of the prize steamer Aries, shows that she was built in Sunderland, England, a little more than a year ago, and was owned by a Spaniard named F.P.
